2023 Narrative: UNFPA Belarus CO in collaboration with the national partner "MamaPro" launched the mobile application of online pregnancy school being available on Google Play (for android) and App Store (for iPhone) for public usage (https://mamapro.health/). The content of the online pregnancy school has been enriched with the new module on preconception care and attracted 31,770 users under the extension of availability by mobile app. Thus, the online pregnancy school covers the needs of both expectant parents and the couple who already have a child. An integration approach with a focus on engaged parenthood has resulted in increase of the level of parents' reproductive literacy, as well as fathers’ involvement in the issues of pregnancy, childbirth, and raising a child.

2024 Narrative: To advance inclusive education, the first-ever Programmatic Framework for Inclusive Education was launched on October 24, 2024, establishing a unified vision to ensure no child is left behind. The framework fostered collaboration among UNICEF, Development Partners, the Ministry of Preschool and School Education, the National Agency for Social Protection, the Zamin Foundation, and parents of children with disabilities. Under the approved framework, a pilot inclusive school in Tashkent is guiding new national standards for accessible school construction, affecting 950 schools and over 2,000 children with disabilities. UNICEF launched inclusive school models and assistive technology integration at regional level, aiming to establish 50 model inclusive schools benefiting over 50,000 students, including 300 with disabilities by 2025. In 2024, the first school-based assessments using International Classification of Functioning (ICF) standards were developed to inform assistive device procurement and infrastructural upgrades.

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: Gender education is becoming increasingly vital in today's society, as it fosters an inclusive culture and prepares communities for constructive engagement in gender-related issues. In collaboration with the Ministry of Information and Culture and the Ministry of Science and Higher Education of the Republic of Kazakhstan, UN Women developed a comprehensive training course and a master's program in "Gender Studies," drawing from international best practices and analyzing the national education system in this field. We plan to pilot the first training course and master's programme in "Gender Studies" in the Kazakh National Women's Teacher Training University. A new two-year master’s degree Educational Program titled “Social and Gender Studies”. This innovative program is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of gender dynamics and social issues, equipping them with the skills and knowledge needed to analyze and address gender inequalities. The curriculum incorporates a range of research, as well as practice-oriented learning methods, including research methods, literature analysis, design and ethical standards of scientific research, project development, and strategic planning to ensure students are well-prepared for professional roles in academia, non-governmental organizations, government agencies, and international bodies. The launch of this educational programmes will enable the training of local professionals with critical analytical skills and knowledge to understand and address gender disparities, promote gender equality, and contribute to the broader goals of social justice and human rights in Kazakhstan. By addressing both theoretical and practical aspects of gender studies, the program aims to create a transformative educational experience that will contribute to the ongoing efforts towards gender equity in the region. Additionally, it will prepare educators who can inspire and educate the younger generation of Kazakhstan on these important issues.

LNOB groups targeted: Children , Migrants, Other, Persons With Disabilities, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls, Youth
2023 Narrative: Over 2023, the Office continued to respond to both the Ukraine refugee response as well as irregular migrant needs.Partnership with Belarus Red Cross (BRC) continued to provide critical information, basic supplies through the Blue Dot and 14 child-friendly spaces. Due to sanctions imposed on BRC resulting from cross-border transfers of children, services and support were delayed in the second half of the year as no other humanitarian partner was able to provide similar support. The office continued entered new strategic partnerships with Ministry of Internal Affairs' Department of Citizenship and Migration (DCM), regional authorities and CSOs to address these challenges.UNICEF supported two regional DCM offices in Gomel and Minsk to establish child-friendly corners, providing family- and child-focused services while registering and interviewing refugees and migrants. This service was considered a good practice, with DCM instructing regional and municipal offices to apply similar working principles in 2024.UNICEF continued to work in broader protection responses with national and subnational partners, responding to critical needs. More than 9,580 individuals (63 with disabilities), including 3,272 children (1,612 girls) received group or individual MHPSS services through child-friendly spaces, the Blue Dot, and other information points. More than 1,650 individuals and approximately 500 children (241 girls) received individual case management and referrals to services.The office continued strengthening protection mechanisms for unaccompanied asylum-seeking children (UASC) jointly with UNHCR, IOM, DCM, and Ministry of Education. An interagency algorithm for UASC was developed including best interests assessment and determination (BID)and case management to the early steps of the intervention measures for UASC. In collaboration with UNHCR, UNICEF conducted BID with seven most vulnerable identified UASC and presented to the working group. This allowed to activate such mechanisms as health care, MHPSS, foster care for UASC in Belarus.In Vitebsk region, UNICEF’s advocacy resulted in establishing an inclusive and social integration center for refugees, migrants and other vulnerable groups based in a school delivering educational services to refugee and migrant children. This center will provide out of school and weekend interventions addressing language gaps, social integration and psychological needs.Within the refugee response, the office continued strengthening capacity of frontline workers: 418 (19 male) social workers, BRC volunteers, psychologists, and teachers gained critical knowledge on GBV identification and referrals, as well as PSEA tools.Almost 500 pre-school and school age children were supported in their online education and school preparation.The office provided cash support to more than 1,235 families including 2,974 individuals (59 with disabilities) and 1,943 children (949 girls) to support basic needs during winter, summer recreation, and school readiness.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Enhancing digital transformation of education with particular focus on vulnerable groups in line with Strategy for Digitalization of Education (2022 - 2027)(MAF)
Description:
The sub-output funded under MAF will focus on the following interventions:
·	Capacity building of teachers on modern didactics for online, offline, and blended learning, including a learner-centred approach, e-pedagogy and special support for the most vulnerable students. 
·	Development and adaptation of content for the Digital School Platform, for students and teachers – with a focus on quality and inclusive digital content for STEM skills, career guidance (based on the Prilike Programme), core-employability skills and prevention of online violence. 
·	Establishing EdTech hubs at schools (primarily schools in the northern parts with large numbers of Roma and disabled students) by fostering focal points for digitalisation among teachers, supporting networks and partnerships between schools.
·	Organizing Digital Skills Summer Camps for disadvantaged adolescents in underserved communities in the north of the country
Implementation partners: Elementary schools, Secondary schools
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output significantly contributes to gender equality and empowerment. This encompasses encouraging at least equal, if not even higher participation of women and girls in all activities, as well as analysing gender-equity with a situation-based approach, strategically considering the gender dynamics among different groups (e.g., among teachers, students, Roma and Egyptian students, etc.). Key project activities focus on the long-term empowerment of the female teaching workforce, promoting gender equality and encouraging girls, particularly the most disadvantaged, to seize educational and career opportunities in STEM and tech-related sectors.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: In terms of a Human Rights Based approach, the sub-output seeks to enable all children and adolescents, in particular those from disadvantaged groups, to have equitable access to school, to benefit from a quality education and to complete all years of schooling, in line with their right to education. This complies with the Montenegrin Constitution, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and other relevant international human rights instruments. The joint project outputs will make the education system more resilient, adaptable to student needs, equitable, and inclusive, while harnessing the potential of technology and teachers' capacity in a meaningful way.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: Main interventions within this output refer to Capacity building of teachers, practitioners and school staff as well as support to infrastructure development, as well as digital skills development of children, adolescents and young people.  Country wide training for ICT coordinators to implement Digitalna škola concept and enhance its use in classroom for the benefit of children, adolescents and teachers is envisaged for at least 170 ICT coordinators, being implemented until Dec 2024 and is on track.Furthermore, capacity-building for primary and secondary teachers is in progress, as envisaged from Q4 2024 until Q2 2025, where at least 300 teachers will be capacitated to implement STEM/coding courses as regular and extra-curricular programs in the area of 3D modelling and printing, programming, coding, PET recycling and robotics.Over 6000 children and adolescents in communities across north, facing different deprivations, particularly in relation to access to digital skills development will be supported to take part in the programme developed and established within EdTech hubs and with active support from, abovementioned, capacitated teachers.Furthermore, UNICEF supported the Ministry to establish the EdTech hubs and related programme across twelve primary and secondary schools in the north of the country, reaching 6,000 students. Over 500 children were supported to develop digital, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills in 12 primary schools, as well as an additional 1,120 through UNICEF supported workshops at the national Days of Science Festival.

Contributing partners: Swedish International Development Agency, United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls, Youth
2022 Narrative: On the policy making front UNFPA synergized with the Government Commissioner for Gender Policy, Vice-Prime Minister of European and Euro-Atlantic Integration to ensure the quality of the draft Strategy for Gender Equality in Education until 2030 and generate the political support for its approval. The endorsement of the gender strategy in education has been hindered for over a decade due to political speculations and anti-LGBTQI discourse elevated by religious institutions. With the policy drift boosted by Ukraine’s EU candidacy and Biarritz Partnership framework, the gender equality agenda has gained momentum and finally received sufficient support from policymakers backed by UNFPA's technical expertise and continuous advocacy efforts. Being approved in December 2022 the Strategy is aimed at ensuring implementation of equal rights and opportunities for women and men, as well as prevention of and counteraction to any discrimination in the educational process at all levels through introducing changes in structural and organizational aspects.In addition to it, the UNFPA-capacitated technical expertise and advocacy resulted in adoption of methodological recommendations (сriteria) for carrying out a gender-sensitive anti-discrimination examination of textbooks. These criteria were approved by the Institute of Education Content Modernization on November 30, 2022 and set a basis for shaping a culture of inclusiveness and non-discrimination within the education system at all levels.  In 2022 to boost institutional capacities of the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine on gender mainstreaming UNFPA facilitated the set up of the working group on equal rights and opportunities for women and men in education and accomplished the gender audit of the Ministry. The gender audit revealed areas for improvement and provided recommendations in terms of ensuring equal rights and opportunities in career promotion, decision making, establishing unified regulatory framework and staff training to address existing gender stereotypes.  From the capacity building perspective UNFPA created and trained a pool of trainers among education professionals in the methodology of social-emotional learning to ensure a sustainable effect of promoting anti-discrimination approach in education. SEEL (Social, Emotional and Ethical Learning) is an educational program developed by specialists at Emory University, USA, teaches methods of coping with stress and emotion management, and helps students succeed in school, in their careers and life. The scale up of the methodology planned for the next year will mitigate the mental health problems of Ukrainian school children triggered by the war and favour the culture of inclusiveness in school communities.
2023 Narrative: UNFPA supported the implementation of the Gender Equality Strategy in Education until 2030 and its operational plan through sustaining an expanded Working Group on ensuring equal rights for women and men in education and developing a roadmap of the Strategy implementation for 2023-2024 academic years in June 2023. The roadmap features the concrete steps for the regulatory framework, higher education, preschool, secondary school and vocational education targeting students, parents, educators, national, and local education management.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNFPA continued supporting the Government in implementing the National Strategy on Gender Equality in Education and making progress toward achieving SDG 4 (Quality Education). - Teacher Standards Enhancement: UNFPA contributed to the enhancement of the Professional Teacher’s Standard, approved by the MoES in August, by integrating anti-discrimination skills and strengthening emotional and ethical competencies.- Gender Audit: To further bolster the MoES’ institutional capacity, UNFPA conducted its first participatory Gender Audit, assessing gender equality policies, corporate culture, staff attitudes and practices, and decision-making processes, highlighting good practices and areas requiring improvement, positioning the MoES as a role model for implementing gender audits across the education sector.- Anti-Discrimination Training: UNFPA also improved the quality assurance mechanism for educational content by equipping 54% of school subject expert commissions’ personnel in anti-discrimination and inclusiveness, empowering them to conduct a more comprehensive evaluation of school textbooks and materials.- SEEL Programme Scaling: UNFPA scaled up the Social-Emotional and Ethical Learning (SEEL) programme, equipping students with the skills to prevent gender-based violence and bolster their resilience during the ongoing war. Thirty newly trained schools adopted the SEEL programme through tailored implementation plans, bringing the total number of UNFPA-supported schools to 105. In December, the MoES approved the report on the five-year SEEL pilot phase, recognising the successful testing of the methodology. The decree recommended the programme implementation in secondary education institutions as part of the New Ukrainian School model and instructed regional education departments to integrate the SEEL programme into the learning process.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Quality, accessible and inclusive education, health and social protection
Outcome: 2 By 2025, people  benefit from more inclusive  and higher quality educational  programmes focused on 21st  century skills for enhanced  employability, well-being and  active participation in society
Output: 2023-2025 2.1 Education systems at all levels have capacities, data and  instruments to provide quality inclusive education, including for digital transformation
Sub-Output: Supporting cultural and educational institutions and CSOs to transmit knowledge of and promote Holocaust education and remembrance
Description: Support to the creation of a traveling exhibition and an accompanying educational program, derived from the joint permanent exhibition in Block 17 of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum. The exhibition is to be established by the  successor states of Yugoslavia, namely Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Republic of North Macedonia, Serbia, Croatia, and Slovenia as a place of remembrance for the victims from the former Yugoslavia in the Auschwitz-Birkenau Concentration and Extermination Camp.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: BiH Ministry of Civil Affairs
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Gender equality will be addressed by mainstreaming gender into its activities through ensuring gender representation, promoting the involvement of women and ensuring that all data gathered is disaggregated by sex. It can be labelled as “significant” in terms of DAC gender equality policy marker, and as GEM 2 in relation to UNSDG-UNCT gender equality marker. The traveling exhibition and educational program will be designed to include diverse perspectives on the Holocaust, with a specific focus on the experiences of women. This includes highlighting the roles of women as victims, resistance fighters, and survivors, ensuring that their stories are prominently represented.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: This will be achieved by promoting a collective memory that acknowledges the past while fostering a future based on tolerance and respect for human rights. In this way, the project not only addresses the regional challenges but also contributes to global efforts to promote peace, human rights, and social cohesion.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Green transition for inclusive and sustainable growth
Outcome: By 2025, all people, including adolescents, young men and women, men and women aged 65 and older and other vulnerable groups, benefit from green and inclusive economic development, realised through comprehensive regulatory frameworks, promotion of business activities, private sector partnerships, and increased participatory decision-making
Output: A set of measures in the framework of inter-agency collaboration for the development of green, circular, low-carbon economy, including through enhanced international cooperation and considering the interests of vulnerable groups, is developed and proposed to the Government
Sub-Output: 1.1.11 Climate Education to Advance SDGs and Climate Action (Climate Box)
Description: UNDP regional initiative for ECA countries will (1) support further implementation of the climate education curricula in Eastern Europe and Central Asia region; (2) disseminate climate education programme in other regions; (3) advance the Climate Box curriculum with new innovative digital and online tools; and (4) support cross-country exchanges and cooperation including student contest on climate change. The proposed Project contributes to the joint effort of the UN Family under UNFCCC’s Action for Climate Empowerment (ACE). This framework promotes education, training, public awareness, public participation, public access to information, and international cooperation for climate action. End date 16/04/2026
Implementation partners: UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing States.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: To boost awareness-raising to enhance behavioral changes, UNDP initiated revision of the climate change curriculum in schools, which is primarily targeted at the schoolers of 7-17 years old and focused on climate change.
2024 Narrative: The Climate Box Project in Belarus made significant progress in advancing climate education through innovative digital and online tools. A newly updated and adapted Climate Box learning toolkit was developed, approved by the Ministry of Education, and prepared for publication. Over 200 teachers were trained across six workshops in different regions, enhancing their ability to integrate climate education into the curriculum. Additionally, a dedicated webpage on the Republican Center for Ecology and Local History (RCELH) website now provides updated Climate Box materials and information on project activities.The project also strengthened climate awareness and advocacy through various competitions, events, and international collaborations. More than 890 students participated in activities such as quizzes, a climate-themed summer school, video and drawing contests, and tree-planting events. Notably, three winning student projects were presented at the III International Teachers' Conference and School Festival in Almaty. The project also introduced unique teaching guides for preschoolers and children with disabilities, approved by the Ministry of Education. Overall, the initiative reached over 460 educators and engaged thousands of individuals through social media and online resources, earning positive recognition from the UNDP regional office.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK FOR ARMENIA
Strategic priority: People’s well-being and capabilities
Outcome: People benefit from a universal, affordable, accessible and quality health system, while adopting healthy lifestyle practices
Output: 1.2 Armenia’s health system is strengthened to be more resilient and shock- responsive
Sub-Output: Women receive high quality and rights based  SRH services, including in  humanitarian settings, due to advanced policy advocacy and advice and improvement of professional education.
Implementation partners: Government of Armenia, Local NGOs
SDG Targets: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.2 1.2 Armenia’s health system is strengthened to be more resilient and shock- responsive
2021 Narrative:
UNFPA advanced the provision of rights based and high quality SRH services (MISP trainings conducted) including in humanitarian services (RH emergency kits provided) through policy advocacy (national reproductive health strategy and action plan 2022-2026 is developed, infertility prevalence survey conducted) and advise and improvement of professional education for OB/GYN (textbook on obstetrics for students of the Yerevan State Medical University is updated).

UNFPA supported the Ministry of Health of Armenia in improving adolescent-friendly health services in primary healthcare facilities by developing a comprehensive model and a roadmap of integration of adolescent-friendly services in primary healthcare facilities.
2022 Narrative: During 2022 overall 65 health workers and 57 rescuers benefited from trainings conducted for obstetrician-gynecologists, midwives, family doctors, nurses and rescuers. 54 MISP kits were procured and distributed to relevant stakeholders. Please see the link: https://armenia.unfpa.org/en/MISPtrainingAraratThe RA Government is able to develop evidence-based policies and programs based on findings and recommendations of the nationwide study on causes of increased CS rates in Armenia, that was conducted in close collaboration with the Ministry of Health.                       In order to improve the quality of provided healthcare four clinical guidelines were updated and further increased the knowledge of over 30 clinical residents on use of clinical guidelines and Emergency Obstetrical Care during a two-and-a half-day training for clinical residents on Obstetrics/Gynecology. https://armenia.unfpa.org/en/ClinicalGuidelinesTraining  Over 30 pregnant women increased their knowledge on how to deal /cope with pregnancy-related fears through session facilitated by prenatal psychologist. The initiative was conducted in the frame of WHO World Mental Health Day initiative and in collaboration with WHO Armenia CO.Mapping of SRHR policies in the context of UHC is conducted.
2023 Narrative: In 2023 UNFPA supported the Goverement to ensure comprehensive Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) services are accessible for refugees and host community (including for youth and women with disabilities) through enhancing of existing SRH services, capacity strengthening, referral pathways, provision of SRH supplies and equipment.UNFPA as a leading agency in developing SRH clinical guidelines and protocols in Armenia continues supporting the Ministry of Health to ensure quality SRH services are provided to population. Obstetrician-gynecologists are able to provide evidence-based medical care as a result of developed two clinical guidelines and nine protocols, that are accessible via special App for Ob/Gyns. All guidelines and protocols will be approved by the Ministry of Health in 2024. 18 clinical residents increased knowledge on use of clinical guidelines and on Emergency Obstetrical Care during a two-and-a half-day training for clinical residents on Obstetrics/Gynecology.As a continuation of UNFPA efforts to decrease the Cesarean Section ( CS) rates in Armenia, UNFPA supported the Ministry of Health to develop a Program and Action Plan to decrease CS rates in Armenia that was adopted by the Ministry of Health on December 9, 2023(Ministerial Order N 5888-L).93 pregnant women increased their knowledge and gained skills on how to deal /cope with different pregnancy-related fears, problems/ through sessions facilitated by prenatal psychologists of the Michel Odent Mother ( MOM) Center. The training sessions were conducted in the frame of schools of motherhood in the three pilot sites (Yerevan St. Gregory the Illuminator Maternity Hospital, Gyumri Maternity Hospital and Akhuryan Mother and Child Health Center). The informational leaflets developed by experts in close collaboration with UNFPA and distributed to pregnant women provides the practical tips on how to deal in different situations ( files attached). Over 97 % of participants evaluated the course as very effective.Additionally, 34 SRH service providers are able to provide effective psychological support to their patients via participation in the two-days webinar on prenatal psychology. Medical equipment /supplies were procured and distributed to the relevant health facilities in Syunik, Gegharkunik, Tavush and Ararat regions based on the rapid needs assessment conducted in the frame of the humanitarian preparedness project.
2024 Narrative: UNFPA Armenia made significant efforts in improving access to quality sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services for all women and girls, including refugees through developing 2 clinical guidelines and 12 protocols, strengthening healthcare provider capacity, providing essential equipment and kits, and enhancing the health system's humanitarian preparedness. The capacity of 311 SRH service providers was strengthened through specialized training in emergency obstetric care, MISP, and psychological first aid, while ensuring uninterrupted delivery of lifesaving SRH services across 34 regional health facilities. Over 7,000 individuals, including women and girls, received vital SRH services through UNFPA-supported health facilities, and 2,013 pregnant and lactating women benefited from CVA assistance in partnership with UNICEF and Armenian Progressive Youth NGO. An online campaign on healthy motherhood, family planning, and STI prevention reached over 230,000 people through videos, infographics, articles, etc.). A new HPV primary screening program is developed with UNFPA support and set to be piloted in 2025.

Description:
Development of AMAL training resources and curricula; training of AMAL Beneficiaries on business development, fruit growing, and livestock topics; Implementation and evaluation of small-scale investments for AMAL ambassadors and beneficiaries (through business plan and questionnaire)
Gender mainstreaming strategy will consist of three major elements:

1. Ensuring sufficient capacities to implement the project in a gender-responsive and socially inclusive manner, and to ensure sustainability. 

2. Ensuring gender-responsive and socially inclusive monitoring and evaluation for effective project implementation. 

3. Mainstreaming gender and social inclusion issues in all outputs and activities. 
In particular, the following particular actions will be taken:
•	Activity 2.2: The social-inclusion and gender sensitivities should be taken into consideration during the establishment of “AMAL network” to encourage the participation of social groups, including both men and women. The regional youth houses supported by UNICEF and the regional women´s centres, supported by UNDP will be engaged in establishing the clubs. 
•	Activity 2.4: The communication and visibility plan will be gender-responsive and socially inclusive, so all social groups, and both women and men will be encouraged to participate in the programme. Existing channels of communication will be assessed, and alternative channels will be developed so both women and men are reached, including from vulnerable groups.

Key interventions and activities under this SOU contribute to achieving cross-cutting results in multiple sectors and across multiple age-groups and target populations affected by the Ukraine emergency. The results will be achieved through multiple strategies along the humanitarian-development nexus and will have in mind the long-term system strengthening in the country.

Human rights marker narrative: The sub-output includes the following elements of the HR marker: it is grounded on a analysis of the needs of refugees from human rights perspective; it is based on a normative framework; it seeks to promote LNOB; it refers to duty-bearers and the fact that the services provided aims at addressing a capacity gap related to refugee crisis
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Sustaining peace is part of the activity’s intended outcomes. Situations of refigees addressed through the Common Country Assessment , MSNA or other analyses); SOU is conflict sensitive and the results are explicitly related to sustaining peace.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF provided various technical support to address emergencies and humanitarian issues, including socio-economic integration. For instance, the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection made significant progress in integrating refugee children into the national social protection system. This was achieved by implementing a family support program that reached approximately 10,000 households and refugees. Also, UNICEF facilitated numerous formal and non-formal learning opportunities, which benefited 66,637 children and adolescents. Through a network of fixed and mobile child-friendly spaces, 52,637 Ukrainian and Moldovan children and their caregivers accessed mental health and psychosocial support. UNICEF also provided dedicated financial and technical support to strengthen the health system, resulting in over 24,400 children and women receiving primary health care services. Furthermore, around 10,000 people were provided with adequate supplies of safe water for drinking and domestic needs, achieved through the distribution of critical hygiene and WASH supplies.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to respond to people’s needs by ensuring equitable access to quality social services including education, health, social protection and decent work through effective policies and appropriate financing mechanisms with the participation of all parties (QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES)
Outcome: By 2027, the people of the Kyrgyz Republic, particularly vulnerable groups, have enhanced resilience, strengthened capabilities, and access to decent work, resulting in full enjoyment of their rights contributing to the socio-economic and gender-transformative development of the country
Output: National and local policies, plans, budgets, and financing mechanisms are evidence-based and aligned to respond equitably to people’s needs in an inclusive, gender responsive and accountable manner.
Sub-Output: Increased access to essential healthcare, education, and social protection services for refugees, asylum-seekers and stateless persons on par with KGZ nationals
Description:
1)	UNHCR provided multi-purpose cash grants to 89 vulnerable refugee and asylum-seeking families (reaching 368 individuals) to support them to cover basic needs. 20 families were also provided with an education grant, supporting 45 refugee and asylum-seeking children for school supplies. 
2)	UNHCR supported 8 refugee students through the Albert Einstein German Academic Refugee Initiative (DAFI) to pursue higher education. 
3)	UNHCR supported 12 refugees and asylum -seekers to seek sustainable livelihood through vocational training and language courses. 
4)	UNHCR IP conducted 2 capacity building activities for 40 social workers, school headmasters, heads of state medical clinics and health insurance personnel to advance access healthcare and education for refugees and asylum-seekers. 
5)	UNHCR supported commitments of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic, UN Country Team and academia to the Global Refugee Compact at the Global Refugee Forum 2023 for the advancement ensure local integration for the refugee community through access to education. 
6)	UNHCR successfully achieved equal access to healthcare for refugees and asylum-seekers on par citizens through adoption of a new regulation "On Compulsory Medical Insurance Policy" by the Cabinet of Ministers of the Kyrgyz Republic. 
7) UNHCR held a Summer Camp for 11 members of the Refugee Youth Group to build resilient youth that contributes to sustainable local integration of refugee community through developing their project planning and public speaking skills.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Cabinet of Ministers, Kyrgyz Ministry of Labour, Social Security and Migration
SDG Targets: 3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,8.8 Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth

2023 Narrative: 1)	UNHCR provided multi-purpose cash grants to 89 vulnerable refugee and asylum-seeking families (reaching 368 individuals) to support them to cover basic needs. 20 families were also provided with an education grant, supporting 45 refugee and asylum-seeking children for school supplies. 2)	UNHCR supported 8 refugee students through the Albert Einstein German Academic Refugee Initiative (DAFI) to pursue higher education. 3)	UNHCR supported 12 refugees and asylum -seekers to seek sustainable livelihood through vocational training and language courses. 4)	UNHCR IP conducted 2 capacity building activities for 40 social workers, school headmasters, heads of state medical clinics and health insurance personnel to advance access healthcare and education for refugees and asylum-seekers. 5)	UNHCR supported commitments of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic, UN Country Team and academia to the Global Refugee Compact at the Global Refugee Forum 2023 for the advancement ensure local integration for the refugee community through access to education. 6)	UNHCR successfully achieved equal access to healthcare for refugees and asylum-seekers on par citizens through adoption of a new regulation "On Compulsory Medical Insurance Policy" by the Cabinet of Ministers of the Kyrgyz Republic. 7) UNHCR held a Summer Camp for 11 members of the Refugee Youth Group to build resilient youth that contributes to sustainable local integration of refugee community through developing their project planning and public speaking skills.
2024 Narrative: UNHCR provided multi-purpose cash grants to 68 vulnerable refugee and asylum-seeking families (reaching 275 individuals) to support them to cover basic needs. 13 families were also provided with an education grant, supporting 57 refugees and asylum-seeking children for school supplies. UNHCR supported 9 refugee students through the Albert Einstein German Academic Refugee Initiative (DAFI) to pursue higher education. UNHCR supported 30 refugees and asylum -seekers to seek sustainable livelihood through vocational training and language courses and some were successfully employed upon graduation from the livelihood courses.  UNHCR IP conducted 2 capacity building activities for 40 social workers, school headmasters, heads of state medical clinics and health insurance personnel to advance access healthcare and education for refugees and asylum-seekers. UNHCR held a Debate Club for 15 members of the Refugee Youth Group to build resilient youth that contributes to sustainable local integration of refugee community through developing their projectUNHCR supported 6 refugees and asylum-seekers through the refugee youth initiative by fostering volunteerism and engaging the members of refugee youth in Youth Advisory Board events, as well as in UN events such as World Refugee Day, UN Day, 16 days campaign against violence, meeting with the UN Secretary-General and others.  With the support of the Red Crescent Society, UNHCR distributed 704 winter clothing items donated by the Japanese company Fast Retailing (UNIQLO/GU) to 151 households (approximate 604 persons) of refugees, asylum-seekers, and vulnerable community members in the Kyrgyz Republic.

2023 Narrative: As part of the UNDP Resilience Building and Recovery Offer, the project supports resilience building and green recovery through repair/ retrofitting of education facilities in the war affected areas. Technical assessment for 12 education facilities have been conducted and infrastructure rehabilitation need identified.Providers of technical design and supervision services have been engaged to support the sub-projects on school repair.Contracting construction companies and implementation of the civil works for repair is ongoing. Furniture has been produced and delivered to 9 educational facilities to ensure inclusive and quality educational environment. The development of New school concept has been launched.
2024 Narrative: The furniture and equipment have been delivered to nine educational institutions in Cherkasy, Kirovohrad, Lviv, and Poltava regions.The Concept of the New Ukrainian School: in collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine, a concept for the restoration of Ukrainian schools was developed. The new model focuses on safety, accessibility, and the comfort of the educational environment. The concept addresses the most pressing challenges, including the arrangement of shelters, evacuation exits, energy efficiency, universal design, and a gender-sensitive approach. The concept for rebuilding Ukrainian schools was presented on December 19, 2024.

2022 Narrative: During all its 16 capacity building events ROCA advocated for the implementation of the UN TBs and SPs’ recommendations, as well as recommendations under the UPR procedure and promoted SDGs achievements, focusing on equality and non-discrimination (e.g., gender, disability and language issues), fair trial, prohibition and prevention of torture, widening civic space (with the emphasis on NGO registration and functioning as part of the Freedom of Assembly and Association).ROCA provided a series of trainings for CSOs and human rigts activists on human rights, non-discrimination, rights of personsl with disabilities, advocacy, etc. ROCA translated in Russian and Uzbek languages UN OHCHR Manual “FROM PLANNING TO IMPACT: A MANUAL ON HUMAN RIGHTS TRAINING METHODOLOGY” (rev. 2019), and disseminated 100 items (50 in Uzbek and 50 in Russian languages) among state officials and CSOs during the events dedicated to Int’l Human Rights Day and Human Rights Education. In addition during 2021, ROCA distributed 120 Nelson Mandela rules in Uzbek to human rights defenders/SCOs and Ombuds office; 30 CRPD in Braille; more than 50 materials on NPM to 23 participants of NPM School; 60 (30 Uzb and 30 Rus) materials for judges on ESCR.

The course covered around 200 law enforcement officials.

2023 Narrative: To follow up on the 2022 Transforming Education Summit and the 2022 Joint Sector Review, UNICEF provided technical and coordination support to the MOES in documenting the agreed policy reform areas in the process of formulating the Partnership Compact. UNICEF was able to advance the progress of a learning recovery programme. UNICEF identified 20,000 children from Grades 5-6 in targeted 460 schools who have fallen behind in reading, math and science.  In partnership with Republican Teacher Training Center and the Online Platform “Mugalim”, UNICEF has developed a teacher training module focusing on Learning Catch-Up. This initiative aims to help 10,000 teachers (around 90 per cent female teachers) from 460 schools to gain practical knowledge, techniques and skills to identify and support students in need of assistance under the Learning Catch-Up programme.
2024 Narrative: A total of 1,023 computers were delivered to 100 scools to support digital learning, and 120 IT teachers (30 per cent female) from these schools were trained to integrate digital tools into curriculum and manage the newly provided equipment. New computers and audio-visual equipment enabled students to successfully connect and participate in the lesson.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to respond to people’s needs by ensuring equitable access to quality social services including education, health, social protection and decent work through effective policies and appropriate financing mechanisms with the participation of all parties (QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES)

Sub-Output: Teachers’ capacities are strengthened to mainstream ESD and climate change education in the national curriculum
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Education and Science
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: To meet Education 2030 Agenda commitments for national applying Berlin Declaration on Education for Sustainable Development; Learn for our planet: act for sustainability, UNESCO and Education 2030 Agenda, which is part of a global movement to eradicate poverty through 17 Sustainable Development Goals by 2030, a national mapping out exercise on existing ESD policies and initiatives was completed and shared with all national stakeholders (Cabinet of Ministers, National Academy of Sciences of the Kyrgyz Republic, national civil societies and higher educational institutions and others).  The mapping findings were transformed into action plans, new policy approaches ( including  support for teachers, competency based education, education curriculum/learning materials) which were included in the national ESD initiative adopted by the Ministry of Education and Science of Kyrgyzstan.
2024 Narrative: A total of 1,200 copies of the four key publications—Financial Literacy Methodological Guide and Workbook, Responsible Consumption Methodological Guide and Workbook—have been printed in both Kyrgyz and Russian languages in Kyrgyzstan. These materials, to be distributed among teachers and learners in Kyrgyzstan, integrate principles of Education for Sustainable Development. By promoting financial literacy and responsible consumption, they aim to equip educators and students with the knowledge and skills necessary to foster sustainable practices in their communities.Regional manual on ESD for teachers has been drafted to address the methodological, intradisciplinary, professional, contextual, and other aspects of teaching and learning in ESD in the region.The regional climate change education ambition report has been finalized assessing existing policy interventions in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.

Strategic priority: Sustainable, climate-responsible and resilient development

Description: The Climate Box has evolved from an innovative toolkit into a comprehensive climate education programme that engages with the education ministries, schools, and informal and non-formal education activities. Strong support from the national educational authorities has been mobilized. The climate education approaches piloted with the Climate Box are relevant in the context of a broader education reform towards more open, integrated, engaging, and forward-looking learning methods. The project has excellent advocacy and youth mobilization potential and supports cooperation and exchanges across educational institutions, teachers, and students.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.3: Increased capacities of MMSEs and enterpenuers to create a conducive environment, to better integrate into the value chains, develop innovative approaches for enterpeneurial activities, and create decent job opportunities
Sub-Output: Supporting the Economic Empowerment of Afghan Women through Education and Training in Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan
Description:
The project is expected to help create new business and employment opportunities for Afghan women and their communities back in Afghanistan. According to the 2018 UNDP Human Development Report, 11 percent of all adult Afghan women have reached at least a secondary level of education and only 19.5 percent are employed, while these numbers are 37 percent and 87 percent for men, respectively. In 2016-2017, more than half of the Afghan population was living below the poverty line.
Between 2019 and 2025, 50 students will attend bachelor’s, master’s, and technical degrees in Agriculture, Statistics/Finance and Mining at academic establishments across Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.
The overall objective of the project is to strengthen human capacity development in Afghanistan by increasing women’s access to quality higher education through expanding cooperation with Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.
The project was launched in June 2019
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Q1-Q2:
•	31 Kazakhstan-based project participants graduate in 2022. 19 Afghan women continue their education in Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.
•	105 Afghan women were awarded the scholarship and started online language courses. 50 students already arrived in Kazakhstan in April 2022. The new cohort of women is expected to start an offline program in Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan in June 2022.
Q3:
Phase 1.
31 students graduated from the programme. 6 Bachelor students in Kazakhstan are continuing their education. 
TVET students in Tashkent completed first year of TVET programme. One more year left before graduation.
Phase 2.
KAZ:      50 Afghan women completed the language preparation courses in August 2022. All 50 students have been successfully admitted to the degree-specific academic programs in 3 host universities in Almaty.  
UZ:    The arrival of students in Tashkent is expected in September-October 2022. It is planned to hold an additional round of selection to award the remaining 16 scholarships. 
KYR:      19 Afghan women and girls were granted visas in August 2022.  The remaining 6 Afghan students are waiting for their visas. The arrival of students in Bishkek is expected in September 2022.
2023 Narrative: The fifth year of project implementation marked the attainment of several milestones and the identification of opportunities among serious challenges. Throughout the reporting period, while most Bachelor students progressed from the third academic year to the final one, the project encountered a few dropouts. However, this challenge was promptly addressed by facilitating new candidates with opportunities to embark on their educational journey in Kazakhstan. In October 2023, three women successfully concluded the TVET program at Kazakh-British Technical University. This strategic initiative ensures that the project stays aligned with its outlined objectives and targets.At the same time, it is crucial to highlight that the evolving geopolitical situation in Afghanistan significantly influences the project implementation from various perspectives. The ongoing escalation of restrictive policies in the country directly affects an essential objective of the initiative, which is the post-educational employment of Afghan women. While the majority of programme graduates have decided to pursue further education and advance their careers abroad, a small number of women who return to their home country attempt to enter the labor market. The UNDP project teams in Kazakhstan and Afghanistan consistently monitor the project graduates, staying informed about their occupations and future plans.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Education
Sub-Output: Supporting the system of psychological care and support (MHPSS) in the national education system in Ukraine
Description:
Evidence shows that Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) is critical in emergency and recovery contexts after exposure to trauma. It can promote emotional regulation, relational skills, effective communication, collaboration, compassion, empathy, and conflict resolution in educational contexts.

UNESCO is working alongside the Ministry of Education and Science to transform the provision of MHPSS inside the school system as part of the nationwide plan to enhance MHPSS in light of current and future challenges, led by First Lady Olena Zelenska.

This initiative adopts a three-domain approach of reforming policy, strengthening capacity, and creating supportive MHPSS tools and materials. Under this initiative, UNESCO will work with local implementation partners to train 15,000 school psychologists, 20,000 school personnel, parents, and caretakers, and reach 160,000 vulnerable children.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: Global Partnership for Education, Government of Japan

Gender marker narrative: The sub-output’s contribution to gender equality is limited compared to its overall outcomes, at the same time it enables these contributions to be tracked and reported through the inclusion of indicators that capture gender-related data, disaggregation  and further analysis
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.1.2 Institutional capacity development
Human rights marker narrative: The project document identifies three elements of the human rights marker, which corresponds to the sub-result making a significant contribution to the realization of human rights.
2022 Narrative: 1. An Analytical Note and a Concept Note developed with policy recommendations to transform the Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) system in Ukraine.2. 15,000 school psychologists trained on crisis-sensitive MHPSS provision.3. Mental health assessment tools adapted and used by school psychologists.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO trained 6,734 school psychologists and 117 master trainers on emergency MHPSS interventions. UNESCO is training additional 20,000 local education actors across 8 prioritized regions in Ukraine, including teachers, school psychologists, parents, librarians, and security officers, on various subjects such as school safety.
2024 Narrative: In June 2024, UNESCO’s program "Safe Education Environment (SEE)" was approved as a standard program by the Ministry of Education and Science through Order No. 814, dated 6 June 2024. This endorsement encourages all schools in Ukraine to implement the program. SEE aims to enhance the physical and psychological safety of schools in emergency contexts. Furthermore, in November 2024, the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine adopted a policy for a pilot project designed to strengthen the security of the educational environment in schools operating under martial law (Resolution No. 1245, dated 1 November 2024). This policy incorporates UNESCO's technical recommendations for optimizing security measures in schools. In addition, 19 specialists in the area of Safe Education Environment and 110 crisis response master trainers have been trained to equip educators with the skills needed to create safe and secure environments. Cascading training sessions have already begun in the Zhytomyr and Odesa regions. As a result, 7,400 teachers, administrators, and other staff, as well as 350 members of cross-sectoral teams, are now equipped to manage emergencies and ensure the safety of approximately 38,000 children in schools. Also, UNESCO supported 20 Inclusive Resource Centres with additional diagnostic tools (SAFA and MPR) and 40 specialists were licensed to use them. These diagnostic tools will help them diagnose a variety of developmental disorders in young children and youth, as well as war-related trauma, including learning disabilities. The 20 IRCs can provide diagnostic services to at least 140,000 children.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.2_Health, education and food systems are strengthened and become more resilient to ensure universal access and quality of services and respond to humanitarian needs
Sub-Output: Refugee and vulnerable Moldovan children, including Roma children and children with disabilities, have improved access to inclusive and quality formal education through targeted support, strengthened coordination, and capacity-building initiatives.
Description:
UNHCR will continue collaborating with the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) and UNICEF to ensure that refugee and vulnerable Moldovan children, adolescents, and youth have access to inclusive and quality formal education. Key efforts will focus on increasing enrollment rates in Moldovan schools, expanding access to preschool education, and ensuring that all refugee families are informed about school enrollment procedures. UNHCR will also support the endorsement and fundraising efforts for the costed roadmap on educational inclusion, ensuring that financial and technical assistance is available to sustain refugee education efforts.

To facilitate effective learning and integration, UNHCR will support targeted Romanian language classes, literacy programs, and catch-up education, particularly for Roma children and other marginalized groups facing barriers to school enrollment and retention. Schools will receive technical support and additional resources, and teacher training programs will be expanded to improve inclusive education methodologies. Furthermore, UNHCR will promote in-person education, mitigating risks associated with prolonged online learning and ensuring that refugee children can fully participate in classroom environments​.

Strengthening child protection and psychosocial support within the education system will remain a priority. UNHCR will work to enhance school-based protection mechanisms, ensuring that refugee and vulnerable Moldovan children have access to safe learning environments free from bullying and discrimination. In line with the new Temporary Protection Directive, and in coordination with UNICEF, UNHCR will support the MER to develop and implement the monitoring system to track refugee children access to education, including its modalities. Additionally, UNHCR will continue advocating for higher education opportunities for refugees, including exploring the potential rollout of the DAFI scholarship program in Moldova. Through these interventions, UNHCR aims to foster sustainable inclusion, ensuring that education serves as a pathway to protection, resilience, and future self-reliance for all refugee children, particularly those from marginalized backgrounds.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: AO Asociatia pentru Abilitarea Copilului si Familiei, Moldova Ministry of Education and Research, Moldova National Center for Child Abuse Prevention, NGO Young Roma
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Normative Support, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Other (including coordination)
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Gender equality is mainstreamed through targeted support for girls, including Roma girls, and gender-sensitive teacher training to promote inclusive education. School-based protection mechanisms help reduce barriers to learning, particularly for girls at risk of exclusion. Higher education advocacy, including the DAFI scholarship, enhances women’s empowerment by expanding access to learning opportunities. The results framework includes sex-disaggregated indicators to track enrollment, retention, and gender equality outcomes.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.3 OU 1.3_Public institutions and CSOs/CBOs have enhanced capacities to ensure quality sustainable people-centered service delivery that is responsive to social, economic and environmental shocks and emergencies, 1.1 OU 1.1_Regulatory and policy framework that is evidence-informed and takes into account demographic trends promotes gender-responsive and human rights-based social protection and equal access to basic services
Human rights marker narrative: The sub-output includes 5 elements of the HR marker: it is grounded on a normative framework, particularly the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD); it seeks to support the implementation of recommendations from international human rights mechanisms regarding inclusive education; it seeks to address discrimination, inequality, and LNOB, particularly by targeting Roma children, children with disabilities, and refugee children who face systemic barriers to education; it refers to duty-bearers and their responsibilities to ensure access to quality and inclusive education; and it promotes participation and meaningful engagement of local communities, including educators, caregivers, and civil society organizations, in strengthening inclusive education systems.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: The sub-output meets three criteria of the Sustaining Peace Marker: it references existing conflict analysis, notably the UNHCR MY Strategy’s situational analysis, which highlights social tensions stemming from perceived disparities in access to services, especially in education; it is designed to be conflict sensitive, through interventions such as inclusive school enrolment support, common learning spaces, and support to both refugee and host communities, aiming to mitigate exclusion and prevent grievances; it seeks to address root causes of conflict, particularly marginalization and lack of access to quality education for children from refugee, Roma, and disability backgrounds.

Description: Technical assistance to the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) in establishing an inclusive and gender-equitable education system that caters to the diverse needs of girls and boys, ensuring equal access to traditional and innovative learning opportunities for all children, including refugees, children with disabilities, children with special educational needs (SEN), and Roma children. This includes promoting gender equality, challenging stereotypes, implementing assistive technologies tailored to individual needs for girls and boys with disabilities and SEN, developing a National Programme on Digital Transformation of the Education Sector, incorporating the empowerment of girls in STEM, reviewing curricula, creating e-learning materials adapted to children with SEN, adopting child-centered methodologies, promoting inclusive education, fostering child rights, addressing mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), building resilience, fostering social cohesion, addressing climate change, and strengthening emergency response capacities at central and local levels.

2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported MER to develop Education Development Strategy 2030, midterm Action Plan 2027 and simulation models to them. These policy documents were approved by the Government in March 2023 and have a particular focus on inclusiveness, equity, gender equality, resilience, WASH, digital transformation, and financial efficiency within the education sector, targeting both development and humanitarian contexts. To support the implementation of these policy documents, UNICEF, as lead and coordinating agency provides support to MER in the digital transformation of the sector focusing on development of policy documents, curricula, standards, training, and digital content, strengthening EMIS. To ensure equitable access of children with disabilities, Moldovan and Ukrainians, to quality education, UNICEF supported mapping of these children and identification of their individual health, protection and learning needs and follow up, UNICEF will procure assistive technologies to ensure their participation in education.

2021 Narrative: 10 Afghan women were engaged in the TVET Agronomy Programme. They have received a TVET, e-commerce business courses and internship in the Uzbek Commodity and Raw Materials Exchange. They also completed the Gender Equality and Women Empowerment training programme. UNDP Uzbekistan contributed to the successful and safe evacuation of Afghan women stranded in Kabul and Karachi following the change of Government of Afghanistan in August 2021.
2022 Narrative: As part of the Economic Empowerment of Afghan Women in Education and Training in Uzbekistan regional programme (Phases 1-2):  10 Afghan women completed Uzbek language courses and TVET orientation courses on Agronomy.10 Afghan women were trained at the Winter School on Gender Development, organized jointly with UN Women.10 Afghan women have been trained in the Business Development Summer School, organized jointly with UN Women.10 Afghan women completed a course under the E-Commerce Development Program and an internship at the Commodity Exchange of Uzbekistan (UzEx).9 Afghan women have completed their first year of the TVET Agronomy Program and are continuing their studies in the second year program.18 Afghan women completed their first (initial) stage of the Uzbek language course (Phases 1-2).
2023 Narrative: Academic Progress: Students continued their TVET studies in Agronomy/Agribusiness and Marketing at TSUE.Supplementary Activities: Participation in language courses, IELTS preparation, and other short courses.Summer Break: Students had a vacation period with some visiting families and others participating in local retreats.Enhanced Support: Continued support from a National Consultant for scholarships and employment opportunities.Entrepreneurship Development: Sessions and masterclasses on business development were organized.Cultural Integration: Various cultural activities and events were organized to support students' adaptation.Accommodation and Well-being: Students were provided with dormitory accommodation and additional support services.
2024 Narrative: Academic Progress: 16 students commenced their 4th semester of TVET studies in Agronomy/Agribusiness and Marketing at Tashkent State University of Economics (TSUE). 14 students completed pre-graduation practical training in the Fergana Valley.Supplementary Activities: Students participated in Spanish and Russian language courses, IELTS preparation, and short courses in haircutting.Summer Break: Students had a three-week vacation, with some visiting families in Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Iran. Others participated in a therapeutic retreat in Chimgan.Enhanced Support: A National Consultant was appointed for international scholarships and employment support. Entrepreneurship development sessions were organized.Hybrid Summer School: Two modules focusing on human rights, gender development, and project management skills were conducted.Spanish Language Training: A seven-month training program was designed to prepare students for scholarships at Spanish universities.Alternatus.Academy Launch: An educational platform specializing in agribusiness and e-commerce was launched in test mode.Cultural Integration: Organized tours, concerts, and events for cultural adaptation and celebrations.Student Departures: Four students left the program for various reasons, including scholarships and family circumstances.Accommodation and Well-being: Students resided in a TSUE dormitory with necessary amenities and received additional support like gym memberships and medical insurance.

Sub-Output: (UN Women) Equip educational specialists, teachers, and relevant institutions to implement and promote comprehensive gender sensitive curricula, initiatives, strategies by applying innovative tools
Description:
2023-2025:
* At least 200 youth with an increased understanding of gender stereotypes and gender equality 
* At least 50 teachers, educational specialists with an increased understanding of gender stereotypes and gender equality  
* At least 15 new educational institutions, NGOs, centers for youth with tools and integrated courses for promotion of gender equality and harmonious relationships
* Ministry of Education and Research has developed and adapted internal mechanisms to prevent SH in the educational system overall. Awareness raising materials on ending Sexual Harassment in the educational institutions developed. 

2025:
- 73 students and 72 professors from three higher education institutions (State University of Moldova, Ion Creangă State Pedagogical University and Technical University of Moldova) have strengthened their knowledge on preventing and mitigating the risks of gender-based violence and sexual harassment in academic settings through training sessions.  
- 135 students across three universities (State University of Moldova, Ion Creangă State Pedagogical University and Technical University of Moldova) shared their perceptions of safety, personal experiences, attitudes, and knowledge of reporting procedures in sexual harassment cases within 10 focus group discussions.  
- Three universities (State University of Moldova, Ion Creangă State Pedagogical University and Technical University of Moldova) have developed institutional mechanism to preventing and combatting sexual harassment, including the reporting mechanism. 
- The Ministry of Education and Research has developed institutional mechanism on preventing and combatting sexual harassment, including the reporting mechanism.  
- School-based Survey has been developed and implemented.  
- 187 experts in curricula evaluation and development the new curricula strengthened their knowledge on gender equality and gender mainstreaming. 
- At least 30 specialists from Moldova State University, equipped with knowledge on existing good practices of other countries, in gender mainstreaming of the legal curricula, due to developed comprehensive comparative analysis report with recommendations. A detailed roadmap for implementation of recommendation developed.

Implementation partners: International Center "LA STRADA", Moldova Ministry of Education and Research, UN Women

It supports gender mainstreaming of educational curricula, and strengthening the capacities of educational institutions to implement programs for promotion of GE, prevention/combating gender inequalities, VAW.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Sub-output is in response to issues identified through human rights analysis, including from a gender perspective (gender discrimination, VAW, stigma among service providers, etc), it is grounded in the promotion of fulfilment of human rights, it supports implementation of recommendations from UPR, treaty bodies or special procedures and targets patterns of discrimination, inequality or marginalization.
