2023 Narrative: A draft CfP has been developed for supporting educational system to mainstream gender in the curricula. First-year students from the Faculty of Law and Faculty of Journalism and Communication Sciences have increased information of gender equality, violence against women, and gender-sensitive communication, as a result of public lecture organized by Moldova State University, in collaboration with UN Women Moldova.
2024 Narrative: A Memorandum of Understanding between the Moldova State University (USM) and UN Women was sign to strengthen joint efforts and collaboration to promote gender equality and combat violence against women and girls. The Ministry of Education and Research is supported by UN Women with EU funds in establishing an institutional mechanism to prevent and address sexual harassment in three higher educational institutions. This mechanism will also include procedures for reporting and addressing cases of sexual harassment, both offline and online. The initiative will be further strengthened through capacity-building and awareness-raising activities, including focus group discussions with students to gather insights into their perceptions of safety, experiences, and attitudes toward sexual harassment.

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority A: People centred governance and rule of law
Outcome: Outcome 1 By 2025, people have access to more effective, innovative, and transparent public administration based upon the rule of law, human rights, gender equality, labour rights, and quality data
Output: Output 1.5. Ministries and agencies of Turkmenistan have sufficient capacities to collect and analyze disaggregated data, taking into account the priorities of state policy and the SDGs for the development of people-centered policies and programmes.
Sub-Output: Capacity development on population data analysis and use, and advancing Demographic Education in Turkmenistan
Description:
Strengthening the national capacity in population data analysis and use for policy making and strategic development. Facilitating participation of Turkmenistan in international and regional initiatives and training events in the area of a unified system of collection, processing and dissemination of international statistics data, including participation in the United Nations Statistical Commission.

Promoting the Demographic Education in Turkmenistan to meet national needs in the use of population data for socio-econimic planning, development of policy and legislation frameworks, population projection by developing national capacities via trainings and partnerships with the lead regional institutions and organizations.
Contributing partners: Government of Turkmenistan, United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: Turkmenistan State Statistics Committee
SDG Targets: 17.19 By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative: Throughout of 2021, the SSC was actively using and referring to the costing completed in 2020 as the major guide in estimating the expenses related to Census processes, expertise and procurement. The UNFPA-led of consultations with major development partners including UNICEF, IOM, UNHCR, and UNDP to discuss and coordinate potential support to the Turkmenistan Census resulted in concrete commitments under the Census Partnership Plan 2021-2023. The joint SSC and development partners' consultations had also helped to move forward on the issues related to the inclusion of migration and disability questions in the Census questionnaire. Those questions were integrated into the questionnaire and successfully tested during the pilot census on 17-27 December 2021. As per initial feedback from the SSC technical staff, the enumerators and respondents did not face problems with the migration and disability questions.
2022 Narrative: The UNFPA closely cooperated with the Academy of State Service, SSC and the Ministry of Education to identify the avenues for establishment of Demographic Education in Turkmenistan. The initiative helped to understand the associated needs and gaps as well as opportunities for effective demographic education. In the absence of formal demographic education in Turkmenistan, the SSC recognizes serious difficulties when it comes to analysis of population data and demographic forecasts. With the support of an international expert from the Institute of Demography of High School of Economics of Russian Federation, a set of training materials for Demographic Education for masters, bachelors and civil servants was developed and tested evoking a great interest on the Academy’s side to mainstream and promote Demographic Education in the educational system of Turkmenistan. Demographic forecasts are to help to understand the needs for family planning, SRH services and services for women subjected to GBV. With this in mind the CO will continue its efforts in promoting the Demographic Education in Turkmenistan by developing national capacities via partnerships with the lead regional institutions and organizations.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNFPA arranged a series of webinars on the use of population data for strategic planning for mid-level decision-makers and practitioners. The topics covered under the webinars included World Population Modern Trends, Population and Sustainable Development, Demographic Indicators, Demographic Projections and Applied Use, Demographic Structures. 20 participants from national ministries and agencies benefited from the webinars arranged in June-July 2023.  A series of seminars on demographic projections and mainstreaming population data into planning and monitoring were arranged for the mid-level decision-makers and technical specialists of the Ministries of Health, Education, Social Protection, Economy and Finance, and the State Statistics Committee in November 2023. A week-long course Population and Development was provided for the students of the Academy of State Services under the President of Turkmenistan. This educational facility is the only one that trains mid-level decision makers who normally in future are selected for higher level GOV positions. Therefore, this investment has a strategic nature as the future decision-makers better understand the population data and its use for socio-economic policies and planning. A lecture for university students was also arranged to evoke interest in mainstreaming demographic education into the bachelor’s programs. All these efforts were highly important as the country has no devoted education programs in Demography. Therefore, this type of intervention helps to keep the national capacity in the use of population data and demographic projections at the appropriate level. Moreover, they lay down a base for more focused and devoted curricula at BA and MS levels, that are being discussed at national level attracting more support and understanding the importance of the population data for development planning and formulating population policies, as well as better understanding the demographic resilience options.   ﻿A staff member of the State Statistics Committee was enrolled in the MS in Demography programme offeerd by Prague University. This investment will help the Statistics Committee to have internal expertise for making demographic projections and analytics.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNFPA continued supporting Turkmenistan's capacity for population data management, driven by the successful completion of the 2022 Complete Population and Housing Census. The comprehensive review of the Census, translated into Turkmen, Russian, and English, was distributed to key national stakeholders, ensuring broad access to this vital information. UNFPA supported the publication of the 2022 Census, which made it possible to publish the data in December 2024. Aiming at increasing the understanding of national stakeholders, a series of workshops were conducted in all regions, disseminating the main results of the Census to local government bodies and public organizations, empowering them to utilize the data for informed decision-making. Furthermore, a Turkmen delegation participated in a workshop in Geneva focused on Population and Housing Censuses, facilitating the exchange of international best practices. Demonstrating a commitment to long-term capacity building, UNFPA supported the education of a staff member of the State Statistics Committee in the MS Programme on Demography at Charles University of Prague.A study tour was conducted for a Turkmen delegation, focusing on international best practices in Civil Registration and Vital Statistics (CRVS) data collection and processing, providing an understanding of the best practices on population data management system, including familiarization with the statistical system for collecting and processing administrative data on civil registration and vital statistics, studying the processes of conducting a population census utilizing population registers, and examining the role of civil registry offices in their interactions with the public. This initiative aimed at contributing to the improvement of CRVS data quality and its integration with census data.

2022 Narrative: During the reporting period the CVETs of the State Employment Service (ІУІ) progressed in its digitalization, with UNDP support. While higher level results are expected in 2023, so far the detailed concept and terms of reference for the mobile application of the SES were developed and agreed upon with the management of SES and the test of e-learning platform for SES was launched. Curriculum for the pilot course "Installation and repair of water supply systems" was designed, and the first lessons were uploaded at the platform and tested.
2023 Narrative: To improve employability of IDPs and other war-affected population, 387 people participated in short-term training and apprenticeship programs in Lviv, Khelnytskyi, Poltava, Chernihiv and Dnipro oblasts (after-training employment rate is 67%). More than 600 people took part in the webinars on the basics of employment in Ukraine. Emergency employment hubs (including mobile hubs, equipped with the vehicles) of the State Employment Service of Ukraine were created in Donetsk, Kharkiv, Mykolaiv, Kherson and Odesa oblasts. Nine shelters for IDPs based in educational institutions were identified and equipped with household assets, IT equipment, furniture, etc. to improve living conditions of IDPs and support normal functioning of the host educational institutions. The management of the host educational institutions were trained on crisis management skills.

2022 Narrative: To strengthen measures on COVID19 infection prevention and control, hygiene supplies and disinfectants to 100% primary health care facilities, around 90% of perinatal centers (including in Transnistrian region), hospital for infectious diseases for children and Republican center for rehabilitation of children with disabilities were procured. Hygiene supplies reached over 60,000 health facilities workers and their beneficiaries. More than 250 families with children with disabilities benefitted out of additional support with hygiene and WASH supplies for COVID19 infection prevention and control.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.3: Increased capacities of MMSEs and enterpenuers to create a conducive environment, to better integrate into the value chains, develop innovative approaches for enterpeneurial activities, and create decent job opportunities
Sub-Output: Phase 2: Supporting the Economic Empowerment of Afghan Women through Education and Training in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan
Description:
The Action represents an expansion of an ongoing EUR 2 million trilateral cooperation programme between the European Union, Afghanistan, and Central Asia. Like the ongoing programme, it aims at building resilience and promoting the academic, economic and social empowerment of women in Afghanistan especially vulnerable women living in challenging conditions by enhancing their capabilities, employability and future prospects through education and training in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and, within the context of this Action, Kyrgyzstan.
Phase 2 of the programme focuses on training of specialists in Agriculture/Agribusiness, Engineering/Construction, Marketing and ICT. Apart from promoting academic, economic and social empowerment of women in Afghanistan, the action will help to strengthen capacity of receiving institutions in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan to manage learning mobility programmes in interaction with UNDP and address gender inequalities in higher education and TVET.
The action is intended as a logical continuation of the ongoing project and aims to further facilitate the development of a sustainable system of academic exchange that will allow women from Afghanistan to benefit from higher education opportunities in Central Asia also beyond the project lifetime.
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: Despite the persistent instability in Afghanistan, UNDP remains steadfast in its commitment to advancing the economic empowerment of Afghan women in Central Asia through education and training, funded by the European Union. In the face of challenges posed by the ongoing conflict, UNDP achieved significant progress in 2023. In August 2023, a total of 27 Afghan women and girls successfully graduated in Kazakhstan, 9 in Uzbekistan, and 14 in the Kyrgyz Republic. Although the majority of graduates secured promising study and employment opportunities in Central Asia and beyond, a subset of project participants encountered specific difficulties. Acknowledging this issue, the EU provided additional funding to UNDP, enabling 11 Afghan women to pursue their studies in La Coruna, Spain, with promising employment prospects. This new funding component has played a crucial role in ensuring the effective implementation of the program, offering vital support to Afghan women as they strive for success in their educational and professional endeavors.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Education
Sub-Output: Standards of non-discriminative gender sensitive curriculum content operationalized in the education system
Contributing partners: Swedish International Development Agency, United Nations Population Fund
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Internally Displaced Persons, Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls, Youth
2023 Narrative: The implementation of standards was undertaken through collaboration of UNFPA and: 1) NGO EdCamp Ukraine resulting in:- a guidebook (algorithm) for educational institutions at different levels to provide a basic set of actions and solutions for ensuring gender equality and non-discrimination, tailored to the specific context and needs of each institution.- Launch of the online course #educationwithoutdiscrimination developed to boost the capacities of educators on identifying and addressing discrimination within the classroom and creating an inclusive learning environment.- Scale up of the social-emotional and ethical learning (SEEL) methodology for 75 schools in 21 regions of Ukraine. Individual implementation plans have been developed for each school to equip educators and students with resilience and soft skills to prevent GBV. The institutionalization of the SEEL methodology has been strengthened through the signing of the joint Memorandum of Understanding for the Development of Social and Emotional Skills in Children and Youth in Ukraine between the Ministry of Education and Science and other national partners. 2. Over 2023, UNFPA has significantly contributed to the implementation of the Objective 2 of the Strategy for Gender Equality in Education, specifically to its task #35 covering professional self-determination and mastering of professional skills in accordance with personal abilities and interests without limiting them to the framework of "female/male" and motivating girls and women to choose non-stereotypical STEM careers.This was achieved through  STEM projects “Science Ambassadors”, “OL Science Festival”, and “Ecolab” in cooperation  with Lviv Open Lab and partnerships with local authorities, academia, youth spaces and civic partners.The “Science Ambassadors” project promoted gender-sensitive science popularisation among educators and helped them master digital teaching tools. It also assisted teachers in presenting themselves and their research effectively, especially for 390 high schoolers from vulnerable backgrounds. The project included a storytelling evening, "Frankly about Science", four videos highlighting women's contribution to science and gender-sensitive teaching, a methodological guidebook titled "How to talk about science and yourself in it", and a social media campaign covering 48000 people.The OL Science Festival featured innovative science shows and hands-on activities covering various fields. As a result, 4322 participants, including young people and families with children from Chernivtsi, Vinnytsia, Odesa, and Lviv, advanced their knowledge about gender stereotypes in science and were empowered with STEM opportunities in profession choice. On average, 36% of male participants improved their understanding of gender stereotypes, while 52% of girls acknowledged opportunities in science-related professions. "Ecolab"  project intensive equipped 42 vulnerable young people  with green skills and knowledge to create an environmentally friendly, sustainable future.3. UNFPA has expanded its cooperation with the Ukrainian Education Hubs, a national network of lifelong learning programs focused on developing Ukraine's human capital implemented in collaboration with the Association of Innovation and Digital Education under the aegis of the Ministry of Education and Science. Apart from the support of Ternopil and Volyn Hubs UNFPA has developed and piloted a SCORM course, "Career Alarm is Over!" which incorporates storytelling, gamification, and interactive tests, and is available on the platform of the Ukrainian Education Hubs (https://bit.ly/scorm_course)- So far, more than 2,000 young people have completed the course, expanding their knowledge and opportunities to choose professions without being constrained by stereotypes.- Over 2,500 young people engaged in 48 training sessions focused on career guidance and STEM. Additionally, 1,075 high schoolers underwent career guidance tests, receiving personalized lists of sectors and professions aligned with their abilities.

Description:
"Global Education Coalition (hereinafter “the GEC”) pledged to support  distance learning efforts of the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine (hereinafter ""the MESU"") to provide teachers and students with access to software and equipment. Through the GEC, Google has partnered with the MESU and UNESCO to support the continuity of education in Ukraine with the contribution of 50,528 devices for teachers and software licensing in line with the MESU’s priorities.

Under this Project, UNESCO committed delivering Google’s contributed devices to the delivery locations in Ukraine as agreed with the MESU for further distribution to teachers by the Departments of Education and Science of the Regional and Kyiv city Military Administrations under the MESU’s control.

In early 2023, supplies and distribution of the devices were finalized."
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Ukraine Ministry of Education and Science
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
Geography: Cherkaska, Khmelnytska, Ukraine, Zakarpatska, Lvivska, Zhytomyrska, Kyivska, Ivano-Frankivska, Volynska, Kirovohradska, Poltavska, Rivnenska, Ternopilska, Vinnytska, Donetska, Chernivetska, Khersonska, Dnipropetrovska

The chromebooks have been donated by Google for the purposes of (i) distribution among the Ukrainian teachers and (ii) creating Digital Learning Centers in Ukraine is aimed at increasing connectivity for education in Ukraine and supporting distant learning during the period of war.Most of these laptops have already been distributed to Ukrainian teachers covering all or almost all regions of Ukraine.
2023 Narrative: In early 2023, supplies and distribution of the devices were finalized.

2021 Narrative:
During the Q1 and Q2, within this sub-output, UNESCO Almaty in cooperation with National Academy of Education under the Ministry of Education and Science of Kazakhstan has started the review and analysis of the primary and secondary education curriculum in order to provide recommendations for integrating topics, learning objectives and outcomes of Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) and Global Citizenship Education (GCED). Currently the draft report has been prepared and reviewed by UNESCO specialists and experts, the Academy is revising the report per the provided outline and suggestions. 
During Q3, the primary and secondary curricula are being reviewed as well as there are several new programmes that have been added, which will also be reviewed and analyzed to provide recommendations on integrating education for sustainable development topics and learning objectives. The final report will be ready by 15 December.

2021 Narrative:
1. Didactic support for “Biology” teachers on the new module “The human organism and health” developed in line with international standards on comprehensive sexuality education (resurse-pentru-cadre-didactice-invatamintul-gimnazial). It is approved by the Ministry of Education and Research and is currently implemented in all schools at the gymnasium level (grades VI-IX). 

2. The national team of 70 trainers among “Biology” teachers trained to support the provision of the new module “The human organism and health” in all 35 districts/municipalities. Consequently, they trained 1112 Biology teachers (80% out of total Biology teachers of the country) and ensured efficient national coverage which is expected to lead to an increase in the quality of provision of health education all over the country. 

3. Didactic support on "Education for Health" optional course available in the Russian language which will increase the access of Russian speaking community of adolescents to the quality health education, including sexuality education, gender-based violence prevention, nutrition, etc. 

4. Teachers, schools psychologists, and nurses from 10 schools trained on quality provision of optional course "Education for Health". 

5. 85 schools from Chisinau municipality, Cahul, Orhei, Rezina, Falesti, and Ungheni have been equipped with innovative didactic materials to increase the learning outcomes of health education courses.

2021 Narrative:
WHO: 
WHO worked closely with IPH and Ministry of Education to develop policies for safe re-opening of school during 2021. This included preparing and disseminating up-to-date leaflets and information materials on COVID prevention measures to be taken by students, environmental cleaning for school maintenance staff. Recognizing the impact that COVID-19 has had on mental health, WHO organized lectures on the subject. These attracted around 800-900 teaching staff from all over Kosovo, including non-Albanian speaking communities. Lastly, a WASH + COVID awareness survey was carried out in 100 schools all over Kosovo, with the results to be published in Q1/2022.

Contributing partners: European Union, Global Thematic - WASH, Swedish International Development Agency, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund

Gender marker narrative: Compliant with the assumed obligations from the National Gender Equality Strategy 2021–2025, the suboutput supports the Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation in carrying out an analysis of subject curricula and textbooks in primary education to assess the extent to which they perpetuate gender stereotypes, and to formulate recommendations towards mainstreaming gender equality in the curricula and textbooks which are included in the draft Education Reform Strategy 2025–2035.

Human rights marker narrative: The strategy will directly address relevant CRC recommendations related to the right to education.
LNOB groups targeted: Minorities, Children , Youth, Persons With Disabilities, Migrants
2023 Narrative: The Government of Montenegro has further confirmed its commitment to develop a comprehensive Education Reform Strategy for the period up to 2030, along with a budgeted Action Plan, by integrating it as one of the key measures in the Economic Reform Program for 2024 - 2026. The Strategy will be developed in partnership with UNICEF and the European Delegation to Montenegro. Following an extended process of project preparation and negotiations, the contract agreement with the EUD was signed and the process of Strategy development officially commenced. Due to UNICEF’s intensive advocacy and resource mobilization, development of a new, comprehensive education reform strategy will be the flagship intervention of the Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation (MoESI), UNICEF and the EUD in 2024. With UNICEF’s advocacy and technical assistance, the public budget for education was increased by approximately 10 per cent by the Mid-Term Expenditure Framework (2024–2026), including a tenfold higher allocation for teacher professional development compared to 2023. Additionally, it was with UNICEF’s extensive support and advocacy that a comprehensive assessment of school infrastructure was launched by the MoESI to tackle the issue of inadequate school infrastructure and to ensure long-term investments.
2024 Narrative: A first ever comprehensive reform Education Strategy 2025-2035 was developed by MoESI, with support of UNICEF and EUD through the joint "Quality Education for All Children" Project, formulating priority, effective, equitable, gender-sensitive, and long-term actions aimed at enhancing the quality, inclusiveness, resilience, governance, and financing of the education system across all education levels, including pre-service teacher training. To ensure that all voices were integrated in the new Strategy, a broad process of consultations was conducted, including over 1,100 students – including those affected by poverty, Roma students, and students with disabilities, over 2,800 teachers, and 5,500 parents, 84% of whom were mothers/female guardians. A two-year, budgeted Action Plan is currently being developed, outlining priority actions for the period of the next two years and a solid financing framework for their timely and quality implementation.

Description: Support adolescent girls and boys across all three regions of Montenegro to receive career guidance and job training through the “Prilike” programme, which is recognized as a precursor to the EU Youth Guarantee scheme, integrating private-sector partnerships and civil society collaboration to support adolescents in acquiring labour market-relevant skills.
Contributing partners: Core Funding, Swedish International Development Agency, TUI Care foundation
Implementation partners: Employment Agency of Montenegro, Ministry of Education Montenegro, Ministry of Sports and Youth Montenegro, NGO Association for democratic prosperity ZID

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported the continuation of Prilike, a school-to-work transition programme, through which 450 adolescent girls and boys across four schools and two regions are receiving support through on-the-job training and career guidance, with the aim of integrating it into the official school curriculum. The programme is synchronized with the school year, providing support to adolescents from September 2023 until July 2024.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF supported the continuation of Prilike, a school-to-work transition programme, with the plan of piloting the programme through the formal education system and integrating it into the official school curriculum. The programme is synchronized with the school year, providing support to adolescents from September 2024 until July 2025.The programme is piloted in the central and southern region of Montenegro, in four different schools (Gymnasium "Slobodan Skerovic" Podgorica, Gymnasium Cetinje, Economics High School "Mirko Vesovic" Podgorica and High School "Ivan Goran Kovacic" Herceg Novi). More than 1600 adolescents across all three regions of Montenegro received career guidance and job training through the Prilike programme which is recognized as a precursor to the EU Youth Guarantee scheme, integrating private sector partnerships and civil society collaboration to support adolescents in acquiring labor market-relevant skills.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.2_Health, education and food systems are strengthened and become more resilient to ensure universal access and quality of services and respond to humanitarian needs
Sub-Output: (UNFPA) Strengthened capacity of the General Education system to deliver quality health education and create an enabling environment for students’ wellbeing and healthy development.
Description:
As part of its ongoing commitment to the Ministry of Education and Research (MER), UNFPA continues to enhance national capacity and policy in the education sector, empowering pupils and youth through life-skills development and supporting their safe transition to adulthood. UNFPA will provide sustained technical expertise to advance national priorities related to adolescent and youth well-being, comprehensive sexuality education (CSE), and safe and healthy development. Additionally, it will support MER in strengthening communication and promoting the roles of schools and families in education. 
In 2023, is formalising its collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Research by signing a Memorandum of Understanding for the 2023-2027 period. 
Following the International Technical Guidance on Sexuality Education and addressing national needs, UNFPA will support the Ministry in developing a health education school club for grades V-VII. In 2023, the curriculum and didactic resources will be developed, with pilot implementation and finalization planned for 2024. 
Additionally, UNFPA will piloted the EduLIFE School Program: friendly environment, access to health education, and menstrual hygiene products. This concept embodies a multidimensional approach to strengthening the educational institutions’ ability to contribute to students' well-being and life skills, encouraging healthy and non-violent behaviour, promoting equal learning opportunities for both girls and boy
In 2024, UNFPA is expanding the "EduLIFE School" model to four new schools, including two designated as Model Schools. This initiative will promote a student-friendly environment, comprehensive sexuality education, and access to menstrual hygiene products. The selection of schools will be carried out in collaboration with the Ministry of Education, with two institutions being reorganized to accommodate refugee students from Ukraine. Key implementing partners will include the NGO “Youth Media Center” and the platform “suntparinte.md.”
In 2025, alongside with other UN agencies, UNFPA is assisting MER in conducting a national school survey among pupils, parents, and teachers. The survey will assess education quality, student participation, informal payments, rights awareness, gender equality, bullying, well-being, and include dedicated questions on CSE. 
As one of the key partners in the National Curriculum reform, UNFPA is building the capacities of curriculum authors to evaluate the existing curriculum and develop a new one. International standards and assessment tools in CSE will guide this process, ensuring the integration of CSE and life-skills topics into the new mandatory national curriculum. 

UNFPA will also support MER in organizing Education Week in May 2025, contributing to organization of a national conference with local and regional education experts and organizing a side event on Dual Education in the Vocational Education and Training (VET) system. 

Building on 2024 achievements, UNFPA will pilot a curriculum-based school club on health education, providing training and continuous support to 30 teachers from various schools.
Contributing partners: Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Swedish Funds, UNFPA Core funds
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Education and Research, Youth Media Center
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The Project's interventions are designed in response to existing data that highlights the inadequate and insufficient sexuality education currently being provided in Moldovan schools: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YtqzN8t4coLivGo0EJ1-8EaXurx7KRaB/view?usp=sharing The interventions will have direct contribution to girls bodily autonomy, empowerment to make informed decisions about their life.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Contributes strongly to sexual and reproductive rights of young people
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Sustaining peace marker narrative: The programme has no targeted peace sustaining interventions, besides the fact that the intreventions are in benefit of all school-aged children in Moldova, including refugee youth, young people from different ethnic minority groups, etc.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, the country office formally collaborated with the Ministry of Education and Research for the entire country programme cycle, by signing a Memorandum of Understanding 2023 - 2027 period. In the framework of this collaboration, UNFPA supported the Ministry in promoting and increasing the communication outcomes on youth empowerment, the importance of life skills development, sharing good practices on teachers' roles, etc. At the same time, UNFPA supported youth consultations on assessment of progress towards the 2023 Agenda of Moldova https://moldova.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/raport_de_progres_odd_2023_vf_07_08_2023_en_final.pdf and on the ICPD agenda. The results were presented by youth representatives from Moldova during the regional event on ICPD30 review held in Geneva from 18-19 October. https://moldova.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/unfpa_moldova_newsletter_october_2023_eng.pdf but also served as evidence-based data for the country presentation of the progress towards SDGs during the UN Summit in September in New York provided by the President Sandu. Under the same area, following the International Technical Guidance on Sexuality Education https://www.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/ITGSE.pdf and existing national needs,  UNFPA supported the Ministry of Education and Research in developing the school club on health education for grades V-VII. In 2023, the curriculum and didactic support were developed, and the programme will be piloted and finalized in 2024.
2024 Narrative: UNFPA expanded its "EduLIFE School" model in four new schools, two of which are Model schools. This initiative promotes a student-friendly environment, access to comprehensive sexuality education, and availability of menstrual hygiene products. The "EduLIFE School" model reflects a multidimensional approach aimed at enhancing the capacity of educational institutions to support students' well-being and life skills. It encourages healthy, non-violent behavior and ensures equal learning opportunities for both girls and boys. A detailed description of the model is available here: https://moldova.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/2024-09/EduLIFE%20School.pdf The selection of these schools was carried out in collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Research, focusing on strategically important institutions:Theoretical High School "Alexandr Pushkin," Ungheni Municipality (model school)Theoretical High School "Mihail Ceachir," Ceadîr-Lunga Municipality (model school).The other two schools were reorganized by the Government to accommodate refugee students from Ukraine:Theoretical High School "Mihail Koțiubinski," Chișinău MunicipalityGymnasium "Taras Shevchenko," Chișinău Municipality.This pilot initiative underscores the commitment to fostering inclusive and equitable education while addressing the unique challenges faced by students in diverse contexts. The key implementing partner of UNFPA is the NGO “Youth Media Center” and the Platform “suntparinte.md”. Key Achievements of the “EduLIFE School” Model Implementation in 2024 Across Four Target Schools are: Infrastructure Improvements - all four schools now feature renovated "EduLIFE" classrooms, modernized medical and school psychologist offices, and access to free menstrual pads.Impact on Girls’ School Attendance - the installation of menstrual pad dispensers led to a significant reduction in school absences due to menstruation-related reasons, with the percentage of affected girls dropping fourfold (from 55% to 12.5%).Student Training and Awareness - over 811 students participated in training sessions on menstrual hygiene, teenage pregnancy prevention, bullying, and other forms of violence. They were also informed about free, youth-friendly health services available in the country.Advancing Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) - schools were equipped to deliver high-quality CSE through the training of teachers, psychologists, and medical assistants in menstrual hygiene and fostering non-violent school environments.Each school received an “EduLIFE Box,” a toolkit containing edutainment teaching materials such as puzzles, board games, and posters.Scaling Up Advocacy - the Ministry of Education and the broader educational community are advocating for the expansion of the UNFPA EduLIFE School Model to all 35 Model Schools nationwide due to its demonstrated positive outcomes. However, scaling up remains contingent on funding availability. UNFPA Moldova will continue its efforts to mobilize resources to achieve this goal.

2023 Narrative: In 2022, in consultation with President’s Office, UNICEF continued its support and technical expertise to the MoES for the development of the national strategy on inclusive education 2022-2032. In cooperation with the Ministry of Education and Science, the World health Organization, the Ministry of Health, local partners and NGOs the needs assessment of children and education systems in assistive technologies and Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) was initiated - their assessment will be finalized in July 2023. Together with the Ministry of Education and Science, UNICEF and partners conducted an analysis of the web accessibility standards that will be included in the modification process of the national digital platform “All-Ukrainian School Online”. The new features aim at making the digital platform more user-friendly and accessible for children with visual impairments. UNICEF supported the development of digital lessons for the All-Ukrainian School Online to cover the gap in content for 5-11 grades.  UNICEF worked closely with MoYS to support its Youth Policy Reform, aiming to activate young people as driving force of emergency response and capacitate them for post-war recovery. UNICEF supported the Ministerial flagship program “Spivdiia” and strengthened 25 youth centers as providers of services for young people. UNICEF scaled up youth volunteering movement, engaging 192,522 young people as volunteers. Focusing on PSS life skills education and socio-emotional learning, UNICEF reached 137,314 adolescents all over Ukraine. To feature the results of young people’s contribution in emergency response UNICEF organize a National event with First Lady of Ukraine “Youth Awards” featuring the achievement 17 young volunteer leaders from UNICEF programs and attended by 300 youth. UNICEF supported the engagement of 41,103 boys and girls aged between 8-17 years. This included IDP children, predominantly those living in collective centers, with limited access to education or those who are out of school in socio-emotional learning, MHPSS and life skills education. They covered Chernivtsi, Ivano-Frankivsk, Ternopil, Lviv, Khmelnytsky, Uzhhorod, Rivne, Lutsk, Vinnytsia, Bucha, Khmelnytsky, Cherkasy Regions.100,767 children and adolescent reached in 2022 (24,535 by the services of Youth Centers - Youth Up; 35,692 Spilno meeting points - PDK; 19,540 equipped with skills and engaged in social cohesion; 11,000 by supporting vocational institutions in Mykolaiv MOES; 10,000 engaged through U-Report - YouthUp). UNICEF covered in Kyiv and Kyivska, Chernihivska, Cherkaska, Poltavska, Zaporizhska, Mykolayivska, Khersonska, Rivnenska, Ternopilska, Dnipropetrovska, Vinnytska, Volynska, Kharkivska, Zakarpatska,Chernivertska, Sumska, Odeska, Khmelnytska, Ivano-Frankivska and Donetska. UNICEF and partners are implementing comprehensive recovery support for Zhytomyr and other select municipalities. This includes supporting an integrated service model including reaching out to students, including children with special educational needs and pre-school age children.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Sub-Output: 2023-2025 2.1.4 Education institutions have evidence and enhanced capacities to effectively provide quality and inclusive education
Description:
Strengthening of the government’s commitment and capacity to develop and implement evidence-based strategic approaches that will lead to sustainable development of education quality and inclusion for all children. Support will be provided to the government in monitoring and evaluation of improvements in education system; developing evidence-based strategies in line with the international standards, focusing on the EU policies and practices. UNICEF will further advocate for continuous participation of BiH in conduction of ILSAs and towards achieving consensus of different education governments on development and implementation of evidence-based strategies. Technical Assistance to Ministries for Education to strengthen capacities of schools to include refugee and migrant children in non-formal and formal education through individual learning materials, cultural mediators, learning support and vocational training

Also, digital transformation in education will focus on access to technology as well as building the ecosystems for AT/AAC. This could be achieved by creating legislative preconditions for public-private partnerships with internet providers to enable Internet access and introducing regular monitoring of ICT infrastructure in schools. To ensure that all children, particularly the most vulnerable (e.g. Roma, children with disabilities, children on the move) are included in learning, UNICEF will support universities and education institutions to reform pre-service and in-service teacher education as per teacher competencies for quality inclusive education with focus on children with disabilities.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Quality, accessible and inclusive education, health and social protection
Outcome: 2 By 2025, people  benefit from more inclusive  and higher quality educational  programmes focused on 21st  century skills for enhanced  employability, well-being and  active participation in society
Output: 2023-2025 2.1 Education systems at all levels have capacities, data and  instruments to provide quality inclusive education, including for digital transformation
Sub-Output: 2023-2025 2.1.6 Government and education institutions have enhanced capacities and financial resources to effectively provide quality and inclusive early childhood education and care
Description:
To improve the quality and inclusiveness of support to young children, UNICEF will support the government institutions with ECEC teacher education in line with the EU recommendations on High-Quality ECEC Systems which also encompass social model of inclusion of vulnerable groups of children. In addition to in-service training, efforts will be invested to enhance the quality-of-pre-service teacher education, which implies better connections of theoretical learning with practice and shifting university education from a teacher-centered to a child-centered approach. Professional development initiatives will also address potential teachers’ biases towards inclusion and gender and build their self-efficacy to support and promote inclusion. 
To increase demand, UNICEF will work intensively to increase community engagement by gaining a better understanding of communities’ knowledge and attitudes towards ECEC, promotion of the importance of ECEC among parents and caregivers, and to address prejudices towards the inclusion of vulnerable groups of children in mainstream ECEC (e.g. children with disabilities, Roma, children without parental care). The parents, families and communities will be involved in design and implementation of those interventions. UNICEF will work on advocacy and professional development initiatives towards building stronger parent/caregiver-preschool partnership, taking into consideration engagement of fathers and men in ECEC. 
UNICEF will also support the establishment of referral mechanisms which can foster quality inclusion of Roma boys and girls in ECEC, by engaging different local sectors and Roma authorities. It will support ECEC systems to introduce and improve inclusive ECEC education for children with disabilities, by supporting governments in establishing integrated early intervention and detection services and mechanisms as part of ECEC (with endorsement of the ICF and in collaboration with health and social protection sectors), by fostering teacher collaboration which brings services to their natural environments (rather than segregated services) and the usage of community referrals outside preschool institutions themselves. UNICEF will promote the social and human rights-based approaches to inclusion in BiH communities, in close cooperation with key advocates- Roma leaders and DPOs (Disabled Person’s Organizations).
Contributing partners: European Union, Government of the United States of America, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: FBiH Ministry of Education and Science, RS Ministry of Education and Culture
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Citizen and community engagement for social cohesion
Outcome: 5 By 2025, there is stronger mutual understanding, respect and trust among individuals and communities.

Sub-Output: 2023-2025 5.1.18 Fostering a culture of peace and appreciation of cultural diversity in education and culture sectors
Description: The Action will offer new approaches to cultural workers and youth to learn about diversity and the value of shared cultural heritage, in order to be empowered with skills and values pertaining to peacebuilding. This will be done through museums which are spaces for cultural transmission, intercultural dialogue, learning, discussion and training, thus contributing notably to social inclusion and skills for sustainable development. Work with education institutions imply fostering the strategic and systemic integration of culture into formal education through providing learning tools and strengthening the skills and competencies of teachers, including transferable/life competencies, necessary to achieve a quality and inclusive educational process in the 21st century.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: The UN Secretary-General’s Peacebuilding Fund (UN Peace Fund)
Implementation partners: BiH Ministry of Civil Affairs
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,11.4 Strengthen efforts to protect and safeguard the world's cultural and natural heritage.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project will leverage the important role young women and girls play in BiH’s peacebuilding processes and ensure that gender is utilized as a common concern of interest among all participating groups. Gender equality is fundamental for democratic and social cohesion processes; therefore, it is strongly mainstreamed into all segments of the project. Since many gender roles and stereotypes are formed in early adolescence, the project will work with educational authorities as well as directly with young people to tackle gender-based stereotypes and bias, as well as any other types of discrimination. Building on the experiences from previous phases, the project will continue strong gender equality promotion including through a gender informed approach as well as integration of gender concerns in the project activities (such as capacity buildings, selection of beneficiaries, small grant facilities awarding, etc.). Such approach will strengthen capacities of men and women youth leaders and intellectuals to become the next generation of leaders who believe in equality while working together towards common goals. Moreover, this will result in the establishment of gender-responsive dialogue and stronger joint problem-solving culture between different groups and mechanisms for peacebuilding. Nonetheless, through the Small Grant Facility (SGF), a strong gender component is envisaged also including support to women’s CSOs contributing to gender equality and women’s empowerment, while taking into account gender-specific issues relating directly to peacebuilding processes.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Collaborative activities related to culture and education stakeholders will ensure cross-sectoral cooperation and promote common topics of arts education, cultural heritage, human rights, and peace education.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way

Sub-Output: Support to Enhancement of Law Enforcement and Judicial Practices on Anti-Corruption and Promoting Integrity Education among Youth in Kazakhstan
Description: The objective is to enhance the capacity of Anti-Corruption Agency’s officers and judiciary in dealing with financial and corruption crimes and to raise awareness on the importance of countering corruption among youth
Agencies: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
Contributing partners: The US Government Department of State's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Anti-corruption Agency, Kazakhstan higher education institutions
SDG Targets: 16.3 Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.,16.5 Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
Geography: Astana, Almaty (city), Kazakhstan, Bayanaul, Zerendi, Pavlodar, Akmola
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: Technical and analytical capacity of Anti-Corruption Agency to investigate corruption-related cases strengthened. 42 officers-analysts (4 women) of Anti-Corruption Agency of Kazakhstan enhanced their knowledge and skills on application of IBM i2 software for criminal intelligence and investigation of corruption-related crimes.Four (4) IBM i2 Analyst Notebook and iBase software licenses purchased and handed over to the Anti-Corruption Agency for further use in its analytical and investigation activities.
2024 Narrative: The curricula of the advanced training courses of the Justice Academy under the High Judicial Council has been enhanced by the new training course on international standards and national judicial practices for adjudicating corruption-related crimes in Kazakh and Russian languages. The faculty of the Academy has started using the course materials at the refresher training sessions for serving judges in Kazakhstan from 1 September 2024. The course has a clear focus on enhancing knowledge, skills, understanding of international standards and gaps in national legislation on the investigation and prosecution of corruption cases. Such specialization will help serving judges to adjudicate corruption crimes by applying national legislation, international standards and best practices, and will contribute to the prevention of corruption among both judges and judicial system personnel.“The fundamentals of Law and Anti-Corruption Legislation” course utilizing the UNODC Global Resource for Anti-Corruption Education and Youth Empowerment (GRACE) initiative products developed, piloted and integrated into the training curricula of Narxoz University. 137 students of Narxoz University have chosen this course as a compulsory discipline in 2024-2025 academic year.Held a series of five capacity-building workshops for some 120 judges (45 women) from district and city courts on practical application of international standards and advanced practices in adjudicating corruption-related and financial crimes The Youth Anticorruption Summer Schools and student case competitions held in Astana city, Akmola and Pavlodar provinces brought together more than 100 representatives from some 30 universities, colleges and public youth associations from across the country. Throughout these activities, participants engaged in collaborative discussions on implementing anti-corruption strategies and enhancing integrity within their respective institutions. Based on the knowledge gained during the Anticorruption Summer School, the Code of Academic Integrity was revised, and new compliance procedure tools were introduced in Karaganda Medical University. Between 2023 and 2024, using the i2 Analyst Notebook and i2 iBase applications, the Agency's officers analyzed over 230 requests from across the country, resulting in the creation of 7,500 analytical schemes. These schemes were incorporated into the evidence base of approximately 140 criminal cases, including high-profile investigations related to multi-billion tenge corruption, embezzlement, and bribery. In addition, using i2 Analyst Notebook and iBase software, officers of the Central Office of the Anti-Corruption Agency started piloting the analysis of bank transactions and electronic invoice scrutiny.

Description:
UNHCR continues to support Primary and secondary education of refugees, as well as University students by covering annual tuition fees.

Within the DAFI Scholarship Programme funded by the German Federal Government, UNHCR also supports limited number of refugee students by covering their tuition fees and other needs related to the tertiary education.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: Government of Germany, Non-core funds, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education of Azerbaijan
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: UNHCR maintains education services, which are crucial for preserving the enrolment of refugee and asylum-seekers children without valid documents, online registration of schoolchildren at the state database, hand-over of education records in cases of voluntary repatriation, school transfer due to family relocation, preventing drop-outs and illegal payments, as well facilitate integration into local school communities. The Government, through the Ministry of Education, State Examination Centre, Baku Education Department and other local education authorities, continued providing access to free-of-charge services on an equal footing with the locals to 371 refugee and asylum-seeker children in over 96 schools. However, this access is in most cases is secured by regular advocacy, monitoring and counselling provided by the Education Coordinator contractor on education services. Education coordinator of UNHCR regularly monitors the academic progress of refugee school children through: visits to schools, visit to families, phone calls and parent council meetings. UNHCR facilitates access to primary and secondary education through liaison with refugee community leaders and parents as well as local administration, on issues pertaining to education of refugee children. In addition, based on the submitted school certificates UNHCR provides education assistance for refugee school children in Azerbaijan both for the general education and preschools. Understanding the needs of refugee school children on Azerbaijani language, UNHCR with the project stakeholder arranges and administers regular courses on Azerbaijani language for academic purposes. In addition, Mathematics, English and Azerbaijani language courses as a preparation for state graduation exams is also conducted to assist refugee school children. Education Coordinator liaises with education administration authorities (Ministry of Education, Baku Education Department, etc) to ensure enrolment of refugees, asylum seekers children on acceptable grades and other issues related to their education and provides regular counselling on education related issues, including information on tertiary education, at UNHCR Reception Centre. Moreover, Education Coordinator identifies children who are not attending schools, reasons, and suggest remedies to the situation through regular/ad hoc update and with the UNHCR team advocates on additional education assistance.  Currently, we are having the overall 371 refugee school children enrolled in general education in 96 public schools for 2022-23 academic year.In 2022 the number of refugees studying in Higher Education Institutions was 62. 21 out of them are supported through DAFI scholarship. 10 DAFI scholars graduated universities in June, 1 was continuous student and 10 new scholars were included in the scholarship programme. Remaining 41 students were supported by the office directly. All 62 students were supported with the laptops by the Office.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
A comprehensive Education Sector Analysis in finalization phase. The Education Sector Analysis provides in-depth insight into the functioning of the system from the aspect of quality, equity, governance, infrastructure and financing. The ESA is to serve as a basis for developing a multi-year Education Sector Plan in 2022. The Digital School Platform  for learning, teaching and collaboration launched and quality digital content developed for children and students from preschool to secondary education, their teachers and parents. Draft Strategy for Digitalization of Education in place and public consultation process conducted. Extensive support provided to improving the quality of inclusive education through capacity building for teachers to use tech-based and non-tech based didactic materials. 	

Sveobuhvatna Analiza obrazovnog sektora u fazi finalizacije. Analiza obrazovnog sektora daje temeljan uvid u funkcionisanje obrazovnog sektora iz ugla kvaliteta, pravičnosti, upravljanja, infrastrukture I finansiranja. Preporuke analize će poslužiti za izradu sektorskog plana u 2022.godini. Uspostavljena i pokrenuta Digitalna škola, platforma za onlajn učenje, nastavu I saradnju. Razvijeni kvalitetni digitalni materijali za djecu i učenike od predškolskog obrazovanja do srednje škole. Razvijena Strategija za digitalizaciju obrazovno
g sistema za period do 2027. Godine I održana javna rasprava. Pružena intenzivna podrška unapređenju kvaliteta inkluzivnog obrazovanja kroz izgradnju kapaciteta nastavnika da koriste asistivne tehnologije u nastavi.
2022 Narrative: The Education Sector Analysis (ESA) was launched as a joint initiative with the Ministry of Education, providing in-depth insights in the education system in the period 2015–2020 from the aspects of quality, equity, governance, and financing. It was agreed with the Ministry of Education to develop a multi-year Education Reform Strategy based on ESA, and EU financial support ensured for the purpose. In preparation for the UN’s Transforming Education Summit (TES), broad consultations with all stakeholders were conducted with support of UNCT and UNICEF , confirming the need to re-imagine education through sound, long-term and budgeted policies. Through the regional DG NEAR funded project and in cooperation with the Bureau for Education, over 20% of teachers received training to use digital tools in teaching in a quality and inclusive manner, reaching almost 50% of all students in primary and secondary schools in Montenegro. The national Digital School Platform was expanded to include 12,000 lessons categorized into 1,000 courses, reaching over 24,000 users. Textbooks Publishing Agency developed the first national Standards for Quality Digital Textbooks, setting the necessary policy framework for future work in this area. Almost 40% of children with disabilities in primary schools, and 25% of children with disabilities in secondary schools, benefitted from the implementation of improved individual educational and development programs. The program for developing social and emotional skills of students was implemented in over half of all primary and secondary schools, reaching as many as 30,000 students.Sveobuhvatna Analiza obrazovnog sektora, koja je pokrenuta kao zajednička inicijativa sa Ministarstvom prosvjete, finalizovana je i predstavljena javnosti. Analiza daje dubinski uvid u funkcionisanje obrazovnog sistema u periodu od 2015 - 2020. godine, iz ugla kvaliteta, pravičnosti, upravljanja, i finansiranja. Sa Ministarstvom prosvjete dogovoreno je pokretanje razvoja višegodišnje Strategije reforme obrazovanja, na osnovu nalaza Analize, i obezbijeđena je finansijska podrška od strane EU za tu svrhu. U okviru priprema za učešće na globalnom samitu o Transformaciji obrazovanja pod okriljem UN-a, sprovedene su široke konsultacije sa svim akterima - u saradnji sa UNCT i UNICEFom - koje su potvrdile potrebu za ponovnim osmišljavanjem obrazovanja kroz kvalitetne, dugoročne i finansijski podržane politike. Kroz regionalni projekat finansiran od strane DG NEAR, a u saradnji sa Zavodom za školstvo, preko 20% nastavnika steklo je vještine za korišćenje digitalnih alata u nastavni na kvalitetan i inkluzivan način, čime je obuhvaćeno skoro 50,000 učenika u osnovnim i srednjim školama u Crnoj Gori. Digitalna škola, nacionalna platforma za onlajn učenje, nastavu i saradnju, proširena je i sada sadrži 12,000 lekcija kategorisanih u 1,000 kurseva i trenutno ima preko 24,000 korisnika. Zavod za udžbenike i nastavna sredstva razvio je prve nacionalne Standarde kvaliteta za digitalne udžbenike, postavivši time temelj za dalji rad u ovoj oblasti. Skoro 40% djece sa smetnjama u razvoju u osnovnim školama i 25% učenika sa smetnjama u razvoju u srednjim školama obuhvaćeni su kroz implementaciju inoviranog individualnog razvojnog i obrazovnog plana. Program za razvoj socijalnih i emocionalnih vještina učenika implementiran je u više od pola svih osnovnih i srednjih škola, obuhvativši skoro 30,000 učenika.

Contributing partners: Austrian Development Agency, European Union, Global Education Thematic Funds, H&M Foundation, ING, Non-core funds, Social Inclusion Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Bureau for Education, MoE
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Extensive support provided to preschools to improve the quality of pedagogical services and care for children, as well as to implement parent support programs. Centres of excellence established in four preschools across Montenegro to provide mentoring support to other preschools in a number of selected areas. New Strategy for Preschool Education in place for the period up to 2025.	

Intenzivna podrška pružena predškolskim ustanovama da naprijede kvalitet pedagoških usluga I brige o djeci, kao I da primijene programe podrške roditeljima. Uspostavljeni centri izvrsnosti u četiri predškolske ustanove čija je uloga da pruže podršku drugim vrtićima u nekoliko oblasti rada. Usvojena nova Strategija predškolskog obrazovanja za period do 2025. godine.
2022 Narrative: The number of of children enrolled in preschool education increased by 7% in comparison to 2021, the coverage rate now standing at 75.99% for children 3-6 years of age (75.23% girls, 76.72% boys). A significant upward was recorded for children from the most vulnerable groups - the number of children with disabilities and Roma children attending kindergartens increased by 7% and as much as 47%, respectively. With the support of the EU and in partnership with Rain Barrel Communications, 42 professionals from 21 preschools participated in the SB4C related training which focused on improving communication skills of preschool professionals for changing attitudes and practices, as well as for engagement with communities and parents. Following the training, community-based action plans were implemented in 19 municipalities, contributing to such significant increase in enrolment. To improve access to preschool for children living in rural areas, a needs analysis was conducted and four new outreach services were established. Currently, 29 outreach preschool services are active throughout the country.Broj djece upisane u predškolsko obrazovanje povećan je za 7% u odnosu na 2021. godinu, te stopa obuhvata trenutno iznosi 75.99% za djecu uzrasta 3 - 6 godina (75.23% za djevojčice i 76.72% za dječake). Značajan porast obuhvata registrovan je i kada su u pitanju djeca iz osjetljivih grupa: broj djece sa smetnjama u razvoju u vrtićima porastao je za 7%, a broj romske djece za čak 47% u odnosu na prethodnu godinu.Uz podršku EU i u saradnji sa Rain Barrel Communications, 42 profesionalaca iz svih predškolskih ustanova u Crnoj Gori (21) učestvovalo je u obuci usmjerenoj na unapređivanje vještina komunikacije sa roditeljima o važnosti predškolskog obrazovanja, te mijenjanju stavova i praksi, kao i vještina za saradnju sa lokalnim zajednicama i roditeljima i starateljima. Nakon obuke, vrtići su sproveli akcione planove u 19 opština, što je doprinijelo povećanom upisu djece u predškolsko obrazovanje. U cilju unapređenja pristupačnosti predškolskog obrazovanja djeci koja žive u ruralnim oblastima, sprovedena je analiza potreba i uspostavljene su interaktivne službe/vrtićke grupe u ruralnim oblastima u četiri opštine. U Crnoj Gori trenutno funkcioniše 29 vrtićkih grupa u udaljenim ruralnim krajevima.  To make sure that teachers and parents support their children through digital and innovative approaches, a variety of digital content was developed and published on the national Digital School Platform continued in 2022. The platform now includes 200 interactive games for children up to 6 years of age, as well as 150 courses with 900 lessons for preschool professionals and parents 36% of all preschool teachers use the platform in their every day work.

2021 Narrative:
To support access and continuity of education for the most marginalized children, UNICEF has provided mentoring and  learning (catch- up classes) support. This includes provision of learning support to 365 Roma students in primary school, 220 Roma students in secondary education and 60 children without parental care living in the institution.

SDG Targets: 10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,10.4 Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.,16.6 Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.,17.19 By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries.
SDG Goals: 10 Reduced Inequalities, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions, 17 Partnerships for the Goals

Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective

2021 Narrative: The capacity building programme was postponed to 2022 due to (1) operational restrictions caused by COVID-19 and (2) challenges related with selection of suitable consultancy needed to support activity with complex thematic focus (supporting establishment of INFF through improvement of child-sensitive public spending on social sectors) Nevertheless, the implementation of agreed activities is on track and all set goals are expected to be achieved by mid of 2022.
2022 Narrative: UNICEF and the Ministry of Finance have jointly improved child-sensitive public spending in social sectors within the UN Joint Programme to support the establishment of the Integrated National Financing Framework in Uzbekistan. Fifty-five staff of the ministries of finance, health, preschool and public education were introduced to the Public Finance for Children Framework and related tools and methods, aiming to improve child-sensitive social sector budgeting in their respective areas. Mentoring was provided to the participants in the development of programme budgets in respective areas. The Ministry of Finance has submitted to the Presidential Administration the programme budget templates for social sector spending, developed during the joint work. It is recommended to use them as a benchmark when submitting budgetary requests to finance development progammes from the state budget.    UNICEF jointly with UNDP continued strengthening SDG financing through enhancing government capacities in programme-based budgeting (PBB). Efforts were geared towards an assessment of PBB implementation in Uzbekistan and support in the development of a technical training manual and materials on PBB for the training of trainers and courses on results-based management and PBB for staff of social sector ministries.
