Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2021 Narrative:
- In 2021, propelled by the Biarritz Partnership’s commitments, the government of Ukraine reconfirmed its dedication to develop an inclusive and discrimination-free education system. In response to this call, UNFPA provided a targeted assistance to the Office of Deputy Prime Minister of European and Euro Atlantic Integration, Ministry of Education (MoES), Ministry of Youth and Sports (MoES), Institute of Education Content Modernization, State Service of Education Quality, Ukrainian Institute for Education Development, as well as to regional departments of education and regional professional development centers for educators in the following areas: (1) building an anti-discrimination expertise of the education content creators and experts, (2) support of young women and girls in a stereotypes-free career choices, specifically in STEM professions, (3) promotion of a zero tolerance to violence.
- To ensure a sustainable and catalytic effect of promoting antidiscrimination approach in education, throughout 2021, in cooperation with NGO EdCamp, UNFPA conducted 28 comprehensive online trainings for 1734 state educational content experts and representatives of the government agencies Institute of Education Content Modernization, State Service of Quality Education, and Ukrainian Institute of Education Development on non-discriminatory and inclusive approaches in education. At a more functional level, UNFPA developed an institutional partnership with the largest textbooks publishing house of Ukraine “Ranok”, certified 43 textbook authors and experts after completion of a training program on creation of a discrimination free content, ​​and issued a guide for educators on non-discriminatory teaching. In line with regular trainings, UNFPA also started the development of a complex online course “Education without Discrimination” which would soon provide a robust multidimensional instruction to educators on a harmful impact of stereotypes and means of creating a safe, diverse, and tolerant education environment.
- To embark a broader teachers’ community on a dialogue about stereotype free education, UNFPA supported the organization of several massive international experience exchange and networking events, particularly a 25-day virtual professional development study tour to Sweden “EdMandry” for 1237 educators which got familiarized  with the specifics of Swedish education system, including the principles of a lifelong learning, project management and non-discriminatory approaches in teaching, and a multi-day National EdCamp Joy conference for 1161 educators which included 18 expert sessions from renowned researchers and community leaders and was dedicated to the tolerance and counteraction of the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on teachers’ and students’ mental health. As a result of these activities, more than 4000 educators improved their competence in applying an anti-discrimination approach in education and acquired theoretical and practical skills of eliminating stereotypes from the education process.
- Responding to existing inequality, UNFPA enforced its support to the national network “STEM girls” which promotes STEM professions among girls and young women all over Ukraine. During 2021 UNFPA ensured that more than 10 000 girls had a chance to practice STEM and improve their chances to get profession in tech or IT sphere through organization of the national virtual celebration of the Day of Girls in ICT and the National Day of Girls in technology, supporting STEM Camp, the Hackathon “Hack4Good” for high school female students and STEM challenges. STEM chapters coordinators received two 5-modules training courses on soft and communication skills to promote STEM chapters in their regions and three quarterly meet-ups, involving 118 coordinators. As a result of such an active engagement strategy, in 2021 STEM girls’ network grew almost three times, increasing the number of its chapters from 31 to 118. The number of active members in the STEM Girls Community also increased from 1,263 girls to 1,513 girls.
- In 2021, UNFPA held its 4th in a row annual contest “Best gender sensitive STEM lesson” which aims to promote gender sensitivity of STEM lessons through integrated approach and innovative methods. 5 best lessons were acknowledged and recommended for application by the Institution of Education Content Modernization. 
- From a public awareness perspective, UNFPA promoted stereotype free career choice through engagement of high-level advocates and popular opinion leaders. In frames of the celebration of the International Women’s Day, the First Lady of Ukraine joined the UNFPA inspirational video about 5 Ukrainian girls who challenged the idea of stereotypical career choice and succeeded. The video reached over 119 000 views in social media and got 61 publications in the media. For youth and teens from the East of Ukraine, UNFPA provided an online training on stereotype free career choice through partnership with NGO Vostok SOS.
- UNFPA sustained its long-term support of WikiMedia WikiGap marathon engaging 101 authors who produced 723 Wikipedia articles about outstanding female Ukrainians jointly with NDI and Swedish Embassy. Moreover, under the WE ACT Programme, UNFPA supported the She did it Wikipedia editing marathon by creating special nominations to focus editors’ attention on improving 250 articles about Ukrainian sportswomen and female diplomats.

2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNICEF prioritized inclusive justice, promoting the rights of children with disabilities in partnership with the Ministry of Justice. Three brochures focusing on education, health, and labour rights, along with two videos featuring sign language and tiflocommentary, were produced. These materials, informed by consultations with children in specialised boarding schools, empower children and their families to understand and claim their rights.

2021 Narrative:
Several efficient and innovative solutions for remote service provision, already tested and piloted in conflict-affected regions of the country, have been scaled up and expanded for use in Kherson region. In total, 20 centers were equipped for provision of additional administrative services. Ten healthcare posts in rural communities were provided with equipment for rapid diagnostic, so that more than 2,000 women in the targeted rural communities got access to medical diagnostics. Moreover, the improved access to healthcare has enabled local residents to utilize treatment and diagnostic opportunities significant to their health and wellbeing. The total number of direct and indirect beneficiaries of these initiatives is 84,839 persons (51,3% women). Lastly, an informative and user-friendly website of the Kherson Children's Hospital was developed and launched in close consultation with the hospital to provide potential patients with better and up to date information. UNDP also helped to address challenges in the education sector. The support included provision of basic equipment (tablets, wi-fi routers) and access to Internet, enabling children from 97 low-income families (in total 441 persons, including 52,6% women) to access online learning during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The information materials on vaccination were broadly disseminated through digital media channels, reaching an audience of 79,958 people, including 36,473 residents of Kherson oblast. Also, as a part of the campaign, two webinars (“Vaccination of children with disabilities” and "Vaccination for communities: COVID-19 and other infections”) were conducted in March 2021 enabling 410 people to receive verified information and and comprehensive answers to common questions about vaccination.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Education
Sub-Output: Access to an early childhood development and preschool education as a part of lifelong learning of children of preschool age improved through better policies, formal services provision and innovative partnerships that allow expand services faster during the war in a sustainable way
Description: Access of the children of the early and preschool age to care and education disrupted by the full-scale invasion due to a long list of damaged and destroyed kindergartens, absence of shelters at the existing public kindergartens, high cost of private services, lack of affordable and accessible facilities at the places of displacement etc. The project is looking into addressing the lack of childcare and preschool services by 1. developing and pilot-testing affordable facilities based on various types of partnerships including public-private partnership, that would allow to overcome the lack of resources to establish facilities, 2. addressing the issue of informal services for children, especially of the early age (0-3), by developing and piloting the package for formalisation of the individual nannies' services, 3. supporting the adoption of care legislation and policies such as the parental leave, that can have transformative effect on gendered parental responsibilities and women's possibilities to engage in paid work.
Implementation partners: Social Partners (employers and employees), Ukraine Ministry of Education and Science

SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2024 Narrative: The ILO supported the development of occupational standards for childcare workers, strengthening professionalization in the sector and improving service quality. Contributions to the new Law on Preschool Education, adopted in June 2024, helped shape policies to enhance early childhood education. Additionally, two onsite kindergartens were established in public and private institutions, expanding childcare options for working parents and promoting better work-life balance.Over 60 women received training in establishing and managing childcare businesses, equipping them with the skills needed to enter the sector. As a result, nine women-led childcare businesses were launched or expanded, currently providing care for 132 children, with enrolment expected to grow. This initiative has not only strengthened women’s entrepreneurship and expanded access to quality childcare services, but also created approximately 40 direct jobs in the new kindergartens, along with additional indirect employment in related services.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.1: By 2025, effective, inclusive and accountable institutions ensure equal access for all people living in Kazakhstan, especially most vulnerable, to quality and gender sensitive social services according to the principle of leaving no one behind
Output: Output 1.1.2: Increased capacity of policy makers and health service providers to improve access to selected quality health services and goods, including those related to COVID-19, HIV, reproductive and mental health related services, for everyone especially the most vulnerable groups of population.
Sub-Output: Provide technical support to reduce risk factors by promoting healthy choices and health literacy in all settings, including educational facilities.
Description: Aiming to support the implementation of the Health Promoting Schools initiative, WHO Kazakhstan, jointly with WHO Europe and the MoH, organised and conducted a 2-day training session for national and regional coordinators. Day 1 covered the theoretical part of the health promotion in schools and introduction to SHE tools with the participation of over 200 people, including schools from difference regions. Day 2 was focused more on practical exercises for regional coordinators and planning further actions. All participants performed tasks on building regional plans, and further actions will be taken jointly with the national coordinator and partner UN agencies to plan joint activities at regional and school levels. To support the national partners in scaling up the initiative further in all regions WHO Kazakhstan jointly with NCPH MoH KAZ produced video lessons in Russian and Kazakh on the concept of the Health Promoting Schools and steps that schools need to take to build healthy and safe school environment for the whole school community.
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Healthcare  , Kazakhstan Ministry of High Education and Science, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 3.4 By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from noncommunicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.,3.5 Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol.,3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: In 2022, the result of a pilot behavioral insights study on salt reduction among selected groups of the population, including health professionals, patients, children, parents and school staff, WHO Kazakhstan, jointly with the Moscow GDO on NCDs, organized dissemination of two posters on alternatives to salt in the aim to promote healthy choices. These materials were printed and delivered in 2000 PHC facilities in all regions of Kazakhstan.WHO KAZ provided support to adopt national guidelines on sodium content in ready products, physical activity and prevention of sedentary behaviour and tobacco cessation services at the primary health care level. Further training on application of the tobacco cessation guideline was conducted in hybrid mode for over 100 Anti-tobacco centers in all regions of the country.WHO Kazakhstan, jointly with the National Centre for Public Health and Ministry of Health, conducted four-hour technical workshops for regional and local coordinators illustrating the rationale behind establishing such a network, the optimal structure and governance framework of the network, the added value of the network to the member cities and regions, optimal timing and next steps and division of responsibilities. On 5 July 2022, WHO Kazakhstan and the Ministry of Health held a roundtable to have a country dialogue with regions. The roundtable was well attended by the representatives of the numerous ministries (including Health, Education, Culture, Digital Affairs, Agriculture, Employment and Social Affairs and Industry) as well as some 40 representatives of the regions joining online. ﻿Obesity: In 2022, WHO Kazakhstan jointly with the National Center of Public Healthcare under the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan (NCPH) and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) published and disseminated results of the fifth round of the WHO Childhood Obesity Surveillance Initiative (COSI). The official launch of the report took place on March 3, 2022, on the eve of World Obesity Day. The survey covered all regions of the country, 6851 children of age 6-9 years, 6330 parents, and 153 schools. Stoke: Marking the World Stroke Day on October 29, 2022, WHO CO co-organized and delivered a public campaign “Let's prevent stroke together!” initiated by the Republican Coordinating Centre for Stroke and Astana City Hospital N2. Salt reduction: With the support of the WHO Kazakhstan, and the WHO Regional Office for Europe, the Salt Reduction Working Group was established by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan in order to coordinate actions to improve the food environment and prevent non-communicable diseases. As a result, a discussion was initiated on the development of national standards for sodium content in prepared foods and foodstuffs based on the WHO Global Sodium Benchmarks, and a package of country support aimed at reducing salt intake in the population and best practices for salt reduction in the WHO European Region were adopted for implementation in Kazakhstan. In 2022 in the result of a pilot behavioural insights study on salt reduction among selected groups of the population including health professionals, patients, children, parents and school staff, WHO Kazakhstan jointly with the Moscow GDO on NCDs organized dissemination of two posters on alternatives to salt in the aim to promote healthy choices. Within the scope of the CACCR, these materials were printed delivered in 2000 PHC facilities in all regions of Kazakhstan. In May 2022, this information campaign was followed by an informal talk about salt reduction on an electronic platform for the general public. Health Promoting Schools: By the end of 2022, more than 1000 schools in Kazakhstan have joined the Health Promoting Schools Network. This initiative has been recognized as a strategic tool to promote healthy behaviours, such as physical activity, healthy rest and play, balanced nutrition and prevention of tobacco use. In Kazakhstan, the Health Promoting Schools Network has been integrated into major regulatory documents, such as the Health Promoting Schools Roadmap for 2020-2025, approved by the Ministry of Healthcare of the Republic of Kazakhstan, the “Healthy Nation” National Project for 2021-2025, and the Prime Minister of the Republic of Kazakhstan. In 2022, in collaboration with UNICEF Kazakhstan and the Kazakh Health Promoting School network, WHO Kazakhstan delivered a series of web-based trainings on the WHO approaches to healthy nutrition, increasing physical activity, and promoting mental health among school aged children. More than 3000 school nurses, psychologists, teachers, and other interested staff members from over 1000 schools were trained in all 20 regions of Kazakhstan on these topics.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, WHO KAZ official launch of results of the 2nd national study on Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC), where various stakeholder participated, including ministries, parliamentarians, UN agencies, sub-regional authorities and municipalities, NGOs, volunteer networks and Internet media platforms. Specific focus was placed on the experience of children and adolescents during the pandemic, including worrying trends showing increase of sedentary behaviour, influence of social media platforms, and use of novel tobacco products and alcohol. In 2023, WHO KAZ launched a platform for dialogue on WASH in schools, engaging national stakeholders to discuss country-wide social campaign TOILE outcomes and plan actions for ensuring children's access to clean water and sanitation. A subregional workshop for Central Asian countries, organized by WHO ECEH and WCO KAZ, aims to strengthen WASH services in schools, considering lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, a sub-regional workshop on water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in schools for Central Asian countries in Astana was organized by WHO ECEH and WCO KAZ. This workshop, attended by country representatives from MoH and MoEdu, focuses on enhancing capacities for safe and inclusive WASH services in schools, with a special emphasis on preparedness and response to health emergencies, drawing insights from the lessons learned during the COVID-19 pandemic. New national WASH standards in schools adopted in KAZ, effective 1 Jan 2024 based on WHO recommendations with support from WCO KAZ, WHO Bonn office, civil activists (TOILE project) and MoH following a country dialogue at the PM's. The new standard will support and guide the school administrations towards building safe and healthy environment for children in schools. FAST Heroes project launched in 20 health-promoting schools, led by WHO KAZ, in collaboration with the Angels Initiative. Over 8000 primary school students will learn to recognize symptoms of stroke and the emergency 103 number to call for help. Tools, including FAST Heroes website and guidebooks, were translated into Kazakh, presented during the workshop on 24 Mar and disseminated to all 20 regions of KAZ.  WHO KAZ with the National Center for Public Health, MoH launches the official website for Health Promoting Schools in KAZ. The website is a virtual space for students and school communities for networking and for essential tools and information about health and health promotion. WHO with the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Health launched the implementation of education tools on immunization among schools. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of addressing health literacy through continually improving the population’s capacity to access, understand and use information to improve their health and well-being. Immune Patrol, a game based educational module developed by WHO. In 2023 the national technical working group established. The game will be piloted in 40 schools (city and rural) in 20 oblasts of Kazakhstan. 40 teachers of biology from 40 selected schools attended in the kick-off meeting, as well as Ministry of Education, Ministry of Health and representatives from partners agencies. During the meeting, representatives from Armenia and Moldova shared results of the Immune Patrol piloting. Participants discussed the opportunities and draft country action plans for integrating Immune Patrol into school curricula through cross-sectoral collaboration.  This sub-output has been completed by the end of 2023.

2022 Narrative: UNICEF and Estonian experts supported the capacity building of 700 teachers and 100 school administrators from 100 model schools across the country, along with coaching to 500 teachers and 100 school administrators, contributing to improved knowledge in modern, child-centred pedagogy including methodologies for distance teaching and learning, networking and building partnerships. In partnership with MoES, National Teacher Professional Development Center (NCTPDC), Education for All Coalition (EFA), state universities and International CK-Foundation, 537 teachers were trained in the use of digital tools, which contributed to improved digital teaching and learning for 15,712 students across 165 public schools.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF established a partnership with the Government of France to foster and strengthen child rights based education and child rights based justice. In addition, MoUs were signed with three private universities and Child Rights Centres were established in Grigol Robakidze University (GRUNI, Tbilisi), Caucasus University (CU, Tbilisi) and East European University (EEU, Tbilisi). Throughout 2023, UNICEF cooperated with Child Rights Centers of universities to strengthen their capacity to reach more beneficiaries with knowledge and advocacy on child rights, including the dissemination of child-rights related data and disparities that may exist due to sex, geographic location, ethnicity, etc. UNICEF in partnership with Education for All Coalition (EFA) continued to train teachers in the use of digital tools.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNICEF established a partnership with Tbilisi state university and jointly established the Child Rights Center. Throughout 2024, UNICEF cooperated with Child Rights Centers of universities to strengthen their capacity.

Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: European Union, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy

2021 Narrative:
UN in cooperation with Macedonian Young Lawyers Association and Ministry of Labor and Social Policy worked together with other relevant national entities to identify the challenges and opportunities in ensuring quality education to asylum seeking and refugee children. As a result, one roundtable with 25 stakeholders from national institutions, schools, NGOs and international organizations was organized, that served as a good platform to explore the existing good practices and align approaches of educational institutions in assessing the previous knowledge of school age children with focus on foreign children in need of international protection.

complementary, UN and partners provided Macedonian language classes, mentoring educational support and catchup classes to 30 asylum seekers and 6 refugees, thus supporting the reception and integration authorities in providing inclusive and a receptive environment for refuges. Complementary assistance to the one provided by authorities to the refugees was also organized by a social partner through activities that facilitate access to social services provided by the national legislation.

New cooperation was established between UN, MLSP and Faculty for Philology “Blaze Koneski” in developing of an Online Language Platform for learning Macedonian Language that would support authorities in providing systemic language classes for asylum seekers and refugees opting for local inclusion. 

UN provided Teaching About Refugees online training to 13 teachers and educators from Primary School “Kliment Ohridski”, Skopje that is hosting refugee children, Nova International School and Youth Educational Forum, equipping the participants with the basic awareness and understanding on the work with students of refugee and migrant background, as well as familiarizing them with resources that could be used in the classroom to cultivate harmony and belonging as part of larger efforts to welcome and fully integrate newcomers into the community.

2021 Narrative: While the 2020/2021 school year ended with the majority of students participating in remote learning, through advocacy, robust monitoring tools, and comprehensive research, UNICEF helped increase the share of schools where students physically attended classes, and jointly with the Ministry of Education and Science led to the actual reopening of all schools in September.
2022 Narrative: An international conference on ‘The Interplay between child wellbeing and academic attainment’ was organized in March 2022, bringing together eminent national and international experts, teachers and professionals (from the UK, US, Canada, Croatia and Moldova) to discuss social and emotional learning, parenting, digital technologies in education and child wellbeing. The conference raised awareness on the importance of social and emotional development and expansion of preschool access to all children, the importance of psychosocial support and wellbeing during the education process and later into adulthood, the different aspects of the increased use of digital technology in education, its effects on the process and the observed opportunities The conference also featured a number of ‘demo corners’ displaying the products developed as part of the social and emotional learning programme, youth engagement and Eduino. The conference reached more than 4,600 participants online, and 200 with in-person attendance.A series of 15 ‘Sharing and Playing’ events were organized at preschools, bringing together preschool professionals and parents from various communities. The events aimed to bring the social and emotional learning programme and resources closer to parents and caregivers and promote stronger parental engagement, responsive caregiving and social and emotional learning (SEL) at home. The hybrid events reached more than 10,000 parents, helping to raise awareness of the importance of SEL, thereby building public demand for social and emotional learning opportunities.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF: The results from the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) of 2022 highlighted concerning setbacks in student learning outcomes in reading, mathematics, and science in the country. This learning crisis is further exacerbated by low preschool enrolment. While there was 6% increase in enrolment of children 3-6 years old, the current rate of 44% still falls considerably short compared to EU targets of 96%. To address this challenge, UNICEF actively advocated with municipalities to transform free school spaces into pre-school facilities as part of the optimization of school’s network initiative. Moreover, UNICEF worked with the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy and 21 municipalities to improve school readiness and early childhood development outcomes of Roma children, aged 3 to 6,by deploying Roma mediators in each of the municipalities to engage with parents of Roma children and facilitate early childhood enrolment and attendance. UNICEF engaged in extensive advocacy efforts that contributed to the submission of amendments to the Law on Primary Education, aiming to ensure that children in educational correctional facilities have access to certified primary education. This provision is intended to empower them to continue their education and acquire the qualifications necessary for future employment. While the amendment has successfully passed the first hearing in Parliament, it is currently awaiting final adoption. Additionally, on the children's takeover of Parliament, organised on the occasion of World Children's Day, allowed a highly visible opportunity for children and youth to express their concerns about the lack of access to and quality of education and to advocate for the fast adoption of the amendments to the necessary laws. UNICEF further emphasized these demands through letters sent to the Minister of Education and Science and Members of the Parliament. The Ministry of Education and Science's absence of feedback on the 2022 Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) strategy stalled the Bureau for Development of Education's (BDE) initial plan to introduce scaling up of CSE as a stand-alone subject in the 9th grade, impeding its implementation.UNFPA continued to work with and to support the BDE in other complementary processes - including participation of a national delegation at the regional CSE workshop in Sarajevo in August 2023, where different approaches and modalities were presented by countries that have advanced with CSE implementation. The lessons learned from the workshop, and the country context were further discussed, and  UNFPA supported the BDE in defining the modalities to integrate CSE topics into existing school curricula, as part of the ongoing periodic review and update process of the school curricula for various related subjects. Furthermore, UNFPA supported the BDE with mapping of relevant stakeholders and experts to assist the BDE in reviewing school curricula and incorporation of CSE topics. As the first step in the process, UNFPA will support the BDE in Q1 2024 with the reviewing of 7th and 8th grade school curricula for Biology (primary school),  where CSE contents would be integrated,  appropriate and in line with the UN International technical guidance on sexuality education. The need for access to information related to the sexual and reproductive health of the young people is clearly stated in the new National Youth Strategy 2023-2027, providing the grounds for intervention in the school curricula.
2024 Narrative: As part of the analysis of the European Child Guarantee, data was collected across various areas, including education, to assess access to education for children experiencing poverty and/or social exclusion. This assessment focused on specific groups such as children with disabilities, children living on the streets, and those in conflict with the law. A validation meeting with relevant stakeholders was held in June 2024.To support evidence-based policymaking in inclusive education, UNICEF held consultations with over 60 representatives from various stakeholder groups. Feedback from these consultations informed the development of a policy document, which was used to advocate for ensuring that the proposed amendments in the Law on Primary Education uphold and advance inclusive education without any regression.UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education and Science in preparing for the transfer of preschool education responsibilities from the Ministry of Social Policy, Demography, and Youth. To facilitate this process, UNICEF engaged with stakeholders to assess the readiness of the target group, identify challenges, and determine the most effective approach for the transition. The insights gathered were shared with the Minister of Education, and the transfer is scheduled to occur within the next two years.

Also, social care of UASC is supported in accordance to gender sensitive standards. Capacity building for institutions (teaching staff, social protection professionals) that is planned by the project aims to encompass topics closely related to gender equality such as preliminary identification of victims of human trafficking.  Some data are collected disaggregated by gender. However, project activities are not primarily designed to target gender related issues and will not substantially improve gender equality.

2021 Narrative:
Responding to the reform momentum, UNICEF supported the development and printing of textbooks for grade 1, developing digital interactive textbooks for Grade 4 and a platform for their offline and online use (E-Library) and kept building alliances and partnerships to upgrade the Eduino portal. The upgrades will allow crowdsourcing of additional teaching resources and uploading of the new interactive digital textbooks onto Eduino. In addition, Eduino was expanded with a dedicated ECD subpage and an affiliate platform for vocational secondary education.
In order to expand the programme’s reach beyond kindergarten playrooms, UNICEF is supporting the development of animated and TV content that is being broadcast nationwide and shared online, to reach children who are not attending pre-schools and help create public demand for social and emotional learning opportunities.
2022 Narrative: To support the inclusion of children with disabilities in preschool education, a digital communicator app CBoard, developed by UNICEF, was localized in Macedonian and Albanian, and a female text-to-speech voice (Suze) was developed, together with a training package on Alternative and Augmentative Communication for education professionals and parents. More than 400 professionals have thus far been trained to use these resources to support children who are facing a wide range of speech and language impairments and difficulties.Eduino– the national online learning platform established by UNICEF 2020, continues to be the main repository of educational resources for all school levels and all stakeholders, with new educational content continuously being developed for different age groups. Through crowdsourcing, the dedicated Eduino Early Childhood Development subpage was enriched with additional 1,500 digital educational games and activities developed by preschool teachers, reviewed and approved by the BDE. Moreover, a virtual science laboratory was developed in 2022, containing a section of self-paced science experiments developed as part of the programme on environment and climate change. Further resources for social and emotional learning and development for preschool-aged children were developed as part of an innovative initiative for youth engagement. The programme was implemented in 20 secondary schools with 215 students from Skopje, Gostivar, Tetovo, Radovish and Kumanovo, who worked in teams, mixed by gender and ethnicity, to jointly produce visual art, drama performances, digital games and music acts for the children in preschools, under mentorship and guidance from subject experts. 49 different products were created and the most successful ones were presented at the education conference in March. Based on this experience, a school guide was developed, offering a model for community engagement of students in secondary schools.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF supported the Bureau for the Development of Education (BDE) in taking-over complete ownership and management over the national education platform EDUINO, through capacity development, strategic discussions and operational planning. The BDE was also provided with tailored materials to inform and assist the maintenance of the EDUINO platform, as a national repository for quality, BDE-approved, free-of-charge teaching and learning materials for all students, teachers and parents in the country.Through funding and support from Sweden, UNICEF supported the establishment of the Science Learning Network (SLN), comprising of six institutions (the Hydro-biological Institute from Ohrid, Galichica National Park, Botanical Gardens in Skopje, Narodna Tehnika – Skopje, Negrevo Nature Preservation Centre and the Macedonian Ecological Society). The SLN members developed a joint educational programme, aligned with curricula and adopted by the BDE, that offers environment and climate change thematic workshops, through an experiential learning approach. To support early inclusion of children with communication difficulties, and successful transition into primary education, UNICEF continued promoting alternative and augmentative communication (AAC), through capacity development of 25 professionals at the five resource centres and introducing AACIn 2023, UNICEF supported the Bureau for the Development of Education (BDE) in taking-over complete ownership and management over the national education platform EDUINO, through capacity development, strategic discussions and operational planning. The BDE was also provided with tailored materials to inform and assist the maintenance of the EDUINO platform, as a national repository for quality, BDE-approved, free-of-charge teaching and learning materials for all students, teachers and parents in the country.To support early inclusion of children with communication difficulties, and successful transition into primary education, UNICEF continued promoting alternative and augmentative communication (AAC), and the communicator app Cboard, through capacity development of 25 professionals at the five resource centres. Moreover, AAC was introduced as a topic in the Programme for Professional Development of Educational Assistants, adopted by MoES in 2023. To support further uptake of AAC, 11 local open events were organised in preschools, to familiarise parents, ECD and ECE professionals with the benefits of AAC, and with available resources. in the Programme for Professional Development of Educational Assistants, adopted by MoES in 2023. To support further uptake of AAC, 11 local open events were organised in preschools, to familiarise parents, ECD and ECE professionals with the benefits of AAC, and with available resources.
2024 Narrative: To support the development of healthy nutrition habits from an early age, in partnership with the Ministry of Social Policy, Demography and Youth, UNICEF supported the development of a training manual on healthy nutrition for preschool staff, by experts in nutrition, health, food safety, early childhood education and development and preschool practitioners. The training manual contains a general module for all staff (preschool teachers, caregivers, kitchen staff, professional team etc) and a module with pedagogical approaches for teaching young children about nutrition, aimed specifically for preschool teachers. A set of practical information materials for parents were also developed, to foster healthy nutrition habits at home. To support the right of every child to attend quality education with their peers and in their local community, UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education and Science to develop Guidance on the Development and Implementation of the Modified Programme for Children with Complex Needs. The Guidance was developed by a working group of experts, practitioners and policy makers and it is currently pending adoption by the Minister of Education and Science. As part of efforts to support the integration of holistic and comprehensive environment and climate change education across the education system, in partnership with the Vocational Education and Training (VET) Centre, UNICEF supported the development of ten green curricula for ten different VET profiles, with accompanying learning materials. The new curricula and learning materials help students develop appropriate skills, knowledge, behaviors, and attitudes to cope with a rapidly changing world and climate. Moreover, through the development of green skills, students can contribute to personal and systemic transformation towards more sustainable lifestyles and facilitate the transitioning to a green economy.UNFPA: Digital tool for sexuality education for youth with autism spectrum disorder and intelectual disability has been developed, and will be further tested and promoted among special educators, teachers and parents of children with disabilities in 2025. The content is developed in a way that is easy to understand, with a lot of visuals / illustrations and simple text / description, to support the learning of girls and boys.

This will be achieved through supporting relevant education authorities in elaboration and adoption of MIL policies and strategies. The ultimate goal of the activity is to gradually and systematically integrate MIL skills and competences into school curricula as well as into teaching and learning process.

Crucial are teachers, school management and other staff, playing key roles in creating safe learning spaces, adapting curricula and providing support to marginalized students. This Joint programme proposes to modernise education and learning in Montenegro, as well as to contribute to the education sector reforms with the ultimate goal of ensuring equal, quality and relevant education for all children and youth. Focal users: Vera Kondikj-Mitkovska, Gjorgji  Dimeski, Jovanka Brajovic Grigorijevic
2022 Narrative: UNFPA: In 2022 UNFPA continued with the support to the CSE and youth related initiatives.Based on the signed MoU with the Bureau for Development of Education (BDE) UNFPA in 2022 continued supporting the BDE in the process of strategic positioning, planning and rollout of Comprehensive Sexuality Education. In the course of 2022, UNFPA and UNICEF contributed to the development of the National Strategy on CSE (finalized in July 2022). This document is a prerequisite for scaling up CSE at national level, following the CSE piloting in 2021/2022, at 3 primary schools. The strategy was designed in a way to offer innovative approaches and solutions to CSE in the educational system. The strategy focuses on 2 main priorities: Improving the knowledge, skills and attitudes of students in the area of comprehensive sexual education and Increasing awareness of the need to study the contents of comprehensive sexual education in primary education. To facilitate collaboration among the Balkan countries Cluster, with support of the EECA Regional office, the UNFPA CO organized a sub-regional CSE workshop, entitled "Championing young people’s health: a journey towards the wellbeing of the 8 billion". The workshop created a platform for partnerships between the institutions working on CSE in the Western Balkans to strengthen CSE advocacy and implementation in the Western Balkan countries by sharing good practices and examples of modalities of CSE implementation by the main key actors and stakeholders from North Macedonia, Kosovo, Serbia, Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition, as part of the SRH portfolio and cooperation with the Macedonian Association of Gynecologists and Obstetricians, out-of-school CSE sessions have been delivered to high school students at several high schools across the country.UNICEFUNICEF continued supporting the implementation of the new Concept for Primary Education and curricula through capacity-development trainings for teachers. The transformation of the former special schools into Resource Centres that support the inclusion of all children in mainstream education was supported through capacity-development for staff and the development of various training programmes - a Programme for Professional Development of Education Assistants, a Training Programme on Alternative and Augmentative Communication and a Training Programme for Teachers Working with Refugee, Migrant and Asylum Seeking Children (the latter was drafted in 2022, but will be piloted and finalized in early 2023).In the lead-up to the Transforming Education Summit organized by the UN Secretary General, a series of 10 national consultations on the future of education were organized by UNICEF and the RCO, with over 600 youth, students, teachers, municipal officials, parliamentarians and CSOs. Based on the input from the consultations, a national statement of commitment was prepared and presented at the Summit in New York by the Prime Minister. Support for strengthening of the counseling and support role of pre-schools continued through mentorship and reflective consultations with the 20 parenting practitioners from preschools, who delivered parenting group sessions that aim to promote positive parent-child relationships and create supportive and nurturing environments for children. In 2022, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic, UNICEF continued supporting schools facing WASH and IPC challenges. UNICEF continued collaboration with the tripartite WASH committee, of representatives from the MoES, Institute for Public Health and the State Education Inspectorate. As a result, 58 predominantly rural satellite schools received mobile handwashing stations – effectively covering 8260 students. Additionally, technical staff representatives from these schools received specialized WASH training and helped advance the hygiene improvement plans of the schools. Finally, a thorough communication strategy was developed to tie IPC and WASH resources with school behaviors and practices conducive to safe environments
2023 Narrative: UNHCR - No substantial results in 2022. UNHCR was invited on meetings to providing advice and technical assistance in producing policies, documents for the education to become inclusive of refugees, asylum seekers and stateless persons. Recognizing the importance of increasing learning outcomes, UNICEF advocated for and invested in the ongoing curricula reform. As part of this effort, the new curricula for grade six and seven was developed and UNICEF supported their alignment with the Primary Education Concept and with the national learning outcomes and assessment standards.To support the holistic integration of separate science subjects into one, as foreseen in the new concept for primary education, UNICEF supported the creation of an experiential learning programme focused on environment and climate change, that enables students to practically engage with the topic with their teachers and apply their knowledge. UNICEF also supported the Science Learning Network, comprised of six science institutions in designing and offering a joint educational programme on environment and climate change, aligned with national curricula and verified by the Bureau for the Development of Education. This programme, developed with financial support from Sweden, helps students acquire practical experience about the environment and natural phenomena and how our behaviour impacts eco-systems. To complement these efforts, raise students’ knowledge of air pollution and support youth to get actively involved in processes at local level, UNICEF has also initiated the development of an experiential learning programme on air quality. UNICEF also established a partnership with the Vocational Training and Education Centre (VETC), initiating a greening revision of VET curricula, to support green skills development in students and facilitate the transitioning to a green economy. As of September 2023, all children with disabilities are enrolled in mainstream primary schools. One of the challenges schools are facing is to develop and implement the modified programme for working with children with moderate to severe learning disabilities. In response to this challenge, the Ministry of Education and Science established a collaborative working group with representatives from the resource centres, the Bureau for Development of Education, the ICF assessment commission, the body for monitoring the implementation of UNCRPD, primary schools and DPOs. UNICEF was invited to lead this group and to come up with recommendations for the necessary support required to assist teachers in developing and implementing the modified programme. UNICEF maintained regular meetings of the intersectoral steering committee tasked to oversee the entire Climate Change Education portfolio. This committee includes members of the Ministries of Education and Science, Labour and Social Policy, and Environment and Physical Planning. These partnerships extended on a technical level with specific units such as the Air Quality unit of the MoEPP, which is extremely beneficial for the sub-regional programme on Air Quality.To ensure system level support, a gap analysis of the services, capacities, and needs for providing mental health in education and social protection was conducted. The gap analysis results were used to draft the first National Action Plan for the mental health of adolescents in the country. UNICEF also led a group of professionals to develop a new counselling programme for parents and students adopted by the MoES. The programme primarily supports students who may display violent behaviour or, for various reasons, are not reaching their full academic potential. The school support involves focused efforts through individual and group counselling sessions with parents and students to overcome challenges and improve their mental well-being.UNFPA supported the data analysis of the Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC) Study, and dissemination of the results at national and regional level. The national findings were presented at a conference organized by the project team at the Faculty of Philosophy in Skopje premises, in the presence of numerous representatives of national institutions, relevant stakeholders, teachers, students, including Ms. Elizabeta Gjorgievska, spouse of the President of the Republic of North Macedonia. After the central conference, the dissemination of the results was initiated in all statistical regions within the country.Through the intervention, UNFPA set the baseline to create a platform for advocacy and promotion of youth wellbeing, addressing violence (including GBV), promoting constructive narratives, inclusion, and building trust among youth and their peers. By promoting findings, the rationale and need of integrating CSE in the educational process becomes even more evident, so that youth can receive age-appropriate credible information, to be able to undertake informed decisions about their life, health and their future.In partnership with the Macedonian Medical Association, UNFPA continued conducting educational-interactive workshops for high school students aged 15 to 18. Facilitated by a gynecology and obstetrics specialist and two actors, the workshops conveyed key messages: dispelling myths about sexual and reproductive health, promoting awareness of modern contraceptive methods and their benefits, underscoring the risks of unprotected sex, particularly regarding unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections (STIs), emphasizing condoms as a readily available and dual-purpose contraception method guarding against both unwanted pregnancies and STIs, including HIV, and stressing the importance of regular gynecological examinations. More than 15 educational sessions around the country were conducted and were attended by more than 1200 students.
2024 Narrative: To protect the health, wellbeing, development and learning of children during heatwaves, UNICEF coordinated the development of a protocol (SOPs) for schools, based on global best practices and technical experts from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Education and Science, the Institute for Public Health and the Bureau for Development of Education. The SOPs were adopted by the Government at the start of the school year.As part of the joint programme with WHO, an action plan for mental health was developed, which included activities aimed at improving the mental health of students in primary and secondary education. This protocol was adopted by the Government in October 2024.The Bureau for Development of Education (BDE) was supported in developing nine programs for implementing extracurricular activities in primary education, aimed at enriching students’ experiences in areas of their interest. Additionally, the BDE was supported in creating a teaching program for implementing a community practice introduced with the primary education concept in 2020.UNFPA: two thematic reports, on peer violence between students at the age of 11, 13 and 15 in North Macedonia and sexual health and wellbeing of youth in North Macedonia were developed based on the HBSC study data with the support of UNFPA CO, which will be published and promoted in the first quarter of 2025. These reports will provide further evidence to support advocacy efforts and strengthen collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Science and the Bureau for Development of Education towards the integration of CSE in the national curriculum. UNFPA's support extended throughout the entire process from data collection and analysis, to visualization and dissemination of key findings on a national level. Advocacy efforts for CSE continued throughout Q4, through the dissemination of the Health Behaviour in School-aged Children (HBSC) study findings, through 14 sessions organized at 10 high schools in Skopje, facilitating discussions and raising awareness about youth and their wellbeing, SRHR, GBV and other CSE related topics among students, parents and teaching staff.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Sub-Output: 2.2.2.1 UNHCR - Socio-economic integration support for refugees including education, access to the job market and skills development
Description: UNHCR supports refugee women and men with their socio-economic integration in Serbia in different areas: access to education, skills building and training, and access to the labor market. This is done in collaboration with the competent ministries and the private sector. It also supports a wider conducive environment for the integration of refugees in Serbian society and working with relevant Ministries to reduce barriers and facilitate access.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: European Union, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: National CSOs Serbia, Republic of Serbia Commissariat for Refugees and Migration, Republic of Serbia Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development, Republic of Serbia Ministry of Health , Republic of Serbia Ministry of Labour, Employment, Veterans and Social Affairs
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,4.6 By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, and achieve literacy and numeracy.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Gender equality in socio-economic integration of refugees means providing equal opportunities for all genders to participate in and benefit from educational programs, employment opportunities, and skills development initiatives. UNHCR intervention involves addressing gender-specific barriers and promoting inclusive practices that recognize the diverse needs and contributions of all individuals. Through the network of private sector companies #ForRefugees UNHCR works on creating stimulating environment for economic empowerment of refugee men and women, and raising awareness about anti-discrimination in the employment process.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Right to work and access is one of the essential rigts of refugees, asylum seekers and persons under temporary protection, as per the Law on Asylum and temporary protection. A/s have the right to work after six months, and persons under temporary protection for the duration of their protection. There is no legal difference in access to work for women. UNHCR works on self-empowerment of refugee women with the private sector and competent state institutions.

2021 Narrative: With the endorsement of the new CPD for North Macedonia, 2021-2025, and following detailed consultations with the Ministry of Health and the Bureau for Development of Education (BDE), UNFPA has signed Memorandum of Understanding with the BDE, outlining the key areas for cooperation and support by UNFPA in the introduction of CSE, from the piloting in 2021, to the full roll out by the end of 2025. This is the first time that we are setting a strategic framework for cooperation in a 5-year period with the BDE; in addition to cooperation in the field of CSE, this opens the floor for UNFPA to contribute and support the review of curricula, with regards to gender roles and stereotypes, sensitivity about PWD, GBV and other sensitive topics.

Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030

Sub-Output: Capacities are enhanced to develop and implement inclusive, student-centred and skills/competency-based general education policies, curricula, and programmes, including for out-of-school children and children with disabilities.
Description: Capacities are enhanced to develop and implement inclusive, student-centred and skills/competency-based general education policies, curricula, and programmes, including for out-of-school children and children with disabilities.
Contributing partners: Government of Bulgaria, Government of France, Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education, Science and Youth of Georgia
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
QCPR function: Normative Support, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 2.2 2.2. Improved national capacities for the implementation of policies and programmes that ensure inclusive and equitable access to quality educational programmes that meet international standards
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2021 Narrative: Teacher training toolkits and facilitators guidelines on quality teaching, inclusive and second chance education developed, piloted in seventeen schools with 200 out-of-school children mainstreamed in formal education; successful models documented and ready to scale up at national level by the ministry of education and science.
2022 Narrative: UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education and Science in the development and finalization of the National Education and Science Strategy (2022 – 2030) and the corresponding work plan for (2022 – 2024). UNICEF also supported the Government’s preparations for the global Transforming Education Summit (TES), including support for national consultations, preparing a national statement of commitment for safe learning and finalization/submission of a national report. UNICEF supported the decentralization of teacher in-service training contributing to the training of more than 1,500 teachers. The reform of the inclusive education system is underway with a series of capacity development sessions for 120 specialists. UNICEF, in partnership with Innovations for Inclusive Society, is supporting MoES to strengthen the quality of education for students with special education needs and/or disabilities by strengthening functional application of resource rooms at 10 public schools, introducing effective transition practices from general to vocational/higher education level, in partnership with 20 state and private vocational education institutions, and establishing school-based parent clubs.
2023 Narrative: The Parliament approved legislative amendments in the Law of General Education to formalize a new model of the inclusive education support system. With the support of the Norwegian Government, MoES, in cooperation with UNICEF and the Norwegian state organization Statped, initiated an inclusive education system reform, including training of 120 counsellors and leaders of the inclusive education support system. Continuing efforts in strengthening the capacities of universities in inclusive education, UNICEF supported the academic staff of seven state universities in further enhancing BA and MA programmes, with 25 professors going through a series of coaching sessions on inclusive education and reaching more than 315 teachers at 105 public schools. As a result of the cooperation between the universities and schools, four school-based Inclusive Education Centers have been established. The Centers have developed annual action plans and have hosted various training/workshops for teachers and students to advance inclusive education initiatives. UNICEF provided technical support to MoES and selected municipalities in the design of education programmes for children with special education needs and disabilities (SEND). After-school programmes for children with SEND, out-of-school children, and children at risk of dropping out of school were designed and modeled in selected public schools and Child Rights Centers. To date, 80 children with SEND and 50 children at risk of dropping out of school have been benefiting from educational and art activities; and 300 students and 100 teachers from public schools in Adjara have been engaged in the promotion of inclusive education culture in schools.UNICEF advocated for the approval of the Catch-up and Accelerated Learning Curriculum as part of the National Curriculum, thereby facilitating the integration of out-of-school children and those at-risk of dropping-out of school into mainstream education.
2024 Narrative: The Parliament approved legislative amendments in the Law of General Education to formalize a new model of the inclusive education support system. UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education, Science and Youth (MoESY) in developing a new model of an inclusive education support system to improve access to education for boys and girls, especially for children with disabilities, national minorities, and children who are not attending school or are at risk of dropping out. In 2023, the Parliament approved legislative amendments in the Law of General Education to formalize the new model of the inclusive education support system. In 2024, UNICEF supported MoESY to initiate implementation of the inclusive education support system with two major interventions: (1) capacitating 70 inclusive education specialists and (2) development (and revision) of different normative documents and instruments to be applied in the system for assessment of a child, for communication and cooperation between different actors (special teacher, parents and etc).With the support of Bulgarian Embassy, UNICEF in partnership with TPDC introduced and piloted after school catch-up programme for boys and girls at risk to drop-out of school. The programme was implemented in the Child Rights Centers of 3 state universities (Kutaisi, Gori and Zugdidi). UNICEF capacitated teachers and students involved in this programme through trainings, educational resources and guidelines.UNICEF, in collaboration with the Government of France, is supporting a consortium of three state universities in the development of Georgia’s first Master of Arts (MA) Programme in Child Rights. UNICEF, with the support of the Embassy of France and in partnership with Child Rights Centers of nine universities, conducted a skills mapping of youth to analyse learning competencies and skills needed to thrive in a complex, interconnected, and technology-driven environment. The mapping exercise covered ten competencies: literacy; multilingualism; science, technology, engineering and math (STEM); interpersonal skills, entrepreneurship, citizenship, digital skills, cultural awareness, green skills and mental health. The report outlines the main findings on areas where further interventions are needed to support adolescents to develop skills for learning, employment, personal and social development and active participation in the society.To enhance girls’ leadership, learning and skills, including digital skills, UNICEF Georgia supported 28 Youth Clubs in two regions, engaging 920 students (402 boys and 518 girls) on STEM, and strengthening their critical thinking and language skills. Objectives of the Youth Clubs are empowering youth through tailored informal education programmes, building skills in analyzing information and data, as well as strengthening communication and leadership skills. Youth Clubs also supported foreign language skills (English) to encourage dialogue and communication between different conflict-affected communities. In addition, in partnership with Business and Technology University (BTU), UNICEF empowered over 60 vulnerable youth (35 boys and 25 girls) in Tbilisi and Batumi with digital skills through eight-month training programme, including trainings and career bootcamps. Most of the young people were from socially vulnerable families; under state care and were selected by the State Care Agency; or selected by the Probation Department of the Ministry of Justice.

2022 Narrative: In partnership with Action Global Communication, UNICEF implemented the “See Every Color” campaign to address stigma against SEN, reaching 300 pupils, 300 teachers, and 1,860 parents and childcare professionals through a series of educational sessions conducted in 20 schools across 6 regions of Georgia. In addition, in partnership with Action Global Communication resources related to building IE was disseminated through social and traditional media, reaching 350,000 people with online content, and 300,000 viewers.UNICEF, in partnership with Gordon College of Education, developed resources and guidelines on inclusive and quality education and increased the capacity of MoES, TPDC and universities on the best international practices. Gordon College also provided technical support to MoES and selected municipalities in the design of non-formal education programmes for children with special educational needs and disabilities (SEN). Gordon College also developed detailed recommendations to improve teachers’ pre-service training, with state universities revising the Bachelor and Master level programmes for teachers’ education based on the recommendations provided.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported the piloting of innovative approaches to strengthen the use of resource rooms for inclusive education in 10 public schools, combined with teacher training and coaching sessions for 242 educators, establishment of school-based parent clubs as well as strengthening transition practices from general to vocational/higher education for children with SEND, in partnership with 20 state and private vocational education institutions.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF supported the Mandaturi office in capacity building of multidisciplinary teams to increase their knowledge on child centered, inclusive and safe schooling and services to children with special needs and disabilities.

2023 Narrative: With UNICEF support, the Ministry of Health started enhancing its sanitary and epidemiological surveillance system to better monitor and identify children’s diseases and conditions associated with ecological risks. The goal is to better understand pollution and climate change’s impact on children’s health and strengthen frontline health service capacities and parental awareness accordingly. UNICEF also supported the MOE’s review of its information management system to better track the impact of pollutants and climate change on schools’ environmental quality.

Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: In ECE governance, the established program quality standards exist and are effectively applied to public providers in certification and accreditation processes. Private and community services are regulated, but the quality assurance monitoring mechanisms are being built with the support from UNICEF through finalized self-assessment tools leading towards restoration of attestation and accreditation system for public and private pre-schools. The self-assessment tools are digitalised by the Ministry of Education for rollout, however, the concept of self-assessment is new and it takes sometime to adapt to it, improve regulations and requiring further work on establishing the benchmarks. More advocacy and technical support are needed to unpack procedures for using the collected data in decision making with link to attestation. Financial and human resources with respect to pre-primary education are allocated, but the equity dimension is not in place, there is limited consideration of efficient early learning models. National data on early learning coverage and service quality are not used for policy decision.
2024 Narrative: In ECE governance, thanks to UNICEF advocacy and supported knowledge sharing between Kazakhstan and other countries, the Ministry of Education initiated the review of national approaches to diversification of models to reach the unreached children of pre-school age and equitable financing.  Financial and human resources with respect to pre-primary education are allocated, but the equity dimension is not in place, there is limited consideration of efficient early learning models. National data on the coverage and quality of pre-school education are not sufficiently used for decision-making.

Description: Support the scale up of the remedial support strategies and guide MOE, local education authorities, and schools in addressing the learning loss among some groups of children lagging behind with gender responsive pedagogy through public and private schools.
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: The impact of COVID-19-induced school closures on learning outcomes remains significant and requires implementing a mix of traditional and new approaches to remedy learning loss. The most affected groups include disadvantaged children, such as rural children, migrant children, and children in economically disadvantaged households. These children run the risk of falling behind even further. While various methods are employed by educators, less time-invasive and more participatory approaches need to be employed and tailored to an individual child. In 2023, UNICEF finalized and validated the piloting of several remedial strategies, including teacher-to-teacher mentorship, teacher-to-student mentorship, and peer-to-peer support through student volunteering. Over 10,000 school-age children joined these programmes, either as volunteers or recipients.medial approaches were validated with the central education authorities. To meet the demand from educators, policy briefs on the Whole School approach were prepared for dissemination and fostering an informed and collaborative dialogue to promote understanding and support for these crucial educational strategies.
2024 Narrative: n scaling up the remedial programmes, UNICEF has compiled a set of resources on mentorship for teachers, guiding them about the delivery of catch up classes with students. The learning loss study report was made availbale to public.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.1: Increased capacities of education stakeholders to respond to evolving learning environment including through strengthening inclusive  blended and digital learning.
Sub-Output: Promote and raise awareness of the government and non-government actors about findings and recommendations of the evaluation for inclusion in education and follow up actions
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of High Education and Science
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNICEF-supported Evaluation of State Programmes for the Development of Education with Focus on Inclusivity and the Evaluation Using Big Data Sources of Information earmarked significant progress in inclusive education, particularly in the context of working with children with disabilities, in Kazakhstan. However, state programs showed limited attention to migrant children and those in conflict with the law, important categories according to government legislations. Additionally, gender equality received minimal emphasis in state programs, with online discussions on education highlighting a disproportionate focus on boys (75%) compared to girls (25%). Finally, conversations on inclusive education in social media tend to be centered in major urban areas such as Astana and Almaty, persisting even when accounting for their elevated population densities. The evaluation findings and recommendations are incorporated into the MoE response plan, influencing the direction of education initiatives with the focus on inclusion, developing ToC and ME framework in alignment with international standards. Additionally, UNICEF created a briefing note on gender-responsive pedagogy for Ministry staff to advance its integration into policy and capacity development.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF informed the MPs and government about the findings and recommendations of the evaluation for inclusion in education. With UNICEF support, the MoE reviewed the draft concept on inclusive education draft law and new paradigm, based on international approaches, UNCRPD concluding observations, and identified gaps which demonstrate medical approach in access to education for children with disability.

SDG Targets: 2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.
