2023 Narrative: In 2023, 10,659 parents and caregivers accessed information and advice to improve child nutrition. This was made possible thanks to UNICEF support, through i) a digital illustrated recipes book developed and disseminated in collaboration with “Magnum CashCarry” LLC; ii) the dissemination of leaflets, promoting breastfeeding, in partnership with “Rascal and Friends” business company, and targeting Fly Aristan airline’s passengers.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.1: Increased capacities of education stakeholders to respond to evolving learning environment including through strengthening inclusive  blended and digital learning.
Sub-Output: Strengthened capacities of educational institutions and stakeholders in Kostanay region to respond to evolving learning environment
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan higher education institutions, Kazakhstan national experts
SDG Targets: 4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environments for all.,9.c Significantly increase access to information and communications technology and strive to provide universal and affordable access to the Internet in least developed countries by 2020.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: In 2021 ITU finalized procurement and delivery of the equipment necessary to create a smart education ecosystem. The core network of the Kostanay Engineering  Economics University (KInEU university) was upgraded to ensure distribution of high-speed internet withing the university campus, a platform for organizing distance learning, videoconferencing, and lP-telephony.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, in consultation with akimats of Kostanay city and the Kostanay region, 6 educational institutions were selected to be connected to the university’s network (KInEU became an Internet-hub for local community):-        Chaikovski Secondary School (Zhitikara District) - 59 students;-        Zhambyl Secondary School (Kostanay District) - 348 students;-        Amankaragai Secondary School named after N.Ostrovski (Auliekol District) - 664 students;-        Amankaragai Secondary School No.2 (Auliekol District) - 199 students;-        Corporate University of LLP “Saryarka AvtoProm”, -        hostel of the “KInEU College of Entrepreneurship”.All facilities were connected at the speed of at 10 Mbps – global absolute minimum recommended by Giga.  Each facility is fully covered by a wireless network and is able to communicate with the university to solve possible technical problems with the network and equipment. Objects are provided with access data to manage their local websites with content placement and administration rights.The smart education ecosystem has improved the quality of education in the connected institutions and allows for context-dependent global learning in the digital age to meet the needs of work and life in the 21st century.Apart from this, 32 lecturers of the KInEU were trained in digital literacy and the use of ICT in the educational process. This course was developed in order to upgrade digital skills of lecturers so that they will be able to efficiently and creatively teach students using the full capacity of equipment purchased to create smart education ecosystem.
2023 Narrative: 1) In March 2023, 2 more rural schools attended by 514 children (Tenizovskaya Basic Secondary School, Mendykarinsky District, and Auliekol General Education School named after Shokan Ualikhanov, Auliyol District)  were connected to the broadband Internetusing ITU Intellectual Educational Ecosystem created at the KInEU university (city of Kostanay). This brings the total number of connected rural schools in Kostanay region under this project in 2023 - 2024 to six (1784 students). In all cases KInEU university served as an Internet-hub, that ensures school connectivity at speed 10 Mbps, in accordance to global minimum recommended by Giga (ITU-UNICEF global project).In addition, these two schools piloted the deployment of exemplary local area networks (LAN) to ensure wireless broadband access for students and teachers for educational purposes. KInEU staff was trained on LANs' design, development of relevant documentation, procurement and installation works, as well as network administration and launch.2) In February 2023, experts from Kazakhstan (KInEU university staff), Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan  took part in the online training 'ITU tools for connecting schools to the Internet' for ITU. Participants gained knowledge and practical skills about the most promising technologies for school connectivity, ITU tools to be used to estimate capital and operating costs in all sections of the telecommunications network (incl. school LAN), mapping and analysing broadband network infrastructure.3) In September 2023, about 100 representatives of Kazakhstan (representatives of the line Ministries, central executive authorities (animats), telecommunication operators, Internet service providers, project organizations, academia and research institutes, school administrators, school computer network administrators, computer science teachers, software developers and other stakeholders), as well as professionals from Belarus, Russia, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan gained knowledge and practical skills on policy and regulatory aspects of school connectivity and on technological and economic aspects of broadband school connectivity at the regional event 'Broadband Week: connecting schools - expanding the opportunities of education of tomorrow!' (Kostanay, Kazakhstan).4) In addition, ITU provides expert assistance to Kazakhstan on addressing challenges related to broadband Internet connectivity at schools, network resiliency and monitoring quality of service. The following national studies are carried out by ITU experts in this area: (a) study on the actual use and quality of Internet connectivity in schools; (b) study on the resilience ofLAN infrastructure in schools. In 2023, a methodology for each study was developed and initial data was collected.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Sustained and inclusive economic and social development
Outcome: Outcome 2: Quality Services for All
Output: Output 2.3 Social protection of all persons in need
Sub-Output: Support to ICF-based assessment for additional educational, health and social support to children and youth
Description: Support will be provided for full implementation of the ICF-based functional assessment system for children and youth, including capacity development for establishing seven regional expert bodies for functional assessment located in Strumica, Bitola, Gostivar, Kumanovo, Stip, Veles and Ohrid, covering the needs of the South-West, Pelagonija, Polog, North-East, East, and Vardar planning regions. The programme will enhance capacities for functional assessment of children and youth, including by supporting capacity development for professionals that will be engaged in the bodies, present the new model for functional assessment to service providers (including Centers for Social Work, schools and kindergartens), as well as parents in the four regions, and support rapid disability assessments and respective plan to provide support services. Technical assistance is also provided for initiating and coordinating legal changes, needed for functional assessment to become a single entry point for children and youth with disability to access support services.
Contributing partners: Government of the United States of America, United Nations Children's Fund, United Nations Partnership on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Health, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy, North Macedonia National Coordination Body on Implementation of the CRPD
SDG Targets: 1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 4 Quality Education, 10 Reduced Inequalities
Geography: Ohrid, Polog, Southwestern, Southeastern, Gostivar, Vardar, Eastern, Shtip, Veles, Northeastern, North Macedonia, Republic of, Pelagonija, Kumanovo, Strumica, Bitola
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Other (including coordination), Normative Support
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF supported North Macedonia to further advance towards switching to functional assessment based on the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) as a single entry-point for children and youth to access various support services in the fields of health, education, and social protection. As a result of the progressive advocacy, the two bodies for functional assessments based on the ICF, covering the Skopje region, and the National expert body for functional assessment that were created with UNICEF support were taken over by the state healthcare system. Namely, the Public Health Center (PHC) Skopje, opened a new Service for functional assessment of children and youth up to 26 years of age, and from January 2021 it started with provision of regular assessments of children and youth from the Skopje region. In the period May-October 2021, with support from UNICEF, training and mentoring on ICF-based functional assessments was conducted in Pelagonija, Polog and South-West regions, involving almost fifty professionals. With UNICEF advocacy the PHC Skopje has engaged twelve of the persons whose capacity has been developed to staff three new regional functional assessment bodies in Strumica, Bitola and Gostivar. UNICEF also supported fifteen workshops to present the new model for functional assessment to service providers – including Centers for Social Work (CSW), schools and kindergartens – as well as parents in the three targeted regions.

UNICEF coordinated with line ministries and other relevant institutions the drafting of amendments to the Social Protection Law, Child Protection Law, Health Insurance Law, Healthcare Law and Primary Education Law in order to consolidate the provision of functional assessments for children and youth in line with the ICF. The amendments were approved by the Government and were put on the agenda of Parliament in December 2021. UNICEF also supported the revision of the draft Rulebook on ICF-based disability assessments, so that it is aligned with the three line-ministries – Health, Education and Science, and Labour and Social Policy – as well as other relevant institutions. 

While UNICEF has supported the establishment of functional assessment bodies which cover four of the eight regions of North Macedonia, children and youth outside the covered regions could not complete such an assessment and were thus not eligible to obtain access to educational and personal assistants. This resulted in difficulties in exercising their right to education, as well as problems in carrying out their everyday activities. To address this, UNICEF supported the creation of a special team to conduct ICF-based disability assessment to children from vulnerable communities in locations that are not covered by the regional assessment bodies.
2022 Narrative: In 2022 UNICEF developed national capacities for expansion of the human-rights based model of disability and needs assessment of children and youth in in the North-East, East, Vardar and South-West planning regions. The initiated establishment of bodies for functional assessment in these regions will complete the introduction of the new model as a single-entry point for support services and benefits throughout the country. With UNICEF advocacy and support, the amendment to the Healthcare Law was adopted in Parliament, which ensured legal basis for the sustainability and the continued functioning of the functional assessment service, with a national and 10 regional functional assessment bodies for children and youth. UNICEF also supported the revision of the draft Rulebook on ICF-based disability assessments, so that it is aligned with the policies of the three line-ministries – Health, Education and Science, and Labour and Social Policy – as well as other relevant institutions. The new model for functional assessment was also presented to service providers – including Centers for Social Work, schools and kindergartens – as well as parents in the four regions.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF developed capacities for expansion of the human-rights based model of disability assessment resulting in launch of two new disability assessment bodies in the North-East and Vardar regions. With UNICEF advocacy and support, the Rulebook on ICF-based disability assessment was adopted by the three line-ministries – MoH, MoES, and MoLSP.
2024 Narrative: Progress was achieved in establishing a system for human rights-based disability assessment of children and youth, as a single-entry point to support services and benefits. UNICEF supported the establishment of new regional functional assessment bodies in Shtip and Ohrid, expanding the coverage to all eight regions of the country. The number of functional assessment professionals in the bodies by 72% and permanent employees by 70%. The number of assessed children has risen by 38% in 2024 compared to the previous year, and the assessments enabled each child to access approximately five different support services and programmes.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK FOR ARMENIA
Strategic priority: Green, sustainable, and inclusive economic development
Outcome: People, communities and regions benefit from equitable economic opportunities, decent work and sustainable livelihoods, enabled through competitiveness and inclusive green growth
Output: 4.2 Capacities at national/ subnational levels are strengthened to design and implement policies for inclusive, green and sustainable economic development
Sub-Output: Opportunities for applied research and higher quality education are expanded through investments in high-tech agricultural teaching facilities and infrastructure.
Implementation partners: United Nations World Food Programme
SDG Targets: 1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional and international levels, based on pro-poor and gender sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries,2.c Adopt measures to ensure the proper functioning of food commodity markets and their derivatives and facilitate timely access to market information, including on food reserves, in order to help limit extreme food price volatility.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: WFP collaborated with the Republican Union of Employers in Armenia and the Armenian National Agrarian University to increase understandings of the feasibility of investment in a range of value chains, and market functionality and upstream supply chain resilience.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, WFP supported Armenian National Agrarian University (ANAU) to strengthen its capacity in delivering agricultural services and knowledge for building sustainable food systems in Armenia. In return, ANAU supported WFP with the implementation of food value chains development in Armenia by providing comprehensive analysis on the development of "Sustainable food value chains" analysis of food systems and agroindustry, assessments of value chains, and research on food loss and waste in the country. In addition, ANAU provided trainings and information sessions on sustainable agriculture, composting techniques, and water management to schools.Acting as an advisory entity and offering innovative solutions in the region, WFP has supported the ANAU Sisian branch which plays a key role in developing food systems including agricultural extension services in Syunik region. In 2022, WFP has renovated a laboratory for soil analysis and initiated the procurement of equipment. In 2023, an intensive orchard and a greenhouse will be established in ANAU's Sisian branch.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, WFP supported the Armenian National Agrarian University (ANAU) in enhancing its capacity to deliver agricultural services and knowledge aimed at building sustainable food systems in Armenia. To serving as an advisory entity and provide innovative solutions to students and farmers in Syunik province, WFP supported ANAU Sisian branch with the establishment of smart farming center, soil analysis lab, intensive orchard and greenhouse. In return, ANAU supported WFP in developing food value chains interventions across the country, providing farmers with training and information sessions on sustainable agriculture, composting techniques, water and soil management.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, WFP strengthened its cooperation with academic institutions by signing of Memoranda of Understanding (MoUs) with the Armenian National Agrarian University, National Polytechnic University of Armenia, and Yerevan State Medical University. These partnerships aim to enhance food security through collaborative efforts, integrating new technologies into agricultural practices. By investing in high-tech teaching facilities and infrastructure, WFP is contributing to the expansion of applied research and the improvement of education in agriculture. Additionally, academic institutions play a crucial role in generating evidence to inform and strengthen WFP's programmatic activities, fostering a mutually beneficial collaboration to drive sustainable solutions in food security.

Sub-Output: Supporting cultural and educational institutions and CSOs to transmit knowledge of and promote Holocaust education and remembrance
Description: Support to the creation of a traveling exhibition and an accompanying educational program, derived from the joint permanent exhibition in Block 17 of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum. The exhibition is to be established by the  successor states of Yugoslavia, namely Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Republic of North Macedonia, Serbia, Croatia, and Slovenia as a place of remembrance for the victims from the former Yugoslavia in the Auschwitz-Birkenau Concentration and Extermination Camp.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Ministry of Culture and Media Montenegro, Ministry of Education Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Gender equality will be addressed by mainstreaming gender into its activities through ensuring gender representation, promoting the involvement of women and ensuring that all data gathered is disaggregated by sex. It can be labelled as “significant” in terms of DAC gender equality policy marker, and as GEM 2 in relation to UNSDG-UNCT gender equality marker. The traveling exhibition and educational program will be designed to include diverse perspectives on the Holocaust, with a specific focus on the experiences of women. This includes highlighting the roles of women as victims, resistance fighters, and survivors, ensuring that their stories are prominently represented.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: This will be achieved by promoting a collective memory that acknowledges the past while fostering a future based on tolerance and respect for human rights. In this way, the project not only addresses the regional challenges but also contributes to global efforts to promote peace, human rights, and social cohesion.

2024 Narrative: Approved in March 2023, the Education 2030 Strategy sets new standards and principles for pupils’ participation in decision making process in schools and education via school management committees and pupils councils. Thus, UNICEF supported development of the new Regulations for Establishment and Management of Pupils Councils that were approved by MER (Ministry of Education and Research) in September 2023. New provisions mandate schools to allocated office spaces for pupils’ councils, funds and resources and additional training of teachers on children participation and engagement. To achieve that, UNICEF contributed to the development of the National Grant Program for strengthening pupils' councils in all schools and TVET (Technical and Vocational Education and Training) institutions.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2021) 4.3 Education system has better capacities to deliver quality and inclusive education to all children and youth and address discrimination
Sub-Output: Build advocacy participatory platform for increasing support for comprehensive sexuality education
Description: Continue building advocacy participatory platform for increasing support for comprehensive sexual and reproductive health education and services for young people, with a focus on 5 districts of the country: Cahul, Ungheni, Rezina, Falesti, and Orhei. So far 40 communities/schools from these districts have been engaged (since 2018).
Implementation partners: LPAs, Schools
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNFPA continued advocating for mandatory (school-based) comprehensive sexuality education in Moldova both at the national level and with a focus on 5 districts where since 2018 the UNFPA in partnership with the Ministry of Education is implementing the Programme on promoting education for health.  

At the national level, three key results have been achieved, namely:
  1. Launching the international ”Out of School Comprehensive Sexuality Education" Guidance, which is now available in Romanian is already applied by professionals to develop the programs targeting specific groups like young people with disabilities, etc. https://moldova.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/pub-pdf/ghid_educatia_sexuala_comprehensiva_extrascolara_unfpa_romanian.pdf
  2. The 3rd Annual National Conference on Health Education ”Strengthening the school environment for healthy and safe development of students in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic” was successfully conducted online in collaboration with NGO "Health for Youth" and in partnership with the Ministry of Education and Research and Ministry of Health. 1700 participants were registered at the Conference, and a total of more than 16,000 views were accumulated on social networks.
 3. UNFPA conducted the assessment of the school-based mandatory curricula to assess the comprehensiveness of sexuality education, applying international methodology developed by UNESCO (SERAT tool). The results will be publicly presented in early 2022 and will guide further interventions at the national level to advance the quality and impact of CSE on young people's sexual and reproductive health behaviors.
4. Over 598 000 young people and adults were informed about the “Health Education” course through social media by diverse advocacy and informative materials and videos developed.  

However, to increase advocacy for CSE at the local level, the following key results were achieved in 5 targeted districts (Cahul, Orhei, Rezina, Falesti and Unghnei):
 1. Five new communities joined the UNFPA Programme, as result, since 2018, 45 communities with advocacy groups (including school representatives, young people, parents, and religious leaders) supporting adolescents and youth sexual and reproductive health and rights and advocate for mandatory health education course which includes comprehensive sexuality education. 
2. 618 new key actors in 5 targeted districts (parents, teachers, young people, etc.) are aware of youth SRHR including the right to CSE/HE, after 10 Let’s Talk events. Since 2018 in total 9816 people/stakeholders have been reached. 
3. Ten local initiatives that promote health education and a healthy environment in schools were supported by UNFPA.

The main partner of UNFPA for raising awareness at the national level and advocacy platform at the local level is the Youth Media Center.

2022 Narrative: In support to the education sector for quality health education in schools, with UNFPA’s support the following results have been achieved in 2022:The “Biology” module on health education and handbook for teachers developed with UNFPA support were translated into Russian.Elements of comprehensive sexuality education were integrated into the continuous training program for Biology teachers of the Tiraspol Pedagogical University, 185 teachers trained.The curriculum of the ‘Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle’ course in VET was revised, handbook for teachers developed. 12 Vocational schools and 90 schools from general education were equipped with handbooks for teachers and interactive learning materials for students (puzzles, board games, etc.) developed by UNFPA.  5 schools organized healthy and safe spaces for pupils based on small grants received from UNFPA.

Description:
Support  women and girls, with focus on the women and girls from excluded groups, to pursue STEM/ICT-related education and jobs, and to launch start innovative tech start-ups.
UNW partner - SEED Forum Moldova

9 women received support and access to Women Hub services in Chisinau for a period of 6 months, free of cost, specifically with access to fully equipped workplace, trainings and networking events.
20 community driven initiatives organized in Chisinau, Balti and Comrat for over 200 women and girls interested in STEM, including 2 informative and networking events for girls and women, 3 career orientation sessions, 2 rounds of digital connections UA - MD bringing together women and girls from Moldova and refugees from Ukraine, 3 idea Hackathons of innovative ideas in the field of Social and Green Entrepreneurship were organized in Chisinau iHub and 2 in the regions Comrat and Balti
- 10 Social Breakfasts within the Women Hub in Chisinau and Comrat were we socialized with the women who are residents in iHUB through the project and outside for knowledge sharing, networking and exchange /of information and opportunities.
Additionally 3 days business camp was organized during the autumn holidays within Tekwill Comrat Center with the participation of 30 high school students.
2 Women Hubs created and equipped  in Balti & Comrat to support girls and women in their STEM careers and helping them acquire the necessary skills to work in this field.
2 Women in Online Work (WoW) programs developed and delivered for 200 women from the Balti and Comrat region, offering the participants not only necessary technical skills for job, but also building confidence and support starting from curriculum vitae evaluation, portfolio building, and online platforms for freelancers’ registration. WoW included a 3 months training and skills development program in 4 directions-  Graphic Design, Web Design, Software Testing, Social Media Marketing.
Together with the Tech Women Moldova organization and with the support of partners, 2 regional the Tech Women Conference were held in Comrat and Balti during October month. On 15 October Tech Women Summit 2022 was organized, a one-day event held for women who are already in the IT industry or who want to get there, such as students, recent graduates, or women willing to make a career shift.
Implementation partners: Moldova, Seed Forum Moldova

2021 Narrative: During 2021, UNICEF provided technical expertise and financial support to both central and municipal capacity development in integrated programming with a focus on education response to COVID-19. Support aimed to bridge the gap between central level policy development and implementation in selected municipalities. UNICEF provided technical and financial support to facilitate the process of safe school reopening through the revision of the Guidelines and the provision of hygiene supplies. In addition, the development and integration of Learning Passport into the shkollat.org learning platform and access to learning content for children and adolescents was supported. UNICEF was a frontrunner office for the early Kosovo-wide launch of the Learning Passport/shkollat.org platform, partnering with UNICEF Regional Office for Europe and Central Asia and UNICEF Headquarters, Global CT (local private IT company), Microsoft local and regional Office to access technology expertise for the development of the learning platform and to leverage resources for its implementation. UNICEF also supported the Ministry of Education, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI) to develop schoolteachers’ IT skills and competencies to facilitate remote learning. Lastly, UNICEF also provided technical and financial support to MESTI to start integrating skills-building programmes for adolescents in upper-secondary schools as part of core subjects teaching methodology.

2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to partner with the Ministry of Education (MOE) and other national stakeholders in advancing 21st century skills. Special focus was on integrating social-emotional skills into the common secondary and higher vocational education.The Universal 21st Century Skills Concept was developed by experts from leading national institutions in cooperation with international experts. Joint work allowed to align the Concept with international guidelines and better define the strategic directions, mechanisms, and conditions for the formation of universal competencies of children and young people at different levels of education. The Concept embraced the general framework of the universal 21st century competencies developed within Belarus educational system, with a particular focus on social-emotional skills (SES). Based on the Concept, an Action Plan to build SES in Children and Young People for 2023-2026 was drafted. The Action Plan clearly defined the main interventions and implementing partners for each block and was submitted to the MOE for endorsement.International expertise was highly appreciated by the National Institute of Education (NIE) and the Republican Institute of Professional Education (RIPE) during development of the SES ME tool comprising 25 criteria and 94 indicators to measure 3 main SES components: emotional regulation, communication, and cooperation. The ME tool was co-created with adolescents from technical vocational colleges who provided recommendations and feedback. The tool will be piloted in 2024.To ensure the quality and sustainability of the SES integration in the education process the SES normative framework was supplemented by development of an in-service training programme for general secondary and technical vocational education teachers and methodological recommendations for different groups (e.g. teachers, administrations, parents) on how to integrate SES in the education process in schools and colleges.The in-service training programme for pedagogues was complemented with a curriculum for an elective courses on advancement of social-emotional skills among 3-4th and 6th-7th grade students and trainer guide developed by the NIE. The programme for pedagogues and the curriculum for school students will be piloted in 2024.

Contributing partners: European Union, Global Thematic - WASH, Government of the Republic of Korea, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.

Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: Preschool enrolment rates have improved reaching 78% (virtually equal between boys and girls) according to National Statistical Office estimates. The number of Roma children attending preschool education increased by 11%, although still not at satisfactory level. The percentage of children with disabilities attending preschool education increased by only 0.6%. In cooperation with Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation, the learning platform ‘Digital school’ continued to expand. Currently over 119 courses with 635 lessons were available to children, parents and professionals by the end of 2023. Topics include interactive activities for children; support to children with disabilities, adaption to preschool environment, mental health, child development and other. During 2023, the "Digital school" was used by 20% of all preschool teachers. Support was also provided to Ukrainian children, who are attending preschool education. Focus of the support was on the adaptation to kindergarten, acceptance of daily routines as well as socialization with peers.
2024 Narrative: Through the programme supported by EU,  60 preschool staff in 12 municipalities with the largest Roma population were trained to provide quality support to Roma children. Children with disabilities in preschool education and first cycle of education were supported through multiple initiatives: the Special Olympics programme "Young Athletes" was expanded to 17 (out of 21) preschool institutions in Montenegro; all preschools in Montenegro were equipped with tablets, with over 230 children with disabilities benefitting from the use of the C-board application.   Following long and intensive advocacy, regulations were changed to increase the number of Roma mediators in schools and preschools and the issue of school transportation for Roma children was resolved.

Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion

Sub-Output: Support to Ministry of Education, Science, and Innovation, other central institutions and schools, to implement strategic interventions at improving access, quality and inclusiveness of education, including by integration of skills development programmes, in line with the Education Reform Strategy (2025 – 2035) and other relevant policy frameworks
Description: Support to design, implementation, and monitoring of programmatic interventions aimed at improving the quality and inclusiveness of education, with particular focus on children from most vulnerable groups in ECE and the fist cycle of elementary school; also, support to implementation of skills development program, with focus on social and emotional development of children and adolescents to improve their resilience
Contributing partners: European Union, Global Thematic - WASH, Government of the Republic of Korea, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: In line with the UNICEF Gender Action Plan 2022-2025, the strategy will contribute to develop a gender-responsive education system, especially when it comes to equitable access to schooling, STEM and digital skills for adolescent girls.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The suboutput addresses  the recommendations of the Committee on the Rights of the Child such as : Improve the quality of education at all levels by providing quality  training for teachers and ensuring that school curriculums and pedagogical methods  are relevant to children’s contexts and future needs, promote the enjoyment of their  human rights, and enable them to express their views freely and have them taken into  account; (c) Allocate sufficient human, technical and financial resources for the  development and expansion of preschool education for all children, including those in  rural areas.
2023 Narrative: With support of UNICEF, the Ministry of Education is implementing several major initiatives as a follow up to the recommendations of the Education Sector Analysis.First and foremost, the Ministry of Education has allocated funds and embarked on the process of conducting a comprehensive school infrastructure assessment, for the purpose on creating evidence on the needs and ensuring quality and timely investment in school infrastructure.As importantly, and based on the Education Sector Analysis recommendations, the Ministry of Education has requested - and been approved through the Mid-Term Expenditure Framework - increased financing for three priority areas: teacher training, digitalization, and school construction.Finally, in cooperation with the Bureau for Education, a skills building initiative is being implemented, aiming at increasing the number of schools and teachers implementing the Program for Developing the Social and Emotional Skills of Students, as a powerful mechanism for prevention of violence and building social cohesion. As part of the project, a training of trainers workshop was organized to consolidate the implementation of the program and ensure its more effective expansion. The social and emotional learning programme was consolidated, by expanding the pool of trainers and by focusing on the schools at highest risk of peer violence. By the end of 2023, over 34,000 children in 110 primary and secondary schools have benefitted from the programme. UNICEF supported the Institute for Public Health to finalize and present a comprehensive situation analysis of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in schools, covering most schools in the country, followed by the implementation of a concrete action plan and guidance for improvements in the area of WASH planning and budgeting, as well as capacity building of school staff and children, with a specific focus on menstrual hygiene management and WASH accessibility for children with disabilities. With this support, more than 60 schools were reached with hygiene supplies and information materials. A new challenge that schools have been faced with mostly due to the Ukraine refugee crisis is how to accommodate and provide quality support to the increasing number of children from other countries. In several municipalities the number of children, non-speakers of Montenegrin, is reaching almost 30 per cent of the whole primary school population. In relation to the humanitarian response to the refugee influx from Ukraine, 625 Ukrainian children in preschools and schools were provided with support for learning through formal and non-formal education.
2024 Narrative: A set of comprehensive programmatic interventions have been initiated to improve access, quality, and equity of education. Following long and intensive advocacy, regulations were changed to increase the number of Roma mediators in schools and preschools and the issue of school transportation for Roma children was resolved. In addition, 60 preschool staff in 12 municipalities with the largest Roma population were trained to provide quality support to Roma children. Children with disabilities in preschool education and first cycle of education were supported through multiple initiatives: the Special Olympics programme "Young Athletes" was expanded to 17 (out of 21) preschool institutions in Montenegro; all preschools in Montenegro were equipped with tablets, with over 230 children with disabilities benefitting from the use of the C-board application. The national Digital School Platform has 27.918 active users, with 53 new courses developed in 2024. Furthermore, UNICEF supported establishment of the EdTech hubs and related programme across twelve schools in the north of the country, reaching 6,000 students. Furthermore, the social and emotional learning program was further expanded to 114 schools, reaching almost 46,000 children.To improve the quality of education and care for Roma children in preschools, outreach visits to Roma settlements were organized and a set of trainings launched for preschool and primary school teachers in cooperation with the Ministry of Education, Science, and Innovation. By the end of the first quarter 2025, at least 90 preschool staff will have improved their capacity to support Roma children, and at least 700 teachers will be trained to use the MEIS based application for Early Identification of Children at Risk of Dropping-Out, as well as for the use of digital technologies in quality and inclusive manner.Also, in cooperation with the Bureau for Education, comprehensive activities are currently being implemented to improve the quality of educational services for children with disabilities in preschools and the first three grades of primary education. By June 2025, at least 300 teachers and 300 novice teachers will receive training on the use of inclusive teaching methods in everyday practice, at least 160 school support staff will have the capacity to develop quality didactive materials, and at least 125 form teachers will be trained to use the enhanced methodology for developing basic literacy skills to children aged 6-9.Finally, in regard of the support to students to develop social and emotional skills, by June 2025 additional 150 teachers will have been trained to implement the SE Skills Program in seven selected municipalites.Compliant with the assumed obligations from the National Gender Equality Strategy 2021–2025, UNICEF joined the OSCE to support the Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation in carrying out an analysis of subject curricula and textbooks in primary education to assess the extent to which they perpetuate gender stereotypes, and to formulate recommendations towards mainstreaming gender equality in the curricula and textbooks which are included in the draft Education Reform Strategy 2025–2035.

2022 Narrative: Needs of skills development in agriculture and irrigation sectors were assessed and its awareness was increased among the policy makers
2023 Narrative: The quality of TVET provision was enhanced through the development of National Occupational Standards (NOS) and Competency-Based Curriculum (CBC) for six selected occupations in the agriculture and irrigation sectors. This was developed by international and local experts through an extensive and consultative process, following the methodology and experience of New Zealand, Australia and the UK, and validated by the relevant line ministries. A series of capacity-building workshops were provided for the teachers and master-teachers of the pilot technicums, Sector Skills Councils and Ministry staff on how to develop and deliver competency-based education and assessment.

Strategic priority: Inclusive human capital development leading to health, well-being and resilient prosperity
Outcome: Outcome 3. By 2025, youth, women and vulnerable groups benefit from improved access to livelihoods, decent work and expanded opportunities generated by inclusive and equitable economic growth.
Output: Output 3.1. Sub-Output: Strengthened capacities of national institutions and educational stakeholders to design and implement digital skills development programmes for women and girls, PWD to ensure inclusive participation in the digital development
Description: Capacity-building and technical assistance in the development of digital skills curricular, disabled-accessible and gender-sensitive training materials and methodologies, creation of inclusive and accessible learning environment.
Contributing partners: International Telecommunication Union, Uzbekistan IT Park
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan IT Park, Uzbekistan Ministry of Digital Technologies, ZTE Corporation
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4.2 Output 4.2. By 2025, Government and other educational stakeholders have increased capacity to provide access to equitable, inclusive, safe and quality education at all levels and promote lifelong learning in an integrated manner, including quality professional development system and decent work environment for education sector employees
LNOB groups targeted: Youth, Persons With Disabilities, Other, Women & Girls
2021 Narrative: (1) Regional baseline assessment on digital accessibility is conducted and published (https://www.itu.int/pub/D-PHCB-ICT_ACCESS_CIS.01-2021); online training courses on web-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/web-accessibility-cornerstone-digital-societyon-line-self-paced-training-0) and ICT-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/ict-accessibility-key-inclusive-communication-line-self-paced-training) are translated into Russian. The principles of the accessible web resources design are localized in Uzbekistan by means of the development of “Recommendations for ensuring the accessibility of web content" (jointly with “IT-Academy" LLC of Uzbekistan and the Association of Disabled Persons of Uzbekistan). These Recommendations can be used to improve the accessibility of websites of government agencies, businesses, social services, universities and other organizations and are aimed at creating inclusiveness of web content for a wide range of users.(2) A training center for children with hearing imparities is inaugurated in Tashkent city at the IT Park premises. Three groups of students, consisting of 24 people aged 13 to 19 years old, underwent training on a graphic design using Photoshop and Corel Draw; the basics of computer literacy and web technologies in two stages, including courses on Microsoft Office and Scratch language programming; and HTML and CSS. The Center is equipped by international standards and has all the necessary audio equipment for each child, taking into account his individual needs. Each teacher was individually trained in sound operation and tuning. Setting up the headphones, children don`t hear interference in the sound, which makes learning possible, accessible, and convenient. The classrooms were also equipped with laptops for each student and teacher, and interactive touch panels were installed for a visual demonstration of the teacher`s materials. The experts have created a special methodological base in Russian and Uzbek languages for the "graphic design" and "the basics of computer literacy and web technologies" courses. These manuals contain a detailed description of each topic, illustrations, and all the necessary terminology that students need.(3) Digital skills trainings for women from the Urgench region. 350 young women from the Urgench region are trained in digital literacy, coding, and graphic design. Digital skills obtained as a result of the training are to enable women and girls to get successfully employed, start their own business, or continue education: for this purpose, the students were acquainted with different online learning platforms. Depending on the level of their preparedness, the applicants were able to register for courses of 1st, 2nd, or 3rd levels: on computer literacy, programming, or graphic design accordingly. The course on computer literacy attracted the maximum number of participants. Courses on programming and graphic design were meant as a kind of basis for further self-tuition or professional education.(4) A digital skills center for women and youth in Tashkent city. Renovation of the center's facility (repurposing of an old PBX exchange) is completed. However, the delivery of the equipment is pending. Three training courses (materials, tutorials for educators) were developed. 50 women underwent training.(5) Awareness raising and advocacy campaign on girls and women enrolment into STEM education. The 10th Anniversary of Girls in ICT Day was celebrated in 2021. This year-long celebration took the form of 10 “moments” – events and activities focusing on the relevant stakeholders, topics, and initiatives that propel the mission of Girls in ICT. The 10 Moments series has been designed with three goals in mind: Build ​momentum and awareness about the importance of encouraging girls in STEM Engage key stakeholders and communities ​Provide an inclusive platform to discuss the best ways to encourage girls to pursue STEM careers
2022 Narrative: (1) Digital skills center for women and youth in Tashkent city is inaugurated in April 2022. 73 women completed in-depth training in frontend and backend development, Android programming and other ICT subjects.(2) Digital skills center for authists. Ongoing negotiations with the national partners.(3) Awareness raising and advocacy campaign on girls and women enrolment into STEM education.
2023 Narrative: ITU cоducted a regional study entitled 'Methodological bases for digital upskilliing of people with disabilities' aimedd at raising awareness on the matter of digital inclusion of people with disabilities, facilitating development of national programms/trainings for digital upskilling of people with disabilities, and promoting further establishment of a network of training centres for persons with disabilities The study contains:an overview of the existing educational programs on digital upskilling, relevant methods and assistive technologies;an anlysis of access to education for different categories of people with disabilities;an overview of public and private programmes to facilitate employment of persons with disabilities;list of professions available for employment of various categories of persons with digital disabilities;recommendations for decision-makers, educational institutions and private sector on digital upskilling of people with disabilities to ensure their proper digital citizenship and employment.9 countries of the CIS Region, including Uzbekistan, took part in the research.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate action, natural resources and disaster risk management
Outcome: Outcome 3: Healthy Environment
Output: Output 3.1 Low-emissions development and climate change resilience
Sub-Output: Guiding education documents and policies incorporate contemporary and scientifically proven approaches to environment and climate change education
Description: Support the revision of curricula in primary education to incorporate a developmental approach in delivering scientifically accurate and contemporary knowledge on climate change and environment.
Contributing partners: Government of Sweden, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,12.8 By 2030, ensure that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for sustainable development and lifestyles in harmony with nature.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 12 Responsible Consumption and Production
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: With funding from the Swedish International Development Agency, UNICEF put an increased focus on environment and climate change education. New partnerships were established with government and Civil society organizations, and environment and climate change content was streamlined in the new curricula for grades 1 and 4.
2022 Narrative: UNICEF in partnership with the Bureau for development of education (BDE), funded by Sweden, contributed with inputs in the natural sciences curricula development for the 2nd and 5th grade in primary education. Additionally, UNICEF in partnership with the BDE developed teaching materials for climate change and environment education with experiential learning activities for preschool (kindergartens) and primary education. The teaching materials, accompanied with videos, serve the teachers and educators for advancing the climate and environment education in kindergartens and schools.
2023 Narrative: The establishment of the Science Learning Network showed strong potential to also accelerate the practical collaboration between governmental and science institutions with environment CSOs. Within the reporting period the six institutions comprising the SLN developed a joint educational programme aligned with curricula and adopted by the Bureau for the Development of Education. In this process the SLN members, education and environment authorities, and environmental CSOs, formed strong partnerships and several other science institutions expressed interest to join the network, namely the remaining three national parks, and the Bio Hacking laboratory in Skopje. UNICEF also maintained regular meetings of the intersectoral steering committee tasked to oversee the entire Climate Change Education portfolio. This committee includes members of the Ministries of Education and Science, Labour and Social Policy, and Environment and Physical Planning. These partnerships extended on a technical level with specific units such as the Air Quality unit of the MoEPP, which is extremely beneficial for the sub-regional programme on Air Quality.
2024 Narrative: In 2024 with UNICEF support seven new curricula for elective subjects were developed and published by the Bureau for the Development of Education. UNICEF's supported creation of a protocol for the operation of schools during heat waves and it has already been adopted by the Government. Recognizing the critical role of environmental sustainability and climate change in shaping future generations, UNICEF facilitated the integration of green skills into the VET curricula across various sectors. This initiative was complemented by capacity development for VET teachers, enabling them to effectively teach the new curricula and promote the development of green skills among students.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate action, natural resources and disaster risk management
Outcome: Outcome 3: Healthy Environment
Output: Output 3.1 Low-emissions development and climate change resilience
Sub-Output: Teachers and pre-school educators have improved capacities in environment and climate change education
Description: Create new professional development opportunities for teachers in the area of climate change and environmental education.
Contributing partners: Government of Sweden, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,12.8 By 2030, ensure that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for sustainable development and lifestyles in harmony with nature.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 12 Responsible Consumption and Production, 13 Climate Action
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: To support teacher capacities, over 60 pre-primary and primary school teachers received a training programme on experiential learning and integration of environmental concepts in teaching, and will be disseminating it through the professional learning communities.
2022 Narrative: In partnership with the Bureau for the development of the Education and the relevant CSOs, funded by Sweden, 113 teachers from 101 schools across the country were trained on integrating experiential learning activities for climate change and environment in preschool and primary education. Over 10,000 children (8% of total children in that age range) experienced these activities guided by the teachers. A handbook with the experiential learning activities for environment and climate change for preschool and primary education was developed and adapted for children with disabilities (hearing and visual impairments, and developmental delays). It was also noted that children with disabilities were actively involved in the experiments thus the experiential learning also contributes to the inclusivity agenda.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF has supported the development of education documents and policies that now incorporate contemporary and scientifically proven approaches to education about environmental impact and climate change. We now have new curricula and textbooks, and comprehensive and cohesive learning standards that horizontally integrate environment and climate change education across different disciplines. Within the reporting period we have also worked to provide teachers with the professional development opportunities that improve their capacities in environmental education implementing quality pre-school and primary school teaching. As a result, nearly 6000 teachers were directly supported with practical tools, guides, trainings and educational resources that facilitate their practical work.UNICEF also supported the development of over 200 high quality resources for students and teachers, including videos, virtual experiments, educational activities, and digital games. All of these resources were tested among teachers as part of 93 professional learning communities. As a result, in the reporting period, thousands of practical activities and experiments were organized across the country, allowing 35.722 children from kindergartens and primary schools to understand complex environment and climate-related concepts through interesting hands-on activities tailored to their age.30 teachers from preschool and 91 teachers from primary school education attended intensive in-person trainings on how to teach and integrate environment and climate change education in their classes using experiential learning (experiments and practical activities). Additional 53 teachers were engaged in a pilot testing and workshop to verify the experiments and activities. 93 teachers who the attended intensive in-person trainings actively organized and delivered peer learning sessions (Professional Learning Communities), reaching at least 1038 colleagues. Through online courses – Eduino webinars a total of 4647 were trained on 1) problem solving methodology in teaching climate change; and 2) using the Eduino Virtual Laboratory in their practice. To further support the use and integration of the educational resources mentioned above, 3 Teacher guides on experiential learning – with activity guides were developed, as were 15 digital teacher guides for experiments developed and uploaded on Eduino Virtual Laboratory. Finally, 60 new classroom scenarios (part of the 3rd teacher guide are in development). These resources are in use by the teachers that attended the trainings and peer disseminations but will still need to be promoted and disseminated to a wider audience.

Contributing partners: Global Thematic Funding, Government of Sweden
Implementation partners: North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, North Macedonia Ministry of Labour and Social Policy, North Macedonia National Park Galichica
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,12.8 By 2030, ensure that people everywhere have the relevant information and awareness for sustainable development and lifestyles in harmony with nature.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: Backed by the government and partnerships with young people and the office of the President of North Macedonia the new climate change programme of the UNICEF CO was propelled forward in less than 10 months. By November a Youth Climate Declaration developed by young people, was backed by the President of the country and presented at the UN Climate Change Conference in Glasgow.
2022 Narrative: UNICEF in partnership with the CSO "Macedonian Ecological Society" developed a framework for the network of science centres to support the implementation of science curricula in the education system based on experiential learning. The science centres that were involved in the developing of the framework were: Hydrobiological Institute - Ohrid, Natural History Museum - Skopje, National Park Galichica, Education Centre "Negrevo in Pehcevo, National Technics - Skopje, Botanical Garden Natural Sciences Faculty - Skopje.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued supporting experiential learning by creating professional development opportunities for teachers, developing high-quality teaching and learning resources and increasing the quantity and quality of extracurricular, experiential learning and community engagement opportunities. To date, the programme reached close to 6000 teachers, developed hundreds of high-quality resources – all in close collaboration with the BDE, the Vocational Education and Training Center and the State Education Inspectorate. In 2023 the six members of the Science Learning Network (SLN) were fully equipped and immediately started providing extracurricular experiential learning opportunities for students. The SLN’s joint educational programme, aligned with curricula and verified by the BDE, reached 1159 students from across the country.Building onto the success of the programme for environment and climate change education, in late 2023 UNICEF established a partnership with the Vocational Training and Education Centre (VETC), initiating a greening revision of VET curricula, to support green skills development in students. The revision is being conducted in cooperation and with co-funding from the Swiss Development Organization ‘Helvetas’.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF continued supporting experiential learning by creating professional development opportunities for teachers, developing high-quality teaching and learning resources and increasing the quantity and quality of extracurricular, experiential learning and community engagement opportunities. To date, the programme reached close to 6000 teachers, developed hundreds of high-quality resources – all in close collaboration with the BDE, the Vocational Education and Training Center and the State Education Inspectorate. In 2024 the Experiential Learning Network (ELN) was expanded with a new member (the BioHack Lab in Skopje) and continued providing extracurricular experiential learning opportunities for students. The ELN’s joint educational programme, aligned with curricula and verified by the BDE, reached over 4500 students from across the country.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Inclusive human capital development leading to health, well-being and resilient prosperity

Output: Output 3.1. By 2025, the capacities of national institutions and social partners are strengthened to design and implement effective and innovative Active Labour Market Policies, decent work and skills development programmes for the youth and adults (including NEET), women, informal workers, migrants, PWD to ensure inclusive and sustainable economic growth and reduced inequalities, including spacial and gender inequalities.
Sub-Output: Capacity of Government, CSOs and private sector is enhanced to equip young people with social, socio-emotional, employability, financial and entrepreneurship skills within the formal and non-formal education systems
Description:
Scale up social innovation and social entrepreneurship progamme UPSHIFT, 
Institutionalize socio-emotional skills programme and social, employability, financial literacy and entrepreneurship skills programme
Pilot digital chat-based skills-building programme FunDoo
Contributing partners: European Union, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, UN Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for the Aral Sea region in Uzbekistan , UNICEF Other Resources
Implementation partners: International Institute of Innovation in the Aral Sea Basin under the Presidetn of the Republic of Uzbekistan, Uzbekistan Agency for Youth Affairs, Uzbekistan Ministry of Employment and Poverty Reduction, Uzbekistan Ministry of Preschool and School Education

SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Republic of Karakalpakstan, Surkhandarya, Fergana, Kashkadarya, Andizhan, Samarkand, Uzbekistan, Navoi
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.1 Output 3.1. By 2025, the capacities of national institutions and social partners are strengthened to design and implement effective and innovative Active Labour Market Policies, decent work and skills development programmes for the youth and adults (including NEET), women, informal workers, migrants, PWD to ensure inclusive and sustainable economic growth and reduced inequalities, including spacial and gender inequalities.
2021 Narrative:
-37 school psychologists were trained to deliver BLS programme, 50 youth worker and teachers were trained in Human-Centered-Design methodology
- 1256 young people were equipped with social, socio-emotional, employability, STEM and entrepreneurial skills, including 858 adolescents through life skills programme, 188 girls through UniSat programme and 212 young people through social innovation programme UPSHIFT (ImkonLab)
- 32 youth-led solutions were supported with seed funding and mentoring
- 4 solutions - eco bags, bio gumus, English training center, peer-to-peer teaching on learning math and English - for school children grew into sustainable initiatives and enterprises
2022 Narrative: In 2022 1,568 young people (1,046 girls and 522 boys) were equipped with life, socio-emotional, entrepreneurship, digital and STEM skills through UNICEF supported programmes. To ensure higher sustainability UNICEF cooperated with the Ministry of Public Education and Ministry of Employment to integrate socio-emotional skills programme into curriculum of schools and employability, financial literacy and entrepreneurship skills programme into curriculum of training and re-training centers. Digital and STEM girls-targeted programmes not only equipped girls with skills, but also motivated to continue education and work in STEM sphere.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF cooperated with the Ministry of Employment and Poverty Reduction on the adaptation and institutionalization of the social, financial, employability and entrepreneurship skills-building programme into TVET (technical and vocational education and training) centers for unemployed youth. The programme has been piloted in TVET centers under the Ministry in two regions reaching 584 unemployed young people (442 girls and 142 boys) for further integration into the TVET curriculum.  In July 2023, UNICEF launched the chat-based learning platform FunDoo, through which 1,086 y.p. (517 girls, 569 boys) gained transferable skills. As of November, nine tasks for developing employability, leadership, efficiency, academic success and self-care skills were available. UNICEF cooperates with the Ministry of Digital Technologies and private sector to benefit more young people. Through UPSHIFT, UNICEF continues to empower youth (285 young people: 144 girls, 141 boys), including the most marginalized Afghan refugees (37 young people: 23 girls, 14 boys), to develop social innovation solutions.

Description: To continue support in reducing risks and enhancing preparedness for emergencies and humanitarian crisis by organization the school and community-level capacity strengthening interventions on  education, gender, water supply, sanitation and hygiene in emergencies; 2) Organiation of school, pre-school and community-based interventions integrating the key principles of Comprehensive School Safety and communies engagement;

2021 Narrative: UNICEF collaborated closely with MoE to adapt the education system and children to socio-economic and climate-change risks. 360 schools and 110 pre-schools were assessed for “school safety” and a database of the findings was developed and submitted to MoE for further evidence-based decision making.
2024 Narrative: The capacity development activities engaging the educational sector professionals across the country were conducted aiming to strengthen the knowledge and skills in Comprehensive school safety framework, Climate Change Adaptation  and Disaster Risk Reduction topics. Ministry of Education and the National Institute of Education with support of UNICEF continued upscaling the advinced interactive teaching and learning methodology in the primary and secondary shools across the country. Intergration of Methodological Manuals for teachers of primary and secondary education was scaled up to ensure that the Cliamte change adaptation and DRR topics are fully incorporated into the eduxcation system of the country. The school-based simulations on emergency evacuation, First Aid support and non-structural school safety were organized engaging adminsitration and teaching personnel, students from 18 target schools as well as the staff and volunteers of the NRCST and the representatives of local authorities countrywide.

QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Normative Support
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project underscores the pivotal role of gender equality in ensuring social cohesion. By actively empowering girls and boys, women and men, decision and opinion makers, the project is challenging the prevailing narratives of gender-based hate speech, violence, sexism and misogyny, and fosters girls’ and women’s significant contributions and participation in the civic and political spheres (output 2.3). By building the capacities of both women and men in key influential roles, including politicians, policymakers and opinion leaders, the project seeks to pave the way for more inclusive, gender-sensitive approaches, emphasizing safeguarding of progress in achieving gender equality and countering any gender equality backlash. The project approach mainstreams gender-quality principles, and all activities are based on gender-sensitive approaches.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: In terms of Human Rights Based approach, the focus of the initiative is not only to enable children to have access to school, but in the long-term to provide opportunities to have a quality curriculum and complete all years of schooling to fulfil their right to education. Crucial are teachers, school management and other staff, playing key roles in creating safe learning spaces, adapting curricula and providing support to marginalized students.   Education authorities are faced with a unique set of challenges in ensuring the continuity and quality of learning with ‘Leave no one behind’ principle.
