LNOB groups targeted: Peasants & Rural Workers, Women & Girls, Youth
2023 Narrative: The project implemented a number of gender related activities including a meeting on March 7, 2023:” The important role of women and girls in the fight against climate change”. The event provided a great opportunity to share innovative ideas and best practices in combating climate change and achieving green growth, raising awareness among young people about how gender equality and climate change intersect. Participants discussed gender equality and women’s empowerment in the context of climate change.The project together with the Nature Protection Society, Tebigy Kuwat, Eco-durmush and Ynanch Vepa NGOs, on the occasion of Desertification and Drought Day, June 17, 2023 launched a competition „HerLand, HerRights“ to draw the attention of society, including women aand girls to the environmental problems of desertification, depletion of soil fertility and land degradation leading to desertification and demonstrate how affected are women when land becomes degraded and water is scarce. On December 2, 2023, an Environmental Brain Ring among youth with focus on women was held in Dashoguz with the aim to recognize the critical importance of addressing waste disposal, recycling, air and water pollution, as well as other climate change issues, the organizers held an intellectual game to enhance awareness and knowledge among local youth. The focus was made on environmental issues related to the Aral crisis, climate change, protection and restoration of natural resources, biodiversity, and fostering active participation of youth in climate action.﻿Initial discussions on LDN methodology and Road map were held with key partners in the framework of the LDN working group on the basis of scientific-public council for combating desertification NGO Tebigy Kuwwat (April 06, 2023); and with local and national authorities and other key project partners within the LDN workshop (July 26,2023) In addition, the project provided support to ICSD in development of the following knowledge products related toLDN/SLM/Biodiversity which were distributed among key partners and other interested parties:1) Target Setting for Land Degradation Neutrality - Technical Guidance, UNCCD Platform – 2016 https://www.unccd.int/sites/default/files/2022-07/Turkmenistan_LDN%20TSP%20Final%20Report.pdf)2) A report on setting national targets for LDN in Turkmenistan, UNCCD platform;3) Introductory Statement on LDN (brief);4) A concept of updating the National Program to Combat Desertification, platform CACILM-II (https://turkmenportal.com/blog/39317/v-ashhabade-obsudili-obnovlenie-nacionalnogo-plana-deistvii-po-borbe-s-opustynivaniem )
2024 Narrative: Under the Conservation of Land Resources (Aral) project the following activities wer implemented:The project supported the national participation at the IFAS meeting in Kazakhstan (March 2024) as an incremental support to initiatives put forward by Turkmenistan to address the problems of the Aral Sea Basin. The project organised a Water Diplomacy seminar in Ashgabat (April 2024). The Water Diplomacy effort aims to foster a collaborative environment for sustainable water resource management, benefiting all participating countries, including Turkmenistan. The project's incremental role in regional Water Diplomacy is to provide a platform for regional cooperation and the development of coordinated strategies to address the complex water issues in Central Asia, as well as to inform the national position supporting negotiations on water resource allocation in the region.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)
Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
Output: Critical ecosystems are better protected throughout the country, and the rational and sustainable use of natural resources, including water and land, is improved through gender-responsive, participatory and conflict-sensitive systems at all levels
Sub-Output: Enhanced responses to local and national water management challenges through improved water education, scientific research and awareness raising
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: Core Funding, The Global Environment Facility
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Academia, Kyrgyz Ministry of Natural Resources, Ecology and Technical Supervision
SDG Targets: 6.a By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacitybuilding support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.,6.5 By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The activity provides limited contribution to gender equality, women and girls empowerment: overall, the gender considerations are kept in mind while planning the activities under this sub-output, and the gender participation is monitored in all activities under this sub-output. While some consideration is being given to gender mainstreaming, the contribution to gender equality and the empowerment of women is limited to the overall objectives of the initiative and collection of some sex-disaggregated data. No gender equality results are anticipated.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: - Diagnostic Analysis of the cryosphere's current condition, focusing on its influence on water resources, has been launched. This report assembles current knowledge of observed and predicted climate change, its impact on the cryosphere in Central Asia's and on the crucial role of snow, glacier, and permafrost on water dynamics. Detailed analyses of climate and cryospheric changes inthe region reveal region-specific impacts on water resources, necessitating continuous monitoring, research, as well as cross-boundary collaboration efforts. With this report, we aim to identify current knowledge gaps and formulate strategies to improve the monitoring and research on the climate-cryosphere-water nexus;- A regional launch event (online) of the UN World Water Development Report’s 2023 edition, organized by the UNESCO Almaty Office for Central Asia, contributed to raised awareness of representatives of academia, government authorities, and NGOs from Kyrgyzstan on water cooperation aspects. -	In cooperation with the International Center for Water Resources and Global Change, UNESCO organized several sub-regional events: 1) Seminar on Climate Change and Glaciers – Significance and Impact on Water Resources; 2) 3rd workshop on “Data and Information for Integrated Urban Water Management”, to which experts from Kyrgyzstan contributed, sharing their country’s experience and case studies. The events facilitated exchange and dialogue among the Central Asian experts on the issues of climate change and its impact on water resources.
2024 Narrative: •	A policy brief on the current state of cryosphere and its impact on water availability in Central Asia was developed to inform policy- and decision-makers about the effects of climate change on the cryosphere and the critical role of monitoring in supporting effective water management.•	Snow depth monitoring with UAV conducted in selected catchments across Kyrgyzstan, capturing the climatic variability and its effects on water availability. •	In cooperation with Swiss development projects, hydrological discharge monitoring equipment was installed on the glaciers Batysh Sook, No 354, Abramov, and Golubin glaciers.•	A subregional summer school on hydrological modelling was organized in Bishkek with 3 people (incl. 1 woman) from Kyrgyzstan trained.•	A real-time basin-scale snow water resources model covering the Amudarya and Syrdarya basins was created. The generated snow water equivalent maps will be used as predictors in updated hydrological forecasting procedures in the region.

2023 Narrative: The partnership with the Agency for Youth and Sports advanced the support for municipal youth councils. 105 young people and representatives from three municipalities worked jointly to design and implement sustainable policies and programmes at the local level. The young people developed detailed (costed) workplans for improving the air quality in their municipality. These solutions were presented to municipal representatives and is expected that will be reviewed at subsequent municipal council sessions.UNICEF also piloted new programmes for youth participation and skills building. Through the Air Care Ambassadors programme, 30 young people developed 67 media products (short documentaries, photographs, etc.). These young people also sent out 16 formal requests on air quality to respective policymakers.Building onto the success of the programme for environment and climate change education, in late 2023 UNICEF established a partnership with the Vocational Training and Education Centre (VETC), initiating a greening revision of VET curricula, to support green skills development in students. The revision is being conducted in cooperation and with co-funding from the Swiss Development Organization ‘Helvetas’.
2024 Narrative: Children and adolescents also engaged decision makers on a local and national level. Through the Air Quality Advocacy programme these young advocates worked in municipalities to formulate specific asks and submit them for official review with the support of Local Youth Councils. Over 250 young people participated in multiple workshops and camps.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2025, all people without discrimination benefit from a sustainable, inclusive and resilient economy in Georgia
Output: 3.3. Increased productive employment, decent work, skills development and effective national social protection for all
Sub-Output: Rural women and men benefit from effective agricutlure vocational education, training and extension systems
Description: Support to modernization of VET and Extension System related to agriculture of Georgia
Contributing partners: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sports of Georgia, Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture of Georgia
SDG Targets: 4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,8.6 By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Guria, Imereti, Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti, Samtskhe-Javakheti, Autonomous Republic of Adjara, Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti, Georgia
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.3 3.3. Increased productive employment, decent work, skills development and effective national social protection for all
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2021 Narrative:
UNDP, under auspices of the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), contributed to establishing Swiss Agricultural School Caucasus (SASC) in Dmanisi, Kvemo Kartli, representing an unprecedented nonprofit private initiative in the field of agricultural VET in Georgia replicating model of the most successful agricultural school in Switzerland – Plantahof. In 2021  UNDP continued to support development of the institution and assist SASC with the swiss knowledge transfer activities for implementing the dual model aiming to transform existing supply-driven VET system towards a demand-led model to meet industry needs for the skilled workforce. 

UNDP VET project continues active partnership and collaboration with the governmental institutions and key stakeholders of vocational education in Georgia to support development of extension services for farmers. In 2021, UNDP was engaged in process of elaboration the New Extension Strategy of Ministry of Environmental protection and Agriculture of Georgia (MEPA) reassuring once more the commitment to promote quality of extension services to improve standards and mechanisms of knowledge dissemination accessible for small farmers. In the same vein UNDP contributed to launching digital extension platform http://regions.mepa.gov.ge in 4 regions for further national upscale, which would potentially reach 40% of farmers countrywide. This platform will contribute to increasing the volume and quality of the extension service provided in the regions, as farmers’ queries will be directed to relevant specialized government agencies able to provide qualified advice. In parallel UNDP supported establishing Farmers’ Extension Boards countrywide. By end of  2021, 21 operations Farmers Extension Boards are in place and functioning, including 3 new extension boards in Guria region that has been recently added to the pilot scheme. 

Under `VET College Development` component UNDP supported elaboration and formalization of 21 regulatory documents and authorized corporate standards for 8 VET-profile colleges. Additionally, 5 VET colleges were supported to elaborate their strategic documents.

UNDP VET project continues strengthening private sector service providers and educational opportunities for farmers.  Similar to other private companies and NGOs (Farmers school, Tabco, Akhazintercont, etc.) supported earlier, the newly established NGO `Qvevris Mze` was supported in elaborating educational training courses (STT) in winemaking using `Kvevri technology` in Kakheti region. 42 private companies joined PPP, including the `Work Based Learning` (WBL) scheme and are involved in the implementation process

As a supplementary contribution to improvement of livelihood of rural population, VET project supported acquisition and installation of 3 meteorological stations in 3 regions (Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti, Racha-Lechkhumi and Samtskhe-Javakheti regions). Access to more on-spot and precise meteorological data and prognosis will significantly improve farmers’ efficiency to plan and conduct agricultural activities as well as informational exchange and communication among the local agri-communities.

Finally, raising awareness of wider population on environment and climate smart (green) agriculture was one of the direction of UNDP’s work in 2021. UNDP assisted Environmental Information and Education Centre` in elaboration of comprehensive educational module on `climate-smart agriculture`, which is designed for all agri-profile colleges and institutions at national level. In its efforts to popularize agriculture among schoolchildren children and youth, UNDP supported launching of `Agri-Clubs in 4 municipal schools of Racha-Lechkhumi region, which will provide children with general agricultural education and practical knowledge of gardening and other agri-fields from local farmers and agri-experts.
2022 Narrative: ®   The work on the new VET strategy 2021-2025 and its action plan development has been commenced in cooperation with the MoES. The VET Project supported the strategy development process together with other donors. Furthermore, the Project considered the priority areas of the new VET Strategy through planning the intervention areas for the next phase of VET Project. ®    UNDP continues its contributions to the working group on the new Extension Strategy Development 2021-2026 which is facilitated by the EU/FAO. The primary goal of the strategy is to improve the competitiveness of the agriculture sector in Georgia by delivering quality advisory services to farmers using modern digital and distance tools. This is to be achieved by strengthening RDA’s existing 54 regional and municipal Information and Consultation Centres (ICCs) throughout Georgia, into a more coherent, results-oriented, farmer demand-driven national extension service. ®   VET Project facilitated introduction of the FAO’s Farmer Field School approach to the Regional Farmers’ Board in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti region to identify needs and possibilities of implementation of joint farmer-oriented projects supporting sustainable agriculture in the region. Information and ideas of cross-team collaboration, available database and follow-up coordination have been discussed in the initial meeting steered by the Project’s regional partner.®   UNDP’s efforts for transforming VET governance system produced the following results: ®   Through the support to new VET framework implementation support activities, new authorization standards are in place and around,10 VET providers authorized in accordance with the requirements of the new regulations. ®   Under the College Development Fund facility, 7 new grant projects were approved and implemented. Overall, 48 private public partnerships formed exceeding the value of GEL 2,1 million and reaching 650 beneficiaries across the country via creating of short-term trainings programs addressing the need on a particular qualification and institutional capacity strengthening of VET providers. ®   Project facilitated further upscale of WBL concept in the country and in 2022, 18 new WBL students' capacity building and labour market transition was supported. ®   The project successfully continued to implement climate-smart and innovative micro-grants program for farmers and increased outreach to 142 farmers. ®   Regional interventions resulted in 13 active PPPs, over 21,235 farmers consulted, and 4,285 farmers trained in the second phase of the project supporting the extension system development in the target regions (Guria, Samegrelo Zemo Svaneti, Samtskhe Javakheti and Racha Lechkhumi Kvemo Svaneti). ®   Swiss Agricultural School Caucasus (SASC) delivered consultations for over 300 Farmers.
2024 Narrative: UNDP supported the transformation of the agricultural education ecosystem by advancing Work-Based Learning (WBL), public-private partnerships (PPP), and the representation of the private sector in the VET System. Further, the UNDP program assisted in enhancing the Performance Management System for VET Colleges by developing standards for VET principals and 360-degree evaluations allowing colleges to conduct digital self-assessments of their service quality. UNDP was instrumental in attracting and retaining young people in agriculture by assisting RDA in establishing and institutionalizing the new internship system for agriculture students at extension services. UNDP continued advancing the transformation of Georgia's agricultural extension system by assisting in the establishment of professional qualifications and the development of the pilot version of its professional growth system. UNDP nurtured a new partnership involving the Ministry of Environment Protection and Agriculture (MEPA), the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), the NCEQE, the Business Association of Georgia (BAG), industry associations, processing enterprises, farmers, and non-governmental organizations which resulted in the development of a policy document on the Employment in Competitive Fields; this policy paper identifies deficient environmental and agriculture professions and outlines the government mechanisms for ensuring high-paying employment in these vocations. The document has been submitted to MEPA, and its enforcement into a Law is expected in the coming months. In 2024 UNDP achieved significant advancements in providing extension services to a total of 14,809 farmers, of whom 4,014 are women, across targeted regions, including Guria, Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti, Imereti, Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti, Samtskhe-Javakheti, and Ajara. Furthermore, UNDP facilitated services for 1,632 Agrarian Vocational Education and Training (A-VET) students, including 506 women, through both A-VET and Adult Education (AE) initiatives. Two notable contributions have been made towards establishing a Vocational Education and Training (VET) system that is more inclusive and aligned with labor market demands: (1) the implementation of an Ethnic Youth Integration Plan in two selected regions of Georgia, which enables 41 general education schools to offer VET courses tailored to ethnic minority communities and populations residing across the occupation line; and (2) the completion of a final draft for a concept regarding an institutionalized social inclusion fund. Additionally, comprehensive concepts focusing on the integration of NEET (Not in Education, Employment, or Training) and ethnic minority youth have been developed, which will serve to guide institutions in enhancing access to both education and employment opportunities. To improve the inclusivity and accessibility of vocational education and training, particularly for rural and ethnic minority groups, the UNDP has undertaken several initiatives: a) the development of a revised version of the State Language Program, aimed at facilitating better integration and enhancing the social and economic engagement of ethnic minority youth; and b) the creation of a training package for Georgian as a Second Language (GSL), consisting of 60 audio files. UNDP assisted in enhancing Performance Management System for VET Colleges: the National Center for Education Quality Enhancement (NCEQE) has developed standards for vocational education and training (VET) principals, contributing to improved performance management in VET colleges. A comprehensive concept and digital tools for 360-degree evaluations have been developed, allowing VET colleges to conduct digital self-assessments of their service quality.UNDP also assisted in digitalization of the registration process for Sector Skills Organizations (SSOs) and training enterprises; implementation of a pilot blended training model for extension specialists that incorporates online learning resources; enhancement of the network of educators through the provision of online coaching sessions; formulation of a comprehensive concept aimed at the digital transformation of VET institutions, with a particular emphasis on developing digital infrastructure, enhancing management practices, and promoting innovative pedagogical approaches. Enrollment in Work-Based Learning (WBL) programs has tripled, reaching a total of 156 participants. Vocational education admissions have seen an impressive fourteenfold increase, totaling 35,457 enrollments. Additionally, the number of vocational education graduates employed in agriculture has exceeded expectations, with 595 graduates, surpassing the initial target by 1.4 times. Notably, the percentage of women benefiting from these programs significantly exceeds the targeted 30%. UNDP has made substantial improvements in the qualifications of teachers and extensionists, with 229 individuals (41% women) as extension officers and 117 individuals (77% women) as agricultural vocational education and training (A-VET) teachers. This development was facilitated through regular online quarterly meetings, coaching, and training in areas such as "Lettuce Production," "Demo Farming," "Basics of Agricultural Cooperative Management," and "Potato Production." Furthermore, 47 field specialists and farmers (12 women) completed the training certificate requirements based on International Standards in Agriculture. UNDP has also achieved important milestones in developing examination requirements for dairy production and formalizing the application of the European Quality Assurance in Vocational Education and Training (EQAVET) indicators among VET providers. Additionally, progress has been made in implementing a Micro-AKIS concept in the Imereti and Guria regions. The development plans for the Agricultural Knowledge and Innovation Systems (AKIS) in these regions, covering the years 2025-2030, have been completed and presented to stakeholders, with participation from 35 individuals (14 women) in Guria and 30 individuals (20 women) in Imereti. The UNDP has implemented effective interventions to support students, farmers, and vocational education and training (VET) institutions, helping them acquire the skills necessary for preparing business plans. In collaboration with the Swiss Agricultural School Caucasus (SASC), UNDP has introduced a work-based learning examination process and established an Alumni Support Fund to assist graduates in launching and managing agricultural businesses. As a result, three A-VET graduates have received financial support of up to $3,000 each to help kickstart their ventures. In order to promote agricultural education among youth, together with 20 educational organizations, UNDP provided Agro-scholarships to 32 students (including 14 women) in amounts of 500, 1,000, or 1,500 GEL. Another noteworthy initiative is the Agriculture and Environmental Protection Olympiad, held on the platform www.http://agroliga.veta.ge. This competition saw participation from 313 young individuals (146 of whom were women), from which 18 winners (10 women) emerged, each receiving various forms of rewards and recognition.  Extension services were promoted among youth by implementing and institutionalizing internships for vocational and higher education students at extension services, offering three-month paid placements. Namely, internship opportunities for vocational and higher education students were offered in six pilot regions in Georgia. More than 100 students will benefit from a three-month paid internship program. Moreover, UNDP has launched a new rural skills development initiative in partnership with the Pakka Foundation, focusing on field training and mentorship for farmers in organic hazelnut cultivation techniques in Kakheti and Samegrelo. To date, Pakka has trained 79 farmers (12 women) with the assistance of field advisers and international organic farming specialists, successfully testing six new techniques alongside farmers involved in demo plots. UNDP further supported increased representation of the private sector in the VET System: The agricultural Sector Skills Organization (SSO) AgroDuo has expanded its membership by enrolling participants from the meat processing and veterinary sectors while providing needs-based training for leaders, trainers, and specialists; and has continued to strengthen the foundational aspects of the skills hub concept which enhances the private sector power in the development of educational standards and programs.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote inclusive and gender transformative approaches to climate action, disaster risk management and environmental protection to conserve natural resources and leverage ecosystem benefits for sustainable human development (CLIMATE, ENERGY, DRM AND BIODIVERSITY)
Outcome: By 2027, the Kyrgyz Republic has started the transition to low-carbon development and risk-informed climate resilience, contributing to people’s fair and equitable access to ecosystem benefits and to empowerment of vulnerable communities in the governance of natural resources and disaster prevention
Output: Capacity of disaster management systems is strengthened, and community resilience to multiple shocks is increased at all levels through enhanced participation of women in DRR planning, as well as effective investments, policies, mechanisms, and tools
Sub-Output: Availability of a curriculum and training materials for postgraduate medical education on preparedness and response to SRH and GBV in Emergencies
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Civil Society Organizations, Kyrgyz Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 5 Gender Equality
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: To strengthen emergency sexual and reproductive health (SRH) and Gender-Based Violence (GBV) care in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, a unified Minimum Initial Service Package (MISP) curriculum and training program for postgraduate medical education will be developed. Support will focus to equip postgraduate medical professionals with the essential skills and knowledge to provide equitable and respectful SRH and GBV care during emergencies, particularly for vulnerable populations, including pregnant women. The results will be captured through the programme’s M&E framework.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: 60-hour curriculum and associated training materials for postgraduate medical education on preparedness and response to reproductive health and gender-based violence (GBV) in Emergencies drafted. This initiative is led by the two chairs of the Obstetrics and Gynaecology Departments, one at the Kyrgyz Medical Institute named Daniyarov and the other at the Kazakh Nazarbayev University. The curriculum will include online sessions hosted on the MOODLE distance-based learning platform, featuring recorded video lectures. Both countries have developed their sections of the curriculum separately, ensuring that the structure, design, and content meet or exceed the national legal requirements for postgraduate medical education in each country. Clear and measurable learning objectives will ensure that students acquire the necessary knowledge, skills, and attitudes upon completion of the course. A comprehensive competency framework outlining core competencies for healthcare professionals to effectively deliver Minimum Initial Service Package (MISP) services has been completed. The competencies include proficiency in managing reproductive health issues in emergencies; skills to respond to and manage crises related to GBV and reproductive health; competencies for working collaboratively with other sectors and professionals in emergency settings. The developed materials include - texts and presentations for lectures; compendiums and presentations for clinical lessons and situational theoretical cases and scenarios for simulation exercises.

Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The sub-output seeks to realize human rights. It includes 4 elements of the HR marker: it is grounded on a human rights analysis; it is based on a normative framework; it seeks to address discrimination and promote LNOB; it refers to duty-bearers and the fact that the advisory services provided aims at addressing a capacity gap.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Sustaining peace is part of the activity’s intended outcomes. Situations of refigees addressed through the Common Country Assessment , MSNA or other analyses; SOU is conflict sensitive and the results are explicitly related to sustaining peace.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, in collaboration with MER, 150 ECE Resource Centers have been created and capacities of over 4,860 educators on playful learning, MHPSS and SEL have been built, benefiting 29,000 children. Additionally, 482 preschools teachers were trained in experiential and project-based learning, directly impacting 10,048 children, including through implementing robotics programs for 1000 children. The Interregional ECD Conference on equitable access to quality education for refugee children was organized.Assistive technologies (AT) for 300 children with hearing and visual impairments have been procured and the purchase of AT for children with intellectual disabilities is in the process. A study on the inclusion of children with SEN and Gap Analysis on provision of AT in education were conducted to reveal trends and design new interventions. The "Learning Together" campaign aimed to combat stigma and discrimination against children with disabilities, SEN, refugees, and ethnic minorities, promoting their right to quality education. The campaign reached 1,800 community members and 300,000 children from 1,204 schools, leading to increased knowledge and inclusive practices.Foundational policies for advancing the digitalization of education agenda (Roadmap for the Digitalization of the Education Sector; Minimum Standards for the Endowment of General Education Institutions with ICT and Internet Connection; Digital Technologies Curriculum for TPD; Methodology for the Assessment of Teachers’ Digital Competencies) were developed. 103 teachers from 12 schools in Cahul and Ungheni received training in digital tools and STEAM-based project learning, benefiting 2,127 students. An e-Learning course was developed, covering student-cantered learning and STEAM education. In addition, 350 All-in-One PC and 350 Interactive Panels have been procured to equip 70 schools.The newly created National Institute for Education and Leadership was supported in developing the regulatory framework and conducting the mentor training programme for 90 national and 920 institutional mentors. In Cahul and Ungheni focal regions, the local network of 24 mentors in formative assessment was capacitated and 164 teachers and managers were trained in applying formative assessment practices, positively impacting 18,686 children. To enhance wellbeing and career counselling services, two guides were developed and trainings targeting relevant school staff have started. The WASH and Green Education agenda was advanced by establishing and co-chairing the WASH in Schools Sector Coordination Council, leading a national-level assessment of WASH facilities and services in schools, conducting a KAP study on WASH in schools, initiating WASH infrastructure projects in 124 schools, and finalizing improvements to WASH facilities in 8 schools. Green skills development was introduced in 20 schools, where managers and young activists were supported to develop and implement school initiatives linked to the promotion of environmental practices in schools and communities.Efficient collaboration with the national and local level authorities, including in focal regions, with national NGOs and INGOs had a determinant role in achieving the education objectives, impacting thousands of children. Particularly, the partnership with the Ministry of Education and Research, Republican Centre for Psycho-pedagogical Assistance and National Institute for Education and Leadership was instrumental in advancing the curricular reform, inclusive education, teacher training, and digitalization.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.2_Health, education and food systems are strengthened and become more resilient to ensure universal access and quality of services and respond to humanitarian needs
Sub-Output: (UNICEF - NEW) Education Second decade: The education system, national and local authorities, will have improved capacities to increase equitable access of adolescent girls and boys, especially the most vulnerable, to good quality and inclusive education, including life-skills and competencies.
Description: Provision of technical assistance to the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) in the implementation of the (ESP) 2030, with a particular emphasis on fostering inclusiveness, gender equality, resilience, WASH, digital transformation, and financial efficiency within the education sector, addressing the needs and rights of all women/girls, men/boys, and encompassing both development and humanitarian contexts
Implementation partners: Government of the Republic of Moldova, Moldova 2030 SDGs Partnership, Moldova Chisinau City Hall, Moldova Ministry of Education and Research, Moldova TEKEDU, Moldova local public administration, Moldova, Centrul media pentru tineri
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: The sub-output’s focus on increasing equitable access of adolescent girls and boys fostering inclusiveness, gender equality, resilience, WASH, digital transformation, and financial efficiency within the education sector, addressing the needs and rights of all women/girls, men/boys, and encompassing both development and humanitarian contexts
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The sub-output seeks to realize human rights. It includes 4 elements of the HR marker: it is grounded on a human rights analysis; it is based on a normative framework; it seeks to address discrimination and promote LNOB; it refers to duty-bearers and the fact that the advisory services provided aims at addressing a capacity gap.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Sustaining peace marker narrative: Sustaining peace is part of the activity’s intended outcomes. Situations of refigees addressed through the Common Country Assessment , MSNA or other analyses; SOU is conflict sensitive and the results are explicitly related to sustaining peace.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNICEF implemented interventions aimed at diversification of adolescents learning opportunities, and skills development, particularly, digital and green.  The STEAM on Wheels curriculum has been developed and digitized, making it accessible online to enrich the learning experience for the GirlsGoIT and STEAM on Wheels initiatives. The content for this open-source platform was crafted with valuable input from girls who participated in summer camps and from beneficiaries of the STEAM on Wheels programme. This initiative has successfully reached over 60 localities. 10,000 children benefited from educational support through UNICEF developed digital platforms. Youth workers in Chisinau Municipality and rayons (Florești, Ungheni, Fălești, Bălți, Telenești, Cimișlia, Basarabeasca, Ștefan Vodă, Cahul, Căușeni, Anenii Noi, Dubăsari, etc.) have been given training and information sessions on MHPSS and GBV (116 activities), benefiting ab. 50,000 Moldova and Ukraine children and adolescents, including vulnerable and refugees. About 1,000 adolescents and youth from Moldova and Ukraine participated in 5-day camps and 5 summer schools on MHPSS and resilience building (including GBV and SEL), participation and civic engagement.  In Cahul and Ungheni focal regions, the schools were supported with improving the engagement of youth in the learning process. About 400 pupils were engaged in planning and implementation of STEAM education projects, which led to a significant improvement in the level of youth satisfaction with the adapted teaching-learning process. Another 2,402 children, youth, and community members participated in WASH related and environmental initiatives, including through 2 organized summer schools. The knowledge in Menstrual Hygiene Management of 462 girls was improved through educational workshops and awareness campaigns.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.2: Enhanced capacities of key stakeholders at national and sub-national levels on labour force resilience and equal skills development opportunities
Sub-Output: Strengthened capacities of national institutions and educational stakeholders to design and implement digital skills development programmes for women and girls, PWD to ensure inclusive participation in the digital development
Description: The sub-out aimes at the delivering a digital upskilling activities aimed at awareness and capacity building on gender digital divide and digital inclusion of people of disabilities
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Digital Development, Innovations and Aerospace Industry
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: 1) A series of training on cyber hygiene (child online safety) and digital skills was conducted for 5th–8th-grade students (299 students in total) from three public schools in Kostanau.2) A hackathon "Business Hack" was conducted in partnership with "SaryarkaAutoProm", "Kostanau Agromechanical Plant" and a network of family cafes "Muslima", which provided the participants with real business cases. 77 persons aged 16+ participated in the hackathon: 12 IT professionals aged 16-26 (2 females) and 14 start-ups led by persons aged 16-25 (2 female leaders).3) Regional baseline assessment on digital accessibility (in Russian with executive summary in English) is conducted and published (https://www.itu.int/pub/D-PHCB-ICT_ACCESS_CIS.01-2021); online training courses on web-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/web-accessibility-cornerstone-digital-societyon-line-self-paced-training-0) and ICT-accessibility (https://academy.itu.int/training-courses/full-catalogue/ict-accessibility-key-inclusive-communication-line-self-paced-training) are translated into Russian.4) In 2021 ITU finalized procurement and delivery of the equipment necessary to create a smart education ecosystem in KInEU University (Kostanay). The core network of the KInEU university was upgraded to ensure distribution of high-speed internet withing the university campus, a platform for organizing distance learning, videoconferencing, and lP-telephony.
2022 Narrative: 1) Smart education ecosystem in Kostanay. In 2022, in consultation with akimats of Kostanay city and the Kostanay region, 6 educational institutions were selected to be connected to the university’s network (KInEU became an Internet-hub for local community) with 600 users in total: Chaikovski Secondary School (Zhitikara District), Zhambyl Secondary School (Kostanay District), Amankaragai Secondary School named after N.Ostrovski (Auliekol District), Amankaragai Secondary School No.2 (Auliekol District), Corporate University of LLP “Saryarka AvtoProm”, hostel of the “KInEU College of Entrepreneurship”. All facilities were connected at the speed of at 10 Mbps – global absolute minimum recommended by Giga.  Each facility is fully covered by a wireless network and is able to communicate with the university to solve possible technical problems with the network and equipment. Objects are provided with access data to manage their local websites with content placement and administration rights. The smart education ecosystem has improved the quality of education in the connected institutions and allows for context-dependent global learning in the digital age to meet the needs of work and life in the 21st century. Apart from this, 32 lecturers of the KInEU were trained in digital literacy and the use of ICT in the educational process. This course was developed in order to upgrade digital skills of lecturers so that they will be able to efficiently and creatively teach students using the full capacity of equipment purchased to create smart education ecosystem.2) The Kostanay Engineering and Economics University named after M.Dulatov with ITU support conducted two trainings to enhance digital and entrepreneurial skills of youth. In February 2022 93 youth representatives (30% women), including start-up leads and youth entrepreneurs took part in a master class for start-up beginners in ICT sphere. The trainees gained knowledge on developing a business model, launching of a start-up with limited seed money, promotion of start-up through CRM system, and on the use of RFID technologies for digital identification and assets control. In July 2022 16 students from 3 higher education institutions took part in the World Skills-2022 Regional Championship in Prototyping. The programm included trainings on 3D printer calibration, performing measurements and drawing sketches , creating and developing a 3D model of the product in a CAD environment and creating a model-prototype.
2023 Narrative: To raise awareness on the matter of digital inclusion of people with disabilities, to facilitate development of national programms/trainings for digital upskilling of people with disabilities, and to promote further establishment of a network of training centres for persons with disabilities ITU cоducted a regional study entitled 'Methodological bases for digital upskilliing of people with disabilities'. The study contains:an overview of the existing educational programs on digital upskilling, relevant methods and assistive technologies;an anlysis of access to education for different categories of people with disabilities;an overview of public and private programmes to facilitate employment of persons with disabilities;list of professions available for employment of various categories of persons with disabilities;recommendations for decision-makers, educational institutions and private sector on digital upskilling of people with disabilities to ensure their proper digital citizenship and employment.9 countries of the CIS Region, including Kazakhstan, took part in the research.

2021 Narrative:
To strengthen the capacities of all Territorial Committees for Consultation and Collective Bargaining (TCCCB), a new round of online trainings was organized by the CNSM, with the support of the ILO. The activity is part of a broad support actions towards the reinforcement of social partnership and enhancement of the social dialogue in the country.
To assist enterprises in complying with the labour legislation, the Employers’ Organization (CNPM), set up a labour law training service, which proved to be highly relevant for enterprises. The service was further digitalized to provide access to all employers and HR specialists to trainings and webinars on labour relations aspects.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development

Output: (2022) 4.3 Education system has better capacities to deliver quality and inclusive education to all children and youth and address discrimination
Sub-Output: Advocacy for adolescents and youth right to comprehensive sexuality education
Description: UNFPA will continue advocating for the sexual and reproductive rights of adolescents and youth, with the main focus on mandatory school-based comprehensive sexuality education. UNFPA will continue building advocacy participatory platforms in 5 targeted districts (Cahul, Orhei, Rezina, Falesti and Ungheni) by engaging LPAs, community members, parents, schools, and young people. But will also support the national biennial conference organized by Youth Klinics, with international participation, in adolescent health and development.
Implementation partners: Youth Friendly Clinic, Youth Media Center
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2022 Narrative: Advocacy platform which supports adolescents’ and youth’ sexual and reproductive health and rights and includes teachers, young people, parents, and religious leaders was expanded in  Chisinau municipality and 5 targeted districts (Cahul, Rezina, Orhei, Falesti, Ungheni) and is currently acting in 50 communities. 1265 key actors (parents, teachers, religious leaders, LPAs, young people, etc.) were informed in 2022 about the benefits of comprehensive sexuality education and sexual and reproductive health and rights of young people. 567539 population was reached through multimedia materials developed and disseminated widely by UNFPA on comprehensive sexuality education and its impact, etc.Two National Conferences on Health Education and Adolescents health and wellbeing were conducted in partnership with Youth Media Center and Health for Youth NGOs/Network of Youth Friendly Health Clinics. About 1000 professionals from education and health communities, parents, young people engaged. The the “Health education” Facebook group which brings teachers and CSO expanded and includes now 419 members. The CSE was addressed in more than 10 TV and radio programmes with participation of UNFPA, Ministry of Education and Research, teachers, young people, parents, and implementing partners of UNFPA.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2021) 4.3 Education system has better capacities to deliver quality and inclusive education to all children and youth and address discrimination
Sub-Output: Develop life skills and healthy behaviors of students in Vocational Education & Training for their development and job readiness
Description: The "Develop life skills and healthy behaviors of students in Vocational Education & Training for their development and job readiness" is joined support of Austrian development Agency and UNFPA in VET for 2020 - 2022. The main outcome is: VET students (boys and girls, including vulnerable and with disabilities) practice safe reproductive health behaviors and adopt a healthy lifestyle.
Implementation partners: Vocational schools
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In collaboration and with core financial support from Austrian Development Agency, UNFPA and Ministry of Education and Research continued implementation of the three years project in Vocational, Education and Training. The main results that have been achieved in 2021 are:
1. Teachers of "Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle" course from 12 VET institutions completed the 10-month training programme on delivering quality life-skills education and have access to electronic and digital didactic materials, but also a variety of innovative materials (board games, puzzles, quiz, posters, Virtual reality tools, etc.)
2. 13 youth-friendly classrooms from 12 VET schools are equipped with IT equipment and are actively used to provide "Decisions for a healthy lifestyle course" and peer education activities. 
3. 322 staff from targeted VET institutions (psychologists, dormitories staff, management, etc.)  received full package of informative sessions on healthy development of adolescents, how to address GBV and risky behaviours.
4. The curriculum of "Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle course" was revised in line with international standards and is being piloted, the continuous education programme for teachers is under development.
5. Communication campaign on health and safe behaviours and the role of life skills health-based education launched and is widely implemented. 
6. Nine business companies who work with the selected VET schools enrolled in a five-month learning programme on youth-friendly workplaces, how to address GBV at the workplace and family-friendly policies.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2021) 4.2 Women, young people and persons with disabilities have improved capacity and are empowered to access and demand quality education, health and social services
Sub-Output: Support Youth Klinics to provide out of school peer-to-peer health education
Description: Support Youth Klinics' volunteers in conducting online and offline peer-to-peer health education including on sexual and reproductive health and rights
Implementation partners: Youth Friendly Clinic
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
In 2021, the UNFPA continued to support the  Network of Youth Kliniks to provide peer-to-peer educational programs for young people in Moldova. 

The volunteers of YK have strengthened their capacity to develop and deliver information through social media by applying posters, videos, etc. To enrich the learning outcomes of young people, UNFPA developed and equipped all 41 YKs with innovative learning materials about sexual and reproductive health and rights, including a board game and online quiz "Without Taboo", puzzles and posters with changes in puberty of boys and girls, board games on HIV/AIDS prevention and use of modern contraception. In addition, 5 podcasts/video formats were developed and will be widely disseminated to young people, parents, teachers in 2022.  

This year the peer education program through social media has been extended to the Russian-speaking community. As result, volunteers conducted an information campaign on 1- Reproductive health; 2- The phenomenon of violence against young people (at home, at school, in the community, between young people); 3 - Cyber Bullying and 4- Mental Health / COVID-19 pandemic conditions (Anxiety, depression, laziness, distrust, isolation, loneliness, lack of motivation). They have reached out to 113646 adolescents and youth up to 24 years through social media and to another  12794 boys and girls through offline peer education activities. 

In addition, to strengthen the capacity of the Youth Klinics network to align their programs and services to the needs of young people from vulnerable groups, in partnership with NGO "Health for Youth" and Coordination Center of YK "Neovita", the international ”Out of School Comprehensive Sexuality Education Guidance” was translated into Romanian and presented to key SCOs working with young people. The YK already applied this Guideline to develop the CSE program for young people with disabilities.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2 - Sustainable, inclusive and equitable economic growth
Outcome: Outcome 2.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, have access to enhanced livelihood opportunities, decent work and productive employment, generated by sustainable, inclusive and equitable economic growth
Output: (2021) 2.2 People from vulnerable groups (including women, youth, people from special status regions) have relevant skills and knowledge and improved access to resources and sustainable jobs and livelihoods
Sub-Output: Support  women and girls, with focus on the women and girls from excluded groups, to pursue STEM/ICT-related education and jobs, and to launch start innovative tech start-ups.
Contributing partners: Government of Japan, Government of Sweden
Implementation partners: Academia, CSOs, Private companies
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Two pre-accelerator programmes were implemented:
-60 pre-selected women-led start-ups benefited from 23 training sessions and 35 follow-up mentoring support each during 6 week-long online intensive program. In addition, they were paired with 58 external mentors focused to help them in specific areas of business.  Participants of the program presented their business ideas at a public demo day organized online. 
 -A web-based educational tool (e-learning platform) was creared to help streamline the learning process within the pre-accelerator, provide trainers, learners, and others involved in education with information, tools, and resources to support and enhance education delivery and management, and ensure continuous post-project education for women. 
 -Online (web-based) catalogue  was developed, containing presentation of women-led startups and business ideas developed at all three pre-accelerators programs supported by the UN Women. 

On 23 of December UN Women’s signed a partner agreement  to support women and girls, with focus on the women and girls from excluded groups, to pursue STEM/ICT-related education and jobs, and to launch innovative tech start-ups. The interventions should, inter alia, help women and girls overcome COVID-19 crisis and navigate in a post-pandemic reality.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Inclusive and non-discriminatory social policies and services
Outcome: 2. By 2025, all girls and boys, women and men, particularly the most marginalised have improved access to and utilize equitable, qualitative, integrated social protection, universal health services and quality education
Output: Pre-school, primary, lower and upper secondary education system is strengthened to provide quality and access to education for all with improved learning outcomes, and with relevant skills for life and work including during COVID-19
Sub-Output: 2.2.4 By 2025, central and local authorities have strengthened capacities to design, implement and scale up quality, gender responsive early childhood and primary education services.
Description:
- Support development of legislation framework for Early Childhood Education (ECE).
- Support local authorities for scaling up viable models for ECE services and development of ECE training package to deliver quality, inclusive and gender mainstreamed ECE programmes in 5 selected municipalities. 
- Strengthen infrastructure of primary schools to increase capacities of teachers on child centered teaching approach through Implementation of assistive technology learning tools in 5 selected municipalities. 
- Strengthen innovative approaches for early childhood programmes and responsive parenting.
Contributing partners: European Commission - Neighbourhood and Enlargement Negotiations, Government of Luxembourg, The EU's Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Kosovo Ministry of Education, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI), Municipal Education Directorates
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,5.b Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF provided financial and technical support to the cross-sectoral working group for the draft Law on Early Childhood Education (ECE). In addition, technical support was provided to the Ministry of Education, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI) for the development of the draft Kosovo Education Strategic Plan 2022-2026, of which ECE is a core pillar.
UNICEF, in close collaboration with the MESTI, supported an analytical review of the ECE Curriculum and Standards framework in Kosovo to inform both a child-centered early learning vision and the decision-making process for the curriculum scope, goals and content priorities for children aged 0-6. 
UNICEF contributed to the reactivation of the ECD Coordination Mechanism hosted by the MESTI through meeting support and technical support for the revision of the Terms of References for the Mechanism, which is set to be formally validated as the ECE Advisory Committee of the MESTI. 
Lastly, UNICEF supported pandemic prevention measures by providing 50 public and community-based preschools with 76 automatic hand sanitizing dispensers.

2023 Narrative: UNFPA Belarus CO jointly with the national partners ensured scaling up of the peer-2-peer extracurricular educational program for youth on SRH issues, gender stereotypes, HIV prevention and healthy lifestyle, approved by the Ministry of Education (MoE), by enriching the peer network with 24 new volunteers-trainers and reaching 2,387 young people through the trainings’ cascades.UNFPA Belarus CO advocacy efforts resulted in launching the series of inclusive educational events “i-communication”, serving as a platform for sharing information on life-saving skills, discussing sensitive topics (SRHR, GBV, positive relationships/friendship for people with disabilities, positive parenting) among young people with and without disabilities, their peers, and family members as part of the inclusive communication tools design ongoing process. It's engaged 98 representatives of the target audience.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Description:
Development of parental programmes for teens for building resilience and proper care. 

Online portal and app for mental health for adolescents and youth built on the platform developed by the UNICEF Regional Office

2023 Narrative: Both adolescents and parents benefitted from the first Parenting for Lifelong Health for Teens programme implementation, piloted with practitioners from the education, health, social protection and CSO sectors. A pool of 12 facilitators were trained, encompassing through the programme over 100 parents and guardians, with the aim to further expand the programme in 2024.
2024 Narrative: As part of the joint UN PBF programme, an open call was developed for the adaptation and implementation of a new cohort of the Parenting for Lifelong Health programme for Teens. The programme will be adapted in Q4 2024 and Q1 2025, and deployed in 2025.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Support to MoE to implement the Strategy for Digitalization of Education (2022 - 2027), with special focus on digital platform deployment, digital content development, and capacity building for teachers and students, particularly most vulnerable ones
Description: Technical assistance to MoE to develop quality digital content for teaching and learning, consolidate and upgrade Digital School Platform, and promote the use of digital technologies in smart and inclusive manner
Contributing partners: European Union, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: With support of UNICEF, the Ministry of Education is implementing a comprehensive set of interventions aimed at creating functional digital eco-systems at the school level, as well as at consolidating the use of the Digital School Platform among all beneficiaries, i.e., teachers, students, and parents. The current initiative includes several key interventions: a massive capacity building component, support visits / information sessions for 40 schools, piloting of the cooperation between two schools based on the Digital School Concept, as well as development of additional digital content for teachers, students, and parents. The number of users of the MoESI Digital School Platform increased by 33 per cent compared to the previous year, with the platform being enriched by additional digital content for students, teachers and parents.  As one of the several countries participating in the Regional Office-led project “A Voice for Every Child”, Montenegro was the recipient of the international 2024 Zero Award for implementing the C-board app for children with severe communication difficulties.
2024 Narrative: The national Digital School Platform (based on the Learning Passport) has 27,918 active users, with 53 new courses developed in 2024. Furthermore, UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education, Science and Innovation to establish EdTech hubs and a related programme across 12 primary and secondary schools in the north of the country, reaching 6,000 pupils. Over 500 children were supported to develop digital, critical thinking and problem-solving skills in 12 primary schools, as well as an additional 1,120 through UNICEF-supported workshops at the national Days of Science Festival.

Description: Support the Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport of Republic of Armenia (MoESCS) to enhance the regulatory framework and governing systems for effective implementation of national school feeding programme contributing to human capital development and social-economic development
Implementation partners: Miinistry of Education, Youth, Sports
SDG Targets: 17.1 Strengthen domestic resource mobilization, including through international support to developing countries, to improve domestic capacity for tax and other revenue collection.,17.3 Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.,17.9 Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the sustainable development goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.,17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development.,17.16 Enhance the global partnership for sustainable development, complemented by multi-stakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology and financial resources, to support the achievement of the sustainable development goals in all countries, in particular developing countries.,17.17 Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 1.1 1.1 Healthy and nutritious food is available and consumed
2021 Narrative: At the national level, WFP  worked with the Government to continue transitioning the school feeding programme to national ownership. In partnership with the Government, WFP is strengthening the state policy and regulatory frameworks and systems to ensure a successful and sustainable handover.   WFP provided technical and financial support to the School Feeding Child Welfare Agency (SFCWA), a national entity developed to support the Government to manage, monitor and implement the national school feeding programme once it is fully nationalized.  In line with the Handover Roadmap, the implementation of school feeding in Lori and Gegharkunik provinces was successfully handed over to the Government in 2021.  in consultation with the MoESC a comprehensive research is commissioned to provide the Government with best available research and contextual evidence serving as a basis for identification of appropriate school feeding modality for Yerevan-based schools.

 - Develop publication based on the training and awareness raising activities conducted

2021 Narrative:
>IT skills of 44 students in Gali and Gudauta improved through trainings programming, robotics, 3D design and graphical design at the newly established IT Centers in Gali and Gudauta.
>67 conflict affected young people in Sukhumi, Gali and Ochamchire were provided with vocational education (culinary courses, courses for electricians and sewing courses) using resources available at VET institutions in Abkhazia. 
>Creative potential of 70 young people in Gali and Ochamchire enhanced their skills at the newly established SmART Class in Ochamchire - a platform for alternative and innovative methods of informal education in the areas of bibliophilia, healthy lifestyle and civic activism, as well as had an opportunity to participate in intellectual games.

Up to 260 conflict affected youth and teachers improved access to quality education services through projects implemented by Innovative Education Foundation (EU COBERM) and Conciliation Resources (EU RRF) provided access of conflict-affected youth to quality education:  
Innovative Education Foundation: The mixed groups of 18 Abkhaz and Georgian educators received necessary knowledge of best educational practices in IT/STEM education through joint workshops, training, webinars and seminars and are able to start applying them.
Conciliation Resources: 240 Abkhaz students got access to online English courses and 90 teachers retrained in delivering English language classes, as well as stress management and skills for conducting lessons in online format
