2022 Narrative: UNDP continued its efforts to ensure participation, inclusion, and access to quality education for conflict affected youth. 10 youth from Gali and other districts of Abkhazia gained access to quality education in Estonia, increasing literacy level, skills of critical thinking, and high competence, contributing to increased chances for employment and decreased poverty.A new platform for cooperation has been established among Georgian and Abkhaz preschool teachers and early childhood educational specialists as a new entry point in confidence building field. The action improves quality of Early Childhood Education in Georgian and Abkhaz preschools through advancing competencies and qualification of teachers and caregivers, and introduces international best practices.  In 2022 UNDP continued expanding digital capacities of underserved communities, cultivating a digital mindset within Abkhazia through creating and piloting short gender-responsive TVET (Technical VET) courses enhanced by digital content and e-learning tools in the demanded skills and specializations (Web Development based on WordPress, Landscape design, Tourism Management, Electrician, Photo/Video Editing). The action increases employment opportunities of youth and adult learners in TaT and Abkhazia and there is an evidence-based demand in local societies to benefit from this opportunity with the aim to advance further their skills and professional career.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030
Outcome: Outcome 4: By 2025, conflict affected communities enjoy human rights, enhanced human security and resilience
Output: 4.1 Improved access to essential services for conflict-affected communities
Sub-Output: Conflict-affected communities have better access to essential social services, including to education, healthcare and improved community infrastructure
Description: Conflict-affected communities have better access to essential social services, including to education, healthcare and improved community infrastructure
Contributing partners: European Union, Government of Estonia, United Nations Development Programme
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4.1 4.1 Improved access to essential services for conflict-affected communities
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: COBERM IV – UK Fund through its partners continued building the resilience of conflict-affected communities through economic empowerment of rural women living in IDP settlements or along the ABL. Through small-grant program, 10 Georgian and South Ossetian women, 21 families or 82 members of the communities increased their monthly income and created services or products, which served more than 900 indirect beneficiaries from target communities and beyond. Young people from vulnerable groups gained better access to local job markets through undergoing digitalized VET courses offered by Sukhumi-based CSO National Resources and Tbilisi-based CSO Innovative Education Foundation. UNDP supported the economic empowerment of conflict-affected communities, including women by providing entrepreneurship training, mentorship, and in-kind contributions. 80 beneficiaries received training and grants for equipment to support their entrepreneurial activities.  Three road infrastructure repair tasks completed in Abkhazia have significantly improved access to public services for 815 rural residents (66% women). 88% also reported an increase in use of public services. This also significantly reduced travel time, cutting school trip for one community from 40 to 10 minutes. UNDP improved access to digital skills and STEM education for 300 young people in Abkhazia (60% female). This was achieved by providing spaces with IT equipment in the Sukhum/i Boarding School and Gal/i College of Humanities. Further 72 young people (82% girls) increased their employability by obtaining various IT skills through specialized trainings. UNDP contributed to improving access to quality healthcare services for rural conflict-affected communities. Six clinics were renovated and equipped with necessary furniture and medical equipment, including a full rehabilitation of the Ambulance and SES premises at Gali Hospital, rehabilitation works at the Polyclinic in New Athos, and Clinical-Diagnostic Laboratory in Agudzera in Abkhazia, as well as full rehabilitation of outpatient clinics alongside ABLs on TAT, Mejvriskhevi, Rike and Orsantia clinics. In total, around 45,000 conflict-affected people benefit from the newly renovated medical premises.  As part of the Referral Program, from January to September (including), 590 patients (401 women) from Abkhazia/South Ossetia received emergency or planned medical care on the TAT including the diagnosis and medication, and support with transportation and accommodation for patients and their family members.
2024 Narrative: Throughout 2024 UNDP continued to provide access to essential social services, such as education and healthcare, as well as improving infrastructure for conflict-affected population.Healthcare: UNDP contributed to improving access to quality healthcare services for IDP communities. UNDP supported the establishment of a Day Hospital (emergency room) in Tskaltubo to serve the local and IDP populations, providing vital medical consultations and testing services within the community. This initiative has raised awareness of prevalent illnesses, symptoms, and treatment options among both IDPs and local residents, improving health knowledge and access to care. Enhanced healthcare services reduce barriers to treatment, contributing to a higher quality of life in Tskaltubo Municipality and potentially lowering morbidity and mortality rates. During the grant implementation period, a total of 1,850 individuals benefited. Of these, 415 were direct beneficiaries, including medical personnel, patients, and community meeting participants (103 men, 312 women, and 88 IDPs), and 1,345 were indirect beneficiaries, such as family members and potential patients (344 men and 1,001 women).UNDP organized activities as part of the 16 Days of Activism against Gender-Based Violence in five IDP settlements. These included an information session with doctors, a Forum Theater for social change, and active engagement of IDP women in theater performances, all aimed at raising awareness about GBV, legal protection, and support services. The campaign mobilized IDP women and youth, promoting collective action and fostering a more equitable society. Throughout the mentioned activities, a total number of 227 beneficiaries were directly outreached and engaged.  As part of the Referral Program, from January to June (including), 178 patients (114 women) from Abkhazia/South Ossetia received emergency or planned medical care on the TAT including the diagnosis and medication, and support with transportation and accommodation for patients and their family members. UNDP also supported an umbrella network in the sphere of healthcare and support to PWDs which brought benefit to 278 (118F) vulnerable people, including PWDs and victims of gender-based violence. Results of 17 CSO grants provided by UNDP’s Civil Society Support Programme (CSSP) include: improving access to quality healthcare for 446 PWDs (237F, 209 M), including children, through services delivered at various rehabilitation centers across Abkhazia as well as psychiatric consultations for boys and girls; providing support to over 50 rural families living in extreme poverty to build their capacities to independently produce agricultural products in an environmentally-conscious way; socialization of 8 PWDs through one-day tours aimed at learning how to live a healthy lifestyle and appreciate nature, and; providing medical support to over 15 elderly people, PWDs and other vulnerable persons through outpatient medical service. Overall, in 2024, over 2500 conflict affected people were directly supported. Infrastructure improvements in 2024 entailed significant work carried out in IDP collective centers and conflict-affected communities. These efforts included bathroom repairs, water supply enhancements, and roof rehabilitation, benefiting over 1,082 internally displaced people living in 21 IDP settlements.  Through the EU4Dialogue project, 42 families in the Torsa IDP settlement regained access to safe drinking water. This initiative included comprehensive repairs to critical water infrastructure, reducing significant water loss and enhancing sustainable water access. Key improvements encompassed restoring water headworks and distribution pumps, installing tanks and filters, and conducting rigorous water quality testing. Additionally, community members participated in water hygiene training, and a village water committee was established to ensure ongoing maintenance and system sustainability. This project has effectively raised awareness of water safety and improved living conditions within the Torsa settlement, contributing to a healthier, more resilient community.  UNDP supported the water well construction in the Ingiri village IDP settlement, providing the IDP population with a reliable and systematic drinking water supply (110 IDPs - 63 women, 47 men, incl. 5 PwDs). Water pumping units and an extensive supply system were installed. Two local community members, selected to manage the water system, completed an intensive internship and are now qualified to operate the technical panel with safety and expertise. The initiative has resolved long-standing water access issues, eliminating life-threatening conditions and ensuring that residents can now live in accordance with sanitary and hygiene standards. Additionally, an extra pump was installed in the basement of the residential building to manage accumulated water, further enhancing living conditions for the IDP families. UNDP supported socio-economic and hygiene improvements in the Tsilkani IDP settlement by upgrading 11 cottage ceilings, installing solar water heaters and dryers, and training seven residents in sustainable energy management. These upgrades, benefiting 200 residents (124 women), reduced energy costs by an average of 28%, with a new energy cooperative established to promote local leadership in energy solutions. UNDP helped install a solar-powered bench in the settlement for internally displaced people in Senaki, offering renewable energy for mobile devices and a free Internet connection. The direct and indirect beneficiaries of the project already have the opportunity to use the free internet 24/7 in their settlement, through which they have maintained access to everything that they did not have before for example, they have learned to use Google, use various searches engines, which they actively use in their practice. beneficiaries included 1500 people, who used the free Wi-Fi during the initiative period.  UNDP has successfully supplied a low-maintenance incinerator for the Gali hospital including building a concrete platform and metal shelter to keep the incinerator secure. The initiative contributed to enhancing bio-medical waste management and environmental standards in Abkhazia. This advancement reduces infection risks within the hospital and provides Abkhazia’s medical and environmental sectors with a sustainable solution for disposing of bio-medical waste from various sources, including other hospitals and animal remains. These improvements contribute to the safety and quality of life for conflict-affected communities by ensuring better healthcare and environmental protection. Additionally, UNDP fostered personal connections between Georgian and Abkhaz doctors, offering promising potential for future cooperation. The incinerator benefited 350 patients (50% women) and is expected to serve thousands of beneficiaries over the coming years.  UNDP has provided the Nikozi outpatient clinic, located in an ABL village, with solar panels to address rising electricity costs and improve service reliability. As the clinic expanded its medical services, its operational expenses, including an annual electricity cost of approximately 3,500 GEL, also increased. Frequent power outages and fluctuations have affected the quality of medical equipment and imposed additional expenses, placing a burden on the clinic’s budget. The newly installed solar power system is expected to provide a reliable, uninterrupted power source, reducing electricity costs and ensuring consistent healthcare delivery. Serving around 5,000 residents in the Nikozi community, the clinic is the sole healthcare provider in the area, making this initiative vital to the well-being of local families and communities. UNDP has empowered marginalized populations in conflict-affected communities by offering access to business education, vocational education and training (VET) courses, and agricultural services. Namely, UNDP supported vocational handicraft classes for 54 women from ABL villages in Samegrelo, enhancing skills in knitting, digital marketing, and social media. Six women secured employment, and four are now conducting master classes in local schools, with six others obtaining grants to support their businesses. Additionally, technical equipment was provided to IDP settlements, enabling 90 women to become skilled in craft-making and promoting their work online to secure independent income. In the Imereti and Racha regions, around 270 (156 women) IDPs received training in business planning and funding opportunities, with 14 participants submitting applications and two successfully funded. Overall, UNDP through the EU4Dialoge project provided socio-economic and livelihood support to 1,831 people (1,121 women). These were vulnerable people including IDPs, rural and conflict-affected communities.  As part of VET support, digitalization and digital literacy was promoted through cross-district knowledge sharing: Sukhum-based IT trainers conducted training at Gal College of Humanities and Sukhum Boarding School, utilizing newly equipped IT classrooms. This initiative provided 44 VET students (24F) with essential IT skills, opening up future career paths in a technology-driven world. Additionally, 32 VET teachers (all female) enhanced their ICT literacy, empowering them to better support student learning. This grant underscores the transformative role of technology in education, equipping youth with skills vital for career development and adaptability in a digital age UNDP enhanced the skills of 19 (3F) young people from remote areas of Abkhazia and TaT by introducing advanced agricultural techniques and smart rural technologies. This included providing smart devices to help automize and improve greenhouse production; thus, increasing sustainable income for target rural groups in Abkhazia and TaT UNDP facilitated access to higher education for 9 (6F) conflict-affected youth residing in Abkhazia to study in France and Estonia. Given the challenges posed by international travel restrictions and the limited eligibility of Abkhaz students for Western scholarship programs, fully funded educational opportunities in the EU have a transformative impact on the personal and professional development of these young people.

Implementation partners: BiH Agency for Statistics, BiH Ministry of Civil Affairs, FBiH Bureau of Statistics, RS Statistical Institute

Description: As a result of close collaboration with mass media, important messages on children’s issues in Uzbekistan were disseminated to both decision-makers and the general public. The focus was on issues such as mother and child health, immunization, nutrition, HIV, Early Childhood Development/Early Childhood Education, quality education, juvenile justice, social protection, mental health, and youth participation. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic majority of these topics have been covered considering prevention measures and psycho-social support targeting the general population including vulnerable groups. Special attention has been paid to the issues of children of migrant parents, reintegration of women and children returned from armed conflict zones. The number of media engagements reached more than 50.
Implementation partners: National Association of Electronic Mass Media (NAEMM), National TV and Radio Company (NTRC)

2021 Narrative: UNICEF continued providing information on various practices and approaches to quality education in the multilingual setting in Abkhazia, including trainings and workshops to build capacity of local teachers and education experts in the field of student centred instruction, life skills and various education practices as well as the development of an online professional development portal for teachers. UNICEF, jointly with education experts and decision-makers, continued discussions and advocacy work for the introduction and piloting of various Mother Tongue Based Multi-Lingual Education models in Abkhazia. UNICEF is piloting a STEM programming in 13 schools in Abkhazia following the development of STEM curriculum, comprehensive teachers’ guide on STEM classroom practices and methodology, and training of teachers in collaboration with Teacher Resource Centers.  UNICEF launched a children’s science show, covering various aspects of informal education and development, and receiving wide coverage on local media and social networks. UNICEF, jointly with local partners, conducted a survey on COVID-19 pandemic effects on youth development and access to education which was used to inform planning of further education activities and interventions.
2022 Narrative: In the Education sector, 32 teachers from 13 schools across Abkhazia participated in training on contemporary approaches into schooling. In addition, 27 teachers from 15 pilot schools which had taken part in the preparatory life skills trainings have delivered their master classes. A total of 230 youth of a network of youth clubs across 18 schools in Abkhazia benefitted from UNICEF implementation of a variety of youth development activities spanning across development of soft and life skills among youth.
2023 Narrative: Following activities were implemented:Established a training and capacity building centre, termed the Innovation Learning Hub (ILH), where pre-service and in-service teachers could undergo training programmes. The ILH will have space where teachers both study and educate at the same time. •            A training programme (3 months) was developed to train staff for the ILH (8 people) in both managerial practices and education approaches that are core to MTB MLE. •            A content and language integrated learning (CLIL) guidebook was developed by teachers based on the assessment of teachers’ application of CLIL methodology from 13 schools where CLIL was originally piloted. •            8 teachers were trained on practical approaches and implementation of Student Centered Instruction (SCI) and CLIL. A group of teachers from 13 schools underwent a training programme on life skills approaches in 2022, using the previously developed programme on life skills. Throughout 2023, UNICEF continued supporting teaching practices and collecting feedback from teachers from 13 schools trained in 2022 on life skills. •            A detailed programme and work plan for pre-school education in multilingual setting was developed by a group of local pre-school educators. Based on this programme, a detailed training programme was developed and 18 teachers from 6 kindergartens in 2 regions of Abkhazia (Gudauta and Gulrypshi) were trained to pilot the pre-school programme in their respective kindergartens. These kindergartens were equipped with visual and aid materials to conduct teaching in language environments. •            A set of teaching materials focusing on language development in the multilingual contexts was developed, and meetings and discussions were carried out to support Abkhaz language application. •            A set of child-friendly materials for pre-school education have been developed. Local artists and young authors developed a new character (a bright orange dog named “Amtsa”, flame in Abkhaz), that is exploring and enjoying its childhood. At this stage, 5 small colorful books have been developed; and introduces them to various developmental topics, including languages, conflict solving and communication skills. In addition, a fairy tale book for children and famous women of Abkhazia were developed. •            The children’s science show “Adunei Show” has been further developed and aired on the show’s YouTube channel, as well as on a local TV channel “Abaza TV” and online streaming platform “Systema”. The programme showed consistently high views and positive feedback from the audiences. •            A parental Telegram and Instagram channel called Agara (Cradle) was developed, with the channel offering practical advice on good parental practices.•            840 students engaged through 28 youth clubs (18 in Abkhazia and 10 in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti regions) benefitted from programmes in science, technology, environment, healthy lifestyles, civic education, media literacy and foreign languages. These activities also improved access to diverse sources of information and strengthening critical thinking skills through various thematic topics. •            Various online and face-to-face activities for youth were undertaken including 72 youth who took part in a summer camp in the mountains of Auadhara•            Media literacy programme reached 88 youth and supported identification of mis/disinformation as well as improved understanding of media content. •            “Voice of Youth” radio programme was developed and broadcast on Radio Atinati•            TV programmes were developed and aired on access to language development and usage, including 10 episodes of a show for children and development of materials in Abkhaz language such as the first and second Harry Potter films translated, and dubbed in Abkhaz.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF established an Innovation Learning Hub, a physical space intended to support the pre-service and in-service training of teachers and provide a platform for discussing the educational needs of children with key stakeholders.UNICEF continued to enhance access to quality education in Abkhazia by improving teachers' professional skills and promoting student-centered teaching approaches. A multilingual education (MLE) programme for preschoolers was piloted in six kindergartens across two districts of Abkhazia, with a plan to gradually introduce this programme into other kindergartens throughout Abkhazia. UNICEF continued supporting a network of 28 youth clubs (18 in Abkhazia and 10 in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti regions), with 755 adolescents benefitting from programs in science, technology, environment, healthy lifestyles, civic education, media literacy and foreign languages. Various activities, online and face-to-face, improved access to diverse sources of information and strengthened critical thinking skills.Additionally, UNICEF expanded its media literacy program for schoolchildren, equipping them with practical tools to combat disinformation. A new partnership was established to connect and empower young people across both sides of the ABL.

Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Agency for Preschool Education, Uzbekistan Ministry of Preschool and School Education

2021 Narrative: The Ministry of Public Education (MOPE) has introduced Inclusive Education (IE) in 42 schools on a pilot basis in 2021 academic year based on the President's Decree # 4860 (2020). UNICEF supported MOPE in developing content for teachers’ training on inclusive teaching and assessment for delivering new curriculum. Training of Trainers (ToT) was conducted in October 2021.  UNICEF collaborated with MOPE to test the newly created resource materials to support the marginalized parents of CWD (by UNICEF ECARO and Office-of-Research-Innocenti)  in 8 schools implementing IE in Uzbekistan. An evaluation of the pilot is underway and based on the results, the resource materials will be further improved for use by several other countries in the ECA region.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, a set of new resources for marginalized caregivers of children with disabilities were finalized and disseminated. During the global launch of these resources held with UNICEF Regional Office in August 2022, lessons from Uzbekistan were presented and discussed. These resources are being used during the modelling of inclusive schools to ensure a comprehensive approach with caregivers engagement and support.
2023 Narrative: In 2023 UNICEF launched the development of National Policy Frameworks for Inclusive Education, outlining inclusive standards, mechanisms, and SOPs for schools. The frameworks are being developed in alignment with broader quality education reform addressing all areas of education, including infrastructure, curriculum, national assessment and teacher professional development supported by UNICEF. Frameworks will be modelled in selected schools informing the development of respective legislation and guidelines. A model of inclusive school in Tashkent is currently being upgraded in line with Universal Design principles to inform the development of new national standards for school construction and equipment.  UNICEF supported curriculum and assessment reforms through extensive capacity building interventions with the newly established National Center for Education Development under the President Administration in the development of National Curriculum and Learning Assessment Frameworks.   With EU support, 100 per cent of Afghan and host community children in need in the Surkhandarya region (n=3081) benefitted from inclusive quality education. Specifically, delivering foundational learning and multi-lingual education, UNICEF developed a dedicated learning support programme benefiting both Afghan children and children of local communities with learning difficulties. This builds on an inclusive quality education model for children facing language barriers or missing schooling.

Description:

Gender marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to gender equality/women’s empowerment

2021 Narrative: Project is under implementation. Online training course for mainstream school teachers on Information Security in Educational Cyberspace is under development by UNESCO IITE's contractor. Currently, draft tutorials and learning support materials are tested with the users and will be further developed based on the feedback.
2022 Narrative: Negotiations with nations partners, fundraising
2023 Narrative: 1) In partnership with UNICON.UZ, the ITU Guidelines on Online Safety for policy-makers, industry, parents and educators were localized (translated into Uzbek) and are being now actively disseminated to the target audience. State authorities are committed to use these Guidelines to formulate national policies and strategies that align with contemporary global Internet safety trends. In parallel, industry organizations will have the capacity to leverage the Guidelines to establish safer and more secure services tailored for children. Simultaneously, parents and educators will gain valuable insights to assist them in recognizing potential threats and risks children might encounter online. This guidance will empower them to preempt and effectively address these challenges in a timely manner.2) In partnership with IT-Park Uzbekistan, the course materials ‘Information Security in Digital Education Space’, developed jointly by the ITU Regional Office for CIS and the UNESCO Institute for Information Technologies in Education, were successfully adapted to the national context and translated into Uzbek. An online course on information security (available at cop-itpark.uz) is specifically designed to provide training for teachers and individuals who engage with children in their professional roles, and it is offered free of charge. Moreover, online course has built-in accessibility features, that allow users with disabilities to successfully complete it. It consists of several modules covering the following topics: information security issues, basic legislation in the field of information technology and information protection, the relationship between the use of digital devices and children's mental health, organizing children's information security behavior in the digital space, cyber hygiene and cyber security for students, computer viruses and analysis of software products aimed at ensuring children's information security in the digital educational space. Upon successful completion of the course, each participant receives a certificate that attests to their accomplished training and signifies their capability to apply the acquired knowledge in their everyday undertakings.3) 305 teachers (275 men and 30 women) from 14 regions of Uzbekistan, affiliated with IT Parks and IT-Academies, were trained on information security during a series of offline trainings. The trained instructors will apply their newfound knowledge over the next six months while teaching IT courses, thereby imparting the fundamentals of online child protection to their students on a consistent basis.4) ITU provided expert assistance to Uzbekistan on addressing challenges related to broadband Internet connectivity at schools, network resiliency and monitoring quality of service. The following national studies are carried out by ITU experts in this area: (a) study on the actual use and quality of Internet connectivity in schools; (b) study on the resilience of LAN infrastructure in schools. In 2023, a methodology for each study was developed and initial data was collected.5) In February and September 2023, 7 representatives of IT Park Uzbekistan took part in online training 'ITU tools for connecting schools to the Internet' (participants gained knowledge and practical skills about the most promising technologies for school connectivity, ITU tools to be used to estimate capital and operating costs in all sections of the telecommunications network (incl. school LAN), mapping and analysing broadband network infrastructure) and ITU regional event 'Broadband Week: connecting schools - expanding the opportunities of education of tomorrow!'  held in Kostanay, Kazakhstan (participants discussed policy and regulatory aspects of school connectivity and gained knowledge and practical skills on technological and economic aspects of broadband school connectivity).

Sub-Output: Promoting ethics in education by introducing anti-corruption policies and measures in overall education system of Uzbekistan
Description: Within this activity, UNESCO conducts comprehensive review of the root-causes for the unethical behavior, corruption, academic and financial dishonesty in education system. Policy options as well as tools and guidance on eradicating the corruption practices in education system governance from national to school levels, will be introduced. This will include enhancing transparent, authentic and robust data collection system, establishing the code of conducts for all education actors (teachers, school leaders, national and regional policy makers, students and parents, local communities); adopting anti-corruption and anti-academic fraud policies with transparent and standardized rules and procedures for admission, retention, recruitment, financing, teaching and learning.

2024 Narrative: The endorsement of first Partnership Compact for Education Reform 2023-2026 in 2023 has enabled the prioritization and acceleration of five new strategic areas related to quality and inclusive education, and contributed to mobilizing over 600 million USD of Development Partners’ financial commitments to education reform. Its implementation was continuously monitored in 2024 within the framework of the Local Education Group, with mid-term review of Compact Priorities expected to be undertaken in 2025. UNICEF supported sector coordination through the Local Education Group meetings, review of Development Partners’ workplans against the priorities articulated in Uzbekistan Compact for Education Reform 2023-26, and initiation of thematic sub-group work on inclusive education.

2023 Narrative: Joint efforts of UNFPA and UNICEF on introduction of the topics about sexual reproductive health, HIV and STI prevention, early pregnancies, and healthy lifestyle into the school curricula of the Republic of Karakalpakstan resulted in improved capacity of 297 teachers on teaching children and peer-colleagues through a series of training supported by UNFPA and inclusion of these themes into the mandatory courses of advanced training for teachers. To further sustain the positive changes, the curricula of Karakalpak State University (pedagogic and psychologic faculties) was updated with evidence-based and reliable information about sexual reproductive health, prevention of HIV and STI, healthy lifestyle, early pregnancy, stigma and discrimination and covered 1875 teachers and students. To elaborate multilevel response to community level, UNFPA capacitated 75 young people - volunteers of the selected districts of the Republic of Karakalpakstan on peer-to-peer approach in delivering key messages and information about sexual reproductive health, HIV and STI prevention, early pregnancies, healthy lifestyle to more than 500 youngsters and adolescents and their parents and community people.	In 2023 UNFPA CO supported development of a long-term strategy for the successful development of capacities of young people to promote the youth networking for raising awareness of young people on essential issues of reproductive health, prevention of HIV/AIDS and STIs, on gender rights, and GBV prevention. The training package for the TOT was developed and the first TOT for the youth peer network was conducted where 21 young people from Tashkent and regions received knowledge and skills on communicating with their peers on different aspects of HIV/AIDS prevention, on healthy lifestyle and reproductive health, gender equality and GBV.
2024 Narrative: ·      With support of UNFPA more than 590 schoolchildren (boys and girls of 6 grade) in Aral Sea region raised their awareness and knowledge about reproductive health, puberty and menstrual hygiene. Results of this activity were summarized to prove early start of SRH education in school compared to 10-11 grades proposed by the Ministry of Preschool and School education of the Republic of Uzbekistan. ·      UNFPA contributes a lot to informing and raising awareness of young people about reproductive health and reproductive rights, gender equality, HIV and STI prevention, gender-based violence prevention, SDGs, and building different soft skills. Nineteen young trainers gained necessary knowledge and facilitating skills to spread this information among peers in secondary schools and high education institutions in the different parts of the country. Working as peers, young trainers covered 360 adolescents with the sessions on the above-mentioned topics in neighboring education settings. This initiative could become a good resource for further work with young people handed over to the Youth Union of Uzbekistan

2023 Narrative: 1) Tashkent International Model United Nations 2023:UNODC ROCA, in collaboration with sister UN agencies - UNFPA and UN Women, played a pivotal role in organizing the Tashkent International Model United Nations 2023 (TIMUN), Central Asia's largest international MUN platform, bringing together over 500 young minds from 14 different countries and simulating 11 UN committees.Having supported TIMUN in Uzbekistan since 2018, UNODC - a global leader against illicit drugs, organized crime, terrorism, and corruption, provided a unique opportunity for young participants to model two UNODC committees: the Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice (CCPCJ) and the Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND).                                                                                                                                                                                                          2) The Youth Media Hub, established in Fergana Valley in 2021 within the framework of the Peacebuilding Funds Project, provided life skills training to 50 vulnerable young people in 2023.
2024 Narrative: UNODC facilitated the Wunderkind Model United Nations (WMUN) Conference in Tashkent, benefiting 80 school students (38 girls and 42 boys) from public and private schools and lyceums across Tashkent. Through featured simulations of UN committees addressing corruption, terrorism, cybercrime, and health coverage, young people have increased the knowledge and skills required to actively discuss these issues.

This strategic framework enabled the consultation and joint coordination between UNICEF, the Ministry of Preschool and School Education, National Agency for Social Protection, Zamin Foundation and main Development Partners such as JICA, UNESCO, USAID, and the World Bank, as well as parents of children with disabilities and OPDs to ensure coherence and complementarity among all inclusive education programmes, with concrete modeling of inclusive education at pre-school and school levels.

2024 Narrative: UNICEF provided technical support to the Republican Scientific and Methodological Center for the Development of Education of the Republic of Uzbekistan (CED) in the development of the Requirements of Education Standards which are enabling competency-based education reform with focus on digital learning, climate resilience, socio-emotional learning for gender transformative and inclusive education. The requirements were reviewed and endorsed within the framework of the Local Education Group (LEG) and approved by the Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan No. 157 dated March 27, 2024 “On measures to improve the development and implementation of state educational standards and state educational requirements”. The Resolution has also established an action plan, mandating the CED to collaborate with the MOPSE towards the development of an overarching Strategy to ensure the integrity and continuity of educational programs in the systems of preschool, general secondary, and vocational education. Currently UNICEF is providing technical support to CED through extensive capacity building interventions to design overall methodology for preschool and school curriculum development with a focus on cross-cutting skills and competencies and inter/intra subject connectivity. Cross-cutting skills and competencies will include 21st century skills with a focus on gender responsive curriculum, socio-emotional learning, formation of life skills, along with introduction of new climate resilience and green competencies. This new framework for curriculum development is expected to improve quality of learning for 9.5 million students (2 million in preschools and 6.5 million in schools).

2024 Narrative: UNICEF finalized a formative evaluation on the established alternative preschool models for scaling up access to pre-school education. UNICEF supported ECE alternative centers are functioning as quality models for larger reform and expansion of ECE services to meet national enrolment targets in rural areas. The evaluation of the modelling showed relevance, effectiveness, efficiency and impact as a pivot role in bridging gap in access to quality preschool education and contributing to children’s opportunity to learn and develop. The results of the evaluation were shared with the Government and other stakeholders for decision making and scale up to achieve 2030 goals of universal enrollment.

2024 Narrative: The National Teacher Training Curriculum Framework (NTTCF) was developed with technical support from UNICEF which defines the overall vision, critical content areas, pedagogy, linkages, and assessment upon which a teacher education program should be based. It will help to develop the range of knowledge, skills, attitudes and values required of a teacher who is entering the preschool education field. The NTTCF was validated with National and International stakeholders and will be finalized and submitted to MOPSE for approval by the end of 2024.  UNICEF provided technical support in the revision of pre-service teacher training curricula. As a result, curricula for 3 years of Pedagogical University (Bachellor’s degree) have been approved, including 4 syllabi for the first year of study and 154 students of the first grade benefited from the new programme. The further revision of the curricula will continue for the next years based on the new framework document to be approved

2024 Narrative: Advancing preschool teacher education system reforms. Over 6,500 preschool teachers and managers have benefited from the newly developed in-service teacher training curricula in 2024 and over 119,000 will go through the new in-service teacher training system based on the new curricula over the next five years. This was made available through the technical support provided by UNICEF in the framework of IsDB funded “Enhancing Quality of ECE in Uzbekistan” Project and teacher professional system reforms happening based on the Presidential Resolution # 231 of June 2024 devoted to improvement of the system of continuous professional development of teachers, which envisaged creation of integrated system of retraining and professional development of employees of educational organizations. Total of 11 Regional Teacher Training Centers to be established nationwide have been identified and UNICEF has started procurement of goods to fully equip the first five Centers to accommodate all teachers through in-service training at regional level within five coming years.   Curriculum development for preschool teachers and methodologists. Based on the technical recommendations of the international experts and the work of the appointed working groups, the curricula for teachers and methodologists have been reviewed and revised from 144 hours into two training pathways: a 100-hour in-person program and a 72-hour online course. The in-person program uses hands-on methods for child-centered learning, managing diverse classrooms and promoting social and emotional growth with big emphasis on practical implementation. The introduction of the online courses will give flexibility through digital tools for easy access. Over 25,700 teachers are currently using the Learning Passport platform and the new curriculum was approved to start implementation from 2025. The syllabi for the new curricula are being revised and developed accordingly and will be finalized by the beginning of the courses to start in 2025. Curriculum development for pre-schools Directors. In alignment with the Cabinet of Ministers’ Resolution #531, which mandates enhanced leadership training for preschool directors, new certified managerial courses were developed at the request of the MOPSE. UNICEF provided technical support in the development of the curriculum for Directors for 144 hours through the review and analysis of their managerial, pedagogical and motivational competencies and needs necessary to lead well in a fast-changing environment.  The curriculum was approved and is being pretested in December for full implementation starting January 2025.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Transparent and accountable democratic governance
Outcome: Outcome 4: Good Governance
Output: Output 4.2 Institutions capacitated for better planning, budgeting and service design and delivery
Sub-Output: Support primary school optimization and improving the budgetary allocations system in primary and secondary education
Description:
Support the Ministry of Education and Science and the local authorities in improving evidence-based sector management by: 
2024: i) Organize consultations and coordination with local and national stakeholders on the school network optimization. ii) Support MoES capacities to generate, disseminate and utilize evidence (including on school feeding, student transport options, addressing the surplus/deficit of primary school staff) in decision-making processes including data needed for school optimization and new funding formula. iii) Support the MoES in gathering necessary data for calculations related to the implementation of the new primary school funding formula, as well as for developing a digital module for calculating the new primary formula; iv) Support the MoES in developing a new secondary school funding formula. v) Support the MoES to prioritize investments in the primary school network needed to support the optimization. 
2021-2023: i) assessing the allocation formulas for transfers from the Government to municipalities that fund primary and secondary education; ii) conducting a thorough analysis of the primary schools network and devise recommendations to improve the allocation of the limited resources to ensure all primary schools enable improved access and good quality teaching in accordance with national standards, laws and educational concepts.
Implementation partners: Association ZMAI, Government of North Macedonia, North Macedonia Association of Local-Self Government Units, North Macedonia Ministry of Education and Science, North Macedonia Ministry of Finance
SDG Targets: 10.4 Adopt policies, especially fiscal, wage and social protection policies, and progressively achieve greater equality.
QCPR function: Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Data Collection and Analysis, Other (including coordination)
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 7 Output 2.2 Quality and affordable education, 8 Output 2.3 Social protection of all persons in need, 6 Output 2.1 Universal access to affordable high quality health services
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education and Science to overhaul the transfers from the Government to municipalities that fund primary and secondary schools. New funding formulas based on the number of students and costs for attaining educational standards were developed and incorporated in the 2022 national budget, increasing efficiency, improving funding transparency and fairness and establishing mechanisms that would enhance quality of teaching. Adequate allocations are also made for inclusion of children with disabilities as well as for teaching in the languages of the smaller ethnic communities. The new formulas provide sufficient funding to schools for adequate maintenance, suitable investment in equipment and teaching aids, professional training and career development of the school staff, as well as increased number of professional associates. For the first time, the 2022 primary education funds transferred to the municipalities, prepared based on the funding formulas developed with UNICEF support, include free meals for students from first to fifth grade thus further expanding universal social protection programmes for children, as well as free tablets for access to digital educational resources for students from families at social risk. 

UNICEF has also supported the drafting of municipal school optimization plans, which aim to identify potential ways to improve the allocation of the limited resources to ensure all primary schools enable teaching in accordance with national standards, laws and educational concepts. UNICEF has supported the development of a school optimization index which measures the gaps for each primary school and municipality to fulfil the educational and infrastructural standards, as well as the gaps in actual costs per student and standardized costs – unveiling the level of financial efficiency. For each municipality where action is needed, a detailed plan is prepared for adjusting the infrastructural and educational capacity, while the financial efficiency will be improved with the use of the new school funding formula. The implementation of these plans will: establish an equitable system for primary education; create equal conditions for teaching in all the schools; implement the new concept of primary education; ensure efficient allocation of resources.
2022 Narrative: In cooperation with the World Bank and the MoES, UNICEF supported the drafting of 80 municipal plans for optimization of the network of primary schools, and commenced work with 10 municipalities to collect and update data needed for the finalization of the optimization plans, as well as consultation with local stakeholders – municipal administration, school staff, parents and students – to adjust optimization scenarios. UNICEF developed the capacity of key Ministry of Education and Science personnel to understand the methodology and key findings from the analyses related to primary school optimization and funding reform, including the school optimization index. In line with the new primary education funding allocation formula and the drive for optimizing the primary school network and its resources, UNICEF supported the MoES and the Bureau for Development of Education to revise the standards for primary schools – updating infrastructure and equipment benchmarks for schools to be able to provide good quality education. The standards provide crucial parameters in the calculation primary education funding allocations, and during the development of the new funding formula it become apparent that they are outdated and need to be revised. The primary education transfers formula has been further upgraded by incorporating costs for implementation of mandatory experiential learning, which will enable even students from poorer households to take part in these activities.
2023 Narrative: A UNICEF international forum brought together policymakers, experts, thought leaders and practitioners to engage in a dialogue on lessons learned and key success factors from school network optimisation in European countries. The Forum was used to transfer lessons learned from similar reforms conducted in EU Member States, and to also bring in expertise and additional support in the process from the OECD and the World Bank. UNICEF established partnership with the Association of municipalities (ZELS) around the issue of school funding reform and school network optimization. The partnership includes advocacy for a new primary education funding formula, gathering feedback from the municipalities to inform its fine-tuning, and developing their capacities to implement it and develop primary school network optimization plans.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF supported national and local authorities in optimizing the primary school network and improving resource allocation. The detailed plans for 10 municipalities were updated, and stakeholder consultations for finalizing optimization plans for other 24 municipalities commenced. Three municipalities started implementing the optimization plans, and unused school spaces were repurposed for ECEC and community services. UNICEF prepared an assessment of investment needs to implement the optimization plans in 80 municipalities and engaged in advocacy to secure the needed $120 million. The new Minister of Education and Science endorsed the national methodology for primary education transfers to municipalities, initiated with the previous Government and supported by UNICEF and World Bank. The Ministry of Finance incorporated it in the Government’s Mid-Term Fiscal Strategy, projecting a 38% increase in operational expenditures over five years ($90 million). The new formula aims to ensure adequate funding for diverse educational needs, incentivize reducing dropout rates, expand extracurricular activities, and reallocate resources to improve efficiency and quality of education.  Advocacy resulted in the Government including the adoption of the formulas for primary and secondary education transfers to municipalities in the EU Growth Plan for the country.

By 2025, Government and other educational stakeholders have increased capacity to provide access to equitable, inclusive, safe and quality education at all levels and promote lifelong learning in an integrated manner, including quality professional development system and decent work environment for education sector employees
2021 Narrative: Mapping School Internet Connectivity: Under the GIGA initiative, UNICEF supported MOPE to map the ICT infrastructure and quality of internet connectivity in 10,000+ schools in Uzbekistan, which stimulated the GOU to connect 90% or more schools to internet (compared to just 7% schools in 2018).  Under the GIGA programme, 7000+ schools are also equipped for real-time monitoring of internet connectivity, thus enabling MOPE to track the quality of school internet connectivity more frequently; and this is being integrated into school EMIS to enhance transparency and accountability of school-related services. Re-imagine Education: UNICEF supported MOPE in modernizing digital learning platform www.maktab.uz to meet the contextual learning needs of children in remote areas, girls, and children with special needs. More than 1000 courses from global resources on foundational, transferrable, and digital skills were curated and translated into Uzbek. Specific initiatives were launched to support girls in STEM, social innovation, and entrepreneurship skills.  Teachers’ online training under “Re-imagine Education”: UNICEF supported development of Teachers’ Professional Development platform which is managed by State In-service Teachers’ Training Instituted named after Avloni. By December 2021, more than 112000 teachers (almost 90 percent of primary school teachers) have been enrolled for undertaking training on new curricula implementation, which were developed and digitalized with UNICEF’s support and placed on the platform. More than 35000 received certificates of successful completion.
2022 Narrative: Within the framework of GIGA Initiative, the real-time mapping of school connectivity has been upgraded using an open-source platform expected to increase efficiency of national contract with internet provider. An innovative business model was developed to prototype extending connectivity to surrounding school communities, the first pilot in Fergana region is enabling access of high-speed internet to 2,000 students and 4,000 households to support learning of children and youth. High-level ownership of GIGA was also ensured with MoU signing with MoPE and Ministry for Development of Information Technologies and Communications.
2023 Narrative: Expanding access to school-based internet connectivity: Pioneering a public-private partnership model, two schools became connectivity hubs with UNICEF support, benefiting over 1000 households and 3000 children in neighboring communities. A private Internet provider and national agency under the Ministry of Digital Technologies signed a profit-sharing agreement, with 50 per cent of profits to be allocated for education and digitalisation purposes, with the expectation that each dollar invested in private sector will yield three additional dollars for public services.  Digital Learning Initiatives: UNICEF launched a pilot of the Eduten digital solution for personalized and gamified learning, including alignment of the platform with the local curriculum, training of 30 teachers to integrate the platform into regular math classes and 30 principals to foster a supportive environment. A total of 259  boys and 265 – girls, 5th-grade students benefited from this pilot initiative as part of a broader strategy to introduce innovative digital solutions for learning in the collaboration with UNICEF Learning Innovation Hub based in Helsinki

2024 Narrative: Data analysis on the status of education was completed in 2024, with data informing the UNICEF situational analysis of children and adolescents in Uzbekistan. The analysis included updated data on school enrollment and out-of-school children based on UNICEF conducted MICS. Key findings highlighted progress in  primary school enrolment rates standing at 99 per cent in 2021-2022. Preschool enrolment increased from less than 30 per cent in 2017 to over 73 per cent in 2024, with nearly 2 million children benefiting from early education programmes during the 2022-2023 period.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support national efforts to promote just, accountable, and inclusive institutions and a diverse civil society that fosters peace, cohesion, and human rights for all (JUST, ACCOUNTABLE & INCLUSIVE INSTITUTIONS AND CIVIL SOCIETY)
Outcome: By 2027, all people in the Kyrgyz Republic enjoy the benefits of fair and accountable democratic institutions that are free from corruption and apply innovative solutions that promote respect for human rights, and strengthen peace and cohesion.
Output: Civil society has the knowledge, skills, and capabilities to exercise their rights, enhancing the voices of women and youth to genuinely participate in public decision-making, and engage in constructive dialogue to achieve social cohesion, justice and equality for all.
Sub-Output: Local authorities, civil society, HR defenders, media, education institutions and communities capacitated and operating in enabled space for dialogue and participation in decision-making and development at national and local levels
Description: Local authorities, civil society, HR defenders, media, education institutions and communities capacitated and operating in enabled space for dialogue and participation in decision-making and development at national and local levels
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Ministry of Justice
SDG Targets: 16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
Geography: Bishkek (city), Osh, Kyrgyzstan, Osh (city), Nookat, Uzgen
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
LNOB groups targeted: Women & Girls, Youth, Older Persons, Minorities, Persons With Disabilities, Human rights defenders (incl. NGOs, journalists, union leaders, whistleblowers…)
2023 Narrative: With UNDP support, the country has achieved remarkable progress in reinforcing local governance and nurturing social cohesion. The refinement of the Local Communities Charter engaged 665 representatives, integrating peacebuilding strategies into local development plans.  Simultaneously, national consultations on amending the Law on Local Self-Governance, involving 10 Members of Parliament, showcased a dedicated commitment to strengthening local governance structures. The Social Cohesion Forum engaged 260 officials, policymakers, religious groups and civil society, identifying priority areas [E40]. The resulting National Action Plan involved 275 representatives, laying the foundation for comprehensive policy implementation.  In youth empowerment, 500 youth benefited from business acceleration programs, resulting in the establishment of 78 businesses and contributing to their economic and social empowerment. The National Youth Congress and a high-level Youth Forum facilitated dialogue between the President, national authorities, and over 2000 young men and women, addressing civic participation and priorities. These initiatives have established a sustainable communication channel between youth and government, ensuring that youth voices are integral to the development agenda. Addressing gender-based digital divides, 180 girls and women equipped with digital skills achieved a notable 54% employment rate. Efforts against hate speech included a gender-responsive campaign utilizing digital solutions, and the Ombudsman Institute launched a Chatbot to increase awareness of misogyny and gender-related hate speech. 9 inclusive Preventing Violent Extremism advisory groups were established, ensuring meaningful civil society engagement in shaping peace and security strategies. The "ARTurduuluk" initiative, involving 26 artists and 400 individuals, promoted intercultural exchange and tolerance, culminating in the "Rhythm of the City" festival, uniting 1000 people in Osh city through collaboration with creative industries and community
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNDP advanced civil society, women, youth and vulnerable groups' participation in decision-making, fostering social cohesion and inclusive development.UNDP supported the roll-out of the State Programme on Preventing Violent Extremism, following its involvement in the policy design phase. Over 680 representatives from law enforcement and non-law enforcement agencies were trained to strengthen their capacity for effective programme implementation. A key milestone was the adoption of the updated Charter of Local Communities, developed through public consultations that ensured representation of women (51.4%), youth, ethnic minorities, and persons with disabilities, enhancing local accountability and fostering community ownership. To promote sustainable dialogue mechanisms, UNDP facilitated institutional development of Public Consultative Councils redefined in 23 multiethnic districts and cities through an order by the Ministry of Culture. These councils are now equipped to implement strategies that strengthen social cohesion and interethnic dialogue.UNDP prioritized youth engagement and economic empowerment to foster social cohesion and innovation. Over 1,500 participants (50% young women) took part in the Jaratman Jashtar Youth Entrepreneurship Forums held in Osh, Karakol, and Bishkek, creating opportunities for networking, collaboration, and idea-sharing among young entrepreneurs, the private sector, and start-up leaders.  Capacity-building initiatives empowered 122 Women Council members and 125 youth with knowledge of human rights, equality, diversity, and decision-making. These efforts resulted in 14 community-based dialogues involving 845 participants addressing conflict triggers such as child safety, gender-based violence, discrimination, social protection gaps, and environmental concerns

Contributing partners: Core Funding, Peace Building Funds, Russian Project on strengthening population data collection, analysis and utilization for policy making in the CIS countries
Implementation partners: Kyrgyz Civil Society Organizations, Kyrgyz National Statistical Committee
SDG Targets: 5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.,16.1 Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
Geography: Bishkek (city), Aravan, Ala-Buka, Nookat, Kyrgyzstan, Osh, Jalal-Abad, Aksy, Kara-Suu
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Girls and women from diverse religious and ethnic backgrounds are principle objective, and UNFPA will support them to actively lead initiatives and promote healthy behaviors, civic education, and peacebuilding. Support will include initiatives on youth leadership activism and meaningful participation in national and local implementation and monitoring processes. The results will be captured through the programme’s M&E framework.
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: 12 Self-help groups (SHGs) received different equipment in support of their business projects. Members of 45 SHGs participated in different capacity building and business mentoring workshops, exchange visits between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan within the PBF project. 6 Association of SHGs formed to continue established self-financing mechanisms and revolving funds, as well as support ongoing and new business projects in border villages.
2024 Narrative: The PBF cross-border project facilitated two impactful exchange visits, showcasing significant outcomes for self-help groups (SHGs) and local self-government (LSG) representatives: A delegation of 27 SHG and LSG representatives from Kyrgyzstan visited six successful business projects established by SHGs in Dustlik and Kairoki villages of Namangan district, Uzbekistan. And a total of 55 SHG and LSG representatives from Uzbekistan toured six innovative business projects organized by SHGs in Alabuka district, Kyrgyzstan. These exchange visits not only strengthened bilateral relationships but also explored new avenues for cooperation and economic development. The success of SHG-led ventures in a different context, fostering mutual learning and collaboration, and demonstration of valuable insights into entrepreneurial practices increased economic ties between the two countries.UNFPA continued to support the capacity building of madrasah teachers and representatives of the religious women centers on reproductive health topics. 60 madrasah teachers capacitated on health education and 62 representatives of religious women centers increased their knowledge on safe motherhood and cervical cancer.A total of 40 young people were engaged in UNFPA Policies and practices communities (PPC) initiative in Muras Ordo. The youth participated in various activities, including capacity-building sessions, community meetings, and intergenerational dialogue workshops. In the living settlement of Muras Ordo, a community initiative was implemented jointly with the Mayor's Office to address social issues, focusing on intergenerational dialogue, creating a green space, and improving mental health and well-being.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Enhanced human wellbeing, capabilities and equality in Georgia by 2030
Outcome: Outcome 4: By 2025, conflict affected communities enjoy human rights, enhanced human security and resilience
Output: 4.3 Strengthening civil society, community resilience, social cohesion and WPS agenda
Sub-Output: WPS promotion in higher education institutions
Description: To partner with higher education institutions to promote the integration of WPS topics into the curricula of relevant academic programmes (undergraduate and graduate levels) as well as student research interest in the WPS field.
Implementation partners: Georgia Journalism Resource Center
SDG Targets: 5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,16.7 Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 4.3 4.3 Strengthening civil society, community resilience, social cohesion and WPS agenda
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
Focal users: Nino Gachechiladze, Tamar Lobjanidze, Medea Gugeshashvili
2021 Narrative:
In 2021, to support the efforts to mainstream gender, peace and security in academia and increase the research interest in the field, UN Women succeeded in establishing a panel dedicated to the WPS topics at the 81st Student Scientific Conference at the Ivane Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University. 28 students from different faculties of the Ivane Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University, David Aghmashenebeli University of Georgia, and Caucasus University presented 19 research papers covering range of issues such as women’s role in peacebuilding and their meaningful participation, feminist foreign policy, women’s economic empowerment in post-conflict settings, UN Security Council resolution 1325 and state of women’s rights in Georgia, and so forth. 
UN Women further worked with the selected higher education institutions such as Tbilisi State University, Caucasus University, Sokhumi State University, Akaki Tsereteli State University, Gori State Teaching University to integrate WPS topics into their curricula.
2022 Narrative: During the reporting period, UN Women continued to support the integration of Women, Peace and Security (WPS) and Youth, Peace and Security (YPS) topics in higher education institutions. In the reporting period, UN Women in cooperation with Ivane Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University (TSU) and Journalism Resource Center organized a dedicated panel on WPS and YPS at the 82nd Student Scientific Conference at the Ivane Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University. 6 abstracts of the academic papers were presented at the conference, among them on the image of the female President of Georgia and the characteristics of its formation, the practice of media coverage of women’s initiatives in support of Ukraine, issues related to violence against women from four universities of Georgia: TSU, University of Georgia, Caucasus's International University and Batumi Shota Rustaveli State University. Around 30 students and members of academia attended the conference’s dedicated section. UN Women plans to further advance its work with the higher education institutions in integrating WPS/YPS topics into the curricula of relevant academic programmes in the next year.
2023 Narrative: Within the framework of the project on: “Accelerating Implementation of the Women, Peace and Security Agenda in Georgia” funded by the Conflict, Stability and Security Fund of the British Government, UN Women continues to integrate WPS issues in the tertiary education field. Throughout the year, fifteen professors representing seven universities, including Ivane Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University, Ilia State University, Georgian Technical University, University of Georgia, Caucasus International University, Sokhumi State University, East European University, and the Civic Education Lecturers’ Association, convened at a workshop organized by UN Women on the Role of Academia in Promoting Gender, Peace, and Security. This collaborative gathering aimed to explore strategies for integrating these vital themes into their study programs. The workshop served as an effective platform for brainstorming and idea-sharing among academia, fostering discussions on how to incorporate gender, peace, and security topics into their curriculum.  In addition to the workshop, over 100 students had the opportunity to attend two lectures delivered by UN Women representatives on Women, Peace, and Security issues. These informative sessions took place at Tbilisi State University and St. Andria University, further contributing to the dissemination of knowledge and fostering awareness among the student community.
2024 Narrative: Throughout 2024, UN Women made significant strides in integrating WPS topics in academia and fostering discussions on gender dimensions in various fields:Textbook Update: The process of updating the textbook "Conflict, Gender, and Peace" was initiated, with consultants contracted to incorporate recent advancements in WPS scholarship. The updated textbook will reflect new research and perspectives on women's roles in conflict prevention and peacebuilding.First Student Conference on “Gender Dimensions of Cybersecurity”: Organized on June 18, 2024, at Ivane Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University (TSU), the conference featured 21 students presenting 13 topics across disciplines such as law, computer science, and medical engineering. A total of 35 students (21 women, 14 men), including ethnic minority students from various regions of Georgia, participated. Speakers from the British Embassy, UN Women, the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI), the Institute for War and Peace Reporting (IWPR), the Regional Institute for Security Studies (RISS), and the Women in Cybersecurity Initiative (WIC) presented recent studies on the gender dimensions of cybersecurity. Overall, 44 participants attended the event.·       As a result, thirteen research papers from the Conference were published on the TSU website in both English and Georgian languages (GEO: კონფერენცია - „კიბერუსაფრთხოების გენდერული განზომილება" (tsu.ge); ENG: Conference - "Gender Dimension Of Cybersecurity" (tsu.ge)).These efforts have contributed to the ongoing promotion and integration of WPS topics in academic settings, enhancing the understanding and engagement of students and professionals in this critical area.

2023 Narrative: In 2023 UNESCO started developing education new MIL Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC): Reporting on Migration and Refugees issues on the international and regional standards relating to freedom of expression, including press freedom, access to public information, safety of journalists and challenges created by the digital world for academic journalism education institutions. Some priority directions, sections and learning modules were determined. In 2024 (MOOC) will be launched and 11 academic journalism education institutions will apply the MOOC in Kyrgyzstan. The step-by-step processes described in the courses explains how to use these tools in practical situations.
2024 Narrative: The MOOC is set to launch in 2024, with  academic journalism education institutions in Kyrgyzstan participating in its implementation. The courses will provide step-by-step processes to help journalists effectively apply these tools in practical situations, enhancing their skills in addressing migration and refugee topics while adhering to established standards of journalistic integrity and safety.

Description:
Advanced training to improve the skills of employees of the educational system in the formation of spirituality, morality, preparation for family life and reproductive health of students (200 ppl.)
Training for teachers of NIS in Turkestan on Valeology course with strengthening SRHR component, Turkestan, 25 ppl. 5 days (July-August 2022)
Sociological research. Assessment of the integration of Valeology course with strengthened SRH component in the curriculum of the 16 schools in Atyrau city.
