SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,5.3 Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 5 Gender Equality
Geography: Kazakhstan, Almaty (city), Atyrau, Turkestan, Astana, Zhetysu Region, Ulytau, Abay, Shymkent (city)
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
2021: 200 school teachers from Almaty, Mangystau, Pavlodar and Turkestan regions were trained through 8 online advanced training courses on the formation of morality, preparation for family life and reproductive health and rights  and region. 
The educational Program for advanced training of employees of the education system on the formation of morality, preparation for family life and protection of reproductive health among students was develped  (80 hours) and submitted for approval to the Ministry of Education and Science.

The Manual for teachers of secondary education organizations on the formation of spirituality, morality, preparation for family life, and the protection of reproductive health in students was revised, adjustments were made to the statistics and the actual material of the manual, a psychological module was developed and included into the manual. The complete manual was translated into Kazakh.

The training course on Valeology with strengthed component on sexual and reproductive health and rights in Atyrau are planned to be conducted in October 2021.
2022 Narrative: More than 700 schoolchildren of Atyrau region raised their knowledge about health and healthy lifestyle, infection diseases, sexual and reproductive health, safe behavior, prevention of unintended pregnancy and prevention of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV and one topic specifically dedicated to prevention measures against COVID-19.During the 2021-2022 UNFPA jointly with the Nazarbayev Intellectual School together with Akimat (Governor Office) of Atyrau region implemented the project on “Strengthening the well-being of students” with the purpose of increasing the capacity of the 16 schools of Atyrau city. To integrate and promote sexuality education UNFPA supported providing two in-depth 3-days training on life-skills based education course with the strengthened component on sexual and reproductive health, safe behavior, prevention of unintended pregnancy and prevention of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV for 64 school psychologists and teachers of the biology. The trainings were delivered in Kazakh language. In 2022 UNFPA assessed the student’s knowledge about life skills and SRH before and after the course. The assessment demonstrated its high effectiveness and proved that the lessons at schools are the main source of information related to the sexuality education. Along with this it should be noted that from the beginning of the lessons at schools there were resistances both from the parent community as well as from teachers. This could be the regional specificity with the more patriarchal values spread in Atyrau region and lack of preventive work in terms of sexuality education.
2023 Narrative: 57 teachers of Turkestan (28) and Kayzylorda (29) regions have been trained in the strengthened course on reproductive health and rights and were equipped with the skills and knowledge on how to provide SRHR, Gender, and GBV issues to the school children.
2024 Narrative: UNFPA conducted training sessions for deputy principals responsible for educational work and school and college psychologists. The training topics included sexual and reproductive health, puberty, STI prevention (including HIV), modern contraception methods, gender equality, the inadmissibility of gender-based violence and harmful practices such as early and forced marriages, as well as family values and responsible parenting.The training sessions were held in the Abai, Ulytau, and Zhetysu regions, and Astana city, involving approximately 130 education specialists and psychologists. The goal was to prepare educators to conduct similar sessions with adolescents in schools, colleges, and boarding schools.Participants significantly enhanced their awareness and skills in working with students, including addressing issues related to sexual and reproductive health, violence prevention, reducing stigma and discrimination, and creating a safe and supportive educational environment.
2025 Narrative: A total of 120 school teachers and psychologists from the Abay, Zhetisu, and Ulytau regions, as well as Astana city, successfully completed training on UNFPA's enhanced Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) course. The training equipped participants with the necessary knowledge and skills to integrate elements of sexuality education into their teaching and counseling practices. As a result, they are now capable of providing consultations and delivering lessons on SRHR, healthy lifestyles, sexually transmitted infections (STIs) including HIV, gender-based violence (GBV), and gender equality.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2021) 4.2 Women, young people and persons with disabilities have improved capacity and are empowered to access and demand quality education, health and social services
Sub-Output: Continue building and maintaining the Network of Youth Peer Educators on Life Skills from Vocational Education and Training
Description: Implementation initiated in 2020 and continues until 2022 as part of the project ‘Develop life skills and healthy behaviors of students in Vocational Education & Training for their development and job readiness’ is implemented by the United Nations Population Fund with the co-financing from the Austrian Development Agency from funds of Austrian Development Cooperation and UNFPA and in partnership with the Ministry of Education, Culture and Research.
Contributing partners: Moldova Ministry of Education, Culture and Research
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Education, Culture and Research, Terre des Hommes
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Established in September 2020, with continued investments during 2021, the “Network of VET Youth Peer Educators on Life Skills” has become functional. It includes 74 peer educators (students from 12 Vocational Education and Training schools) who delivered peer education activities to 2085 young people (650 boys and 1435 girls) in 2021. In total, 2327 VET students have been reached by peer educators since September 2020 when the Network was established.  

To ensure the quality of peer education activities, peer educators have passed a complex training program, which also included an offline summer camp. They have learned about healthy nutrition, prevention of bullying and GBV, sexuality, and changes in puberty, HIV and STIs prevention, prevention of teenage pregnancy, etc. Due to the extended COVID-19 period and restrictions for offline events, to ensure meaningful and equitable engagement of peer educators they have been equipped with tablets and the internet. 
The Network of Peer Educators teamed up with Pupils Council in VET and jointly organized an informational Campaign on preventing HIV/AIDS starting with December 1st. Moreover, 311 parents of VET students have been taught by psychologists and specialists on adolescents' development how to support their children in a safe transition to adulthood. 

The main UNFPA implementing partner in building the Network is Foundation Terr des Homme Moldova, with core funds from the Austrian Development Agency and co-financing from UNFPA.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2022) 4.3 Education system has better capacities to deliver quality and inclusive education to all children and youth and address discrimination
Sub-Output: Develop life skills and healthy behaviors of students in Vocational Education & Training for their development and job readiness
Description:
In 2022, UNFPA will complete the implementation of three years joined the project with the Austrian Development Agency that invests in life skills-based health education, creation of safe 
spaces in vocational educational institutions and workplaces, as well as in empowering young people to develop healthy behavior, address gender stereotypes, and prevent gender-based violence among 
young people. The focus will be channeled to supporting nine business companies who work with 12 VET targeted schools to increase their capacity in creating youth-friendly workplaces, to pilot and finalize revised curriculum of the course of 'Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle", developing guidelines for teachers and developing a continuing education training program for teachers.
Contributing partners: Austrian Development Agency, Core Funding, Moldova Ministry of Education and Research
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Data Collection and Analysis
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2022 Narrative: In partnership with Austrian Development Agency, UNFPA is supporting the Vocational Education and Training sector to increase its capacity in supporting VET students in their healthy development and life skills acquiring. In 2022, all proposed results were achieved, namely:Curriculum of the ‘Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle’ discipline was revised and approved by the Ministry of Education and Research. Is being currently used in all VET schools. The revision was informed by the study on knowledge and behaviours related to health and wellbeing of VET students conducted by UNFPA in 2021 but also international standards on comprehensive sexuality education.The Handbook for teachers based on the revised curriculum was developed. It includes practical guidance, based on best practices that were jointly developed by a team of 5 experts and educational community.Training programme for continuous education of teachers of the "Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle" was developed and  16 national trainers were trained (from the north, centre, and south of the country). In the upcoming implementation period, two VET institutions are planning to accredit this course and further deliver it to the entire VET sector based on the needs and request.9 business companies that are working with VET schools have learned how to create  youth-friendly workplace, including harnessing the potential of young professional employees; promoting gender equality at work; mentors’ and coache’s roles in facilitating the integration of young employees; work-life balance, and family-friendly policies. 3 companies (33%) updated their internal policies and regulations to better address the needs of young employees and prevent gender-based violence in the workplace.

Plan name: Republic of Moldova - United Nations Partnership Framework for Sustainable Development  2018-2022
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development
Outcome: Outcome 4.1 - The people of Moldova, in particular the most vulnerable, demand and benefit from gender-sensitive and human rights-based, inclusive, effective and equitable equality education, health and social policies and services
Output: (2021) 4.3 Education system has better capacities to deliver quality and inclusive education to all children and youth and address discrimination
Sub-Output: Support education sector in gender mainstreaming of the curricula and provide transformative capacity development for education specialists, teachers etc.,
Implementation partners: CSOs, La Strada, Moldova Ministry of Education, Culture and Research
SDG Targets: 5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
168 teachers, dormitory staff, management of institutions, out of which 147 women and 21 men are aware of gender discrimination, stereotypes, VAW aspects, as a result of  8 informative sessions “Development of the healthy behaviors and life skills amongst youth in VET schools for better opportunities”,  conducted during April-June 2021.  The activities represent the part of a comprehensive training programme supported by UNFPA. This activity will build further on the existing partnership framework with MECR (Ministry of Education, Culture and Research) to promote gender equality and elimination of violence against women.  
A draft analytical note containing recommendations for the development of the mechanism for reporting the cases of Sexual Harassment within educational system was developed and is undet revision. The document will serve as a further base for the advocacy efforts with the Ministry of Education, Culture and Research to establish such a mechanism in order to prevent VAW at all levels.  

A Partner Agreement on the development of the “Harmonious Relationship Course” for grade 8-9 and thus gender mainstreaming of the Curricula was signed with a national NGO in order to ensure that VAW and GBV prevention programs are in place at the MECR. The main expected results of the partnership are the following: to have the adapted Curriculum for the gymnasium level (8th and 9th grade), as well as Methodological Guide, Student Notebook and Teacher’s Manual; to achieve the final endorsement of the course by the MECR of the Republic of Moldova and afterwards to support it to be rolled out to 5% (23) of gymnasium in different regions of the Country. This will result to a young generation with knowledge and tolls to combat stereotypes and gender discrimination and advance favorable social norms that prevent VAWG.

Sub-Output: 3.3.5 Increasing capacity of the primary health care and education systems to help children and adolescents to manage stress and crisis effectively and successfully by training mental health professional, expanding access to quality assistance and online services, and educating adolescents, young people, and their parents/caregivers on mental health
Description: The sub-output is to be funded through BeCAP project supported by the European Union. Among other planned activities, the project is to address the consequences of the COVID-19 on adolescents mental health, further enhance online counselling and strengthen the national primary health and education systems to be more resilient to such type of crisis while providing quality services and support to youth and adolescents. The first installment of funding was received in 2021. The project is however still not registered due to complicated negotiating and planning process with the national partners. Regarding this, UNICEF Country Office in Belarus adjusted its programming to support a part of planned activities through other funding, while continuing negotiations with the national partners.
Contributing partners: European Union, Global Humanitarian Response Fund, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Belarus Ministry of Education, Belarus Ministry of Health
SDG Targets: 3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership, Data Collection and Analysis, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Migrants, Other, Persons With Disabilities, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Victims of grave human rights violations of (slavery, torture, trafficking, sexual exploitation and abuse...), Women & Girls, Youth
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF prioritized provision of sociopsychological support through different types of services and platforms including humanitarian-development nexus. These efforts resulted in 14,533 people benefitting from UNICEF supported services: 823 consultations were provided by online counselling platform talk2ok; 83 children received assistance related to cyber violence through kids.pomogut.by; 1,663 calls were processed by the National Child Helpline; 11,964 people received other services.UNICEF partnered with the Republican Centre of Psychological Assistance(RCPA) to enhance the quality of online psychological assistance foradolescents through the Talk2OK platform. UNICEF supported platform maintenanceand enhanced user-friendliness with video and audio chats for directconsultations. The platform was also improved with an accessible version forusers with vision impairments. To enhance capacity, UNICEF facilitatedcoordination and online counselling skills among 64 psychologists and 46 peersupport. To date, approximately 3,000 consultations have been conductedincluding 828 in 2023, assisting adolescents to overcome situational anxiety,depressive and suicidal thoughts, negative relations with parents and adults,peer aggression and bullying.In partnership with the Institute of Psychology of BSPU UNICEF supported piloting of an 8th -11th grade psychological well-being elective course in 50 schools. Approximately 900 students gained skills in critical thinking and crisis support techniques. The course curriculum and the methodological guidelines were approved by the Ministry of Education, and a pool of psychologists and social pedagogues was trained, laying the foundation for scaling this course throughout the school system.Social-emotional skills and MHPSS interventions were complemented with a large-scale SBC campaign to raise awareness on the importance of psychological well-being of adolescents and to promote online and offline psychological assistance in education and healthcare institutions. SBC activities had social media coverage of 1,5 million and traditional media coverage of around half a million. An impact assessment will be conducted in 2024.

2023 Narrative: Institute for Public Health of Montenegro testing behavioural insight interventions for immunization (so called SMS reminders) in order to increase the coverage rates with the first dose of the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine. According to the KAP implemented in November 2023, 28% of parents of children 0-6 reported receiving SMS reminders. Further, 27% of those who report receiving the reminder, subsequently vaccinated their child. In 2023, UNICEF signed with the Institute of Public Health of Montenegro a Memorandum of understanding on joint management and promotion of the mobile app for parents Bebbo.
2024 Narrative: WASH FIT guidelines were adapted and promoted through the health system alongside training of key personnel on hand and environmental hygiene, infection prevention and control (IPC), and cleaning and waste management procedures in healthcare facilities. Also, cleaning guidelines, waste management plans/protocols in healthcare institutions, guidelines for cost calculations and budgeting for continuous implementation of WASH activities in addition to job descriptions of WASH coordinators in Healthcare facilities were developed. For equitable access to WASH for vulnerable communities, qualitative and quantitative assessment of the state and quality of water, sanitation and hygiene services in Roma and Egyptian settlements was conducted and their awareness raised through collaboration with Roma mediators. In total 14 municipalities with Roma settlements were included and 210 Roma families reached through integrated social and behavioral change interventions and community engagement.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Support the national authorities in creating inclusive and equitable quality education for refugees and stateless children and youth at all levels.
Description: In 2024, UNHCR worked to support the education of refugee children, with the focus on increasing the primary school enrolment rate for Ukrainian refugees and the provision of support in overcoming language, cultural, psychological and other obstacle to equitable and quality education, to result in a better learning outcome for refuge children. As a result of the serial of workshops with refugee parents, which were coordinated by the Ministry of Education, Innovation and Science, the primary school enrollment rate of Ukrainian refuges increased. In addition, as a result of the improved cooperation on with the Ministry and upon the UNHCR’s advocacy efforts,  the Law on General Education was amended to include stateless persons and to ensure adequate support to refugee children. The need for a specific support to refuge children was also acknowledged in the Strategy of Education to cover the period up until 2030, which was enabled in cooperation with UNICEF.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro, NGO Red Cross Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Normative Support, Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: UNHCR, within its age, gender and diversity (AGD) approach, ensures that the needs and aspirations of women and girls are particularly taken into account in the process of design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation project cycle. Due to the proportionally high number of women among the temporary protection holders, the porgrammes in relation to this group were particularly designed to address their needs in terms of education.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: UNHCR has been an important partner to the Ministry of Education in ensuring inclusive and equitable quality education for refugee children, with a particular focus on the refugee children from Ukraine. UNHCR convened numerous meetings to provide the Ministry of Education and other relevant counterparts with the technical expertise and the data from the field obtained in a direct outreach with refugees necessary for an adequate response to the increasing education needs of refugee children.
2024 Narrative: Refugee children still need additional support in overcoming language, cultural, psychological and other obstacles to ensure they have access to equitable and quality education that would ensure that they complete their education with relevant skills, knowledge and competencies.Through a series of workshops, UNHCR directly reached Ukrainian refugees and raised awareness of the importance of school enrollment. It also provided information about the enrollment procedures and offered legal support related to enrollment. However, the schools are struggling with capacities, and those schools with the highest number of refugee children cannot provide sustainable and adequate support to children. Teachers also lack the capacity and skills to work with refugee children, which needs to be tackled in the upcoming period.The overall school enrollment rate among Ukrainian refugees has increased in comparison to the previous year, but it still stands low at 20-25% of children from Ukraine attending Montenegrin schools. The vast majority of refugee children from Ukraine participate in online school. UNHCR, together with the Ministry of Education and UNICEF, will continue to undertake efforts to boost the enrollment rate and provide conditions for refugee children to be able to maximise their learning outcomes.

Plan name: Turkmenistan - United Nations Partnership Framework for Development 2016-2020
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 5 - Governance and the Rule of Law
Outcome: Outcome 5.1 - OUTCOME 8: State institutions implement and monitor laws, national programmes, and strategies, in a participatory manner and in line with the country's human rights commitments
Output: Output 5.1.3 - 8.3. Awareness of children, women, men people with disabilities on human rights is increased
Sub-Output: 5.1.3.6 - Informational and educational campaigns in partnership with NGOs and POs to increase the public awareness and education on countering-trafficking, labor laws and migrants’ rights issues
Description:
Raising the awareness of people speaking local languages and those outside major and capital cities through producing and publishing information materials on the human rights (HR), and rights of VOTs (RVoT) based on the international conventions and national law of Turkmenistan, migrants’ rights (MR) and labor law; The information materials will be drafted in consultation with the National Institute of Democracy and Human Rights under the President of Turkmenistan.

Goal: To raise the awareness of general public of Turkmenistan about the risks of illegal migration and human trafficking in persons, thus, to prevent the potential risk of being trafficked; decrease the vulnerability of country's population by enhancing the understanding of international migration law, human rights, and rights of migrants and victims of trafficking. 
Objective: Combat irregular migration and human trafficking through information and education campaigns by increasing public knowledge, changing behaviour and attitudes on the issues of human trafficking by the means of traditional communication tools such as posters, leaflets, advertisements in newspapers and television commercials as well as community meetings and workshops, public forums held in schools.
Organize regular inter-agency consultations and public awareness raising on anti-human trafficking issues
Implementation partners: Institute of Democracy and Human Rights, Institute of State, Law and Democracy
SDG Targets: 8.7 Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labour, end modern slavery and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labour, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labour in all its forms.,8.8 Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.,16.a Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.
SDG Goals: 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth, 16 Peace and Justice - Strong Institutions

2021 Narrative: 150 professionals from health, education and social protection sectors nation-wide have completed 3 modules out of 6-module traning on preparation of the trans-disciplinary specialist. As part of the above training, all 9 multi-disciplinary teams , engaged in facilitation and supervision of the above training as local trainers, also provided individual support programmes for young CwD an their families in line with social model of disability. These programmes incorporate child and family assessment, development of the individual program for the child and family, monitoring and tracking of data, as well as refer and support transition of the child to a mainstream pre-school facility, and overall social inclusion of the family.
2022 Narrative: Development of early intervention services for young children with disabilities and their families was strengthened with a 6-module training program on preparation of trans-disciplinary specialists delivered for 150 childcare practitioners from health, pre-school education and social protection sectors. This in-service training package with additional modules on mental health on children and communication strengthened the knowledge and competencies required for provision of early interventions via trans-disciplinary team modality.

Plan name: Turkmenistan UNSDCF 2021 - 2025
Strategic priority: Priority C: Quality, inclusive, and affordable health, education, and social protection systems
Outcome: Outcome 5. By 2025, the education and skilling system offers all people the skills and knowledge for employment success in a diversifying economy and enhanced social integration and resilience
Output: Output 5.2. Secondary education system is strengthened to ensure the quality of education with focus on life skills (social and emotional skills, creativity, problem solving, life skills) including prof. targeting for all children
Sub-Output: Update of curricula and teaching methods in line with the competency-based approach in education
Description: Support for the introduction of competency-based education in secondary education curricula, improvement of pre-service and in-service training programs, development of a national system for assessing learning outcomes based on the competency-based education approach. Technical support to development of teaching-methodological materials based on competency-based education approach using virtual reality/augmented reality technology and educational robotics for STEAM subjects (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics).
Implementation partners: Ashgabat Education Department, TK Ministry of Education and Science, Turkmenistan National Institute of Education, Turkmenistan State Pedagogic College named after Aman Kekilov, Turkmenistan State Pedagogic Institute named after Seyitnazar Seydi
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2021 Narrative: UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education in introducing competency-based education into the national education system. The steps for initiation of the integration of competency-based approach with relevant assessment approaches for learning achievements in curricula were agreed upon with education stakeholders. In the framework of the implementation of the roadmap, UNICEF organized capacity-building training for 14 specialists who work in curriculum development and approval processes from the Ministry of Education, National Institute of Education, Pedagogical Institute and Pedagogical schools to strengthen their skills in competency-based education. In addition, 17 schoolteachers from selected pilot schools received training to strengthen their capacity in competency-based, interactive, and child-centred classroom practices to support the development of children’s functional and transferable life skills and competencies.
2022 Narrative: Ministry of Education has increased capacity in delivering competency-based curriculum at primary and secondary levels aimed at developing foundational, transferable, and digital skills. UNICEF organized trainings to strengthen national capacity in developing teaching materials aimed at formation of competencies in schoolchildren. In three selected pilot schools, 180 students in Grade 5 were taught with newly developed teaching materials based on the competency-based education approach in Maths, Turkmen language, and English language subjects.
2023 Narrative: Ministry of Education has increased capacity in delivering competency-based curriculum in STEM subjects at primary and secondary levels aimed at developing foundational, transferable, and digital skills. UNICEF organized Educational Robotics training for 27 school teachers, Educational Robotics teaching manual and video lessons were developed. UNICEF and the Ministry of Education organized a national competition in Educational Robotics in which 254 pupils participated. Development of elective course on teaching educational robotics at schools is initiated.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF concerted efforts led to establishment of a robotics club in a mainstream secondary school in Arkadag city with a set of training materials developed to promote learning in STEAM subjects (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics) and competency-based education approach. This extra-curricular activity aims to provide a platform for the Ministry of Education to further consider promotion of competency-based teaching and learning across formal curriculum. The competency-based approach was further enhanced through a series of training on information, communication, technology (ICT) skills for the graduates of the orphanages in Ashgabat and Balkanabat cities. As a result of the 2-week training programme, the graduates, both girls and boys, enhanced their life skills for further empowerment and inclusion.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Education
Sub-Output: Supporting education planning, management and learning  (e-governance)
Description:
This action funded by the Global Partnership for Education (GPE) aims at supporting the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine (MESU) in strengthening education strategic planning, management and learning in Ukraine. More specifically, the action includes four workstreams:
(1) Support establishment of unified legal framework, policies, data standards and coordination mechanisms for expansion of e-governance in education.
(2) Expand development of digital services and data systems across all levels of education for improved sector-wide education planning, management and learning.
(3) Strengthen alignment of data systems within education and their integration with government level data systems and national e-governance online services for citizens coordinated by the Ministry of Digital Transformation (MoDT).
(4) Foster evidence-based decision making by expanding analytical capabilities of the MESU data architecture.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Non-Governmental Oranizations

2023 Narrative: UNESCO has identified an implementation partner to support this activity.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, a unified legal and policy framework for education data systems was developed, along with software requirements specifications for various educational levels and a roadmap for integrating the Ministry of Digital Transformation’s framework into education governance. A quality assurance framework for IT service providers, data standards to ensure interoperability, and a costed strategy for an EMIS help desk were also finalized. To oversee and validate these outputs, an Acceptance Commission comprising MESU, government agencies, and UNESCO was established. Additionally, capacity needs of agencies working on education statistics and analytics were identified, and preparations began for implementing a management information system for technical, vocational, and extracurricular education institutions.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Education
Sub-Output: Supporting the comprehensive rehabilitation of education infrastructure in Ukraine
Description: Considering the achievements made to date under UNESCO’s Emergency Assistance Programme (July 2022 – December 2024), and in line with the priority of the MESU of creating a safe learning environment while returning to face-to-face education, UNESCO is mobilizing resources for Ukraine focusing on comprehensive school rehabilitation. Specifically, UNESCO plans to rehabilitate damaged and destroyed infrastructure of education institutions, procure the necessary furniture and equipment for classrooms, shelters and campus, ensure accessibility for people with disabilities, the installation of necessary facilities for water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) and supporting winterization of schools and shelters, including heating and insulation. Meanwhile, UNESCO plans to build or enhance schools shelters, ensuring that they meet the safety requirements set by the government. As part of these activities, UNESCO will support the creation of inclusive spaces where students and teachers can access MHPSS services, sports and physical activities, as part of the build back better approach and in consideration of the needs emerging from the current war.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation

The project served as a basis for sound chemicals management at each stage of chemical life-cycle. The outcomes of the project contributed significantly to improvement of methodological base for assessment of risks of chemicals to human health in Georgia, capacity building in the health sector, prioritization of chemicals and a pilot mapping of chemical risks.

Plan name: United Nations Transitional Framework
Strategic priority: Strengthening Systems
Outcome: Community Recovery interventions and nexus approaches in key sectors address displacement and strengthen individual and community resilience
Output: Infrastructure Reconstruction
Sub-Output: Support for Ukraine in culture and education through UNESCO: Emergency response for World Heritage and cultural property: damage assessment and protection’
Description:
Support to strengthen Ukraine’s capacity to undertake the urgent protection of cultural heritage during the ongoing war and to engage in reconstruction and enhanced protection measures. It will focus primarily on properties inscribed on the World Heritage List and sites on Ukraine’s Tentative List, which will be supported through the development of emergency preparedness and mitigations plans. 
Support for continued satellite monitoring (by scaling up the existing partnership with UNITAR/UNOSAT), which will be complemented with in-situ assessment of a selected number of damaged cultural properties to better define the necessary measures to address the most urgent protection needs. Two sites will receive special attention: Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra (part of the World Heritage Site ‘Kyiv: St Sophia Cathedral and Associated Monastic Buildings, Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra’) and the historic centre of Chernihiv.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: International Centre for the Study of the Preservation and Restoration of Cultural Property, United Nations Institute for Training and Research
SDG Targets: 11.4 Strengthen efforts to protect and safeguard the world's cultural and natural heritage.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance

Gender marker narrative: The sub-output’s contribution to gender equality is limited compared to its overall outcomes, at the same time it enables these contributions to be tracked and reported through the inclusion of indicators that capture gender-related data, disaggregation  and further analysis.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.1.1 Data generation, 3.1.2 Institutional capacity development
Human rights marker narrative: The project document identifies three elements of the human rights marker, which corresponds to the sub-result making a significant contribution to the realization of human rights.
2023 Narrative: As a pivotal starting point, two training programs were orchestrated for museum professionals, designed to introduce them to the UNESCO ICCROM Re-ORG—Collection Storage Reorganization workshop. This training represents a practical and valuable resource, equipping museum staff with the knowledge and materials to enhance storage facilities. Furthermore, this capacity-building program is now being extended to encompass university students actively contributing to the museum's efforts in reorganizing its storage spaces. To foster increased awareness regarding the museum's mission, a communication video elucidating this training program is also currently in development. Upon the successful conclusion of the workshop, two prominent international experts that support UNESCO in the context of emergencies, namely Mr SAYED Abdelhamid Salah Abdelhamid and Ms Hebatallah Mohamed Helmy Abdelhamid, will furnish UNESCO with a comprehensive needs assessment, highlighting the equipment required to elevate the museum's storage facilities to the desired standards.
2024 Narrative: As of November 2024, UNESCO has verified damage to 468 sites since 24 February 2022 -– 145 religious sites, 238 buildings of historical and/or artistic interest, 32 museums, 33 monuments, 17 libraries, 1 archive and 2 archaeological sites. Moreover, first-aid equipment was installed on 11 buildings (8 in Odesa, 2 in Kyiv, and 1 in L'viv) to monitor the dynamic of cracks, caused by missile attacks, and inform upcoming repair/restoration activities. In 2024, UNESCO and ICCROM implemented a joint damage assessment mission to assess 7 priority sites and held 4 online thematic meetings with the dedicated Working Group of 12 heritage experts established by Ministry of Culture and Strategic Communications of Ukraine. In addition, 2 joint UNESCO/ICOMOS missions were organised to Chernihiv to provide technical assistance in the development of the Plan and capacity building training for 31 participants, including representatives from the Ministry and Chernihiv Regional Administration. The aim of the second mission was to conduct the advanced documentation of the Chernihiv Drama Theatre, including on-the-job training for 11 students and 2 professors from Chernihiv Polytechnic.  UNESCO and ICOMOS also implemented documentation work at Saint-Sophia Cathedral, the Bell Tower and Metropolitain's house, including on-job capacity building sessions on proceeding and collecting 3D data, and developing guidelines for emergency preparedness plans. The final UNESCO-ICOMOS documentation mission in 2024 at the World Heritage property ‘Wooden Tserkvas of the Carpathian Region in Poland and Ukraine’ included on job capacity building sessions on proceeding and collecting 3D data, and on developing guidelines for emergency preparedness plans.

2021 Narrative: UNICEF concerted advocacy efforts with the Government resulted in establishment of the inter-ministerial Working group (MoE, Mejlis, MoHMI amd MoLSP) to lead the process of development of the national concept of inclusive education (IE) in line with the country’s commitment under the National Plan of Action for Realization of Children’s rights in Turkmenistan for 2018 – 2022. A series of 13 technical webinars on IE strengthened capacity of the Working group WG to lead the above process which and also included training on the principles of inclusive education and child-centered pedagogy.  As a result, the national concept of IE with the detailed Action Plan was developed by the WG with close technical assistance from the international expert (Ms. Filomena Pereira, Head of inclusive education unit, Ministry of Education of Portugal) for finalization, approval by the Government, and further initiation in 2022. Due to pandemic related restrictions, the planned introduction of the principles of IE in selected mainstream education facilities and study visit on IE were cancelled.
2022 Narrative: In 2022, as a result of continued UNICEF technical assistance to the national inter-ministerial Working Group on inclusive education coordinated by the MoE, the national concept of Inclusive Education (IE) for 2023-2028 was developed and ready for finalization and adoption. Support for building initial capacity of pedagogical professionals on promoting inclusive learning environment and inclusive pedagogy led to development of a training course on inclusive education for introduction in the menu of in-service trainings for teachers at the National Institute of Education in 2023.
2023 Narrative: The national concept of IE with the Action Plan is finalized by the MoE with engagement from the MoHMI and MoLSP, with the Government to proceed with the approval process. UNICEF assisted the first-ever Turkmen text-to-speech voice was developed that can be installed in screen-reader assistive software for visually impaired people, including children, to access digital education materials, to use computers and smartphones, and overall contribute to promoting inclusive education practices.
2024 Narrative: Piloting of inclusive education principles was initiated in 4 mainstream education facilities in Ashgabat city (2 kindergartens and 2 secondary schools) to focus on building capacity of teachers and multi-disciplinary professionals for inclusive teaching, learning and supporting the students with disabilities, providing assistive devices for the target children, improving physical infrastructure for accessibility as well as promoting a welcoming and supportive environment for children with disabilities and their families.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Sustainable, climate-responsible and resilient development
Outcome: Outcome 5. By 2025, the most at risk regions and communities of Uzbekistan are more resilient to climate change and disasters, and benefit from increasingly sustainable and gender-sensitive efficient management of natural resources and infrastructure, robust climate action, inclusive environmental governance and protection.
Output: Output 5.3. Governance system capacity and regulatory framework on Disaster Risk Reduction and natural/cultural heritage protection are strengthened to effectively deliver on obligations under the Sendai Framework on DRR and related Conventions
Sub-Output: Strengthening DRR & CC in education
Description: Strategies for strengthening DRR & CC in education and draft models for establishing school environment clubs to address DRR and CC issues are developed. UNICEF introduced DRR themes and related messages in teaching and learning materials for primary and secondary grades through training of curriculum experts and textbook writers.
Implementation partners: Uzbekistan Ministry of Emergency Situations, Uzbekistan Ministry of Preschool and School Education
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: Identification and prepositioning of essential emergency supplies.·        On December 1, 2021, UNICEF and the Red Crescent Society of Uzbekistan signed a Programme Cooperation Agreement.·        UNICEF Country Office has procured the following kits for the preparedness measures: the Early Childhood Development (ECD) Kit in the amount of 45 kits, Family Hygiene and Dignity kit in the amount of 400 kits, Recreation kit for individual and team sports in the amount of 25 kits, School-in-a-box, 40 students in the amount of 45 kits, and WASH  Dignity Kit, First Response, 5 Households, with Water Purification Tablets in the amount of 175 kits. Thus, UNICEF and the Red Crescent Society of Uzbekistan are ready to support more than 8,000 people in total, including 2,000 households and 5,000 children.·        UNICEF and the Red Crescent Society of Uzbekistan supported 183 families, comprising 438 males and 474 females, by providing locally assembled Family Hygiene and Dignity Kits during the extreme cold weather in 2023. ·        UNICEF and the Red Crescent Society of Uzbekistan supported 110 families, including 237 males and 316 females, by providing locally assembled Family Hygiene and Dignity Kits during the mudflows in Samarkand, Bulungur, and Tailan districts in April 2023.WASH preparedness activities·        In Uzbekistan, UNICEF supported the review of the national WASH in Emergencies legislation and policies, mapping WASH actors' capacities in emergencies and the development of recommendations for the WASH sector preparedness and response planning and coordination. In addition, 190 school technical staff, teachers and schoolchildren from Tashkent and Termez cities, Chirchiq, Yuqorichirchiq, Kasansai and Bulungur districts improved their knowledge and understanding about the importance of accessing clean and safe drinking water, adequate and accessible sanitation facilities, proper hygiene practices, regular handwashing, proper waste disposal, and functionality and cleanliness of WASH facilities in schools in emergencies. They were also involved in behaviour change exercises linked to promoting and practising effective WASH habits in emergencies to prevent the spread of infectious diseases and create a healthier learning environment.
2023 Narrative: Development of country specific GBV risk mitigation strategy and capacity development in GiE and GBV risk mitigation·        UNICEF in Uzbekistan organized two workshops in Tashkent and Samarkand for 50 national stakeholders, representatives of the education sector and the Ministry of Emergency Situations dedicated to building capacity on the GBV safety audit tool through the lens of GBV prevention, gender awareness and prevention of GBV in emergencies. In addition, UNICEF in Uzbekistan led a brainstorming session on gender barriers to integrating gender into national emergency plans.Development and testing of a well-functioning gender-responsive complaint and feedback mechanism (AAP)·        In Uzbekistan, UNICEF developed and tested a well-functioning gender response complaint and feedback mechanism to ensure accountability to affected populations. The Uzbekistan disaster response framework, including the government tools and systems for AAP/CEA, was reviewed to identify entry points for incorporating and managing the feedback and complaint mechanism. This review helped map out the strengths and gaps of the existing AAP/CEA systems, including their alignment with international standards and the extent to which the tools and systems are accessible to all affected populations, including vulnerable groups. The review also reflected on inclusivity, gender, language and cultural sensitivity. The proposed new and improved tools were presented to the staff of MES and RCSU.Disaster and Climate Risk Reduction (DRR): DRR interventions and school safety enhance preparedness for possible disasters and reduce their impact on children and their communities. ·        Ten schools, namely: School No. 17 and School No. 25 in Samarkand Region, School No. 83 and School No. 154 in Tashkent city, School No. 2 and School No. 35 in Tashkent Region, School No. 1 and Boarding School No. 45 (a school for visually impaired children) in Namangan Region, and School No. 7 and School No. 26 in Surkhandarya Region, have been identified as the most vulnerable schools in the target regions.·        2,380 school administrators and teachers (1270 female, 1110 male) were trained in DRM, climate action, reducing non-structural risks, and inclusive and gender-sensitive approaches in school DRM planning.·        School DRR teams were established in each school, and risk and vulnerability assessments were conducted to determine the climatic-geographical, socio-economic, and engineering-technical features of those vulnerable regions and target schools.·        An inclusive school DRM and Climate Action training package was introduced to schools through workshops, seminars, simulation exercises, and evacuation drills.·        School DRM plans were developed and non-structural risks were assessed with the engagement of teachers and students.·        1,715 students (787 girls and 928 boys, including 72 boys and 48 girls with disabilities) benefited from their engagement and participation in the school DRR learning and practicing interventions.Youth Engagement: Young volunteers, adolescent girls and boys in disaster risk-prone areas engaged in community DRR, climate change, disaster preparedness and comprehensive school safety.  In Uzbekistan, UNICEF partnered with ICP to engage young volunteers, adolescent girls and boys in ten selected target schools from Tashkent and Termez cities, Chirchiq, Yuqorichirchiq, Kasansai and Bulungur districts in community DRR, climate change adaptation, disaster preparedness, and comprehensive school safety. Three-day training seminars were organized in Tashkent and Samarkand for 45 teachers from target schools in two cohorts on 21st-century skills, time management, stress management, DRR and climate change. Furthermore, ICP organized five training seminars for 232 (125 boys, 107 girls) adolescent girls and boys, members of newly established School DRR clubs in each target school for engaging in community resilience and school safety, including search and rescue operations and first aid. 125 volunteers of RCSU, in turn, supported the School DRR Clubs to conduct simulations and drills on how to act in emergency situations. Finally, the trained teachers and RCSU volunteers organized seminars on youth engagement and action planning for the school DRR club members. As a result, the schoolchildren from the School DRR Clubs in the target schools engaged in community and school observations, interviews with teachers, parents and community members, and reviews of school preparedness plans. The School DRR Club members developed their school hazard profiles, drafted action plans to improve disaster preparedness, and showcased them to the school community members.Shock Responsive Social Protection: Support the development of coordination, governance, financing, and/or programme design for social protection in emergencies in all five Central Asian countries. In Uzbekistan, UNICEF supported the government to strengthen preparedness of the national humanitarian and social protection systems to respond to shocks through several activities. This includes: (1)  Updating an assessment of the national system’s readiness to activate emergency cash support protocols to reach affected households. The assessment has been accomplishing using the CADRI Social Protection Assessment tool with a combination of desk review and key informant interviews. The final report suggests on potential opportunities, barriers, and detailed recommendations (along policy, programmatic, systems, and related dimensions) for improving the delivery of humanitarian cash transfers in Uzbekistan. (2)  in-depth review of the legal system pertaining to humanitarian and social protection system. In particular, the review presents results of exploration of existing national legislation and concrete recommendations in regard the amendments required for the social protection system to be able to scale up cash assistance as part of a national humanitarian response. A validation workshop has been conducted in participation of key stakeholders to present preliminary findings and recommendations of above two assessments as well as to collect feedbacks of national partners in regard prioritising the further steps based on feasibility and importance.(3)  Training Workshop on Scaling Up Emergency Cash Transfers in Response to Emergency Situations has been conducted for government counterparts in Uzbekistan during the period of 17-19 July 2023. More than 25 key staff representing 16 ministries and agencies, responsible for humanitarian response in case of emergency situations participated in 3-day training. The training was adapted to local context and was articulated around a series of applied thematic sessions, which exposed participants to practical operational issues when designing and delivering emergency cash transfers through the national social protection system in response to emergencies. (4)  Initial assessment of the role of cash transfers and other social protection responses to climate-induced heatwaves has been conducted, considering that it is one of the biggest hazards in Uzbekistan. According to UNICEF’s Children Climate Risk Index, 9.6 million children under 18 are exposed to heatwaves in Uzbekistan or 91% of the children. In the context of climate change, the severity, duration, and intensity of these events are expected to increase, impacting the lives and livelihoods of millions of children and their families. Yet, globally, the linkages between shock-responsive social protection, including using cash transfers as a response mechanism, are under-researched. In this regard, data collection has been conducted, which was followed by a rapid literature review and development of a report looking at the potential role of cash transfers in response to climate-induced heat waves and recommendations on the ways forward.

Outcome: Outcome 5. By 2025, the education and skilling system offers all people the skills and knowledge for employment success in a diversifying economy and enhanced social integration and resilience
Output: Output 5.3. Capacities and mechanisms are in place to ensure the effective implementation of the national programme on inclusive education

Description: Support for the implementation of the Education Management Information System (EMIS) in pilot schools, development and approval of normative regulations on EMIS in education sphere.
Implementation partners: Turkmenistan Ministry of Education, Turkmenistan National Institute of Education
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.,4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.,4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2021 Narrative:
"
An introductory online Capacity building workshop on EMIS was held in collaboration with the National Commission for UNESCO and UNESCO Bangkok office on 18-19 October 2021 in Turkmenistan. This workshop created a forum for discussion on available EMIS in Turkmenistan and spaces to improve the system. More than 40 participants from different organizations of Turkmenistan including representatives from the Ministry of Education, state statistics committee, state institutes and academies and universities in Turkmenistan. Experts from UIS and UNESCO Bangkok provided technical presentation on EMIS. The workshop also benefited from a presentation by Kazakhstan as one of the best practices on EMIS in the region. Discussions have been ongoing with UNICEF for further cooperation in the future.
"
2022 Narrative: The national education system continued to develop its capacity in collecting and using data in education management through initiating the development of Education Management Information System (EMIS). Evidence was generated on the state of the existing national EMIS using the SABER-EMIS framework. The evidence generated was used in drafting EMIS development action plan and supporting the policy dialogue at the Ministry of Education level for its approval and implementation. The foundational modules of EMIS software application were developed and delivered to the Ministry of Education and installed on test server. Foundational capacity in EMIS at various levels of the education system was strengthened through capacity-building.
2023 Narrative: The capacity of the national education system in education data management was strengthened. 25 national specialists were trained in the foundations of EMIS and using the pilot Education Management Information System of the Ministry of Education. Data collection modules of the pilot EMIS were improved. Draft EMIS regulations of the Ministry of Education developed.
2024 Narrative: Initial capacity development for including children with disabilities into EMIS was organized as part of piloting of inclusive education principles initiated in 4 mainstream education facilities in Ashgabat city (2 kindergartens and 2 secondary schools).

2021 Narrative: To bridge the education and labour market gaps, UNDP in 2021 renovated four laboratories in regional Vocational Educational Institutions that now provide a labour market responsive training to local youth in culinary, sewing, milk processing and veterinary. Overall, 100 youth (60% women) were trained in upgraded vocational education facilities. Two more models were introduced as part of market-responsive Vocational Education and Training (VET), including VET-employer partnership models in milk processing and light industry sectors. Awareness raising and educational Kolba Job platform was launched, which is currently used by 10,000 online users providing information about self-employment, freelance, and remote labour market opportunities.

Description: The Education Sector Plan will comprise a long-term Education Sector Strategy Education 2030 and a medium-term Programme for its implementation 2021-2025. It will be based on the key findings and recommendations from the Education Sector Analysis (ESA) undertaken in 2019, a solid, nationally owned analysis of the challenges in delivering quality education in Moldova. The ESP will determine a long-term vision, based on the ESA and linked to the National Development Strategy ‘Moldova 2030’,  SDG nationalized agenda, EU Association Agreement priorities focusing on  quality of teaching and teachers, education environment, learning outcomes and competencies aligned to the labour market and other international commitments of Moldova government in line with government’s primary responsibility to ensure the right to education for all and the national legal provisions for compulsory education

Once approved, the ESP will inform the revision of Curricula, Early Learning and Development Standards, Child Friendly Scholl Standards, learning assessments, and serve to better coordinate partners and mobilize additional domestic and external resources.

SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,5.3 Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.,5.4 Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.,5.a Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
"UNFPA supported 4 Youth Centers (implemented by Youth Approached in Health Association) and 1 Women and Youth Support Center (in collaboration with Ankara Metropolitan Municipality) in 2021. In all 5 five service units, beneficiaries who are mostly refugee women and young people have been provided with empowerment activities including life skills education, Turkish language courses, mentoring, economic empowerment activities including home-based work, Turkish conversation clubs and recreational activities. The empowerment activities have been conducted by the service providers of the service units in partnership with provincial partners such as public education centers of MONE, municipalities and TÖMER which provide A1-A2-B1 level of language courses. Youth Centers have started to collaborate with the Provincial İŞKURs (Turkish Employment Agency) and Metropolitan Municipality’s employment centers to apply and enroll the beneficiaries in the certificate programmes. In Ankara, synergies have been established with the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality's Turkish language courses and International Vocational Courses Center (UMEM) for vocational training programmes. 
The Youth Centers conducted a digital story telling activity with the aim to develop the participants' capacity on sexual and reproductive health (SRH) and gender based violence (GBV), as well as building their skills on script writing and storytelling. At the end of the training, the participants came out with the scripts to be converted into short animation movies, conveying messages on SRH and GBV, to create awareness among their peers. As a result, the participants created 4 scripts to be crafted as short animations, with the following subjects: gender-based violence, peer bullying, sexually transmitted infections and family planning methods. The animations were broadcasted in the Project’s website (https://www.gencmulteciler.org/en/english/) and social media accounts, and were disseminated through telephone networks such as Whatsapp, reaching out to the beneficiaries."

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls, Youth
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to partner with the Ministry of Education (MOE) through multi-year inclusive education project, focused on enabling all children to learn in their community schools and kindergartens. Key interventions included developing normative frameworks, educational standards and programmes for children, and strengthening the education system’s capacity to prepare teachers for inclusive practices.A National Strategy for Inclusive Education and Action Plan was drafted and submitted to the MOE for approval. A gender review of the Inclusive Education (IE) Strategy was conducted, with recommendations integrated into the document. In addition, a legal provision to establish inclusive education resource centers was developed and submitted to the MOE. Four educational standards for pre-school and secondary education, criteria assessment of early complex assistance, and translation of publications into accessible formats were also established to ensure consistent and quality implementation of inclusive practices across educational institutions. Methodological materials covering career orientation for children with disabilities and recommendations on how to conduct flexible assessments of student’s knowledge and skills were developed.UNICEF in partnership with the Republican Institute of Professional Education and the Belarus State Pedagogical University updated educational standards, curricula, and pre-service training programmes for student teachers. Becoming a mandatory training for all student teachers from September 2023, these programmes will ensure that all future educators are equipped with knowledge and skills for inclusive teaching. Two new methodologies on inclusive education practices will be integrated into curricula for special education students, who are being trained for work in resource centers for inclusive education, psycho-medico-pedagogical commissions, and early complex assistance services. The Academy of Post Graduate Education (APE) introduced training programmes including an online course on inclusive education into their in-service curriculum in 2023-2024 and tested them with educators and practitioners.One hundred eighteen (118) schools and kindergartens from all over Belarus were selected for piloting new curricula, educational standards and support system of the network of inclusive education resource centers. A needs assessment in each school and kindergarten for assistive devices and technologies for children with special education needs was conducted. UNICEF started procurement of required assistive equipment to be completed in 2024.Three study tours to Russia to learn best inclusive education practices for representatives of the MOE (including Deputy Minister of Education), National Institute of Education (NIO), Republican Institute of Professional Education, Academy of Post Graduate Education, Belarus State Pedagogical University, Deputy Heads of Oblast Education Departments, and school and pre-school directors were conducted.

Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: The Global Environment Facility, UNESCO Regular Programme
Implementation partners: Committee on Environmental Protection under the Government of Tajikistan, Tajikistan Academy of Science, Tajikistan Agency for Hydrometeorology
SDG Targets: 6.a By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacitybuilding support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.,6.5 By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: •	Local scientists, academia and youth representatives were brought together in a national workshop to review the country's perspectives on cryosphere, water resources and climate change and identify the national priorities and related impact to facilitate the development of a comprehensive Diagnostic Analysis of cryosphere in Tajikistan. A situational analysis for Tajikistan’s cryosphere dynamics was developed to inform further adaptation actions, and a comprehensive Diagnostic Analysis is currently under development.•	Cryosphere change scenarios projecting glacial degradation in Tajikistan from 2000 to 2100 were developed, with a focus on glacier evolution and meltwater contribution to major Central Asian rivers.•	A policy brief on the current state of cryosphere and its impact on water availability in Central Asia, incl. Tajikistan, was developed to inform policy- and decision-makers about the effects of climate change on the cryosphere and the critical role of monitoring in supporting effective water management.•	UNESCO, in cooperation with UNRCCA and GIZ, supported the Government’s efforts in promoting its glaciers agenda by co-organizing an International Glaciers Forum in Dushanbe in the framework of the 3rd High-Level International Conference on the International Decade for Action “Water for Sustainable Development” 2018-2028. The event provided a platform for governments, scientists and development partners to discuss the joint efforts and commitments, fostering regional and global cooperation in the preservation of glaciers and adaptation to climate change in Tajikistan and Central Asia in general.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Human capital development, reducing vulnerability, social inclusion
Outcome: By 2027, all people, especially the vulnerable, benefit from strengthened human capital including early childhood development, and more resilient, gender-responsive, and quality healthcare and education
Output: 3.2. Quality education
Sub-Output: Facilitate the certificate recognition for refugees to ensure that their prior learning was recognized and valorized in education and employment
Description:
Following UNHCR's advocacy efforts, the Ministry of Education, Science, and Innovation agreed to propose an amendment to the Law on Recognition of Foreign Diplomas and Qualifications. This amendment acknowledges that refugees cannot always obtain all the documents necessary for the recognition of foreign diplomas as required by regular procedures. The new provision will ensure that the rejection of an application for the recognition of foreign educational documents and qualifications cannot be based solely on the absence of official documents proving a certain foreign professional qualification. This change aligns with the Law on International and Temporary Protection of Foreigners. The adoption of these legal changes is expected in 2025.
Consequently, the Ministry of Education has started collaborating with the Council of Europe to determine the manner of establishing qualifications and skills for refugees who do not possess the respective educational certificates (prior test). UNHCR will continue to make significant effort to contribute to the adoption of this procedure.
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro, NGO Civic Alliance Montenegro, NGO Red Cross Montenegro
SDG Targets: 4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.
