2023 Narrative: The measure has not been implemented yet, but UNHCR remains committed to ensuring that the recognition of qualifications for refugees is aligned with international standards in this regard. For this purpose, it has established cooperation with the national ENIC Centre of the Ministry of Education and ensured that this activity remains a part of the 2023-2024 AP for the Strategy of Migration covering 2021-2025.
2024 Narrative: Support adaptation of the legal framework governing the recognition of foreign diplomas, since refugees, due to the nature of their status cannot obtain all the documents necessary for the recognition of foreign diplomas as in regular procedures. The decision to reject an application for recognition of foreign educational documents and qualifications cannot be based solely on the fact that there are no official documents proving a certain foreign professional qualification. UNHCR is in communication with the Ministry of Education in Amending the respective law and ensure the most favorable standards for refugees in this regard.

Description: Provision of psychosocial and parenting support services for children and caregivers, provision of non-formal learning and social inclusion activities, programmes with CSOs on provision of  psychosocial support to refugee and migrant children and families, prevention of GBV and violence against children and women,  increased level of knowledge and information about PSEA policies as well as available support services on local and national level and gender based violence  and VaC prevention.
Implementation partners: Ministry of Education Montenegro, Ministry of Interior Montenegro, NGO Red Cross Montenegro, NGO Ukrainian association Dobro djelo
SDG Targets: 16.2 End abuse, exploitations, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Gender marker narrative: Since the majority of refugees targeted are women and children, the suboutput focuses on gender-sensitive programming in all sectors of support.
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Protecting refugee and migrant children and women rights and providing them with essential services are at the core of the suboutput.
LNOB groups targeted: Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Children , Women & Girls
2023 Narrative: To help children and families cope with stress, UNICEF partnered with the Red Cross that regularly conducts psychosocial support activities for most vulnerable families. At the meetings, parents and children spend time together, participate in creative workshops, communicate with other families. UNICEF supported ukrainian NGO Dobro Djelo to organize workshops with clinical psychologist, cognitive-behavioural therapist and trauma expert where children and caregivers were provided with mental health and psychosocial support. In the reporting period, 389 children and caregivers have benefited from these activities. In cooperation with several women NGOs, 214 women, girls and boys were provided information on how to access GBV risk mitigation, prevention and/or response interventions. 13 most vulnerable children have continued to received individual case management from Red Cross and other NGOs specialized staff. As part of the UNICEF and Ministry Education programme, supportive Ukrainian speaking staff in the schools with the most refugee children are engaged and trained to support children in learning. Learning material on the Digital Scholl platform translated in Ukrainian language and prepared to be shared with refugee children and families. Psychosocial support was provided to 186 children through implementing group workshops based on the standardized package ‘’Empower yourself” while individual sessions were provided to 6 children. Furniture and IT equipment was procured for 6 primary schools and 4 preschools to support enrollment and quality conditions for children from Ukraine. Through the creation of a web service between the databases of the Ministry of Interior and the Ministry of Education, to enable the identification of children who are in Montenegro, are of school age but are not enrolled the system is identifying the refugee out-of-school children (OOSC).  A total of 505 Ukrainian children currently enrolled in formal education system are benefiting from the set of activities implemented by the Ministry of Education with UNICEF support. Classrooms open to children from foreign countries | UNICEF UNICEF supported Ukrainian NGO Dobro Djelo to organize non-formal education support, including early learning (Montessori educational group for children; art classes; music classes, Ukrainian Saturday school for first grades students;) with additional 113 children benefiting from non-formal learning support and provided with learning materials. UNICEF, in collaboration with the Ministry of Health is supporting 5 PHCs in the 5 cities where the vast majority of the refugees live. Thus far the PHCs organized training for all PHC on health services and entitlements for the refugees and piloted breastfeeding counselling centres in the 5 municipalities. The PHCs have also produced and disseminated information material for parents on the Montenegrin immunization calendar, breastfeeding and breastfeeding counselling centres, and on the Bebbo mobile app for parents. The PHCs have also introduced an online feedback mechanism for refugees using the UNICEF data collection platform InForm.  776 refugees were supported and provided with primary health services with UNICEF support to the Ministry of Health and 5 primary health centers focusing on the following priorities: Strengthen the knowledge and communication skills of healthcare workers for working with refugees. Facilitate the communication of refugees with the health system Facilitate the access of refugees to health care, with a special emphasis on the care of mothers, babies and small children. Facilitate the identification and overcoming of possible difficulties that may arise when refuges are accessing health care through mechanisms for providing feedback in Ukrainian and Russian languages.  Through support coming from UNICEF, Institute for public health of Montenegro has intensified work on strengthening HIV/AIDS testing services on primary health care level as well as treatment and clinical management on secondary and tertiary level of health care. At the same Institute for public health has distributed around 700 rapid tests for anti-HIV 1/2 antibodies, HBsAg tests and anti-HCV antibody tests.  27 mothers from Ukraine were supported with breastfeeding and young children and infant nutrition counseling in the primary health centeres.  With UNICEF support, Ukrainian NGO Dobro djelo organized 2 educational groups held by specialist staff for pregnant women and parents of newborn babies. With UNICEF support, primary health centers in 5 municipalities have introduced an online feedback mechanism for refugees using the UNICEF data collection platform InForm. Through this service refugees have the opportunity to provide feedback and complaint on the health services and based on that the institutions should plan follow-up actions.  UNICEF supported the Ukrainan women NGO Dobro Djelo to establish a helpline for feedback and complaints, sharing concerns and asking questions benefiting 64 people in the reporting period (in total 695) out of which close to 80 % were women. The cooperation with NGO Dobro Djelo, enabled UNICEF to be in direct contact with the affected population with focus on women and children which contributed to a more inclusive overall refugee response.  UNICEF supported ukrainian NGO Dobro Djelo to organize non-formal education support and inclusion activities such as : course on sexual education; chess classes, basketball trainings for children; tennis group trainings, Christmas event (500 guests); music concert;)  Since both gender-based violence and human trafficking are forms of violence, in which the perpetrators use a series of manipulation techniques, the victims themselves are often not even aware that they are victims. That is why, the UNICEF supported NGO Womens Right Center designed the brochure "There is a Way Out", which provides knowledge about these issues. The brochure has been translated into Ukrainian, Russian and English, which makes it accessible to a large number of migrant and refugee women. The brochure was printed in 1050 copies and distributed to the final target group through the departments of the Ministry of Internal Affairs in Budva and Podgorica that work directly with migrants, asylum seekers and refugees. Links available below:   https://womensrightscenter.org/en/there-is-a-way-out-brochure-for-migrant-women-facing-violence/
2024 Narrative: No activities focused on support to refugee and migrant children implemented due to lack of funding.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.3_Public institutions and CSOs/CBOs have enhanced capacities to ensure quality sustainable people-centered service delivery that is responsive to social, economic and environmental shocks and emergencies
Sub-Output: (UNFPA) Strengthened capacity of the Vocational Education and Training system/schools to deliver quality life skills education and create an enabling environment for students’ wellbeing and job readiness.
Description:
Over the last years, UNFPA has been supporting Vocational Education and Training (VET) to increase the quality-of-life skills-based health education and create safe and friendly school spaces so young people can develop healthy behaviors and increase their job readiness. 

In 2023, UNFPA will continue its work in this area and will invest in developing a continuous training programme for teachers in VET on health education; developing the teachers' handbook for the ‘Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle’, based on the recently revised curriculum; support the functionality and capacity building of the Network of Peer Educators in VET to reach out to 2000 VET students with informative activities on healthy behaviors, mental health, sexuality, and reproductive health and rights, etc.; analyze knowledge, attitudes, and practices related to sexual and reproductive health among students in VET.

During the period 2024–2025, the focus will be on strengthening the capacity of teachers delivering the Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle course across all VET institutions by accrediting the continuous training program. Additionally, efforts will be made to equip schools with edutainment materials and menstrual hygiene products, as well as create a youth friendly learning classroom in 20 targeted VET institutions endowed with IT equipment.

Furthermore, support will be provided to strengthen the Peer Educators Network in promoting life skills education and increase capacity of business companies from dual VET in creating a youth-friendly workplace. A dedicated training program will also be organized for nurses, psychologists, and social pedagogues working within VET institutions to enhance their ability to support students' well-being.
A parenting program will be developed and implemented to engage parents of VET students in supporting their children's education and development. At the same time, Youth Centers will receive support in designing and implementing career guidance and employability skills programs, ensuring that young people are better prepared for their transition into the labor market. 

The support will continue by 2027, with other strategic and system-wide interventions with support from the Austrian Development Agency.
Contributing partners: Austrian Development Agency, UNFPA Core funds
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Education and Research

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The Project's interventions are designed in response to existing data that highlights the inadequate and insufficient sexuality education currently being provided in Moldovan schools: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qgQL606-nwQnOZgEoZHr59hhqTl2jpXu/edit#heading=h.gjdgxs The interventions will have direct contribution to girls bodily autonomy, empowerment to make informed decisions about their personal and professional life. The  Project interventions aims at contributing to reduction of adolescents teens pregnancy and integration of menstrual health and hygiene in vocational schools.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Contributes strongly to sexual and reproductive rights of young people
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNFPA with support from the Austrian Development Agency and in partnership with the Ministry of Education and Research, continued to support vocational-technical education to help students develop healthily and harmoniously. The investments were mainly focused on 12 VET schools. Two Centers of Excellence from the VET system were supported to develop a continuous training programme for teachers in VET on health education based on the curriculum that was revised with UNFPA support in 2022. The curriculum of the "Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle" course was revised, didactic support was developed, as well as a continuous training program for teaching staff was institutionalized. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/school-career-students-technical-vocational-education-better-prepared-employment-through Youth-friendly spaces for learning and personal development were created for students in the dormitories of 12 vocational schools. The Network of Peer-to-Peer Educators Vocational Education and Training organized about 192 information activities regarding the development of life skills for almost 6279 girls and boys. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/teachers-and-students-vocational-institutions-speak-importance-life-skills-education-their
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNFPA, with the support of the Austrian Development Agency and in collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Research, continued its efforts to enhance the vocational-technical education system in Moldova, promoting the healthy and holistic development of students.Advancing Teacher Training in Health EducationTwo Centers of Excellence within the VET system implemented a continuous training program for teachers, grounded in the health education curriculum revised with UNFPA support in 2022. This initiative strengthened the capacity of 48 VET institutions to deliver life skills development activities with 64 teachers across all VET institutions trained to teach the course "Decisions for a Healthy Lifestyle." https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/two-centers-excellence-moldova-are-accredited-conduct-continuing-training-programs-life-skills Equipping Schools with Educational ResourcesAll 79  vocational schools, colleges, and centers of excellence received educational resources to facilitate and enrich the life skills and comprehensive sexuality education delivered by teachers. Each institution was equipped with an EduLIFE box containing interactive materials such as board games, puzzles, cards, teachers’ guides, posters, etc. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/educational-resources-and-menstrual-hygiene-products-worth-approximately-15-million-mdlImplementing Menstrual Health and Hygiene Programme in the VET systemTo ensure equal opportunities for girls students from VET to attend schools and exercise their right to education, all vocational institutions have been equipped with dispensers and free menstrual hygiene products. A pilot program conducted by UNFPA in 2023 in four general education schools demonstrated that health education and free access to menstrual hygiene products significantly reduce absenteeism among girls and decrease bullying incidents. Results showed that after installing sanitary pad dispensers, the percentage of girls missing classes due to menstruation dropped over fourfold—from 55.2% to 12.5%. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/educational-resources-and-menstrual-hygiene-products-worth-approximately-15-million-mdlExpanding Peer-to-Peer EducationThe Network of Peer-to-Peer Educators on Life Skills in Vocational Education and Training expanded to 20 institutions under the program “Connecting Youth with Jobs through Life Skills Development in Moldova.” Peer educators conducted approximately 200 activities, reaching 9,324 students (both girls and boys) with essential information on life skills development. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/network-young-peer-educators-expands-20-vocational-technical-institutions-across-countryPiloting Training for the private sector on Youth-Friendly WorkplacesA training program for dual education business companies focused on creating violence-free and youth-friendly workplaces was successfully piloted in partnership with the National Chamber of Commerce and Industry. It trained 24 national trainers, who in turn prepared 27 master instructors from 20 dual education companies to champion these practices within their organizations.https://chamber.md/maistrii-instructori-vor-crea-si-promova-spatii-prietenoase-pentru-tineri/

This will also include work in relation to curriculum reform and support to teachers in promoting skills among children and youth

SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.

Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 5.3 Output 5.3. Governance system capacity and regulatory framework on Disaster Risk Reduction and natural/cultural heritage protection are strengthened to effectively deliver on obligations under the Sendai Framework on DRR and related Conventions
2023 Narrative: In Uzbekistan, UNICEF partnered with ICP to engage young volunteers, adolescent girls and boys in ten selected target schools from Tashkent and Termez cities, Chirchiq, Yuqorichirchiq, Kasansai and Bulungur districts in community DRR, climate change adaptation, disaster preparedness, and comprehensive school safety. Three-day training seminars were organized in Tashkent and Samarkand for 45 teachers from target schools in two cohorts on 21st-century skills, time management, stress management, DRR and climate change. Furthermore, ICP organized five training seminars for 232 (125 boys, 107 girls) adolescent girls and boys, members of newly established School DRR clubs in each target school for engaging in community resilience and school safety, including search and rescue operations and first aid. 125 volunteers of RCSU, in turn, supported the School DRR Clubs to conduct simulations and drills on how to act in emergency situations. Finally, the trained teachers and RCSU volunteers organized seminars on youth engagement and action planning for the school DRR club members. As a result, the schoolchildren from the School DRR Clubs in the target schools engaged in community and school observations, interviews with teachers, parents and community members, and reviews of school preparedness plans. The School DRR Club members developed their school hazard profiles, drafted action plans to improve disaster preparedness, and showcased them to the school community members.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Climate change, sustainable environment and livable cities
Outcome: 3.1 By 2025, all relevant actors take measures to accelerate climate action, to promote responsible production and consumption, to improve the management of risks and threats to people, to ensure sustainable management of the environment and natural resources in urban and ecosystem hinterlands.
Output: Output 3.1.4 Green innovations and climate friendly technologies for circular economy, sustainable production and consumption, are prototyped and scaled at sectoral, urban and rural level.
Sub-Output: 3.1.4.14 Develop and prototype green innovations and climate-friendly technologies, implement and scale pilot projects across various sectors and regions, engage with stakeholders to adopt sustainable practices, provide training and resources, monitor and evaluate impacts, and promote circular economy principles through educational initiatives.
Description: This activity aims to spearhead the adoption of green innovations and technologies in the agriculture sector that contribute to a circular economy, emphasizing sustainable production and consumption. The activities under this output involve developing prototypes of new technologies that can minimize environmental impact of the production system and enhance resource efficiency. These prototypes are tested through pilot projects in various settings, from urban centers to rural areas, to ensure their effectiveness and adaptability. Successful prototypes are then scaled up, with a focus on widespread application and integration into existing systems. By working closely with local businesses, municipalities, and communities, the project fosters a collaborative approach to sustainability. Training programs and resources are provided to stakeholders to facilitate the transition to greener practices. Continuous monitoring and evaluation help measure the success and impact of these innovations, ensuring they contribute to a sustainable and resilient economy
Contributing partners: The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration
Implementation partners: Adana Metropolitan Municipality

Implementation partners: Armenia Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport
SDG Targets: 1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.,4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
SDG Goals: 1 No Poverty, 4 Quality Education, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Geography: Vayots Dzor, Syunik, Kotayk, Gegharkunik, Armenia
QCPR function: Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing, Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: UNDP facilitated availability of up-to-date labor market information for decision-makers in charge of reforms in vocational education and training. UNDP efforts in this direction addressed the demand and supply mismatch in the labor market as one of the reasons of unemployment, particularly among the youth. To address this gap, UNDP developed methodology for analysis of demand and supply of skilled labor force for planning of annual enrollments at Technical and Vocational Training Institutes. To ensure the vocational education system equips students with in-demand skillset, UNDP completed development/revision of state competency-based education standards with corresponding modular programs for a number of occupations in high demand. To enhance the capacities of local vocational institutions for delivering modern curricula, UNDP equipped 10 of them with IT, sewing and greenhouse production equipment, benefiting 2,537 students (women 1,395, men 1,142), and strengthened the capacities of 620 teaching staff (women 434, men 186). For higher efficiency of career guidance system, UNDP trained overall 100 career counselors (all women). As part of its efforts towards strengthening the human capital in the regions of Armenia, UNDP helped 80 young people (women 45, men 35) develop transferable skills and facilitated the labor market entry of 90 youths (women 50, men 40) through active labor market programmes.
2023 Narrative: UNDP continued supporting the institutional capacity building of state bodies responsible for formulation and implementation of employment policy with a quantitative methodology on analyses of labor market demand and supply in cooperation with State Statistical Committee and international experts. As part of its broader efforts in this realm, UNDP continued strengthening the career guidance system in vocational education through capacity building of 104 (women 95%) career guidance and professional orientation specialists.Simultaneously, 2,258 youths (1,204 women, 1,054 men) accessed labor market responsive training with UNDP support through modernized laboratories (IT and design) in 8 vocational facilities. To ensure wider outreach and inclusion into innovative non-formal training, especially for young women and NEET youth, UNDP partnered with “Technological Training Center-Federation of Armenian Associations Auvergne Rhone Alpes” Educational Foundation for launching an online learning platform with 500 students on innovative low carbon technologies highly needed in the labor market.Overall, 150 young people (women-70, men-80) increased their employability with UNDP support accessing upskilling/reskilling opportunities in the growth sectors of Armenia through non-formal training, business capacity development and on-the-job training programs. This provided 66 youths (women-37, men-29) with decent jobs across the regions of Armenia.
2024 Narrative: UNDP leveraged innovative digital solutions as a development enabler to enhance the institutionalcapacity the state bodies responsible for employment and VET policies through 2 innovative modelsaimed at labor market (LM) demand and supply analyses in cooperation with the National Center forEducational Technologies (www.ktak.am). One of the innovative models refers to the upgrade of theEdu2Work platform with VET data. The other model aims at identifying the career paths of VET alumni.Through 2 digital models, now the respective line ministry has access to real-time data and is enabled tomake evidence-based decisions on the ongoing VET reforms [E46-47]. As part of its broader efforts,UNDP continues capacitating 100 career guidance specialists (95% women) in analyses of LMinformation. Simultaneously, more than 170 VETIs’ directors/deputy directors increased their knowledgein “Strategic Management of VETIs” aimed at enhancing the quality of VET. As part ofcompetency-based VET, 105 students (48w) accessed newly established 4 workshops (welding, sewing,driving, photovoltaic systems) followed by the training of 24 VET teachers in the field of solar energy. Topromote the digital and inclusive agenda in the VET, UNDP equipped the National Centre for VocationalEducation and Training Development (www.mkuzak.am) with a server to enable information exchangeamong VET institutions. In the field of non-formal education, especially for refugees and NEET youth,UNDP partnered with “Aren Meghrabyan Foundation” in the implementation of 2 trainings for 72 youngpeople on 3D Modeling and Web Design. In bordering areas, UNDP provided grants to 13 MSEs tosustain and enlarge businesses, create new jobs (33), and strengthen resilience to external shocks. WithUNDP support 601 (479w) people benefited from upskilling/reskilling opportunities. Through on-the-jobtraining with 219 regional employers, 525 displaced population (441w) have been integrated into thelabour market, and 247 people (47%) have secured decent jobs after completion of the training inArmenia [E11].

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.1: Increased capacities of education stakeholders to respond to evolving learning environment including through strengthening inclusive  blended and digital learning.
Sub-Output: Conduct baseline review of the current available quality assurance instruments in pre-school education to inform improvement of data, monitoring and self-assessment.
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of High Education and Science
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2022 Narrative: As of September 2022, Kazakhstan had 10,857 preschool organizations providing early childhood education and care to almost 900,000 children. Most preschool organizations are public (57%), but the number of private preschool organizations has drastically increased during the last decade (NEDB, 2021-2022). The newly adopted government Concept of Education Development for 2022-2026 focuses on pre-schools. All pre-school organizations will introduce international tools of quality assessment of upbringing and education. Parents will be able to choose a place in any preschool organization, on the principle of per capita financing. However, the gaps in capacity of pre-schools in planning and monitoring of quality remain. The Ministry of Enlightenment (MoE) has established a new Pre-school education department. At the World ECCE conference, Kazakhstan among other countries adopted the ‘Tashkent Declaration and Commitments to Action for Transforming Early Childhood Care and Education.’ The Declaration seeks to renew and strengthen political commitments and action toward ECCE from birth to 8 years of age. In 2022 UNICEF continued introducing new components into the quality assurance system of public and private pre-schools like self-assessment tools, a set of indicators, score card, capacity development of 351 kindergartens in planning and monitoring. Ultimately, this new methodology will result in an available baseline data on ECCE, improved Education Management Information System (EMIS) with ECE indicators, certification and accreditation of service providers, and advancing decision making around such dimensions like pedagogy, time for play, child’s interactions with space and materials, interactions between children, interactions among staff and parents/family engagement.

During 2022, 74 youth peer educators (10 boys and 64 girls) have organised 124 peer-to-peer activities (online, hybrid, and/or offline modality) involving 4867 young people (2494 girls and 2373 boys, out of which 21 young people with disabilities) from targeted VET institutions.Peer-to-peer educators held discussions with their peers on topics such as violence prevention, reproductive health, contraception, hygiene, addictions (drugs, alcohol, etc.), stereotypes, etc. During the activities with their peers, educators used board games together with the board game "Fara tabu".

2021 Narrative:
ILO: The capacity of Education Inspectors and Municipal Education Directorates to promote active and proactive action of schools in child protection and in addressing non-enrolment, prevention of school dropout and reintegration of children that dropped out, is strengthened. 

A ToT Program on teachers’ role to implement the SOPs (through prevention measures as well as through supporting withdrawal and reintegration of children involved in WFCL through education services), was prepared (including all supporting documents for accreditation by MESTI). A three-day ToT workshop with 21 potential trainers was organized in cooperation with Education Trade Union (SBASHK), and the Training Program for teachers is accredited by MESTI in Aug 2021. 

The Module on Early Warning System in the Education Management Information System is upgraded to enable real time reports on number of children combining school and work.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.1: By 2025, effective, inclusive and accountable institutions ensure equal access for all people living in Kazakhstan, especially most vulnerable, to quality and gender sensitive social services according to the principle of leaving no one behind
Output: Output 1.1.2: Increased capacity of policy makers and health service providers to improve access to selected quality health services and goods, including those related to COVID-19, HIV, reproductive and mental health related services, for everyone especially the most vulnerable groups of population.
Sub-Output: Integration of training courses on sexual and reproductive health into the national medical education system
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan Ministry of Healthcare
SDG Targets: 3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.,3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 5 Gender Equality
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
The 60-hour (2 credit hours) continuing education course for obstetrician-gynecologists and health managers was developed based on WHO/UNFPA guidelines and the latest technical recommendations and in line with the requirements and standards of national medical education. The course program includes the following sections of antenatal care: • preconception preparation; • examination and laboratory tests during pregnancy; • non-pathological conditions during pregnancy; • pathological conditions during pregnancy; • drug therapy during pregnancy and postpartum contraception; • approaches to improve the current practice of antenatal care at the PHC level by assessing the quality of current practice using the WHO tool The training course consists of thematic presentations, a facilitator’s guide, a set of video lectures, and two job aids (thematic video) allocated to the Moodle platform (Edu-open.kz). The course is presented to MOH for inclusion in the Catalog of the National Medical Education System.
During the second quarter of 2022, the MoUs with four national medical universities were signed. Karagandy, West Kazakhstan, Semey, and Kazakh National medical universities exist. On 16-31 May 2022, 107 faculty staff members of four medical universities attended distance-based training on family planning and modern contraceptives at srh.org.kz. 100 out of 107 (93%) completed the course and obtain the certificate.
2022 Narrative: To enhance the institutional mechanisms to deliver comprehensive SRH services and information with a focus on the furthest behind, the UNFPA CO focused on promoting international norms and standards in the medical education system. To achieve this goal, the UNFPA CO started work in 2022 simultaneously in 2 directions: (i) establishing partnerships with 4 leading medical universities in the country (Karagandy Medical University; Semey Medical University; Asfendiyarov Kazakh National Medical University, and West Kazakhstan Medical University), covering 80% of all medical students in the country, and (ii) developing new curricula corresponding to the UNFPA mandate.As a result, the 60-hours training curriculum on “Quality assurance of the inpatient perinatal care” developed in 2021 with UNFPA support was approved by the National Academic Council and recommended for roll-out in all medical universities in the country. As the first step of the curriculum's roll-out implementation, 25 faculty staff from national medical universities strengthened their capacity with UNFPA support in 2022 during an initial 8 days' combined training (5 days online via the Moodle platform and 3 days face-to-face held on 29 August to 7 September in Astana.To further align Kazakhstan's medical education with international standards, the UNFPA CO helped to develop in 2022 training curricula on “Effective Antenatal Care” and "Clinical management of uncomplicated and complicated labor and birth at the hospital level" and facilitated their piloting via digital platform edu-open.kz. Both courses were submitted to the National Academic Council under the MoH for approval and inclusion into the postgraduate medical education. Throughout its support UNFPA facilitated the use of information technologies as an innovative way to strengthen capacity not only via in-person training but also via specially designed training platforms solutions1) The "SRH.ORG.KZ" distance-based training platform on Family Planning and modern contraceptive methods, developed in 2020 by the CO was approved on 27 May 2022 by the National Academic council under the MoH and recommended for roll-out among professional society. The roll-out of the platform in 2022 was started by training of 182 medical universities’ and nurses colleges faculty members, and 120 PHCs health professionals.2) The “EDU-OPEN.KZ” digital solution specially designed by the CO in 2021 based on the Moodle platform. This website is used for all training provided by the CO in 2022 more than 250 trainees used this as a tool for homeworks and remote learning.3) Learning short videos. For the curriculum on "Clinical management of uncomplicated and complicated labor and birth at the hospital level" three learning short videos developed on “Using Labor Partogram,”; “Emergency care algorithm for severe obstetric hemorrhage,”; “The labor care algorithm for obstetric-gynecologists and midwives”.
2023 Narrative: UNFPA focused on the promotion of international standards and recommendations on SRHR in the national medical education system. UNFPA supported organizing the First Congress of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. During the Congress, UNFPA presented to the academic society five curricula on family planning and modern contraception, antenatal care, effective perinatal care, quality assurance in maternities, and CEMD (Confidential Enquiry into Maternal Deaths), which were developed with UNFPA support in 2021-2022. Furthermore, the Republican Academic Council on 20 September 2023 approved postgraduate curricula developed with UNFPA support on (i) Guiding Principles of Antenatal Care, and (ii) Guiding Principles to Manage Physiological and Complicated Labour and Birth. To roll out both curricula among national medical universities, UNFPA conducted two workshops which covered 65 faculty staff members and leading health professionals from 7 medical universities and all 20 regions of the country.
2024 Narrative: The CO works on integrating the SRHR international standards into the national medical education curricula. The Roadmap of the Ministry of Health for 2024-2026 will ensure that future healthcare providers receive comprehensive SRHR education, promoting long-term change. In addition, UNFPA expanded its work in the medical education sector and engaged the National Association of Nursing Colleges (which brings together 67 colleges nationwide) to implement updated curricula on SRH.Moreover, in the reporting period, the CO supported training 	752 health professionals (against a plan of 600) in family planning and modern contraceptives at the innovative distance-based learning platform “srh.org.kz” launched by the CO in 2022. The average score on the exam is 80%, and the threshold value is 70%.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework

Description:
Joint UN Project: Enhancing citizens’ trust in institutions and building resilient communities, UNESCO component, including:
•	Implement a comprehensive Media and Information Literacy concept in elementary and secondary schools is accompanied by establishment of a Resource Centre for Media and Information Literacy within the public university. Additionally, provide support for academia-facilitated thematic dialogue platforms, fostering interaction between students and diverse social actors, including decision-makers.
•	In collaboration with the Ministry of Culture and Media, this activity will support citizen engagement, especially among youth, in promoting and protecting human rights, diversity, equality, and a culture of peace.
•	Collaborating with the Ministry of Culture and Media, the activity promotes citizen engagement, especially among youth, in advocating for human rights, diversity, equality, and a culture of peace. Aligned with Montenegro Media Strategy, it supports the Ministry's application of the Code of Ethics for journalists, emphasizing sustainability and institutional backing through the establishment of a National Multi-Stakeholder Media Coalition for ethical journalism and addressing potential harmful online content

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The project underscores the pivotal role of gender equality in ensuring social cohesion. By actively empowering girls and boys, women and men, decision and opinion makers, the project is challenging the prevailing narratives of gender-based hate speech, violence, sexism and misogyny, and fosters girls’ and women’s significant contributions and participation in the civic and political spheres (output 2.3). By building the capacities of both women and men in key influential roles, including politicians, policymakers and opinion leaders, the project seeks to pave the way for more inclusive, gender-sensitive approaches, emphasizing safeguarding of progress in achieving gender equality and countering any gender equality backlash. The project approach mainstreams gender-quality principles, and all activities are based on gender-sensitive approaches.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: UNESCO, in partnership with the Ministry of Culture and Media - specifically its Directorate for Media - successfully initiated the establishment of a mechanism for close coordination aimed at combating hate speech, online harassment, and disinformation. Aligned with Montenegro's Strategy for Media and its Action Plan, this mechanism includes a mandatory reporting system for such cases and the development of recommendations to enhance media practices and address these challenges. Furthermore, the project has launched a capacity development program designed to enhance the quality of education and strengthen teachers' pedagogical skills in addressing critical challenges such as fact-checking, artificial intelligence manipulation, and combating stereotypes, prejudices, and hate speech.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2023 – 2027
Strategic priority: SP1_Just and inclusive institutions and equal opportunities for human development
Outcome: OC1_By 2027, institutions deliver human rights-based, evidence-informed and gender-responsive services for all, with the focus on those who are left behind
Output: OU 1.4_Rights holders, in particular from vulnerable groups, are empowered to access and claim for quality public services
Sub-Output: (UNFPA) Out-of-school comprehensive sexuality education for youth, including young people with disabilities, is operationalized following international standards.
Description:
To complement the formal/school-based comprehensive sexuality education and reach out to adolescents and youth from vulnerable groups and remote areas, UNFPA has been supporting for many years the out-of-school programs. 
In 2023 UNFPA will continue implementing the out-of-school comprehensive sexuality education (CSE) program. This initiative will follow UNFPA’s International Technical and Programmatic Guidance on Out-of-School CSE and will focus on reaching adolescents and young people in rural areas, those with disabilities, and youth from the left bank of the Nistru River.
In 2024, the initiative aims to foster a more inclusive and supportive environment where all young people, regardless of their background, have access to comprehensive sexuality education and essential resources for a healthy and informed future. To achieve this, several institutions and organizations working with youth will be equipped with dedicated spaces for non-formal sexuality education activities.
Additionally, civil society organizations, particularly those in underserved regions, will receive support to enhance their capacity in promoting young people’s sexual and reproductive health and rights. Specialists from various organizations will be trained to deliver accurate, age-appropriate education on these topics, ensuring that young people are well-informed and empowered.
Furthermore, parents and caregivers of adolescents with disabilities will be provided with the necessary knowledge and resources to support their children’s development and smooth transition into adulthood.
In 2025, UNFPA will continue strengthening civil society organizations and youth networks across Moldova, including those on the left bank of the Nistru River, to develop and implement programs on sexual and reproductive health and rights tailored to diverse youth groups. To support these efforts, UNFPA will create guidelines for delivering youth-friendly health services for vulnerable youth, aligned with international out-of-school comprehensive sexuality education (OOS CSE) standards.
A digital training program will be introduced for facilitators working in CSE, ensuring they are well-equipped to provide accurate and effective education. Additionally, new educational and interactive materials, such as the Diary of an Adolescent Boy/Girl, will be developed to make information on sexual and reproductive health and rights more accessible and relevant to young people. 
Building on UNFPA Moldova’s expertise in youth well-being and global best practices, and in partnership with the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) and the Youth National Agency, UNFPA will establish the Future-Ready Hub—a pioneering space dedicated to life skills development, innovation, and modern technologies. Bringing together adolescents, youth educators, youth workers, NGOs, and the private sector, the Hub will foster a collaborative, forward-looking environment.
Contributing partners: Embassy of Sweden, Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, UNFPA Core funds, United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: Moldova Project Association (MPA) Moldova, Motivatie
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being, 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality
Geography: ATU from the left bank of the Nistru river, Moldova, Republic of
QCPR function: Direct Support/ Service Delivery, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: The Project's interventions are designed in response to existing data that highlights the inadequate and insufficient sexuality education currently being provided in Moldovan schools: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YtqzN8t4coLivGo0EJ1-8EaXurx7KRaB/view?usp=sharing The interventions have direct contribution to girls empowerment to make informed decisions about their life, bodily autonomy and works with boys and girls, family members to empower them to avoid GBV, risky behaviors that may lead to teen pregnancy, etc.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: Contributes strongly to sexual and reproductive rights of young people from left bank of Nistru river, as well as of young people from diferent voulnerable groups, including rural youth from poor socio-economic environment, youth with disabilities, refugee youth.
Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: With support from Norway's government, Sweden and in partnership with Association “MOTIVATIE” and NGO “The Moldova Project”, UNFPA launched the out-of-school comprehensive sexuality education programme following UNFPA International Technical and Programmatic Guidance on out-of-school CSE https://www.unfpa.org/featured-publication/international-technical-and-programmatic-guidance-out-school-comprehensive targeting rural adolescents and young people, young people with disabilities, adolescents, and youth from the Transnistrian region. As a result, over 315 adolescents and young people increased their knowledge of GBV prevention, SRHR, contraception, and available services in their communities and have been empowered to adopt healthy and safe sexual and reproductive health behaviours.Representatives from 10 NGOs from both banks of the Dniestr river and 45 family members empowered in youth SRHR. https://moldova.unfpa.org/en/news/unfpa-and-moldova-project-empower-adolescents-and-young-people-vulnerable-families-know-their  https://motivatie.md/ro/motivatie-combate-stereotipurile-tinerilor-cu-dizabilitati-in-domeniul-sanatatii-sexuale-si-reproductive/341 https://www.facebook.com/unfpaMoldova/posts/pfbid0ARdVa4nvi6dZisLqSEoa6D4YGC12NKBeiv4wvBeRNUSQa2RjKSsLnwU29zqe2cxrl
2024 Narrative: With support from Norway's government, Sweden and UK, and in partnership with Association “MOTIVATIE” and NGO “The Moldova Project”, UNFPA continued implementation of the out-of-school comprehensive sexuality education programme following UNFPA International Technical and Programmatic Guidance on out-of-school CSE https://www.unfpa.org/featured-publication/international-technical-and-programmatic-guidance-out-school-comprehensive targeting rural adolescents and young people, young people with disabilities, adolescents, and youth from the left bank of Nistru river. As a result, UNFPA has supported:Equipped with youth-friendly spaces seven institutions and organizations working with young people, including those from vulnerable groups, spaces where non-formal activities aimed at facilitating sexuality education will be conducted. Spread across the country, the organizations (the "Phoenix" Center in Rîșcani, the Temporary Placement Center in Soroca, "Everyone Contributes to Change" in Criuleni, "Sun Shine" in Chișinău, the Personal Assistance Directorate in Chișinău, the "MOTIVAȚIE" Association, and "Eternity" in Fălești) are now closer to young people and better able to meet their needs for knowledge and development.38 civil society organizations and institutions in the field of social assistance, including from the left bank of the Nistru River, have been empowered in the area of adolescents and young people’s sexual and reproductive rights and health.31 specialists from civil society organizations have been trained as facilitators in programs on sexual and reproductive health education for young people.76 parents/caregivers of adolescents with disabilities from both sides of the Nistru River have increased their knowledge about sexual and reproductive health and have been empowered to support their children in the transition to adulthood.A training program on youth-friendly health services was piloted for medical workers on the left bank of the Nistru River.598 young people from vulnerable groups benefited from long-term education programs on sexual and reproductive health, including 298 young people from rural areas, 140 from placement centers, 99 young people with disabilities, and 61 young people from the left bank of the Nistru River.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Gender marker narrative: The planned interventions under this suboutput significantly contribute to gender equality as they promote the active participation and access to education for refugee girls, incl. from the Roma community, however, there are no specific gender equality indicators in the M&E framework (the current indicators capture gender disaggregated data by sex).
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Human rights marker narrative: The suboutput contributes significantly to the realization of human rights for refugee children in Moldova (incl. Roma). The activities of the suboutput target patterns of discrtimiination inequality and fosters meaningful participation and engagement, and integration of refugee children into the local education system.
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
Sustaining peace marker narrative: ased on UNHCR's MY strategy, situation analysis included therein and 2023 risk register the activities have been designed to strengthen refugee inclusion in the education system (incl. for Roma children), social cohesion, and to support reconstruction efforts in Ukraine (for those for return). Hence, marking 1.
2023 Narrative: To further strengthen access to national education system for refugee children,- UNHCR supported MLSP through rehabilitation of two child care facilities and equipping them furniture - Through implementing partners ,Charity Center for Refugees and Ave Copiii, educational activities were conducted in blue dot and school supplies were distributed.  - Three highchairs were supported with tech labs through the provision of furniture, IT equipment - School furniture was provided to six schools
2024 Narrative: To further strengthen access to national education system for refugee children, UNHCR,  -continued to co-lead the Education Working Group and ensure smooth coordination in the education sector -conducted field visits, together with the Education Working Group co-leads and partners, to locations around the country, to meet with schools, parents, and local Directorates of Education, to identify challenges to school enrollment and find solutions -donated 496 desks and 496 chairs to schools with refugee children enrolled in order to improve conditions -rehabilitated three creche groups to improve access to creche services for children aged 0-3 -developed, jointly with UNICEF, a roadmap and action plan for the full inclusion of refugee children in the Moldovan education system -partner CCR offered Romanian language classes to 1282 children and 366 adults.

Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.2  3.2 Educational environment is more inclusive, safe, and enabling
2023 Narrative: In the field of protecting cultural heritage:Completed in 2023: UNESCO project to support the “Management of heritage properties of religious interest in Armenia” (US$ 67,000). It resulted in the development of management plans for all World Heritage properties in Armenia (Cathedral and Churches of Echmiatsin and the Archaeological Site of Zvartnots; Monasteries of Haghpat and Sanahin; Monastery of Geghard and the Upper Azat Valley).UNESCO project to support “Community inventory, documentation and safeguarding of folklore of the Syunik region of Armenia” (US$ 75,000). This project, implemented by the Institute of Archeology and Ethnography of the National Academy of Sciences, is entering its final phase which consists of finalizing the inventory, having it validated and integrating it into the national inventory.Launched in December 2023, to run throughout 2024-2025: UNESCO to provide assistance to Armenia to prepare the nomination of the "Tatev and Tatev Hermitage monastic complexes and the adjacent areas of the Vorotan Valley" on the UNESCO International List of Cultural Property under Enhanced Protection (US$ 55,450). In the field of educationLaunched in 2023: UNESCO is leading two projects on Vocational Education and Training and skills development for displaced youth and adults and to bolster the education system in providing psychosocial support for refugee populations (USD 100K). In the field of supporting anti-doping in sportsIn 2023, Armenia benefitted from UNESCO support (USD 83,267) for the implementation of 5 projects in the fields of policy advice, mentoring and capacity-building and education focusing on youth and sports organizations. In support of protecting documentary heritage:In 2023, UNESCO supported the National Commission in organising an international conference on "Archives - the memory of humanity", dedicated to 100th anniversary of National Archives of Armenia” (USD 26K).
2024 Narrative: Psychosocial SupportUNESCO partnered with the Republican Pedagogical-Psychological Center to enhance the psychosocial resilience of refugee children affected by the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. Over the course of the project, hundreds of school psychologists and teachers were trained to provide targeted support. The initiative culminated in a closing ceremony in December 2024, where a UNESCO-supported conceptual framework for psychosocial support in schools was launched and approved by national authorities.Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) and Skills DevelopmentIn 2024, UNESCO provided technical assistance to strengthen Armenia’s TVET system, focusing on the ICT sector and skills profiling for youth, adults, and refugees. Two key workshops brought together government institutions, TVET institutes, and other stakeholders to discuss priorities for reform. Building on these efforts, the National Centre for Vocational Education and Training Development submitted a proposal for future funding to advance sectoral qualifications in ICT, Light Industry, and Construction.Cultural HeritageUNESCO supported the completion of a community-based initiative to document and safeguard the living heritage of Armenia’s Syunik region. Community members from 20 villages were trained to identify and record their traditions, with their findings made publicly accessible through a newly established website. Additionally, at the request of national authorities, UNESCO is preparing a community-based needs assessment for refugee communities in Armenia, set to begin in early 2025.Support for Scientific HeritageUNESCO contributed to the Armenian government’s efforts in organizing an international conference on the Astronomical Heritage of the Middle East, fostering dialogue on the region’s rich scientific legacy.

Implementation partners: LPAs

Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
568 youth from around the country, out of which 419 girls and 149 boys are aware about persistent gender inequalities, VAW issues, gender-based discrimination, obsolete stereotypes as a result of innovative workshops, mentoring porgrams, application of street art tools, VR tools, guided discussion etc. supported by UNW in partnership with several local and national NGO's, including initiative groups etc.  31 people, out of which 27 women and 2 men, 2 nonbinary people and 1 woman with disabilities, both program participants and their friends and relatives from Chisinau, Balti, Soroca, Cimislia, Budesti, Falesti, Cricova, Criulen district, Ocnita district, are ready to identify and promote innovative approaches on EVAW, as a result of mentoring program“Youth for Gender Equality”, implemented by the GENDERDOC-M Information Centre and Women for Women NGO as well as of the result of the 9 community-based initiatives developed by themselves together with the mentors tackling issues as sexual harrasment, discrimination, stereotypes and gender inequalities (info on each project is attached). 

150 young persons (111 girls and 39 boys) from Varnita, Falesti, Anenii Noi, Balti, Sarata Veche, Straseni, Glodeni, Singerei are aware about gender equality, graffiti techniques and how to reflect on emerging global issues around gender equality, patriarchal masculinities, obsolete social norms, by applying innovative tools as street art and urban performances, as a result of workshops and summer camps launched by the UNW in partnership with Urban Spirit NGO.

Over 100 girls aged between 15 and 18, from 8 teams, are aware about GE, VAW, Sexual Harassment, as a result of the event, organized by AO Codrenii, within the national program "Sipoteni Youth Capital 2020-2021", coordinated by the Ministry of Education, Culture and Research, in partnership with Sipoteni City Hall, Moldovan Football Federation, UN Women Moldova and with the financial support of Sweden.  UNW supported the organization of the Regional Women's Football Cup which took place in Sipoteni village, Calarasi district as well as promoted women in sport initiatives. 

Another 22 girls, with age from 10 to 13 years, part of the sport club “Narta” SS Drasliceni, participated within the 13-th edition of the annual International Football and Volleyball Tournament “SOUTH BLACK SEA CUP 2021” from Bulgaria, Byala city, with support of UN Women. This activity enabled the participation of the representatives from female football team from community level in a European football and volleyball tournament, and by this contributed to challenging harmful gender stereotypes around involvement of women in sport, specifically in the context of Generation Equality Forums.
33 teachers, facilitators and psychologists out of which 28 women and 5 men from the 12 institutions, as well as 267 youth representatives (159 girls and 108 boys), are ready to combat stereotypes and gender discrimination and advance favorable social norms that prevent VAWG, through innovative tools, as a result of 2 Training sessions for teachers / facilitators / psychologists and 11 piloting activities, conducted by NGO IDIS “Viitorul” and supported by UNW.

LNOB groups targeted: Children , Migrants, Other, Persons With Disabilities, Refugees & Asylum Seekers, Women & Girls, Youth, Victims of grave human rights violations of (slavery, torture, trafficking, sexual exploitation and abuse...)
2023 Narrative: Over 2023, UNICEF continued to respond to both the Ukraine refugee response as well as irregular migrant needs. While reduced from the numbers experienced in 2022, the migrant crisis at Belarus’ borders with countries from the EU continued to be an issue with extremely vulnerable irregular migrants attempting to make dangerous crossings.While resources focused on the Ukraine crisis managed in a separate output, general emergency preparedness remained a critical issue for UNICEF revitalizing its partnership with the Ministry for Emergency Situations to enhance preparedness capacity and implement a campaign for trauma prevention. These steps extended support to migrant and refugee families and children in need, as well as reinforced the national emergency preparedness and response system for trauma prevention at-large.UNICEF rolled out of Core Commitments for Children in gender, integrating the prevention of and risk mitigation for GBV for all in programme responses with specific attention to the safety and resilience of girls and women. In response to the Ukraine crisis and continued irregular migrant crisis, UNICF continued to provide GBV and child safeguarding training and outreach for partners.Through experiences from the migrant and refugee crises, UNICEF strengthened protection mechanisms for unaccompanied asylum seeking children (UASC) jointly with UNHCR and IOM, advocating with the Ministry of Internal Affairs' Department of Citizenship and Migration and the Ministry of Education for development an interagency algorithm for UASC, adding best interests determination (BID) and case management to early intervention measures. In collaboration with UNHCR, UNICEF conducted BID with four vulnerable UASCs from places such as Yemen and Liberia. Advocacy of these cases to the working group resulted in activization of healthcare, MHPSS, and foster care for the UASCs.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4 - Inclusive and equitable social development

Output: (2021) 4.1 National health system and civil society have improved capacity to assure access and quality of health services
Sub-Output: Ensure access to WASH in health, education and social services facilities, including placement centers, centers for children in conflict with the law
Description: Health, education and social services facilities ensured with WASH and hygiene supplies and IPC knowledge
Contributing partners: United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Moldova Ministry of Health, Labour and Social Protection, Moldova National Agency of Public Health
SDG Targets: 6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF provided around 1300 Primary Health Centers and 41 Youth Friendly Health Services nationwide with essential hygienic products, including over 50,000 liters of sanitizer and 40,000 liters of liquid soap. Additionally, 29 medical institutions providing care to pregnant women and newborns, including 9 institutions from Transnistrian region, benefitted from provision of essential WASH/hygiene supplies for pregnant women, postpartum patients, newborns, and frontline service providers. UNICEF donated 900 l of disinfectant, 700 l of liquid soap, more than 4,800 diapers and other WASH supplies for children and Municipal Hospital for Contagious Diseases for Children
The Manual for child protection specialists in COVID-19 pandemic was developed with UNICEF support and approved by Ministry of Health Labour and Social Protection. The document includes a comprehensive set of targeted guidelines for key professionals on how to better deliver assistance and services to families and children and ensure a unified approach to implementation of main cross-sectoral mechanisms and sectoral tools during pandemics. 
1000 litres of hand sanitizer, 4600 gloves and over 10,000 masks with screens for the work with children with hearing disabilities were offered to the Republican Centre for Psycho-pedagogical Assistance and all 35 District Psycho-pedagogical Assistance Services.  
To ensure a safe environment in educational institutions during the times of “the new normal”, as per the request of the Ministry of Education, Culture and Research (MECR), UNICEF purchased over 1,000 liters of hand sanitizer
UNICEF purchased also WASH/hygiene supplies for over 20 residential institutions for children, aiming at reaching approximately 1500 children.
