Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3: Prosperity and Planet - Inclusive Economic Growth and Environmental Sustainability
Outcome: Outcome 3.1: By 2025, all people in Kazakhstan, especially the most vulnerable, benefit from inclusive, resilient, and sustainable economic development with improved productive capacities, skills and equal opportunities for sustainable and decent jobs, livelihoods, and businesses.
Output: Output 3.1.2: Enhanced capacities of key stakeholders at national and sub-national levels on labour force resilience and equal skills development opportunities
Sub-Output: Capacity -building to safeguard living heritage for SD and its transmission through education in Central Asia
Description: Building capacity for safeguarding living heritage, and to integrate living heritage in sustainable development, notably in formal education. Particular focus will be placed on ensuring women's participation in promotion of ICH through more holistic, multi-disciplinary approach.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Kazakhstan civil society organizations
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,8.10 Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education, 5 Gender Equality, 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: The annual training for Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH) facilitators was conducted in 2023. Four local experts from Kazakhstan National ICH Committee and culture experts improved knowledge and skills on Sustainable tourism and Intangible Cultural Heritage.The support was provided to the work of the National Committee on ICH.Awareness raising sessions were organized for the group of schoolchildren from the Network of the UNESCO Associated School, UNESCO Chair of Pedagogy and students from history faculties of the selected universities in Almaty.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK FOR ARMENIA
Strategic priority: People’s well-being and capabilities
Outcome: People exercise their talents and skills, benefitting from ageappropriate, life-long learning, inclusive and quality education in an enabling and safe environment
Output: 3.1 Education system is strengthened to deliver quality and inclusive education to all, including in pre-primary schooling
Sub-Output: National systems and capacities of officials and other stakeholders are strengthened to develop evidence-based policies, plans and budgets, ensuring inclusive and equitable education outcomes for all children.
Description:
General theme: Promoting legislative multi-sectoral approach
Outcome 3: Education
Output 3.1: Education system is strengthened to deliver quality and inclusive education to all, including in pre-primary schooling
Existing programme: Stronger Services for Equal Participation and Inclusive Development
Contributing partners: Asian Development Bank, Core Funding, European Commission, Global Partnership for Education, Government of Austria, Government of France, Government of Japan, Swiss Committee for UNICEF, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Global Thematic Humanitarian Fund, UNICEF National Committees, UNICEF WASH Thematic Trust Fund, United Nations Multi-Partner Trust Fund, United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Local NGOs
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF, acting in the capacity of Grant Agent, in cooperation with the Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sports (MoESCS), the Asian Development Bank (ADB; Coordinating Agency) and the 40+ members of the Local Education Group (LEG) launched the Education Sector Plan Implementation Grant (ESPDG) activities supported by the Global Partnership for Education (GPE). In this context, five thematic studies, as well as “Education Sector Review in Armenia” have been initiated on general education (including pre-primary level) and will be completed in 2022. The ESPDG process triggered a transparent policy dialogue between the MoESCS, developmental partners and key education stakeholders, and will influence the upcoming national education sector strategy. 
In close collaboration and discussions with MoESCS and NCET, the e-module on the assessment and registration of preschool and school-age children with special education needs (SEN) was tested. It is planned to have a separate Module within the Educational Management Information System (EMIS), to be used for coordination and evaluation of the services, and for information exchange with the health and social protection sectors. The finalization of the e-system, including the development of the submodules on SEN assessment, service provision and education progress of children, including CWD, as well as piloting are planned for 2022.
2022 Narrative: The State Education Development Programme of the Republic of Armenia until 2030 was approved by the Parliament in September 2022. As a result of UNICEF support, the document is equipped with a solid evidence base that informed key decisions and directions within the Programme; it enjoys good consensus among actors of the education sector and beyond; and it will be accompanied by a costed action plan to ensure effective implementation.  Comprehensive education sector assessments and reviews are not a common practice in Armenia. Usually, education system’s analytical work is fragmented and scattered in different documents. With UNICEF support and continued partnership, MoESCS finalised and released five thematic studies and the Education Sector Review report, a comprehensive evidence base used to inform reform efforts. The process was highly participatory and aimed at establishing a systematic approach for education sector analysis, enhancing the quality of education sector plans, budgeting as well as to ensure regular joint education sector reviews. The various components of the plan are consistent between them and with government-wide strategies and international commitments, including the pledge made by the Government of Armenia at the Transforming Education Summit this year. The Government is likely to face challenges in mobilizing sufficient financing to implement the strategy. Implementation and monitoring a large number of activities and indicators is another challenge. The costed action plan under preparation with UNICEF support is expected to mitigate those risks and improve operationalization.There is a persistent teacher shortage, especially in rural and remote communities, and the shortage is likely to become even more acute in the nearest future. The Education Sector Plan notes that 46% of teachers are over 50 and only 11% under 30. According to 2022 university admission results, few young people selected teaching as a profession. Thus, replacement of retiring teachers is a concern that MESCS is addressing by scaling up a new incentive scheme through which teachers can earn higher salaries if they successfully engage in a voluntary certification process based on new professional standards. This provision is based on the recommendations of the UNICEF-supported study on teacher deployment whose findings were discussed with the ministry. The National Center for Education Technologies through E-School Armenia scaled up the online mentor school model for online teaching and learning earlier developed with UNICEF support. The initiative allowed to identify and use the potential of highly qualified teachers and schools.In response to children’s needs arising from recurrent escalations along the border between Armenia and Azerbaijan and other tensions of geo-political nature, special attention was given to education continuity in safe and enabling environments. In five schools and three kindergartens in Syunik region, UNICEF and partners provided healthy lifestyles and hygiene education, and repaired WASH facilities ensuring gender and disability aspects are duly considered. Eight schools received new school furniture and UNICEF learning and recreation kits. Children from Nagorno Karabakh stranded in Armenia due to the Lachin corridor blockage received school bags and stationery to support their temporary placement in schools in Armenia.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued its collaboration with MoESCS and partners around the ongoing education reforms becoming a partner of choice in the education sector. UNICEF contributed to policy dialogue by supporting national consultations for the 2023-2026 Action Plan (AP) adjacent to the State Program for Development of Education until 2030 (EDP), which was adopted in late 2022 with UNICEF support. The AP defines clear targets, and timeframes for implementation and was approved in March. The European Union chose UNICEF to act as technical assistance agency for the implementation of the EU Budget Support, which covers a significant part of the budget required for the education sector reforms until 2026. UNICEF initiated the Education Joint Sector Review for the first time in years, which will contribute to improving the monitoring and accountability functions. UNICEF produced an Education Budget Brief and conducted the Education Sector Plan Appraisal that provided key recommendations that informed and influenced various reform decisions with consideration of gender and disability. System capacity, including the capacity to effectively monitor the ESP implementation and coordination are recognized as critical issues by both reports. The reports also highlight the importance of investing in datasystems for better planning and implementation of education programs. They recommend investing in EMIS to enhance scope and coherence of data collection between education levels and to enhance disaggregation by disability, gender, age, and other parameters. Partly because of this and previously generated evidence, MoESCS recently introduced a new management model of public educational institutions separating educational and administrative-economic processes, an approach that should lead to a clearer distribution of duties and responsibilities. A new funding formula for public education institutions was initiated and will be implemented in 2024. UNICEF in collaboration with the Ministry and CSO partners contributed to strengthening the teacher professional development system, which this year has involved an increased number of teachers in voluntary teacher certification. In 2023, certification was held in all subjects, and those who do not work anywhere, but have a pedagogical education, were allowed to participate. This move was coherent with the recommendations of the UNICEF 2022 analytical report that advises reconsidering the standards and the content of voluntary certification making it attractive to more teachers. UNICEF supported teachers’ forums and conferences contributing to professional development opportunities, sharing best practices, and promoting pedagogical innovations.
2024 Narrative: The MoESCS sustained education reforms despite the significant challenges and uncertainties that Armenia and the wider region have faced in recent years. 2024 was an important milestone as the country reached the midpoint of the Education State Programme's 2023-2026 Action Plan (AP). In this framework, UNICEF’s analytical work, high level technical assistance, field-level engagement, and capacity development initiatives have comprehensively contributed to advancing education reforms.Under the budget support agreement between Armenia and the European Union (EU), UNICEF provided technical assistance to the MoESCS to enhance quality and equity of education services, through improved coordination, monitoring and enhancement of professional competences. UNICEF in collaboration with the MoESCS initiated a joint sector review (JSR) of the education sector to discuss the progress of the reforms in January 2024. This review aimed to discuss the progress of reforms and its findings were presented to development partners and education stakeholders during the first high-level policy dialogue held in Armenia under the EU's budget support agreement with UNICEF technical inputs, a newly established platform of regular policy dialogues that contributes to greater accountability and joint monitoring of the situation in the education sector. Subsequently, these discussions informed a revision of the key targets in the 2023-2026 Action Plan at the end of the year. Overall, it was noted that while Armenia has made significant progress in enhancing educational content, improving professional competencies, changing teaching methods, student assessment and evaluation approaches, and creating child-friendly learning environments through initiatives like the "300 Schools and 500 Kindergartens" programme. At the same time, there are also challenges that require further attention. Some of those issues are related to refugee children from Nagorno-Karabakh, integration of out-of-school children, enhancement of educational leadership, and early childhood education.In response to the refugee influx from Nagorno Karabakh, UNICEF continued to support the MoESCS in accommodating and effectively including refugee children in Armenia’s education system, focusing on areas where the system has been mostly overstretched by the additional number of students. In order to expand learning spaces in schools with high concentration of refugee children together with children from host communities, 65 classrooms in 22 schools from Kotayk, Vayots Dzor, Ararat, Armavir and Gegharkunik regions were provided with school furniture and educational supplies. 5,155 children have received learning materials, including school bags with stationery. 8,072 refugee children have accessed remedial education and MHPSS services. In order to address psycho-social needs of refugee and other vulnerable children, UNICEF in collaboration with UNESCO initiated a partnership with the Republican Pedagogical-Psychological Support Center (RPPC) to enhance Mental Health and Psychological Service (MHPSS) in schools focusing on social-emotional learning, psycho-social resilience building, and creating a safe environment for children to learn and thrive. A training program on MHPSS in schools and a manual for building psychosocial resilience in children was developed and piloted. This resource helps educational staff create a supportive learning environment. As a result, 690 school psychologists and 362 teachers improved their skills in providing effective MHPSS services to children.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK FOR ARMENIA
Strategic priority: People’s well-being and capabilities
Outcome: People exercise their talents and skills, benefitting from ageappropriate, life-long learning, inclusive and quality education in an enabling and safe environment
Output: 3.2 Educational environment is more inclusive, safe, and enabling
Sub-Output: Affordable and quality cross-sectoral social policies, schemes and services for children with disabilities and their families are strengthened and support their development, a quality education and transition to independent living.
Description:
General theme:  Enhancing schools' physical structures
Outcome 3: Education
Output 3.2: Educational environment is more inclusive, safe, and enabling
Existing programme: Strenghtening national education system in inclusive access and learning
Contributing partners: Core Funding, European Commission, Government of France, Government of Norway, Swiss Committee for UNICEF, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, United Nations Multi-Partner Trust Fund
Implementation partners: Armenia Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport
SDG Targets: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
LNOB groups targeted: Children , Persons With Disabilities, Women & Girls
2021 Narrative: UNICEF engaged with national partners in elaboration of reasonable solutions aimed at adjusting the learning environment, including water sanitation and hygiene (WASH) aspects and teaching methods/skills/materials in mainstream schools to accommodate the needs of CwD, children in refugee-like situation as well as children from other vulnerable groups. Learning environment of 10 schools was improved through partial renovation of WASH facilities, provision of furniture, delivery of hygiene sessions, lifesaving Explosive Ordnance Risk Education seminars and ensuring remedial classes to help students catch up on lost learning.
2022 Narrative: The government continued to make considerable efforts to bring its legislation and practices in line with the standards and requirements of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UN CRPD) and guarantee cross-sectoral policies and schemes to ensure integrated support for children with disabilities and their families. To operationalize the implementation of the Law on Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities adopted in 2021, major legislative reforms are ongoing for alignment of sectoral policy frameworks with UN CRPD. Several policy papers were also developed based on the fundamental principles of the Convention such as the social model of disability, the procedures for reasonable accommodation in educational institutions, revision of the funding formula for inclusive education and minimum standards for physical accessibility of all preschool and general educational institutions. This process is supported by UNICEF in collaboration with other UN agencies, to enable the transition to the new disability assessment, certification, and to initiate a service delivery nationwide pilot in 2023. With UNICEF technical assistance, MoLSA developed several regulatory acts to operationalize the legal framework for the reform of Disability Assessment System and introduce the Functional Assessment of Disability taking into due consideration child-related aspects. Specific interventions include the revision of the disability assessment/certification and individual service provision planning procedures, updating the list of Assistive Technology (AT) addressing the needs of children throughout their lives and across settings such as home, school, and community. A set of assessment tools for 4 age groups and 7 types of special educational needs (SEN) assessment were developed and piloted among preschool/school age children with the purpose to make the SEN assessment more measurable, accurate, and informative. The new Individual Educational Plan (IEP) was tested for both preschools and schools and proved to be more user-friendly. With UNICEF support, MESCS modelled the Special School for children with hearing impairments as a Resource Center. Progress was also made in enhancing operational features of e-disability and the SEN module of the Education Management Information System (EMIS) in order to enhance data collection on children with disabilities and their participation in school. As a result of UNICEF policy advocacy, an action plan aimed at enhancing the quality and accessibility of inclusive education services as well as ensuring inclusion starting from early year at preschool level was adopted by the Government. Through partnership with the Republican Pedagogical and Psychological Support Center (RPPC), the pedagogical-psychological support system for children with special educational needs and children with disabilities was strengthened.Along with the reforms, cooperation and partnership with Organizations of Persons with Disabilities (OPDs), NGOs and international organizations was prioritized by the Government and resulted in more participatory processes and consultations for developing inclusive strategic papers and projects for persons with disabilities. The current joint efforts of UN agencies with the government, OPDs and international partners bring a fresh perspective for successful evolvement of the current reforms.
2023 Narrative: 2023 saw significant efforts to operationalize the National Disability System reform. Sectoral policy frameworks were aligned with the UNCRPD aiming to shift perceptions towards persons with disabilities (PwD) and provide the Government with clear strategies to operationalize community-based services, including for children with disabilities (CwD). The pilot phase of the Personal Assistant model was initiated engaging children with disabilities. UNICEF also contributed to the strengthening the new disability assessment and certification scheme, by costing the setup of one testing unit in the Unified Social Service USS) and equipping it with assistive devices, by building the capacity of multidisciplinary assessment teams (including health, social and education/developmental professionals) and by contributing to the development of an e-disability information system. UNICEF also provided technical support in generating country-specific evidence on ecosystem to support access to assistive technologies as well as on assessment of child disability. Both aim at supporting policy development to enhance functioning, participation in learning and social inclusion of children with disabilities from early years through adulthood. UNICEF in collaboration with UNDP and UNFPA continued to promote adherence to UNCRPD principles and the advancement of the rights of persons with disabilities. UN agencies stimulated the engagement of persons with disabilities in national development mechanisms and supported the enhancement of the capacity of Organisations of Persons with Disabilities (OPD). UNICEF’s cooperation with OPDs promoting the rights of children with disabilities and underrepresented groups resulted in the establishment of a platform for regular consultations on disability issues and validation of legal and policy reform documents, and disability service models. UNICEF conducted a capacity needs mapping among OPDs. Based on its findings, a series of awareness-raising campaigns were organized with OPDs, NGOs, and line ministries on Disability System Reform, UNCRPD, CEDAW, Universal Design, and reasonable accommodations. The CO continued its partnership with the Republican Pedagogical and Psychological Support Center in strengthening the pedagogical-psychological support system for children with special educational needs, including hearing impairments. The revised toolkit for Special Educational Needs assessment (SEN) was applied in secondary schools making the assessment process more participatory, accurate, and informative. UNICEF and its partners introduced three innovative service provision models, including: the first Armenian language augmentative and alternative communication application for tablets offered free of charge in App Store and Play market; “Internet of Things” that aimed to create opportunities for 14–18-year-old adolescents with and without disabilities to identify and develop smart solutions to issues that concern them; the Special Equipment library for children with disabilities, with a lending option of therapeutic equipment and positioning devices necessary to ensure their uninterrupted rehabilitation therapies at home.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, UNICEF continued supporting the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (MoLSA) in enhancing the realization of disability rights for children in Armenia, contributing to the operationalization of the National Disability System Reform in line with the provisions of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) and the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC). The Government approved several sectoral legal documents that were developed through UNICEF technical assistance, including amendments to the regulation on the provision of Personal Assistant Services and the amendments in the Regulation of Day Care Centers. These provisions will enable children with disabilities to receive tailored support that helps them function optimally in daily life, enhancing their ability to participate in educational and social activities. In addition, progress was made in the policy dialogue related to disability-inclusive social protection and services, a topic that was discussed at the two-day international conference titled "Towards a World without Barriers: Accelerating Implementation of Disability Inclusive Social Protection" organized in Yerevan by MLSA in collaboration with the Asian Development Bank, GIZ, UNDP, UNICEF, and UNFPA. The conference reviewed progress and addressed ongoing challenges related to disability-inclusive social protection and services in the region and globally.The CO continued its partnership with the Republican Pedagogical and Psychological Support Center (RPPC) in strengthening the pedagogical-psychological support system for children with special educational needs and disabilities. The focus was on enhancing SEN assessment, service provision and monitoring. The CO invested in ongoing teacher training through introduction of the Interpersonal Communication and Community Engagement to Support Inclusion training package. Trainings for trainers were conducted in all regions of Armenia for 244 specialists (242 women, 2 men) from 12 regional pedagogical psychological support centers.The MoESCS approved an action plan and schedule for reorganization of the special general education institutions (https://www.arlis.am/documentview.aspx?docid=192158). This is an important milestone towards a more operational environment for including children with disabilities and with special educational needs in mainstream educational institutions. UNICEF provided technical assistance for the development of the resource center charter and for piloting the transition from special school to mainstream school with a group of 15 students with hearing impairments. The Resource Center for Children with Hearing Impairments will officially start operating in September 2025. UNICEF supported the development and publication of 6 methodological manuals aimed at increasing the efficiency of inclusive education and improving professional skills of pedagogical workers involved in this process. The CO provided didactic materials to 25 regional chapters of RPPC, including bags with assessment tools for mobile teams to provide services to students in educational institutions within their catchment area.In 2024, UNICEF delivered targeted disability inclusion activities as part of the refugee response in partnership with Organizations of Persons with Disabilities (OPD), including SOURCE Foundation, “Havat” NGO of Hard of Hearing Children’s Mothers and Lady Cox Rehabilitation Center, the latter being a refugee-run OPD that UNICEF supported also in adjusting to Armenia’s operational environment. More than 300 refugee children with multiple disabilities received needs-based and specialized support, developmental and rehabilitation services, MHPSS, assistive technologies, and humanitarian assistance.Awareness-raising activities included producing video reels on topics related to children with hearing impairments, validating best practices and lessons learned from two assistive technology models, and organizing a two-day workshop on "Access to Services for Persons with Disabilities." Parents of CwD, practitioners, policy makers and NGO/OPD representatives got an opportunity to learn about innovative practices in the country, remaining challenges in service provision and voice their suggestions.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION FRAMEWORK FOR ARMENIA
Strategic priority: People’s well-being and capabilities
Outcome: People exercise their talents and skills, benefitting from ageappropriate, life-long learning, inclusive and quality education in an enabling and safe environment
Output: 3.1 Education system is strengthened to deliver quality and inclusive education to all, including in pre-primary schooling
Sub-Output: Policies, financing and infrastructure are improved, and capacities are strengthened ensuring all young children, including from border areas, having access to quality and inclusive preschool education.
Description:
General theme: Developing early learning models
Outcome 3: Education
Output 3.1: Education system is strengthened to deliver quality and inclusive education to all, including in pre-primary schooling
Existing programme: Future today; Quality preschool and ECD
Contributing partners: Asian Development Bank, Core Funding, European Commission, Global Partnership for Education, Government of Austria, Government of France, The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, UNICEF Education Thematic Fund, UNICEF Global Thematic Humanitarian Fund, UNICEF National Committees, UNICEF WASH Thematic Trust Fund, United Nations Multi-Partner Trust Fund, United States Agency for International Development
Implementation partners: Armenia Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport
SDG Targets: 4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
Geography: Shirak, Tavush, Lori, Syunik, Gegharkunik, Armenia
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Children in approximately 200 rural settlements of Armenia, and children with disabilities are missing the opportunity for early learning due to the absence of the pre-school services or a lack of skilled care givers, reasonable accommodations/services, and standard curricula. UNICEF in close collaboration with MoESCS and MOTADI, identified the target communities for establishment of early learning services in 2022-2023, guided by the provisions of the Law on Preschool Education and the 2021 Action Plan on Implementation of Inclusive Preschool services. As of December 2021, 15 communities have initiated renovation works, 3 of them have already finished, the rest will finish in the 1st quarter of 2022. It is expected that, overall, 289 children in rural underserved communities will gain access to preschool education services. 
UNICEF continued advancing early identification and intervention practices. Specifically, the training module and practical guide on “Basics of Early Identification and Intervention” for doctors and nurses was tested in Amasia health center and was accredited by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Armenia. Several legal documents were developed/finalized to enable the provision of multi-disciplinary rehabilitation services for children, including the Follow up Growth Charts for children with cerebral palsy to be used by primary health care workers; the follow up of neonates with developmental risk factors; antenatal screening of Alpha-fetoprotein. Finally, the early identification of developmental delays/ disabilities and intervention policy framework has been revised. Early identification of children with developmental delays is critical in the early stages to facilitate early intervention for maximizing the developmental potential of children, and improving outcomes for children, families, and communities.
The provisions of the Law on Pre-school Education started to be implemented in 2021. Specifically, 2021-2023 Action plan for making all preschools inclusive was adopted, state budget was allocated for establishment of alternative pre-school services. The draft of preschool education standards was developed and are at the final stage of public review. The Government program for 2021-2026 targets establishment or renovation of at least 500 kindergartens and preschools by 2026, ensuring furnishing and equipment.
UNICEF Armenia provided technical assistance to selected communities in defining the terms of reference and recruiting the educators for the preschool services, training and mentoring of selected educators for 15 early learning centers and building the capacity of the staff of reference kindergartens to further support the newly established alternative preschool services and provide them with methodological guidance thus ensuring the sustainability of the initiative.
2022 Narrative: With UNICEF continued support, the policy framework, infrastructure and technical capacities of service providers continued to be strengthened to ensure all young children have access to quality and inclusive preschool. The enrolment of children in preschool institutions (public and private) during 2021-2022 school year increased (32.3%) in comparison with the 2020-2021 year (24.3%). This can be considered an indication of positive trends also due to continued efforts to invest and prioritize early childhood education, although enrolment rates still remain lower compared with the pre-COVID situation (34.7%) and inequities between rural and urban areas remain. Despite some improvement in enrolment rates including in rural areas, the limited number of preschools remains a key bottleneck with children in approximately 200 rural settlements missing the opportunity for early learning due to the absence of pre-school services.  Hence enlargement of the network of preschools remained a priority in the 2021-2026 Government Programme and the new ESP. In this context, as a result of the tripartite collaboration between UNICEF, MoESCS and MOTAI, 256 children (out of them 130 girls) 3-6 years old benefited from 15 operating alternative early learning centers in rural settlements, and around 400 parents learnt about holistic child development and upbringing. Young women from those rural communities were trained to work as teachers, which contributed to establish sustainable solutions for the functioning of the preschools, besides contributing to their income and empowerment. During renovation access to clean water, and energy efficient measures were considered. The preschool buildings were equipped with solar photovoltaic system to ensure access to renewable energy systems. Outdoor playgrounds were established close to the early learning centers to ensure outdoor activities of children. Simultaneously, another 10 rural settlements were supported by the state-budget to establish alternative preschool education services. The training module and practical guide on “Basics of Early Identification and Intervention” for primary health care staff were included in the List of accredited training for in-services continuous professional development. The Concept on Early childhood intervention and rehabilitation services for children was developed with UNICEF support and is awaiting approval by line ministries (MoESCS, MoLSA and MoTAI). Subsequently, they will become the basis for the development of the Action plan for strengthening early identification of developmental delays and disabilities, early intervention and follow up. Early identification of children with developmental delays is critical in the early stages to facilitate early intervention for maximizing the developmental potential of children, and improving outcomes for children, families, and communities.
2023 Narrative: UNICEF continued to advocate and provide technical assistance for strengthening policy frameworks, infrastructure, service providers’ technical capacities, and data systems to ultimately ensure all young children have access to quality inclusive preschool. The number of preschool facilities, including nursery-kindergartens and pre-primary classrooms in schools, grew by 10%. The enrolment of children 0-6 age group in preschools increased to 36% during the 2022-2023 academic year compared to 32.3% in 2021-2022. This can be attributed to continued efforts, also supported by UNICEF, to invest and prioritize early childhood education. Preschool network expansion remains a top focus in the ESP. In this regard, UNICEF, MESCS, and MTAI continue close collaboration. In 2023, UNICEF increased the number of alternative preschools in remote settlements to 40 by establishing 9 new facilities. The expansion of the network of the alternative preschools contributed to the gender equality in the country by empowering particularly women caregivers to get engaged in income generation and community life thus increasing the use of the full talent pool of the population and to enhancing women’s economic independence. 518 children 3-6 age group (45% girls, 55% boys) in remote settlements benefitted, and 600 parents learned about holistic child development. State funding was provided for the establishment of alternative preschools in 3 more rural settlements. Access to, gender-sensitive WASH facilities, energy efficiency, and climate resilience measures were considered throughout the refurbishment process, including installation of photovoltaic systems. To ensure outdoor learning activities, playgrounds were established near alternative preschools. 80 young women from rural settlements were trained to become preschool educators. 2,134 children (45% girls, 55% boys) in 23 state kindergartens functioning as resource hubs for alternative preschools benefitted from additionally capacitated staff and improved furnishing.Financial mechanisms to enhance mainstreaming inclusion at preschool level have been introduced nationwide. Furthermore, several provisions were approved to set standards and better regulate the provision of services, including the preschool education program for each age group, regulations on selection of preschool educators, mandatory in-service training requirements and the list of required furniture and equipment. A two-day national conference on preschool education was held with UNICEF support, involving 300 teachers, administrators, academics and other practitioners, who learnt about new regulations and developments and discussed the way forward. This first ever experience of this kind has the potential to create a platform that brings together different experiences and enables greater ownership over the ongoing reforms among practitioners. Despite significant improvement in preschool enrolment rates, the lack of preschools continues to be a major bottleneck and became more evident with the arrival of refugees in September.  In this context, through a collaboration between UNICEF, MESCS and local authorities, a mapping exercise of preschool facilities in areas of high concentration of refugees was initiated to identify priority communities where facilities and services need to be expanded. UNICEF also initiated a partnership to expand the capacity of early learning services by establishing 20 fully equipped preschool classrooms. To strengthen the system’s capacity to early identify children with disabilities or special educational needs and include them in preschool from the beginning 325 primary health care doctors and nurses (97% women) accomplished accredited Training on “Child development and early identification”. Child development assessment kit was developed and distributed with Posters “Red flags Early identification guide” to iPHC sites covering 13% of 0-5 children population.
2024 Narrative: UNICEF continued to support the operationalization of the Law on Preschool Education, enhancing policy frameworks and service providers' capacity to provide quality inclusive preschool services. Despite advancements in the enrollment rates for children 3 to 5 years old, enrolment for children below 3 remains extremely low at 4% and policy dialogue between UNICEF and MoESCS led to the important decision of piloting new mechanisms to expand coverage.Despite improvements in enrollment rates, the limited number of preschools remains a key bottleneck contributing to inequities between rural and urban areas (46% urban, 24% rural). A differentiated approach was taken to address the lack of preschool education in around 200 rural settlements, with tailored solutions.The enlargement of the preschool network has remained a priority in the 2021-2026 Government Programme. In this context, as a result of close collaboration between UNICEF, MoESCS, MOTAI, and local self-government bodies, 5,685 children (47% girls, 4% refugees) aged 2-5 benefited from the services of 50 kindergartens and 37 alternative preschool education facilities refurbished and equipped with soft furniture and didactic/learning materials.Through parental education sessions, around 400 parents learnt about nurturing care, holistic child development, caregiver-child positive interaction, importance of early learning, healthy nutrition, and pediatric diseases.Investment in preschool staff capacity development remained a key priority, featuring enhanced training and more structured communication. The MoESCS and UNICEF organized the second National Conference on Preschool Education, offering a valuable and ongoing strategic forum for 600 preschool practitioners to engage in discussions about recent developments, challenges, and future directions. This initiative acts as a mechanism for improved accountability and systematic monitoring. In addition, 230 preschool educators built their capacity through training modules developed based on international best practices covering: positive parenting; inclusive pedagogy; disaster risk reduction; psychological first aid and trauma-informed practices with young children and their caregivers. In 10 preschool education facilities, expansion of learning spaces was initiated to expand access for refugee and host community children. Renovations integrated considerations related to access to clean water and energy efficiency.1,500 preschool educators have benefited from state-supported continuous professional development, while 26 educators have received formal qualifications, with these processes continuing to evolve. In collaboration with UNICEF, new training modules focusing on positive parenting and psychological/psychosocial first aid have been developed and submitted to the MoESCS for integration into these professional development programs. 360 children aged 5-6 from refugee and other vulnerable families, including children with disabilities/developmental delays benefited from a one-month course implemented in 20 schools, to reach the state-defined standards necessary for successfully mastering the school curriculum. The related education package developed by UNICEF in collaboration with MoESCS and CSOs, is considered for potential expansion to help prepare more children without preschool experience for school entry."Let’s Play Activity Cards - Play-Based Activities for Healing and Learning" originally created by International Step by Step Association (ISSA) have been translated, adapted and introduced for caregivers and parents by UNICEF and a national CSO. The cards contain a set of play-based activities that help reduce stress, strengthen family bonds, and provide children with safety and comfort. Through various types of play, around 5685 children from target 20 preschools had an opportunity to express their feelings, heal, and continue learning about their world.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.2: Improved knowledge and life skills of People of Kazakhstan, especially vulnerable groups for sustainable development, well-being and resilience.
Sub-Output: Develop a training program for teachers and educators to instill key competencies and skills to mainstream gender equality in and through education, and to promote learning about a culture of equality and non-discrimination at all levels of education
Description: In the pursuit of advancing education and enhancing the skills of educators and teachers on gender aspects in education, UNESCO has undertaken a comprehensive training program. This initiative aims to empower educators with the latest knowledge and teaching methodologies to further improve the quality of education across various regions. The groundwork for this ambitious endeavor began in 2023, with UNESCO engaging in meticulous procurement procedures to identify the most suitable and responsible organization to spearhead the training initiative. After a thorough evaluation process, it was determined that collaboration with the National Center for Advanced Training, known as "Orleu," and the Ministry of Education would be instrumental in achieving the program's objectives. The National Center for Advanced Training "Orleu" has established itself as a reputable institution committed to the enhancement of educational practices. Its expertise in advanced training aligns seamlessly with UNESCO's vision for integrating gender aspects into teaching standards globally. By joining forces with the Ministry of Education, the program gains access to valuable resources and an extensive network, further strengthening its potential impact. As part of the work plan, the training sessions are scheduled to be conducted in regions in 2024.
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1: People - Human Development and Equal Participation
Outcome: Outcome 1.2. By 2025 all people in Kazakhstan especially the most vulnerable are empowered with knowledge and skills to equally contribute to sustainable development of the country.
Output: Output 1.2.2: Improved knowledge and life skills of People of Kazakhstan, especially vulnerable groups for sustainable development, well-being and resilience.
Sub-Output: Prepare and conduct trainings and seminars to increase the awareness and capacity of education system employees to promote teaching a culture of equality and non-discrimination and gender competencies from secondary schools and higher education institutions in the Zhetisu and Ulytau regions
Description: In 2023, UNFPA implemented a proactive initiative to enhance awareness and capacity among education staff in Kazakhstan's Turkestan and Kyzylorda regions. The program aimed to promote equality, non-discrimination, and gender competencies in secondary schools and higher education institutions. Training sessions targeted 57 education staff members, including teachers, administrators, and support staff. The comprehensive curriculum covered various topics such as gender-sensitive teaching methodologies and strategies to prevent discrimination. Sessions were conducted in two phases, allowing for focused attention in each region and fostering a collaborative learning environment through interactive discussions and knowledge sharing.
Implementation partners: United Nations Population Fund
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 3 - Principal contribution is to the realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: In 2023, the UNFPA undertook a proactive approach to enhance awareness and capacity among education staff to promote a culture of equality, non-discrimination, and gender competencies in secondary schools and higher education institutions. The initiative targeted two distinct regions of the country, namely the Turkestan region and the Kyzylorda region, with a series of training sessions and seminars. The training program aimed to equip education staff with the knowledge and skills necessary to foster an inclusive and equitable learning environment. The primary focus was on secondary schools and higher education institutions, recognizing the pivotal role these institutions play in shaping societal attitudes and norms. A total of 57 education staff members from the two selected regions were actively involved in the training sessions. These individuals represented a diverse cross-section of the education system, including teachers, administrators, and support staff. The comprehensive training covered various aspects, including the promotion of equality, non-discrimination, and the development of gender competencies within educational settings. The training sessions were conducted in two phases, reflecting the commitment of UNFPA to widespread impact. In the Turkestan region, training took place from November 7 to November 11, 2023. The subsequent phase unfolded in the Kyzylorda region from December 6 to December 10, 2023. The staggered schedule allowed for focused attention in each region, ensuring that participants could fully engage with the content and apply the acquired knowledge in their respective contexts. The training curriculum encompassed a range of topics, including but not limited to gender-sensitive teaching methodologies, creating inclusive learning environments, and strategies to address and prevent discrimination within educational institutions. The sessions were interactive, encouraging participants to share experiences and best practices, thereby fostering a collaborative learning environment.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Peace - Effective Institutions, Human Rights and Gender Equality
Outcome: Outcome 2.2: By 2025, state institutions at all levels effectively design and implement gender-sensitive, human rights and evidence-based public policies and provide quality services in an inclusive, transparent and accountable manner.
Output: Output 2.2.1: Enhanced capacities of state actors in participatory, inclusive and gender sensitive budgeting and planning to implement the 2030 Agenda.
Sub-Output: Conduct a comprehensive analysis of national education policies and programs based on the UNESCO Gender in Education Toolkit to promote gender equality in and through education.
Description: In 2023 UNESCO conducted a comprehensive review of national education policies and programs to promote gender equality in and through education. A meeting on the results of the national policy analysis with the participation of the Ministry of Education, project partners and interested stakeholders is planned for April 2024. In the future, the recommendations developed as part of the analysis will be used in the field of education.
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace

A meeting on the results of the national policy analysis with the participation of the Ministry of Education, project partners and interested stakeholders is planned for April 2024. In the future, the recommendations developed as part of the analysis will be used in the field of education.

Plan name: UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework 2021-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 2: Peace - Effective Institutions, Human Rights and Gender Equality
Outcome: Outcome 2.2: By 2025, state institutions at all levels effectively design and implement gender-sensitive, human rights and evidence-based public policies and provide quality services in an inclusive, transparent and accountable manner.
Output: Output 2.2.1: Enhanced capacities of state actors in participatory, inclusive and gender sensitive budgeting and planning to implement the 2030 Agenda.
Sub-Output: Conduct anti-discrimination and gender-lensed expertise of educational materials to identify negative gender and/or other biases and prejudices and provide specific recommendations and proposals for mainstreaming gender equality in curricula and methodologies.
Description:
In 2023, UNESCO partnered with the National Academy of Education to review educational materials, focusing on anti-discrimination and gender-sensitive content. The initiative aims to ensure inclusivity and diversity in educational resources. Through meticulous examination of textbooks and aids, potential biases are identified and addressed.

Scheduled for April 2024, the presentation of analysis results will disseminate findings and highlight areas for improvement to stakeholders like educators and policymakers. Recommendations from the analysis will be integrated into curricula and teaching methods, facilitating seamless adoption and fostering a sustainable impact on educational practices.

This collaboration underscores UNESCO's commitment to inclusive education, aligning with its mission to promote sustainable development and social progress.
Implementation partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNESCO entered into a contractual agreement with the National Academy of Education to conduct a comprehensive examination of educational materials with a specific focus on anti-discrimination and gender-oriented content. The purpose of this initiative is to ensure that educational materials align with principles of inclusivity, diversity, and gender sensitivity.The examination involves a meticulous review of educational materials, including textbooks, teaching aids, and supplementary resources. The emphasis is placed on identifying and addressing any elements that may perpetuate discrimination or lack gender sensitivity. The goal is to create an educational environment that is inclusive and reflective of diverse perspectives.The presentation of the analysis results is scheduled for April 2024. This presentation will serve as a platform to disseminate key findings, highlight areas for improvement, and emphasize the importance of fostering an educational environment free from discrimination and inclusive of gender perspectives. Stakeholders, including educators, policymakers, and curriculum developers, will be invited to participate.As a critical outcome of the project, recommendations developed within the framework of the analysis will be integrated into curricula and teaching methods. This proactive step ensures that the impact of the examination goes beyond identifying issues to actively contributing to the enhancement of educational content and methodologies.The implementation of the recommendations is expected to follow a carefully planned timeline, allowing educational institutions and policymakers to incorporate the changes seamlessly. The gradual integration will foster a more sustainable and widespread impact on educational practices.UNESCO's collaboration with the National Academy of Education in conducting an anti-discrimination and gender-oriented examination of educational materials represents a significant commitment to fostering inclusive and equitable education. The presentation of analysis results in April 2024 will mark a pivotal moment in advocating for positive change, and the subsequent integration of recommendations into curricula and teaching methods will contribute to creating a more enlightened and inclusive educational environment. This initiative aligns with UNESCO's broader mission to advance education for sustainable development and social progress.In 2023, UNESCO entered into a contractual agreement with the National Academy of Education to conduct a comprehensive examination of educational materials with a specific focus on anti-discrimination and gender-oriented content.
